DOC.HEAD: Sotheby's Buys Gallery in Largest Art Deal Ever
DOC.TEXT: Sotheby's auction house announced Wednesday that it will buy the contents of a Manhattan gallery for $142.8 million in what may be the biggest art deal ever, both because of the number of paintings and their value. Sotheby's will acquire one of the great inventories of 20th-century art when it buys the 2,300 works from the Pierre Matisse Gallery in a joint venture with William Acquavella, a New York art dealer. Until now, Sotheby's has represented art sellers, putting up for auction works owned by others and taking a commission from the sale. With the acquisition of the Matisse Gallery works, Sotheby's will be in the business of owning the art it sells, rather than operating in the auction house's traditional manner of representing sellers. Acquavella will be managing partner of the joint venture company being set up with Sotheby's, to be called Acquavella Modern Art. ``As far as I know, it is the biggest art deal both in the number of paintings and the art value that has been done in the art world,'' Acquavella told The New York Times. The gallery's inventory of 2,300 works by artists including Joan Miro, Alberto Giacometti and Marc Chagall is being sold by the estate of Pierre Matisse, an art dealer and son of painter Henri Matisse. Pierre Matisse died Aug. 9. Some of the artworks will be sold at auction. But Acquavella said he also planned to have exhibitions around the world and work with dealers in different countries to sell the works privately.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Contras in Mountains Refuse to Disarm
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Contra rebels outside this mountain hamlet refused to begin handing over their weapons Wednesday, the day the anti-Sandinista guerrillas were to start demobilizing. Two hours after Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was sworn in as president, about 500 rebels gathered on a hillside in one of five security zones where the demobilization is to take place. Israel Galeano, a top rebel chief, and 12 other Contra commanders were on hand. Galeano delivered an anti-Sandinista diatribe and vowed he would be the last to lay down his weapon. Then he invited his men to surrender their arms. The guerrillas broke out in laughter en masse. ``Nobody gives up his gun!'' shouted one, and all cheered. Galeano, known as Commander Franklin, addressed the troops after meeting briefly with Spanish Maj. Jose Luis Gracia, representative of the United Nations Central American peacekeeping force. Gracia said the U.N. contingent was ready to begin accepting the rebels' weapons. The peacekeepers, however, have no mandate to forcibly disarm the Contras. The incident occurred in Zone 1, a security enclave 85 miles north of Managua that covers 174 square miles. While it is not the largest of the five zones geographically, it is thought to harbor the most fighters. About 3,000 Contras are estimated to have arrived the past week. About 9,000 Contras are to gather in the five zones in coming days. The rebels, who roam the zone at will, are unsupervised and have Soviet-made assault rifles, grenade launchers and other weaponry. They have small stores of food and are supposed to receive demobilization aid from the Organization of American States. The assembled rebels were also addressed Wednesday by Roberto Ferrey, who traveled to the zone to represent Mrs. Chamorro. ``Now it is the turn of the resistance to take action contributing to peace and reconciliation,'' he said. ``You have to make an effort to understand that the Sandinistas are no longer in power.'' He appealed for demobilization before June 10, the date agreed to in a pact signed last week by Oscar Sobalvarro, the No. 2 man in the Contra command. Several Contras, though, rose to challenge Ferrey. ``Jackson,'' a regional commander, told assembly: ``I'd rather take to the mountains, live in the jungle with my comrades until our conditions are met. And those conditions have not yet been met.'' Of the dozens interviewed at the assembly, not a single Contra said he would hand over his weapon as long as the Sandinistas controlled the army and security forces. Mrs. Chamorro named Gen. Humberto Ortega, former President Daniel Ortega's brother, to head the army as a conciliatory measure. She is commander in chief.

DOC.HEAD: Bishop Who Disciplined Catholic Politician Undergoes Brain Surgery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with surgery over, tumor found. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholic Bishop Leo T. Maher, who drew widespread attention when he banned a pro-choice political candidate from receiving Communion last year, underwent surgery to remove a brain tumor Wednesday. Maher, 74, was in serious condition after the 2{-hour operation at Scripps Clinic in La Jolla. Doctors said they were optimistic he would recover from the surgery but expressed concern about a recurrence of the life-threatening tumor. Dr. Thomas Waltz, who led the operating team, said doctors removed 75 percent to 80 percent of the tumor, which was about 3 inches in diameter and located in the back right portion of the brain. ``It's a tumor that you really can't classify as either malignant or benign,'' Waltz said. ``It doesn't spread to other parts of the body, but it can recur.'' He said the tumor's possible recurrence can be suppressed by radiation therapy. Maher checked into the clinic Monday after his physician became concerned over his condition, the Diocese of San Diego said in a statement. Tests then revealed the brain lesion and the surgery was scheduled, said Sue Pondrom, a spokeswoman for Scripps Clinic. In the past several weeks, the diocese said, Maher ``has grown increasingly aware of a lack of physical strength and at times has demonstrated a loss of equilibrium.'' At midday, Pondrom confirmed that the operation had been completed but said no information on the bishop's condition would be released until later in the day. Scores of Catholics started a prayer vigil for the bishop on Tuesday. Under diocesan law, Maher must retire as head of the 460,000-member diocese by his 75th birthday, July 1. He has held the position since 1969. His tenure has been marked by great growth in the diocese as well as by controversy. Most recently, he last fall banned Lucy Killea, then an Assemblywoman running for state Senate, from receiving Communion because of her outspoken views in favor of abortion rights. The sanction and its implications on the abortion issue and the separation of church and state became focal points for voters, who elected Killea, a Democrat, over Republican Carol Bentley. Bentley, a pro-life candidate, blamed Maher's intervention and the subsequent national publicity Killea received for her loss in the Republican-dominated district.

DOC.HEAD: Top Politician Stabbed in Neck by Female Assailant at WGerman Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with police identifying the woman, hometown, relatives saying suspect had history of mental illness. Picks up 14th pvs, `Oskar Lafontaine...'
With LaserPhotos FRA3,FRA5
DOC.TEXT: A woman in a white dress stabbed opposition leader Oskar Lafontaine in the neck Wednesday while offering him flowers at a campaign rally. Officials said he was in serious condition. Lafontaine, the left-of-center governor of Saarland state and Chancellor Helmut Kohl's leading challenger in the upcoming December elections, was stabbed with a knife as he was about to sign his autograph for his attacker, police said. Hospital authorities said the 46-year-old leader of the Social Democratic Party was in serious condition due to blood loss but that his life was no longer in danger. A neck artery was severed in the attack, ministry officials said. Police late Wednesday identified the assailant as Adelheid Streidel, 42, from Bad Neuenahr southwest of Bonn. The television network ZDF quoted relatives as saying the woman had a history of mental illness. Kohl, in Paris for a West German-French summit, said the attack has ``deeply shaken me. At this hour one can only hope that Oskar Lafontaine survives.'' The statement was released by the chancellor's Bonn office. Social Democrat spokesman Eduard Heussen said the attacker approached Lafontaine on the dais at a rally in a Cologne suburb with a bouquet of flowers and an album containing poetry. The woman stabbed Lafontaine while he was looking at the album, Heussen said. Lafontaine was rushed by helicopter to the University Clinic in the Cologne suburb of Lindenthal, police said. In a late-evening news broadcast, the ARD television network showed the politician lying on the floor as blood poured from his neck. Several people crowded around him trying to administer first aid. ZDF said Lafontaine could not be moved for up to 45 minutes because his condition was so poor and loss of blood so great. The stabbing suspect, wearing a white dress, sat impassively as a throng of policemen screamed at her, ``Who are you? Who are you? Tell us your name! Say it!'' The woman stared at police and the camera and said nothing. The television showed her being hustled out of the hall by a group of policemen. An Interior Ministry spokesman said the woman was arrested. Hans-Juergen Foerster, a spokesman for the Federal Prosecutor's Office, said there was no evidence the woman has a ``terrorist background.'' Authorities said there was no known motive for the 9 p.m. attack. ``Oskar Lafontaine collapsed immediately, covered with blood. The attacker was captured,'' ZDF reported. ZDF said 800 to 900 people were at the campaign rally in suburban Muelheim. ``Everyone in the hall was horrified. There was mass confusion,'' said ZDF. Lafontaine is one of West Germany's most colorful, acid-tongued and popular politicians, an unrelenting critic of Kohl and his policies of speedy German unification. Lafontaine, divorced, is also known as having an active social life, and reports on who he's been seen with often prove to be leading news items for the tabloid press in West Germany. His most recent liaison is with a Frankfurt hotelier's daughter whose dyed blond punk-style haircut delighted news photographers. On Monday, Lafontaine harshly criticized Kohl for the projected cost of German reunification, set for July 2. The outspoken politician, whose party trounced Kohl's Christian Democratic Union in state elections in January, has been considered a tough opponent in the chancellor's bid for a third four-year term. Lafontaine, a party activist at age 21, became mayor of Saarbruecken at 32. In 1987, he became deputy chairman of the Social Democrats despite opposition from the party's conservative wing, headed by former chancellor Helmut Schmidt. He strongly opposed plans under Schmidt's government in the late 1970s to station U.S. medium-range nuclear weapons in West Germany. Lafontaine is governor of tiny Saarland state, one of the poorest regions in West Germany. It borders France and Luxembourg.

DOC.HEAD: A Feminist Fight Over First Lady's Appearance at Seven Sisters School
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Some Wellesley College students have inadvertently hit a feminist sore spot by protesting Barbara Bush's selection as commencement speaker. The students gained headlines by circulating a petition saying ``to honor Barbara Bush as a commencement speaker is to honor a woman who has gained recognition through the achievements of her husband, which contradicts what we have been taught over our years at Wellesley.'' The petition was signed by 150 of the 2,200 students at the elite women's school. But defense of the first lady percolated slowly and then poured forth, even from some of the most liberal corners of the Boston area. ``What seems to have happened here is that the feminist standards of the '90s are being applied to a woman who matured in another era,'' wrote Boston Globe columnist David Nyhan, who is no Bush fan. ``Barbara Bush is a woman of exemplary values, vast charm and unrivaled popularity, to list those traits in descending order.'' The flap has stirred the tranquil college campus, nestled in a corner of this posh Boston suburb, where the cost of tuition, room and board runs to about $18,000 a year. Students involved with the petition have become a little publicity shy in the wake of the criticism, according to the senior class dean. In another Globe article, Suzanne Gordon, a freelance writer and feminist who has a book due out in January called ``Prisoner of Men's Dreams,'' laid out her argument against the students. Gordon wrote that the petition ``made me mad enough, even as a long-time feminist, to speak out against what has become an increasingly popular rendition of feminist thinking.'' ``What the Wellesley protesters have inadvertently revealed is how much the original goals of the women's movement have been distorted by the male-clone careerism of today's `dress for success' feminists,'' she said. Susie Cardenas, a senior who helped push the petition, did not return several messages to her dorm telephone. Lorraine Garnett Ward, dean for the 600-member Class of 1990, defended the petitioners, although she pointed out they do not represent a majority of senior class. ``Wellesley College students are extremely thoughtful people who are not at all whiney,'' Ward said. ``I think this is a college which encourages young women to think _ and think aloud.'' Feminist author Betty Friedan said she had no problem with the choices Mrs. Bush made in her life, but added the first lady should use her influence to help other women. ``The choice to marry and the opportunity to exert influence as first lady is to be envied, but it is also to be used,'' said Friedan, who teaches at the University of Southern California. ``What I would do is say, `We challenge you to take a leading role in demanding that this nation take a leading role on child care.' '' A spokeswoman for Eleanor Smeal, former president of the National Organization for Women, who now heads the Virginia-based group The Feminist Majority, treaded a careful line when talking about Mrs. Bush. ``Our impression is that if for instance it was an Eleanor Roosevelt, who was someone who really used her role to improve the status of women, this probably wouldn't be happening,'' said Tamar Raphael, after speaking with Smeal. ``We know Barbara Bush is really for women's rights, but she really hasn't used her position yet to do that.'' Several students said the timing of the protest made them uneasy. ``I'm primarily a little embarrassed just because I feel we invited her and it's a slap in the face,'' said Erica Herz, a senior. ``There are a lot of people who are happy she's coming.'' Marcy Goldstein, a junior, said, ``It would be wonderful to have such a well-known person on campus.'' Mrs. Bush still plans to attend the June 1 graduation ceremonies, according to her press office.

DOC.HEAD: Poachers Kill Rhino Popular With Tourists
DOC.TEXT: Poachers have killed a rhinoceros seen by nearly every visitor to a game reserve where she had claimed a domain for herself and a male calf. Richard Leakey, the director of state Wildlife Management Service, said investigations were underway in the southwestern Masai Mara Game Reserve on the death of the black rhino, nicknamed Halima. Halima is a common name for women along Kenya's Indian Ocean coast. ``The animal was killed by unknown person or persons using a high-powered rifle,'' said Leakey in a statement Monday. Leakey deplored what he called ``senseless killing of a well known tourist attraction'' and said Halima's horn had been recovered. Halima, who left a year-old male orphan calf, permanently lived in a place called Musiala in the game reserve, and her defiance of migratory habits made it possible for every interested park visitor to see her. Rhinos are normally killed for their horn, which is then ground into a powder that is considered an aphrodisiac in the Far East. The horn is also used to make ornate handles for daggers in Persian Gulf countries. Poachers, cashing in on the demand for rhino horns, have reduced the animal's population in the East African nation from 20,000 in the late 1970s to an estimated 400 at present, most of them in sanctuaries. Conservationists say the slaughter of wildlife, particularly elephants and rhinos, has been reduced dramatically since Leakey became Kenya's director of wildlife management early 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Five And Wound Seven in Attack on Coffee Bar
DOC.TEXT: In what appeared a drug-related mob hit, masked gunmen killed five people and wounded seven as they opened fire inside a coffee bar and at occupants of a car parked outside, authorities said. Tuesday's slaughter was carried out in the style of the Camorra, a crime syndicate that is a rough equivalent of the Sicilian mafia, said investigating Magistrate Paolo Albano. He said it appeared the killings were part of battles over the flourishing illegal drug trade in the area. The attack occurred in the early hours in the hamlet of Pescopago, about 20 miles north of Naples. The dead included two Tanzanians, one Iranian and one Italian. Police said they could not immediately identify the other dead. Among the wounded was the 13-year-old son of the coffee bar's owner. Doctors operating on one of the wounded, a 23-year-old Tanzanian, found 10 bags filled with heroin in his stomach, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. ``There are Africans who sell drugs here, and the massacre is either directed towards the Africans who are operating on their own or towards Africans whom the Camorra supplies with drugs,'' Albano said.

DOC.HEAD: What's In a Name? A Week of Honors If Yours is Shakespeare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Some people might think that fussing over a name is much ado about nothing, but those people aren't named Shakespeare. Of those who are, about 115 turned up to celebrate the Bard's birthday Tuesday at the site of the new Globe Theater. It was the largest gathering of Shakespeares since 1964, which was celebrated as the playwright's 400th birthday. All seemed proud of their illustrious name. Of course, it may be that none of the latterday Shakespeares is related to England's premier playwright. Genealogies are hazy on this point. But never mind. ``We all like to think we're related to the Bard,'' said Stanley Shakespeare, a London hairdresser, who pored through phonebooks for six months to compile the invitation list of 600 Shakespeares throughout Britain. He's not picky. Invitations went to people named Shakespear, Shakspear, Shaxper and other variations. Those who came to London will be guests of honor at a week of readings, dinner parties, films and concerts organized by the Friends of Shakespeare's Globe. But for most of the Shakespeares, the important thing was being together as a family. ``These Shakespeares are all fantastic, really friendly and we all feel a natural empathy with each other, even though most of us have never met before,'' said 33-year-old Phil Shakespeare, a supermarket manager in West Bromsgrove near Stratford-Upon-Avon, the playwright's birthplace. He munched on a piece of fried chicken and chatted briefly with a new acquaintance, 35-year-old Rosamund Shakespeare, who carried 10-month-old Hillary Shakespeare on her hip. Ms. Shakespeare said she kept her maiden name and passed it to her daughter because ``I think it sounds nicer than my husband's name _ Kukowski.'' Besides, she added, she has always been fascinated by the playwright and as a teen-ager hitchhiked with her brother to Stratford-Upon-Avon, arriving long after dark. ``We couldn't find a room and slept on the steps of the Royal Shakespeare Theater. I thought it so ironic that the Shakespeares couldn't find a bed for the night in Stratford. ``The next day I put a rose on William's grave,'' she said. The Shakespeares donned yellow hardhats and visited the construction site where a replica is being built of the Elizabethan Globe Theater, the playhouse most closely associated with the Bard. A 30-foot-high banner bearing Shakespeare's portrait was unfurled next door on the new Midland Bank building, also under construction. Gangs of workers stopped drilling and hammering to listen to a few lines from Henry V. Then, Gordon Schwontkowski of Cary, Ill., told the Shakespeares how he hand-painted the huge banner at night in his high school gym as a donation to the theater project. The banner will hang at the worksite until the Globe opens in 1993. Last year, archaeologists uncovered the original theater about 300 yards from the new site on the south bank of the Thames. After lunch, the Shakespeare clan visited the site. Carl Shakespeare lingered behind to enter his name in the guestbook alongside the signatures of Stanley Shakespeare, Beryl Shakespeare, Dorothy Shakespeare and the rest. The 25-year-old research chemist said he never felt any impulse to write, although he was capable of turning a pretty phrase. ``When I was 13, I wrote a descriptive story about the wind which my teacher said was the best she had ever read. She read it aloud to the class and I must admit, it was pretty good,'' said Shakespeare, who paused a moment to reflect. ``Who knows?'' he said. ``Maybe there's a budding Shakespeare in all of us.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Pump-it-up Arnold Schwarzenegger is mellowing out. The 42-year-old muscle man who won Mr. Universe five times, was named Mr. Olympia seven times and starred in a series of hit movies that grossed more than $1 billion says he is no longer ``as hungry, not driving as hard.'' He drinks coffee, smokes cigars, is down to a trim 215 pounds and professes to be a devoted daddy, treasuring the early morning wake-up screams of his 2-month-old daughter, Katherine, according to the May issue of GQ magazine. Schwarzenegger is married to NBC newswoman Maria Shriver. Learning to diaper the child proved to be a challenge. ``The first time, I got the waistband around the baby's neck,'' he admitted. His latest movie, ``Total Recall,'' an adventure set in the future, comes out next month.

Richard Nixon is moving on down to a three-bedroom townhouse. The former president put a for-sale sign on his seven-bedroom house in this northern New Jersey community and plans to move into a three-bedroom, four-story townhouse in nearby Park Ridge, spokesman John Taylor said Tuesday. ``The Nixons have decided that they would prefer to spend their energy on activities other than maintaining a large house on four acres,'' Taylor said. Taylor said he did not know the purchase price of the new home or the asking price for the 15-room contemporary house in Saddle River. The Nixons bought it in 1981 for $1.25 million and made $300,000 in improvements, he said.

Sammy Davis Jr. had his spirits lifted in his battle with throat cancer by a visit from his newborn grandson. Sam Michael Garner, Davis' second grandchild, was born Friday in a Los Angeles hospital. Daughter Tracy Garner stopped by the Davis home with the baby Tuesday after leaving the hospital, said spokeswoman Susan Reynolds. Davis, who has been recovering at home for six weeks, was encouraged by the visit, she said. Frank Sinatra visited on Monday. Davis, 64, was diagnosed with throat cancer in September. He underwent radiation treatment, but the cancer recurred and he turned to chemotherapy, which he completed March 13.

City officials have cleared the way for a promoter to resume negotiations with Paul McCartney for a July concert at the Yale Bowl. Deciding that the potential profits for the city were too great to pass up, the Board of Aldermen voted 19-6 Tuesday to grant a permit for the ex-Beatle's show despite strong opposition from people living near the arena. One condition was that the city receive at least $325,000 from the concert. Concert promoter Jimmy Koplik, who is negotiating with both Yale and McCartney's representatives, said Tuesday he was sure the conditions could be met. He said New Haven already is listed on the musician's itinerary.

Cher will rest her vocal cords and test her bowling arm Monday to raise money for a homeless shelter in the city. The singer and actress, in town to perform at the Sands Hotel & Casino, will participate in the $1,000-a-lane fund-raiser at the Showboat Hotel Casino. Proceeds will go to the 240-bed Atlantic City Rescue Mission.

Country singer and actor Hoyt Axton has filed for divorce from his wife of 10 years. Axton, 52, and his wife, Donna, separated Jan. 7. Monday's filing indicated there was a premarital agreement that would give custody of their 7-year-old son, Matthew Christopher, to Mrs. Axton.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Baseball umpire Bob Engel has been charged with stealing 4,180 baseball cards from a store. Engel, 56, was released on $5,000 bail Saturday for arraignment May 2 on misdemeanor counts of commercial burglary and petty theft, police said Tuesday. A store security guard told police Engel put seven boxes of cards valued at $144 into a brown paper bag he pulled from the waistband of his pants. Police said Engel told them he took the cards to collect and trade. Engel was back at the ballpark on Sunday, when he worked the Los Angeles Dodgers game from first base.

Kurt Masur, in his first visit to the New York Philharmonic since being named music director, said he wants to start a children's choir and have more rehearsal time for difficult works. His five-year contract was announced two weeks ago. It starts in the fall of 1992. Asked what changes he intends for the Philharmonic, the 62-year-old music director of the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig on Tuesday mentioned closer cooperation with the Juilliard School, which is next door in Lincoln Center. ``I'm not one of those who is promising everything before the election and then not doing it later,'' Masur said. ``I only can promise you one thing: I will do this as honest as I did everything in my life.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Seeks to Avoid Making `Wrong Mistakes' on Sanctions
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: When President Bush agonizes over a difficult choice, as he's done this week on the issue of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union, he sometimes likes to quote a favorite philosopher, Yogi Berra. ``I love the old expression of Yogi Berra's _ you say, `what happened to the Mets, Yogi?' He said, `Well, we made the wrong mistakes,''' the president told a group of building contractors on Tuesday. Bush used the words of the often verbally befuddled baseball great to explain his decision _ at least for the moment _ not to slap a series of economic penalties on the Soviet Union in response to its crackdown in Lithuania. ``I expect in this job I'll make plenty of mistakes, but I don't want to make the wrong mistakes,'' Bush said. Once again, the issue of sanctions was presenting a major foreign policy dilemma for Bush. Just as he resisted imposing sanctions on China last year in the aftermath of the bloody Tiananmen Square massacre, the president once again finds himself under pressure from conservatives in Congress to act more decisively. It was, to use another favorite Bush Berra-ism, ``deja vu _ all over again.'' Last summer, Bush finally imposed a series of non-economic sanctions on the Beijing government, while saying he did not want to go further for fear of hurting the Chinese people. Among those sanctions was a ban on high-level contacts between governments. However, the president then sent national security adviser Brent Scowcroft on a secret mission to express U.S. feelings about the use of force against China's own citizens. When confronted with the apparent violation of his own no-contact edict, Bush said he did not want to take any steps that would isolate China from the community of nations. He now is making similar arguments for withholding sanctions against the Soviet Union that would show U.S. displeasure with the Kremlin's efforts to block Lithuanian independence. Administration sources said Bush marched to the brink of announcing sanctions on Moscow _ only to back away, at least for the moment, in response to skepticism from U.S. allies in Western Europe over such a course and concern that U.S. sanctions could only make matters worse. Explaining his reluctance, Bush said: ``You've got to look at the real options. I'm old enough to remember Hungary in 1956 and where we exhorted people to go to the barricades, and a lot of people were left out there all alone.'' The president used the same argument recently for explaining why his administration would not formally recognize the new government of Lithuania. The only sanctions Bush said he would consider are economic ones _ and sources say these would deal mainly with withholding trade and investment concessions that the United States was otherwise prepared to grant Moscow. Economic links between the two superpowers right now are slight. And Bush has repeatedly ruled out this government's main economic leverage over the Soviet Union: a grain embargo. The Bush administration, and the Reagan administration before it, has argued that the trouble with economic sanctions is that they rarely work the way they are intended _ and often wind up hurting the wrong people. Bush voiced such an argument over past sanctions against the white minority rule government of South Africa. Economic penalties now in place were imposed by Congress over Reagan-Bush administration objections. More recently, the president _ yielding to congressional pressure _ voiced support for keeping the sanctions in place against Pretoria, even though he disputes their value. He has said they should remain on at least until more progress is made toward a one-person, one-vote government. Ironically, in Central America, where U.S. sanctions have taken a major toll on national economies, Bush is having a hard time winning congressional support for undoing the impact of those sanctions. Vice President Dan Quayle heads today for the inauguration of Nicaraguan President-elect Violeta Chamorro without the aid Bush promised her U.S.-backed government and the new government of Panama. Years of U.S. economic sanctions against the leftist government of outgoing Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega and the Panama dictatorship of Manuel Antonio Noriega left both countries' economies hobbled. The president's $800 million aid package for the two nations remains stalled in Congress. Bush invoked the Yogi Berra ``wrong mistakes'' quote twice on Tuesday. After he told it to a group of agricultural writers, he added: ``You've got to think about that one. And I don't want to make the wrong mistake.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Hopeful Gets Tips From Unsuspecting Rival
DOC.TEXT: A fledgling Ohio politician is coming clean, less than two weeks before a congressional primary election, in hopes that voters will like a candidate who tells the truth about telling a lie. Ricky Lee Mattox, a Democrat who wants to oust Republican Rep. Donald ``Buz'' Lukens, confessed to using a masquerade to get Lukens to explain the secrets of his past successes. Using another name and posing as a college student researching a paper on political strategy, Mattox asked Lukens to map out the tactics he used to win election and re-election. Lukens obliged. Although embroiled in the worst political mess of his 20-plus-year career, the congressman met with his would-be rival at a restaurant in Middletown, Ohio, in February and described how to win in the 8th District. ``What he said was, `I would never tell one of my opponents this, but...''' Mattox said from Oxford, Ohio. ``He confided in me tactics about his first and second campaigns that I thought were brilliant. ``I came out of the meeting with a lot of respect for him,'' the 28-year-old Mattox said. ``I've never met anyone with as much political knowledge.'' Lukens said Tuesday that he remembered meeting Mattox. ``He seemed receptive. He seemed like a nice guy,'' the incumbent said. ``I am a little surprised that Ricky would go to that extent,'' Lukens said. ``If he had just told me he was Ricky Mattox I would have given the same advice.'' But would he have gone into the same step-by-step detail? ``Oh, sure,'' replied Lukens. ``There's no secret about it. There's nothing magic. The key is timing and application.'' Lukens then detailed how he goes about working the district, beginning with tiny farm towns and ending in the cities. His description matched exactly Mattox's inventory of Lukens' campaign tactics. It also matched second-hand accounts of Lukens' own activities as he struggles for his political life while uncertain of the outcome of his appeal for a sex-related misdemeanor involving a teen-age girl. Lukens has been highly visible in his district, making the rounds of service-club breakfasts, farm group meetings and other small gatherings. Lukens has steered clear of Republican meetings and candidate forums, since his official stance is that he's waiting for the 10th Ohio District Court of Appeals to settle the challenge of his conviction for contributing to the unruliness of a minor. Mattox hasn't followed Lukens' advice. Lukens advocates steering clear of areas where opponents are strong and concentrating instead on ``where the ducks are.'' Mattox spent a lot of time going door-to-door in Hamilton, Ohio, the hometown of his chief Democratic rival, Gregory Jolivette. Lukens told Mattox that a year of advance work was a basic requirement. Mattox launched his campaign three months before the May 8 primary. But that doesn't mean Mattox didn't value the deceptively gathered strategy. ``If I were running a full-scale campaign I would follow the strategy exactly,'' he said. Mattox maintained he had nowhere else to turn as a Democratic candidate in a district that had sent Republicans to Congress for a generation. ``I wasn't receiving any advice from the Democratic Party here,'' he said. ``I wasn't receiving any help.'' Mattox, who has never before sought elective office, admitted he was going public with his subterfuge out of desperation because his campaign has attracted little attention. While he was in a confessional mood, Mattox also admitted that he has been deliberately misleading about how he has made ends meet since his medical discharge from the Navy. The former missile technician routinely describes himself as a data base operator for Essenza Corp. He now says that is true, but not precisely accurate. Mattox actually punches ordering information into the computers at Essenza's SDS Pizza near the Miami University campus in Oxford. He said the job is part-time, temporary and chosen for flexible hours during the campaign.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Greg Weiler volunteered to work on a committee studying traffic problems, only to resign because freeway gridlock kept him from attending the meetings. Weiler missed two recent 7:30 a.m. meetings because he was trapped in traffic on Interstate 5. ``I can't participate in planning the traffic solutions because the traffic is so bad I can't get there,'' Weiler said. The real estate lawyer had served on the citizens advisory committee to the Orange County Transportation Commission for five years. Weiler wrote his resignation letter after spending 75 minutes stuck on the freeway. ``Such a commute is enough to cool the ardor of the most passionate volunteer,'' Weiler wrote. ``Henceforth, I will limit my public service to activities that keep me off Interstate 5.'' Committee chairman Bill Daly said he understands why Weiler quit. Some mornings, the committee has trouble getting a nine-member quorum because of traffic, he said.

L. Montgomery Shepard got tired of being called a tightwad for giving a mere $100 reward to the child who found his wife's jewelry-laden purse. So last week he gave Jennifer Hawkins of West Palm Beach, Fla., a check for $1,000. She earlier received $1,000 for being honest from a civic group. ``The letters we're getting are just terrible. We're not cheapskates,'' Shepard said. Jennifer found the purse outside a hotel as she and her father were jogging March 2. Shepard said his wife, Betty, had dropped it there while they were vacationing. The pocketbook contained about $15,000 in jewelry and $2,600 in cash, Shepard said. But news reports that the purse held about $200,000 in jewelry apparently inspired a flurry of derisive letters to the Shepards. Shepard, who is active in the Republican Party, said he even got sniping comments from ranking GOP leaders in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Space Telescope Opening a Window on the Beginning of Time
DOC.TEXT: Already they're saying it's the biggest happening in astronomy since Galileo put his eye to a telescope. So, step right up folks, and discover the wonders of the universe. See how big it is. Learn its age. Look at light created 14 billion years ago and arriving at your eye only this instant. Ride along to the beginning of everything, almost, to the Big Bang of 10 or 20 thousand million years ago. See stars born and see them die. Watch galaxies form. Follow the flow of gas into the Milky Way's halo. Peer deep into the universe, past so many stars in our own galaxy that it would take a person more than a lifetime to count, to a hundred billion other galaxies each with about 200 billion stars. For scientists, and then the rest of us, all that becomes possible now that the space shuttle Discovery has carried the Hubble Space Telescope into the sky to see what no one has seen before. The telescope, a silvery tube as long as a tanker truck, has an unmatched ability to detect and capture the faintest light. Light, speeding along at 186,000 miles a second, is the messenger of creation. Tracking the trail of light from today to the first moments contains all the information we will ever have about the creation of the universe. The Hubble promises to give science an open window perhaps to the first echoes of creation. This is a world-class event, even if astronomy is not your thing. Superlatives? ``In the history of optical astronomy there have been two great leaps in the resolution of the universe: Galileo's telescope in the autumn of 1609, and the Hubble Space Telescope in April 1990.'' _ Eric J. Chaisson, a senior scientist at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore. One more? ``No one ever made anything that good,'' James Westphal, California Institute of Technology. Another? Dr. Lennard Fisk, NASA's chief scientist, predicts that the Hubble telescope ``will literally be the dawn of a new era in astronomy.'' Eras rarely can be proclaimed in advance. But the HST, named after Edwin Powell Hubble, holds that kind of promise. Hubble was an astronomer in the first half of the century who concluded not only that distant galaxies are moving away from Earth but that the farther away they are, the faster they move. The theory of an expanding universe supported the belief that the universe originated in a cosmic explosion and that all matter is still rushing from the site of that so-called Big Bang. Astronomers think the Big Bang occurred 12 billion to 20 billion years ago and sent the entire universe flying out at incredible speed and heat. Eventually matter cooled and condensed into galaxies, stars and planets. There are bigger telescopes than the Hubble, but they are all on Earth and all subject to a major limitation _ the atmosphere _ which is fine for breathing but lousy for seeing through. The problem of skywatching through layers of air has been likened to birdwatching from the bottom of a swimming pool. The Voyager spacecraft, which sent back astonishing views of Earth's sister planets, had to travel 12 years to get close enough for pictures as they whizzed past. With the Hubble, says scientist Edward Weiler, such pictures are possible any time we want. The telescope is 42.5 by 14 feet and consists of a 94.5-inch primary mirror that gathers incoming light. ``On a clear, dark night you can see a flashlight from two miles away,'' says Weiler, chief NASA scientist on the Hubble project. ``With a 28-power telescope you can see it on the moon 250,000 miles away. With the HST you could see a firefly in Australia from Washington.''

DOC.HEAD: Navy Would Close Some Bases Still Under Construction
DOC.TEXT: Home ports under construction in New York, Alabama, Mississippi, Texas and Washington state are among 34 military installations the Navy is considering for possible closure. A three-page list of Navy recommendations for closure, realignment and consolidation surfaced Tuesday during a hearing by two House Armed Services subcommittees. The list drew immediate criticism from a lawmaker who released the document, and a Navy statement that it was a preliminary compilation and not a ``hit list.'' The Pentagon ``politically wants us to open and close bases at the same time,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., who opposes continued spending on new home ports nationwide. Vice Adm. Stanley R. Arthur identified the list as candidates for closure and realignment drafted by Navy officials. A Navy spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Craig Quigley, said later that the list was an informal document that is part of the early stages of the service's review of all shore establishments. The review is expected to be completed by July or August. ``Appearance of a facility ... in no way indicates it's on some hit list,'' Quigley said. Lawmakers also reacted angrily in January to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's plan to close or scale back 72 domestic bases and 14 overseas installations. Democrats including Rep. Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, criticized Cheney's list as partisan for singling out bases in Democratic districts. Navy officials appeared before the House Armed Services seapower and military installations subcommittees Tuesday to discuss ``strategic home porting,'' under which the Navy's fleet of 550 ships are spread among 41 ports. ``Strategic home porting remains a valid military objective because of its beneficial effect on peacetime readiness,'' said Jacqueline Schafer, assistant secretary of the Navy for installations and environment. She indicated, however, that the Navy is reviewing all its installations, including the new home ports, for possible closure and realignments. According to the list, closing the home port on Staten Island, N.Y., which is 90 percent complete, would cost $142 million and result in annual savings of $7 million. Navy spokesman Quigley said Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett III met with New York Mayor David Dinkins and stressed that the service plans to base its ships at Staten Island. Shutting down the facility at Everett, Wash., the least developed of the home ports, would cost $20 million. Annual savings were estimated at $22 million. The other home ports on the list are in Ingleside, Texas; Mobile, Ala.; and Pascagoula, Miss. Among other installations on the list were those at Hunter's Point, Calif., and Sand Point, Wash.; a naval air station in Brunswick, Maine; and a naval supply school in Athens, Ga., home state of the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Democratic Sen. Sam Nunn. The list also included consolidating 13 facilities, including two at the naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba; two in Michigan; two in Oregon, and three in Wisconsin, Aspin's home state. The Navy is considering keeping open six facilities that had been included on Cheney's list as candidates for closure or realignment. All are in California, including the naval station in Alameda and the shipyard in Long Beach. At Tuesday's hearing, the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, recommended that the Defense Department withhold additional money for the home port projects due to the changing situation worldwide, fiscal constraints and the unlikely chances of a 600-ship naval fleet ever being built. The GAO also estimated that the cost of building and operating the new home ports would exceed $1 billion, compared with the Pentagon's initial cost estimate of $799 million.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Base Closings
DOC.TEXT: Here is the list of 34 bases the Navy is considering for possible closing. The bases are listed as they appear on the service's list. Naval station in Ingleside, Texas. Naval station in Mobile, Ala. Naval station in Pascagoula, Miss. Naval station in Staten Island, N.Y. Naval station Puget in Everett, Wash. Naval station in Hunter's Point, Calif. Naval station Puget in Sand Point, Wash. Naval supply facility in Antigua. Naval station in Rota, Spain (Waterfront and naval air station). Naval air facility in Mildenhall, United Kingdom. Three outlying fields at naval air station in Whiting, Fla. Naval air station in Brunswick, Maine. Naval air facility in Kadena, Japan. Naval air station Souda Bay, Germany. Naval air facility Midway. Naval air station Bermuda. Naval hospital in Rota, Spain. Naval supply school in Athens, Ga. Naval education and training program management support activity at Saufley Field, Fla. Naval facility Bermuda. Naval facility Guam. Commander naval base in Philadelphia. Naval supply office in La Maddelena, Italy. Navy and Marine Corps Reserve Center in Danville, Ill. Naval reserve facility in Butte, Mont. Naval reserve center in Wichita Falls, Texas. Naval reserve center in Pittsfield, Mass. Naval reserve center in Frankfort, N.Y. Naval reserve center in Hutchinson, Kan. Naval reserve facility in Alexandria, La. Naval reserve center in Portsmouth, Ohio. Naval reserve center in Bedford, Mass. Navy and Marine Corps Reserve Center in New Rochelle, N.Y. Naval reserve field in Carlsbad, N.M. The list included these mergers of reserve training centers, without saying where the resulting consolidated centers would be located: _Wisconsin: Navy and Marine Corps center at Green Bay, Navy center at Sheboygan and Navy center at Oshkosh. _Michigan: Navy center at Southfield and Navy and Marine Corps center at Detroit. _Oregon: Navy and Marine Corps center at Salem and Navy center at Eugene.

DOC.HEAD: Delayed Divorce Meant $550,000 Windfall
DOC.TEXT: A woman unlucky in love found good fortune in divorce when a paperwork error delayed her marital split long enough for her husband to win the lottery. On Tuesday, a state appeals court upheld a judge's ruling cutting Bonita Lynch in for $550,000 of her ex-husband's winnings. ``Fortune favored husband with a jackpot, but, because his marriage had not ended, fortune dealt his wife a share,'' Judge Noel Fidel wrote for the three-judge appeals panel. ``Though the lottery was a windfall, spouses marry for better or for worse and share no less in windfalls than in labor's wages.'' Ms. Lynch had been living apart from her husband, Michael, for about two years when she testified at an uncontested divorce hearing on Feb. 10, 1987 that their marriage was irretrievably broken. She should have gotten her divorce that day, but her lawyers had given her husband the wrong date for the hearing, forcing a delay. The matter still wasn't final 11 days later when her husband won $2.2 milllion in the state lottery. Lynch, a computer expert, had bought the ticket with Donna Williams, a girlfriend he married after the divorce became final. He died last Oct. 30, but his widow fought on behalf of his estate to keep his first wife from taking a cut. Under Tuesday's ruling, Lynch's widow gets to keep half the $2.2 million jackpot because half the ticket was hers to begin with. The remaining $1.1 million will be split evenly between Lynch's first wife and his estate. ``In Arizona, `it ain't over till it's over,''' said Bonita Lynch's attorney, Kenneth J. Love, borrowing from Yogi Berra. Love said Ms. Lynch had no comment on the ruling and did not want any details about her released. J. Douglas McVay, a lawyer for Lynch's widow, said no decision has been made on an appeal. A call to a Phoenix-area listing for Donna Lynch was not immediately returned Tuesday. Michael and Bonita Lynch married in 1968 and separated in 1985. He began living with Donna Williams in 1986. Bonita Lynch filed for divorce the same year. After Lynch won the lottery, she filed for a share of the winnings. Superior Court Judge Rufus Coulter awarded her a share on the grounds all assets acquired during a marriage are community property. Lynch appealed, saying that his ``will to union'' with his first wife had ended by Feb. 10 and that it was her lawyers who made the mistake. The appeals panel rejected the arguments, saying that the paperwork errors were unintentional. ``This case displays the hand of chance,'' Fidel wrote. The appeals court also said it was unclear when the ``will to union'' was really broken because the couple discussed reconciliation through much of the separation. As late as 1987, Bonita Lynch helped her former husband ``in a medical emergency, checked him into an alcoholic rehabilitation program, and agreed to join him in family counseling,'' the court said.

DOC.HEAD: After 50 Years, US Weighs Ties with Albania
DOC.TEXT: After more than 50 years, the United States is ready to pursue normal diplomatic relations with Albania despite its reputation as one of the world's most rigid police states. The State Department responded favorably on Tuesday to a statement last week in which Albanian President Ramiz Alia expressed interest in establishing diplomatic ties. He made the same overture to the Soviet Union. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler, in a statement, referred only indirectly to Albania's human rights record. ``Establishment of diplomatic relations would create the opportunity for dialogue through which we would be able to communicate our concerns and encourage respect for human rights in Albania,'' she said. Albania has been one of the world's most reclusive nations for years, shunning diplomatic ties with all but a few countries while preserving its status as a bulwark of orthodox communism. It is the only European country that has refused to participate in the 35-nation grouping than addresses issues related to continental security and cooperation. But Alia's speech a week ago, in addition to making overtures to Washington and Moscow, indicated an interest in Albanian membership in the European group formed 15 years ago in Helsinki. The most recent State Department report on human rights conditions worldwide, released in February, said Albanians are ``permitted only very limited civil and political rights'' under their Marxist government. The death penalty can be imposed for such non-violent crimes as unauthorized attempts to emigrate or for anti-government propaganda. Albania officially has been an atheist state since 1967. More than 2,100 religious structures were shut down and many religious leaders were persecuted, imprisoned or executed for continuing their religious functions, the report said. Information about specific human rights abuses has been difficult to obtain because of strict official censorship. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, has said that repeated appeals to Albanian authorities for the release of prisoners of conscience have not been answered. One sign that Albania has begun to open up was its decision to grant a visa to Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy, D-Mass. He is scheduled to visit Albania during the first week in June. He is believed to be the first representative of the U.S. government to visit Albania since relations were broken before World War II. James Mahoney, Kennedy's executive assistant, said Tuesday that the congressman intends to explore opportunities for cooperation with Albania. As for human rights, ``we'll be looking at those issues before departure,'' Mahoney said. State Department officials said Albania had been sending out feelers to the U.S. government expressing interest in broader contacts. The overtures began about six months ago, apparently at the time when other communist regimes in Eastern Europe were collapsing. Thus far, however, Albania has been spared the kind of upheaval that has taken place elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Albania has never been a member of the East bloc and looked with disdain on those governments, accusing them of ideological deviationism.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Many Smokers Often Don't Ask Before Lighting Up
DOC.TEXT: Common courtesy often goes up in smoke when it comes to lighting up indoors. Smokers do not ask first, and non-smokers are unwilling to kick butts, researchers say. Half of the smokers surveyed said they light up indoors without asking anyone if they mind, according to a study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. And despite the habit's declining social acceptability, non-smokers are reluctant to ask smokers not to puff. Even though about 90 percent of non-smokers consider secondhand smoke annoying and harmful, the study found, just 5 percent asked people to put out their cigarettes in 1974 and 1987. ``The low percentage is striking, given that most non-smokers are annoyed by secondhand smoke and consider it harmful to their health,'' the researchers wrote. ``A plausible explanation is a desire to avoid a confrontation.'' The survey of 22,043 people found that the proportion of smokers who say they don't smoke in indoor public places rose from 5 percent in 1974 to 33 percent in 1987. The study also found that when they are inside public places that have no rules on smoking, 21 percent of smokers will light up without hesitation and 26 percent will look around first to see if others are smoking, then light up. Fourteen percent will ask others if they mind before lighting up, 33 percent will refrain from smoking and 5 percent will do ``something else.'' In Washington on Tuesday, Tobacco Institute spokeswoman Brennan Dawson said the survey's findings that just 21 percent of smokers light up without hesitation demonstrate ``an enormous application of common courtesy.'' ``We are all taught as children to play nicely together,'' she said. ``And that travels over into adulthood, or at least it should. Smokers are doing a lot of different things, according to this, to play nicely.'' But the study's lead researcher, Dr. Ronald M. Davis of the Centers for Disease Control, said it will take laws _ and not just courtesy _ to dissuade many smokers from lighting up around non-smokers. ``The bottom line is that most non-smokers are suffering in silence,'' said Davis, director of the CDC Office on Smoking and Health at Rockville, Md. Davis noted that surveys have found 29 percent of Americans smoked in 1987, compared with 40 percent in 1965 and 44 percent in 1949. The article said that authorities have concluded that passive smoking causes lung cancer in non-smokers and that a report estimated passive smoking causes 3,800 lung cancer deaths among non-smokers each year in the United States. The researchers' data were based on results from the 1987 National Health Interview Survey of Cancer Epidemiology and Control and compared with surveys conducted by the Roper Organization in 1974, 1976 and 1978. The 1987 nationwide, random survey's margin of error was plus or minus 2 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany to Allow 100 Percent Foreign Ownership of Businesses
DOC.TEXT: East Germany plans to permit 100 percent foreign ownership of businesses, a newspaper quotes the economics minister of the formerly Communist country as saying. Gerhard Pohl says East Germany will repeal recent laws that restrict foreign ownership in joint ventures to 49 percent, the Hamburg-based Bild newspaper reported today. Many foreign companies have shied away from investments in East Germany because of restrictions limiting investors to a minority share. ``We are pulling back the joint venture legislation of the Modrow government,'' Bild quoted Pohl as saying. The interim government of former East German Communist Premier Hans Modrow introduced the restrictive legislation earlier this year. Pohl was quoted as telling the mass-circulation daily that the new laws will be passed ``very soon.'' But he added that East Germans will receive preferential treatment in investments, Bild said.

DOC.HEAD: Can an Environmentalist Enjoy a Steak?
DOC.TEXT: Roughage has found its champion in the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, which argues you've got to eat green food if you're going to be an environmentalist. Eschew meat and save the Earth, says this outfit; eat salads and preserve the rain forests. ``If you're a meat eater, you are contributing to the destruction of the environment, whether you know it or not,'' says Neal D. Bernard, president of the 30,000-member committee, which observed Earth Day by passing out recipes for vegetarian chili and black beans and rice. ``Clearly the best thing you can do for the Earth is to not support animal agriculture,'' says Bernard, 36, a 1980 graduate of the George Washington University School of Medicine and the nephew of two Illinois cattle raisers. Mainstream environmentalists say he's gone too far and the National Cattlemen's Association picks a bone with him. ``The claim that to be a proper environmentalist you can't be a meat-eater is a bunch of bull,'' says cattlemen's spokeswoman Alisa Harrison. ``There is no current sound scientific evidence that shows that by being a vegetarian you're going to be a better user of natural resources.'' ``We don't have a problem with people choosing to become vegetarians,'' Ms. Harrison says. ``What we don't like is groups like the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine spreading false rumors about our use of natural resources. They're misleading and they're not based on scientific evidence.'' But Bernard cites statistics to make his case: _It takes 39 times more energy to produce beef than soybeans having the same caloric value. _Producing enough food to feed a meat-eater requires 4,200 gallons of water a day; to feed a vegetarian requires 300 gallons. _Nearly 4 billion tons of topsoil are lost each year in the United States, chiefly because of overgrazing by livestock and unsustainable methods of growing feed. _Tropical rain forest is being cleared in Latin America to raise cattle; a pound of hamburger represents 55 square feet of burned-off forest. _Intensive cattle raising produces mountains of manure, a source of methane gas, contributor to the greenhouse effect. Most environmentalists don't catch the connection until he spells it out for them, Bernard says. ``They picture a pastoral scene, a few cows grazing and a few chickens clucking,'' he says. ``Little do they know that cows are raised on enormous feedlots for a portion of their lives and you can't keep the manure from running off into streams. By and large, raising animals for food is a very unfriendly industry from an environmental viewpoint.'' Other environmentalists have a ``yes, but'' response. ``It's like saying if you drive a car you can't be a good environmentalist,'' said Michael Oppenheimer, senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, who sees a ``holier than thou'' mentality at work in Bernard's scenario. ``If their point is to draw attention to the effects of meat-eating and let people weigh that in deciding what to do environmentally, that's understandable,'' Oppenheimer said. ``Meat-eating is one of the things a lot of Americans do in excess and could cut down on and do the environment a favor.'' Added Paul Allen, spokesman for the Natural Resources Defense Council, ``You can be a vegetarian and still be a lousy environmentalist if you're not active and involved.'' Allen said his group serves mostly fruit and cheese when it has a reception, ``but that may be more a function of our not being able to afford shrimp.''

DOC.HEAD: A Mother Hopes To Find Four Contra Sons Alive
With PM-Nicaragua Bjt
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Four sons left Joaquina Garcia nine years ago to join the Contra rebels and she has not seen them since. Now that the rebels are disarming she hopes to find them _ ``if they're still alive.'' Like dozens of other anxious parents and relatives, Mrs. Garcia, 46, plans to spend two days in a nearby U.N. administered security zone searching for the young men. Rebels are gathering in five such zones, where they are to surrender their weapons before returning home. ``They went to war nine years ago, when they were barely 11, 13, 17 and 18 years old. I don't know if they're alive or dead,'' Mrs. Garcia said Monday. She said her husband also ``fled toward Honduras'' five years ago, leaving her alone with five small children and a little farm perched on a rocky mountain slope. There she grows beans and corn and also takes care of a girl a Contra woman gave birth to four years ago and then abandoned. ``I have been suffering bitterly,'' Mrs. Garcia said. The U.S.-supported Contra rebels were supposed to gather in the security zones before President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro takes office today. By Tuesday, Sandinista troops had pulled out of the La Rica area in northern Nicaragua together with armed civilians who guarded a Sandinista-run cooperative. The Contras, an estimated 9,000-strong inside Nicaragua, have agreed to disarm by June 10. The La Rica zone was opened Monday and is run by Gen. Agustin Quesada, the Spanish commander of a United Nations observation force. The area includes a camp which can house 2,000 Contras. On Monday a small group of rebels, among the first to arrive, sat on the banks of a river chatting with friends and relatives and washing their fatigues. They still carried their Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles, and some were carrying hand grenades and small missiles. Many echoed their leaders and said they would demand that the Nicaraguan army be disarmed and purged of its Sandinista leaders. Sandinista officers have agreed to give up their party posts while retaining military positions. ``If the Sandinistas continue where they are, then we have fought in vain,'' said a 30-year-old Contra who identified himself only as ``Rubi.'' ``The nine must leave,'' he added, referring to the nine Commanders of the Sandinista Revolution who led the insurrection that overthrew Anastasio Somoza's dictatorship in July 1979. One of the commanders is Gen. Humberto Ortega, the outgoing defense minister. He stepped down from his party post on Monday but is to stay on as army chief. At the Sandinista-run cooperative farm at Las Colinas, one mile south of La Rica, residents said they no longer feared the Contras. Three years ago at least seven people died in a Contra attack on the small cooperative of 30 metal-roofed homes. Justina Ortez, whose 22-year-old son was killed defending the cooperative, said she does not fear the Contras. A rebel who called himself ``Danilo'' walked through the settlement, trying to reassure residents. ``The ones you have to fear are the nine'' of the Sandinista directorate, he kept saying. On the road linking this village to Managua, 150 miles to the north, were three bridges and two Sandinista army trucks destroyed by the Contras. Asked about this, one of the rebels shrugged. ``Dona Violeta (Chamorro) is going to have a lot of work,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials at Odds Over Cutting Prices of Repossessed Properties
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan bailout officials disagree over whether to offer price discounts to speed the sale of repossessed real estate. Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke, who regulates nationally chartered banks, warned of the consequences that discounts could have for struggling S&Ls and banks operating in fragile real estate markets. However, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., pointed to the potential escalation of taxpayer costs if property sales are delayed. The board of the Resolution Trust Corp. on Tuesday postponed action on the issue for two weeks after the two officials voiced their disagreements. It had been set to consider a plan that would have allowed the agency to sell properties as much as 20 percent to 30 percent below their appraised value. Seidman is chairman of the RTC board, which is conducting the cleanup of failed S&Ls, and Clarke is a member. ``I think we have to be awfully careful,'' Clarke said. ``We have a number of (solvent) institutions out in the marketplace holding an awful lot of property ... that we'd like to keep out of the RTC. I'm not sure we know as much about the broader consequences ... as we should.'' The agency's current policy is to sell no property in six distressed states _ Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Colorado, New Mexico and Arkansas _ for less than 95 percent of its appraised value. It is intended to prevent properties from being ``dumped,'' sending depressed properties even lower. However, agency officials are having difficulty attracting bids close to the appraised price and want to offer a reduced price without a costly and time-consuming second appraisal. Also, in some areas of the country, qualified appraisers are hard to find because RTC ethics rules preclude hiring anyone implicated in an S&L failure. Seidman, while agreeing to the two-week delay, said, ``We are sitting here with billions of dollars of property which is costing us huge amounts of money as long as we keep it.'' ``We've got to convince bidders they can get a bargain from us. ... Otherwise, we won't have any customers,'' he said. ``... The first citizen volunteering to buy out of patriotic motives has yet to come forward.'' The policy under consideration would permit the RTC to sell property for 85 percent of appraised value after it had gone unsold for six months, or four months in the case of single-family homes. It would allow an additional 5 percent cut after three more months. The plan also would allow the agency to sell properties at well-advertised auctions for as little a 70 percent of appraised value or, in the case of properties appraised at less than $100,000, for the highest bid regardless of the appraisal. The proposal drew praise from analysts who complain real estate sales so far have been too slow. They said that after the changes the agency would still comply with last summer's S&L bailout law, which requires properties in distressed areas be sold at 95 percent of ``market value'' rather than appraised value. ``Market value is not what an appraisal says it is. It's what a buyer is willing to pay,'' said Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, a Washington research organization. ``As long as you have a sufficient number of bidders, that is the market price.'' Joseph E. Robert Jr., chairman of J.E. Robert Companies, an Alexandria, Va., real estate management firm, said he doubted prices would be further depressed by quicker sales. ``The market has already taken into consideration the overhang and the fact that the RTC has this property,'' he said. In a related matter, a Bush administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Peter Monroe, a deputy assistant housing secretary, is the leading candidate for a top position in the bailout operation. He is set to replace William Taylor as president of the RTC Oversight Board, the Treasury Department-led panel that oversees the policy and purestrings of the bailout operation. Seidman's board has overall supervision. Taylor, a Federal Reserve Board regulator, has been serving in the position temporarily for four months since Daniel Kearney quit amid reports that he believed the Treasury Department was giving him too little authority.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors Want More Money to Fight Root Causes of Drug Abuse
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Big-city mayors say they can't fight a war on drugs without more money to battle the poverty, hopelessness and despair that fuels the drug problem. ``We are fighting the war on drugs in America today in large part because our nation has not prevailed in the war on poverty,'' Houston Mayor Kathryn Whitmire said as more than 100 mayors concluded a two-day meeting Tuesday with police chiefs on the drug problem. Some Democratic mayors leveled a blast at federal drug policy chief William Bennett, saying he was ignoring drug treatment, education and poverty. Bennett, told of their comments, shot back: ``Some of these folks think leadership is coming to Washington twice a year and complaining.'' Boston Mayor Raymond L. Flynn called Bennett ``a little bit hypocritical'' for focusing on law enforcement and failing to address the hopelessness that drives inner-city youths to drug abuse and the drug trade. New York Mayor David Dinkins said Bennett, who was secretary of education in the Reagan administration, had ``sent exactly the wrong signal'' by suggesting drug education programs don't work. ``Bennett's repudiation of drug education was a cynical statement from the man who ran the Education Department through the era of `just say no,''' Dinkins said. ``But it was a typical example of the type of leadership we're getting from Washington _ leadership that says we have more needs and then gives us less.'' Their comments came a day after Bennett addressed the gathering and encountered only gently challenging questions. ``What's with these guys?'' Bennett said in an interview after their remarks Tuesday. ``I was there yesterday ... Did they wait until I leave and then snipe at me?'' Bennett called Dinkins' remarks ``New York bull.'' He said he had never repudiated drug education but had said that education alone was not sufficient to keep young people away from drugs. The mayors issued a closing statement urging the Bush administration to reverse itself on its opposition to providing federal aid directly to the cities to fight drugs, rather than routing it through the states. Mayors contend states have delayed or kept the drug enforcement money for themselves. The mayors said the war on drugs cannot be fought without addressing urban poverty, joblessness and despair that encourages people to seek escape through drugs and makes drug dealing the easiest route to affluence. Whitmire said the mayors want more money for the Head Start program for disadvantaged pre-schoolers, for job training for abusers and for drug treatment programs for anyone who wants it. ``We can no longer conceive of winning the war unless we are able to offer the most basic economic opportunities to all members of our communities,'' she said. Flynn, at a news conference, disputed Bennett's assertions that overall drug use is down and that most drug abusers have jobs. Flynn said casual drug use may be declining but addiction and drug-related violence is increasing. ``The problem of drugs in this country is getting worse and worse,'' Flynn said. ``It's not getting better.'' Don Hamilton, Bennett's press secretary, responding to Dinkins' comments, said federal grants to states for drug education has almost doubled under the Bush administration, from $288 million in 1989 to a proposed $488 million for fiscal 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Withdrawing Nominee to Nuclear Weapons Post
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is giving up its 10-month fight to win Senate confirmation of a former civilian nuclear power regulator as head of the nation's atomic weapons production. In a letter to President Bush released Tuesday, Victor Stello Jr. withdrew his name from consideration, saying he believed the president needed to find someone who could win confirmation to the sensitive job ``at the earliest opportunity.'' ``It has become clear to me that I cannot be that person,'' Stello wrote in the letter dated April 20. Greenpeace and other national environmental groups, as well as prominent members of Congress, strenuously opposed Stello's nomination. They accused him of improper behavior during parts of his 24 years with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which has jurisdiction over civilian nuclear reactors. Stello was the NRC's chief staff official before he came to the Energy Department on temporary assignment last July after Bush nominated him for the weapons chief's job. ``Given his questionable record on health and safety issues at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Victor Stello should not have been nominated for this job in the first place,'' Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., said in response to Stello's withdrawal. Wirth helped lead the campaign against Stello's confirmation. Among the accusations against Stello is that he altered agency rules at the request of nuclear utilities, to the detriment of safety, and that he authorized cash payments to an informer as part of a personal vendetta within the NRC. In two confirmation hearing appearances before the Senate Armed Services Committee last fall, Stello strongly denied that he acted improperly. He asserted that nuclear safety was his primary concern and that he was well suited for the job. The withdrawal of the Stello nomination ends an extraordinary chapter in the administration's effort to revitalize the crippled nuclear weapons complex by putting an experienced nuclear power expert in charge for the first time. Key elements of the weapons complex, which include 17 major production plants and laboratories in 12 states, are shut down because of safety and management problems. Tom Olson, an Energy Department spokesman, said Stello would remain at the department in a civil service job that does not require Senate confirmation. His responsibilities will include overseeing efforts to restart idled reactors at the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina, Olson said. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said during the Senate hearings that Stello was the only qualified person willing to take the job. Olson said Tuesday evening that Watkins had no comment on Stello's withdrawal. The Armed Services Committee was set to recommend Stello's confirmation in January but balked upon learning that he was the focus of an investigation by David Williams, the NRC inspector general. Williams is investigating allegations that Stello and other NRC officials pursued a vendetta against Roger Fortuna, who was in charge of investigating wrongdoing at nuclear plants. The allegation was that Stello believed Fortuna was too hard on the industry. The results of Williams' investigation have not been made public, but in his letter to Bush, Stello noted that the Armed Services Committee planned to hold up further consideration of his nomination until it reviewed them. ``My experience over this past year has led me to the conclusion that final action by the Senate on my nomination will not take place in the foreseeable future,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Cutting Off Funds to Assess Alaska Spill Damage
DOC.TEXT: The Exxon Corp. says it isn't happy with the way the federal government is trying to assess the long-term damages from last year's Alaska oil spill and doesn't plan to contribute any more money for the effort. Officials of an inter-agency trustee council told a congressional hearing Tuesday that efforts to determine the evironmental damages caused by the massive spill from the tanker Exxon Valdez cost $35.4 million in the first year, more than twice the amount provided by Exxon. Damage assessment studies to be continued this year could cost an additional $30 million, according to an internal trustee council document made public by a House Interior and Insular Affairs subcommittee. Shortly after the March 24, 1989 spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound, Exxon agreed to provide $15 million an an initial payment for the government damage assessment program. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan at the time characterized the payment as only a first installment from the oil company. But members of the trustee council told the subcommittee on water, power and offshore energy resources Tuesday that Exxon has stonewalled requests for additional money. ``The trustees have requested that Exxon fund the remaining $20 million (of 1989 costs), but so far Exxon has declined to respond to that request,'' said Alan Raul, general counsel of the Agriculture Department and a member of the trustee council. The minutes of a March meeting of the trustee council, released by the subcommittee, quoted Justice Department officals as advising the participants they ``should not expect further money from Exxon.'' The cost of damage assessment will be borne by the federal government, although some of the money likely will be recovered as part of the damages sought from Exxon in a civil suit that is yet to be filed against the oil company. C.M. Harrison, executive vice president of Exxon Co., USA, acknowledged that Exxon plans no further payments for damage assessments. ``The process has not worked as Exxon anticipated,'' Harrison said in a statement to the subcommittee. He complained Exxon was not given access to data collected as part of the damage assessment process and said there was too much ``emphasis on litigation.'' Exxon so far has spent more than $1 billion in cleanup costs from the spill, which contaminated miles of scenic Alaska coastline. The Justice Department also is pursuing criminal charges against Exxon that could lead to fines and penalties of more than $600 million upon conviction. Meanwhile, several environment groups complained the damage assessment process is inadequate and money shortages are causing the trustees to curtail some studies essential to determining overall harm to wildlife and natural resources. It was previously reported that the trustees decided in their March meeting not to proceed with 24 of the 63 damage assessment studies. ``The lawyers and not the scientists have driven the assessment process,'' complained Erik Olson of the National Wildlife Federation. He maintained some of the studies were halted because they were too expensive and likely would not produce large payoffs in damage recovery as a result of the eventual civil suit agaist Exxon. ``Apparently, decisions on which studies to continue are based at least in part on financial considerations,'' said Robert Adler, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council. Members of the trustee council are officials of the Agriculture Department, Interior Department and the Commerce Department's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Crack Vial Factory Seized
LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Police investigating a smuggling operation stumbled across a factory in Brooklyn that was producing millions of vials used to peddle crack. The factory in a one-story garage was discovered Monday when police were looking for a gang member wanted for producing drug paraphernalia, authorities said. Customs officials said the factory was the largest found in the New York metropolitan area and probably was turning out 2 million of the plastic, half-inch vials a day. ``Four or five times we've found machinery, but nothing close to this scale,'' said Customs agent Victoria Ovis. Three people were arrested under a state law passed last summer against producing drug paraphernalia. Customs officials also said they seized three plastic molding machines and hundreds of thousands of vials. The owner of the building was not identified, police said. Crack vials previously were imported from Southeast Asia and labeled as perfume containers on shipping manifests. But since 1987, when a federal law outlawing imports of drug paraphernalia went into effect, domestic production of the containers has increased, The New York Times reported today. Making packages for illegal drugs is estimated to be a $1 billion-a-year industry.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Protest Removal of Head of Defense Agency
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers are criticizing the Defense Department for removing the director of its high technology research agency.
