Members of Congress said the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is the only place in government where tax dollars are used to promote cutting-edge technology that can help make U.S. businesses more competitive overseas. The Pentagon said Craig Fields, who headed DARPA for a year, was transferred rather than fired from the agency. But his supporters in industry and in Congress contended Fields was removed last Friday for emphasizing dual-use technology, which has civilian as well as military applications. ``This is the triumph of ideology over the national interest,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. Gephardt referred to conservatives in the administration who argue that government should refrain from investing in non-defense research from which private industry would profit. They say the free market should be allowed to work and that industry should finance its own research. Gephardt was among 11 lawmakers of both parties who signed a letter Tuesday urging the Defense Department to reinstate Fields to his post at DARPA. He also asked the House Armed Services Committee to investigate the situation. The research agency has a $1.2 billion budget, about half of which goes to dual-use technologies, Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., said at a news conference. DARPA-funded projects include super computers, artificial intelligence, software, semiconductor manufacturing technology and biotechnology. Levine, whose home state is a high-technology center, is co-chairman of the Congressional High-Technology Caucus. Levine also chairs Rebuild America, a public-policy group that promotes high-technology industries. He said he is drafting legislation that would put DARPA under control of the Commerce Department and require that funds be spent only on dual-use technology except in special cases. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., who signed the letter, said he does not want President Bush ``to go down in history as the president who presided over the economic decline of the United States of America because he and members of his administration were blind.'' He was joined by Rep. Don Ritter, R-Pa., who is chairman of the congressional Technology and Policy Task Force as well as ranking member of the commerce and competitiveness subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Other signers of the protest letter were Reps. Les AuCoin, D-Ore.; Norman Mineta, D-Calif.; Edward Markey, D-Mass.; Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass.; Marcy Kaptur, D-Ohio; and Helen D. Bentley, R-Md.; and Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Commerce subcommittee on science, technology and space. A Pentagon statement said Fields on May 6 would begin serving in a new post that would make him responsible for ``evaluating and recommending actions to streamline the large and complex research and development laboratory infrastructure'' of the Defense Department. It said Victor Reis, the deputy director of DARPA, has been named acting director pending the appointment of a new director.

DOC.HEAD: US Armenians Commemorate Deaths of 1.5 Million Ancestors
DOC.TEXT: When John Yervant was 8 years old, he says, the Ottoman Empire _ the forerunner of modern-day Turkey _ ordered all Armenian residents to leave the town of Erzerum. Yervant's family embarked on a harrowing journey, eating grass to survive, stumbling across dismembered bodies, seeing babies trampled by horses. His father, Yervant says, was tortured and killed by the Turks. On Tuesday, Yervant, 83, knocked on the door of the Turkish Embassy to deliver a petition demanding that Turkey admit to the Armenians' claim that the Ottoman Empire committed genocide and killed 1.5 million Armenians between 1915 and 1923. The embassy refused to open the door. ``We know very well what they want and we don't deal with them,'' said press counselor Tacan Ildem. Yervant was among several hundred Armenians who staged a protest outside the embassy on the 75th anniversary of the start of the Armenian deportations. Commemorative events also were being held in Chicago, Dallas, San Francisco and New York, among other cities. Turkey says 300,000 Armenians died in the deportations but rejects the accusation of genocide, saying Turks and Armenians alike were the victims of a civil war, famine and epidemic. Turkey says Armenians started the civil war, in collusion with Czarist Russia, in order to secede from the waning Ottoman Empire. In a statement on the Senate floor, Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kansas, said 1.5 million Armenians were killed ``as a result of conscious, vicious policies of the Ottoman Empire.'' Dole led a fight in February for a resolution commemorating April 24 as Armenian genocide day, but the measure was defeated under strong pressure from Turkey and its lobbyists in Washington. ``We ought to be ashamed,'' he said. ``One reason 6 million Jews were slaughtered is because of Hitler's conviction that no one remembered the Armenian genocide.'' President Bush, whose administration also opposed the resolution, issued a proclamation to the nearly 1 million American Armenians, marking April 24 as ``a day of remembrance for the more than a million Armenian people who were victims.'' Although he deliberately refrained from using the word ``genocide,'' supporters of Turkey were angered. Armenians, who trace their roots to the second millennium B.C., once commanded a mighty empire stretching from the Caspian Sea to the Mediterranean. In modern times, Armenians enjoyed a two-year period of independence in 1918 on territory that is now the Soviet Republic of Armenia. Today, about 4 million live in the Soviet Union and another 3 are scattered in Turkey, Lebanon, Iran, France and the United States. Yervant's story had a happy ending. He was placed in an orphanage, ran away to France and became a dancer with the Folies Bergeres. He came on tour to the United States during the 1930s and stayed.

DOC.HEAD: Returning Hostages Must Handle Anger, Readjustment, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: Once the euphoria fades from the homecoming of long-term hostages such as Robert Polhill, they risk another prison, built of depression, anger, anxiety and a host of other mental problems. They may also face families that learned to live without them, and a society that forces them to play heroes while blaming them for their captivity. Still, such problems can be avoided or eased by proper mental health care and the basic resilience many hostages show, experts say. ``The remarkable thing isn't that they have problems when they return to the environment, but that people do successfully return, that they do reconstruct their lives,'' said Dr. Harry Holloway, chairman of psychiatry at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences in Bethesda, Md. In fact, David Jacobsen, who spent nearly 17 months as a captive in Lebanon before gaining freedom in 1986, says the experience can make a person more tolerant and understanding. ``You really come to grasp what are the real values of life,'' he said in a recent interview. ``You understand what it is as an innocent person to make it through another day of hell.'' Polhill, who rejoined his family this week after more than three years in captivity in Lebanon, is at the U.S. Air Force Hospital in Wiesbaden, West Germany. Col. Dr. Kenneth Koskinen, medical director of the hospital, said the ex-hostage is ``intellectually very sharp, has a great sense of humor and, considering his ordeal, has a reasonably positive mental status.'' That is encouraging, but University of Maryland psychiatrist Dr. David McDuff cautioned Tuesday that recovery from being a hostage is a long-term process that can take many years. Lingering problems can include anger and depression that began during captivity, said former State Department chief psychologist Samuel Karson, who oversaw evaluations at the Wiesbaden hospital of Americans who had been hostages in Iran. Anger arises as a captive starts thinking, ``Why are they doing this to me?''' Karson said. The anger toward captors is compounded because a hostage is helpless to act on it, he said. ``You can't understand their language, they have full control over you, and you're turned into a helpless child all over again.'' A hostage can also be angry at the U.S. government for not getting him out sooner, he said. Depression can begin from the separation from family and the insecurity about one's future, he said. And it does not simply disappear upon release, he said. ``I'm afraid people's internal systems don't work like a radio or TV set (where you) just flick the switch, now it's off,'' he said. Immediately after release, an ex-hostage may also dwell harmfully on his actions during captivity, said McDuff, who has participated in Army teams that recovered hostages and hijacking victims. Hostages can become ``extremely self-critical'' as they review their actions, feelings and thoughts, McDuff said. They might blame themselves for not stopping beatings other hostages received, or for thoughts about harming their captors, he said. Former captives often fail to see that ``the rules in the middle of a period of captivity really have more to do with survival than with anything else. It's not like the normal world.'' A released hostage may also risk post-traumatic stress disorder, which can include excessive dwelling on the hostage experience, a withdrawing from contacts and activities that might trigger recollections, and anxiety. Still other difficulties can spring from adjusting to the private and public worlds to which a long-term hostage returns. His children have grown years older, shaped by a culture that differs markedly from the life he endured for years, Holloway noted. And he must fit into a family that has built a life without him, Holloway said. The hostage also faces the expectations and attitudes of society. Hostages are pressured into the roles of heroes ``when they're not feeling very heroic,'' Holloway said. Paradoxically, society may also blame them for being taken hostage, McDuff said. ``In order to feel comfortable in this world,'' he said, ``we have to believe and think that things like this don't happen unless somebody does something that makes it happen.'' What can be done to help newly freed hostages cope with their return? A key step, experts say, is to give them immediately a week or so out of the public eye, much like the decompression period deep-sea divers take to adjust to a normal atmosphere. During this time, hostages can become acquainted with their families and the changes they missed. They can come to terms with their thoughts and actions in captivity. They can vent and deal with anger. ``Let them make the choices,'' Karson said. ``That's how they realize that they really are free again.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Plods Ahead on 1991 Budget
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Committee meets 10 a.m. EDT; House debate begins late afternoon; top possible
DOC.TEXT: Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee trying to craft a 1991 budget face an uncertain path, while the major hurdle to House passage of a similar package seems to be dissolving. The Senate panel was meeting for the second day today to try to write its version of a $1.2 trillion spending package. Tuesday's opening session spotlighted the disarray on the panel. Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., was ready to let the committee vote on several proposals and said he believed the panel would ultimately approve about $40 billion in budget cuts. But some Democrats said they would offer plans of their own. Two of them _ Sens. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., and Charles Robb, D-Va. _ might not vote for Sasser's proposals, asserting that more dramatic budget-cutting is needed. With Democrats holding a 13-10 majority on the panel _ and Republicans expected to oppose any Democratic package _ the prospects for approval seemed uncertain. GOP lawmakers said they were unhappy with the Democratic alternatives, saying they would be meaningless unless the White House and Congress could negotiate ways to pare the deficit. Republicans also said the Democratic plans would fall short of reducing the 1991 deficit to $64 billion, as the Gramm-Rudman law requires. ``We're going to be $20 billion off,'' predicted Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Budget Committee. Across the Capitol, conservative House Democrats, displeased with the defense cuts their party's $1.24 trillion spending plan would impose, seemed likely to vote for it anyway. Their support would probably assure approval of the measure in the Democratic-dominated House, where debate was scheduled to begin today. The conservatives reasoned that approving the measure would move the process one step closer to negotiations with the administration, which they believe are necessary. ``I sense a general leaning, reluctantly so, to support the budget and move the process to the next step,'' said Rep. Charles Stenholm of Texas, a leader of about 40 conservative Democrats. ``That's what I intend to do.'' Like their Senate counterparts, House Republicans are nearly all opposed to the Democratic budget. They say only bargaining between President Bush and congressional leaders will produce a legitimate spending blueprint for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. The House budget would set defense spending at $295 billion, $8 billion less than what Bush wants.

DOC.HEAD: Restrictions on Funds Said Prolonging AIDS Epidemic
DOC.TEXT: Restrictions on the use of federal AIDS prevention and education funds are prolonging the epidemic and should be removed, the National Commission on AIDS says. The restrictions are preventing communities from targeting effective messages on how the AIDS virus is spread and what people can do to protect against it, such as using condoms and cleaning intravenous needles, the panel said Tuesday. ``Our only weapon is education,'' said June Osborn, commission chairwoman. ``To put some artificial limits on that is like declaring you're only going to use a certain caliber of weapon ... to fight a war.'' The recommendation to remove these restrictions was one of five made by the commission in its second report to President Bush. The panel also urged Bush to coordinate the federal government's response to the epidemic, to support legislation to provide $600 million in federal funds to areas hit hard by the disease and to pump federal dollars into housing for people with AIDS. In addition, commissioners sought House support for an anti-discrimination bill that has been passed by the Senate and endorsed by Bush. Because AIDS is transmitted chiefly through sexual intercourse with an infected person and by sharing needles with an infected IV-drug user, the content of government-funded messages about spread of the disease has been a subject of sensitivity. An example of content-restrictions can be found in the Centers for Disease Control's proposed revisions of regulations on AIDS-related education materials produced with CDC funds. One provision requires that this material not contain ``terms, descriptions or displays which will be offensive to a majority of the intended audience or to a majority of persons outside the intended audience.'' Another provision of that regulation says federally funded educational programs and materials ``shall not be designed to promote or encourage, directly, intravenous drug abuse or sexual activity, homosexual or heterosexual.'' Commission member Diane Ahrens, who directed a working group on government responsibilities and is a county commissioner in St. Paul, Minn., said the restrictions make it difficult for communities to target those most at risk of getting AIDS. ``There's a feeling that its inappropriate for Washington or Atlanta (CDC headquarters) to tell folks in the South Bronx or Boise (Idaho) how they should direct their educational programs,'' she said. ``What is appropriate for the South Bronx may not be appropriate for Boise. ``We're talking about a deadly disease here,'' she said. ``You have to talk about using bleach (to disinfect needles) if they are abusing drugs ... you need to talk about use of condoms, and that may not be acceptable to some communities, but you have to be relevant to the community you're trying to reach.'' In some cases, states and cities are imposing similar restrictions on the use of their funds. ``The chilling effect sort of permeates the system,'' said commission spokesman Tom Brandt.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Cutting Tariff on Caribbean-Made Tennis Shoes
DOC.TEXT: The Senate says it won't agree to cut the tariff on tennis shoes manufactured in the Caribbean, after a debate that featured several members waving various brands of shoes in the air. On a 63-33 vote Tuesday night and despite the desires of the Bush administration, the Senate rejected cutting in half the 48 percent to 67 percent tariffs on rubber-sole, canvas-top athletic shoes produced in the Caribbean. To opponents, led by Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine, the issue was jobs _ not shoes capitalizing on the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles fad. ``This amendment will destroy an industry (and) ... cost hundreds if not thousands of jobs in this country,'' said Mitchell, citing 800 mostly elderly and women workers at New Balance and Etonic athletic shoe plants in his state. The amendment by Sen. Bob Graham _ who held up a pair of $7.95 Ninja Turtle shoes _ was defeated after Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said its passage could kill a bill providing permanent duty-free status for most imports from the Caribbean and Central America. ``The U.S. industry is on its knees and it's not fair to make matters worse,'' said Bentsen, who as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee is one of the most powerful voices in Congress on trade issues. The overall bill was approved later on a 92-0 vote after the Senate agreed to a further amendment banning imports from Burma over alleged human rights violations. It now goes to a conference committee with members of the House, where similar legislation making the Caribbean Basin Initiative permanent was approved last year. Graham and other supporters of his amendment argued it would shift jobs in the tennis shoe industry to the Caribbean from China, Korea, Taiwan and other Far East countries. ``The question is not about whether jobs will be lost in the United States,'' said Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., ``The real debate is whether we're going to move production from mainland China ... a country that massacres its students ... to struggling democracies in the Caribbean.'' Packwood waved a pair of shoes that later were pointed out to be Korean-made. Opponents, however, also waved various brands of tennis shoes produced in their states and said the job-losers would be Americans rather than Chinese and Koreans. They said 11,000 U.S. jobs have been lost since 1980, when half of all shoes sold in this country were U.S.-made. Today, with only 8,000 Americans still employed in shoe manufacturing, they said, imports now account for 82 percent of all shoes sold in the country and 74 percent of the athletic shoes. Earlier Tuesday, the Senate approved several amendments, including one by Packwood that would prohibit the export of logs harvested on government-owned forest land. The bill extends indefinitely the duty-free access of Caribbean goods, an authority that otherwise would expire in 1995. It also continues a variety of temporary duty suspensions for various chemicals and manufacturing components not produced domestically. In addition, the legislation lifts trade sanctions imposed in 1985 against Nicaragua, including the restoration of a sugar quota worth up to $33 million this year. The 1983 Caribbean Basin Initiative was intended to lift the depressed economies of 24 Caribbean and Central American countries through a combination of direct aid and an elimination of tariffs and quotas to encourage new export industries in the region. Excluded from the duty-free program, however, were various classifications of textiles, clothing, luggage, shoes, dinnerware, leather products and other ``sensitive'' goods that compete directly with U.S.-made products.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Lawyers Seek to Overturn Guilty Verdict
DOC.TEXT: John Poindexter's lawyers are urging acquittal or a new trial for the former national security adviser, asserting that Iran-Contra prosecutors failed to prove their case and used the defendant's protected testimony to convict him. In post-trial motions, the lawyers said Tuesday that Poindexter was victimized by statements he gave to Congress under a grant of immunity from prosecution and that he therefore should be retried. Former White House aide Oliver North testified that he watched as Poindexter tore up a presidential document ratifying a shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran. At Poindexter's trial, Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., blurted out a reference to Poindexter destroying the document. ``The testimony of both witnesses was derived from Admiral Poindexter's immunized testimony,'' the defense attorneys contended. The politically embarrassing document that Poindexter destroyed portrayed the U.S. government as trading arms for hostages, something then-President Reagan had said he would never do. No part of a criminal case may be based on a defendant's statements given under a grant of immunity. Poindexter was convicted April 7 of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. A jury of eight women and four men found he had covered up from Congress North's secret Contra resupply network and the U.S. role in the November 1985 Hawk missile shipment. In urging U.S. District Judge Harold Greene to issue a judgment of acquittal, Poindexter's lawyers said prosecutors: _Failed to prove there was a single conspiracy joining the Contra and Iran portions of the case. _Didn't show that Poindexter knew there was an official congressional inquiry into North's Contra activities. _Presented no evidence to show that Poindexter intended to obstruct Congress when he deleted 5,000 computer messages. _Didn't explain how his alleged lies to Congress about the missile shipment were material to the congressional inquiries. Poindexter's lawyers also said Greene made prejudicial comments that warrant a new trial. As an example, they pointed to the judge's suggestion at one point during North's testimony that there was evidence of a conspiracy. Prosecutor Dan Webb also ``clearly prejudiced'' Poindexter by suggesting in a ``highly inflammatory'' closing argument that Reagan had lied to the American public about the Iran initiative, said Poindexter's lawyers. Webb said ``you don't lie to the American public.'' The prosecutor was referring to Reagan's statement on Nov. 13, 1986 in a nationally televised address that the U.S. government didn't trade arms for hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Bastion Winces At Transfer Of Power
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Two AK-47 assault rifles stand in the corner and Vladimir I. Lenin gazes down from a Cyrillic-captioned photograph in the office of Jose Ortiz, who promises a strong civic opposition from the Sandinistas. The city of Esteli, called ``the cradle of the revolution,'' remains a bastion, perhaps the last, of the outgoing leftists who ousted the tyrannical Somoza family dynasty 11 years ago. Esteli's inhabitants are sad to see the revolution wane. ``The FSLN remains by far the strongest political party,'' says the 49-year-old Ortiz, leader of the regional branch of the Sandinista Worker's Federation. The former construction worker and guerrilla combatant used the initials for the Sandinista National Liberation Front, which is handing over the reins of government to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. ``None of those 14 little parties would have gotten even a pinky finger into political power on their own,'' he said, refering to the broad alliance that propelled Mrs. Chamorro to the presidency. He commented in his office on the main square of this north-central city of 31,000 residents, the only metropolis of considerable size won by the Sandinistas in the Feb. 25 elections. Nationwide, the presidential, legislative and municipal ballot was a landslide for the United National Opposition coalition (UNO). Many of the pastel-painted buildings along Esteli streets are still pocked with bullet holes from fierce combat during the revolution that brought the Sandinistas to power. Part of downtown was demolished by bombs and rockets delivered by President Anastasio Somoza's warplanes. Some walls are patched. Others wear colorful murals of militia men and women brandishing arms, Sandinista doctors administering vaccines, young militants teaching peasants to read. It was a social experiment hailed throughout the hemisphere. ``Maybe because we in this city suffered more than anyone we've been the ones to more completely understand what the revolution meant,'' said Rafael Chavarria, an accountant waiting for a bus on the sidewalk along the lovely central plaza. Chavarria, the son of peasant farmers, identified closely with the Sandinistas but is not a party militant. ``It's clear that since the revolution more poor people have been able to overcome their circumstances and make for themselves a better life than their parents' life,'' he said. ``Now our role must be one of constructive criticism, to call the new government's attention to what goes wrong. But always by civic means,'' he said, eschewing any recourse to violence. Indeed, after the nearly decade-long insurgency of the U.S.-funded Contra rebels, what he and Ortiz and most Nicaraguans appear to most fervently desire from the transition is peace. ``People did not vote for either conservatives or communists or any of the parties in UNO. Nor did they vote against the Sandinistas,'' contended Ortiz. ``What they voted for was peace, because they believed that if the Sandinistas won, the Contra war imposed by the United States would continue. ``Most of the comrades (Sandinistas) understand this transition. Otherwise, we wouldn't be handing over power peacefully. We're not radicals,'' he said. ``The Sandinista movement was not born July 19, 1979 (the date of the revolutionary victory). We have decades of experience of political struggle. Now our job is to present opposition, a strong opposition. We're going to defend what we've achieved.'' He and Chavarria agreed that three things threaten Nicaragua: renewed and escalated civil strife; failure of an estimated 9,000 Contra rebels to demobilize by June 10, as they have promised, and revanchist anti-Sandinista measures by the new government. Mrs. Chamorro has insisted that her principal objective is reconciliation. ``If the idea is to wipe the slate clean and start anew, then we can achieve peace,'' said Chavarria. ``But if they start with `You did this to me, so I'm doing this to you,' ...'' he shook his head as his voice trailed off. Asked why he had the Soviet-made assault rifle in his office, Ortiz defended the concept of a militia. ``All the weapons belong in the hands of the people,'' he said. ``I'm not going to use that gun in any aggressive way, but if any SOB Contra comes after me, I'm ready to blow him away.''

DOC.HEAD: Stepfather Says Bomb Builder's Suicide Sign of Remorse
LaserPhoto NA4
DOC.TEXT: A man who committed suicide shortly after a bomb he built maimed a 5-year-old girl at a K mart a year ago may have taken his life because ``a good little girl was the victim,'' his stepfather says. David L. Swinford, 19, shot himself in the head in a car on a rural road on April 19, 1989, two days after the bombing and hours after having discussed the blast with his mother and sister, authorities said Tuesday. Swinford, of rural Noblesville, was identified as a possible suspect within days of the bombing, but investigators only recently developed conclusive evidence he built the device, said Charles Petersen, agent in charge of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in Indianapolis. Tests on a screwdriver and knife from Swinford's car determined they were used in making the pipe bomb, which was concealed in a pump-type toothpaste dispenser and blew the girl's hand off as she lifted it from a shelf, Petersen said. Petersen said authorities knew of no motive for the bombing. But Swinford's stepfather, David W. Whitesell, recalled a conversation his family had while watching a TV account of the bombing a few hours after the incident. During the discussion, Whitesell said, his wife, Grace, wondered aloud who would commit such a crime involving a child. ``David replied, `What business did a little girl have to do in the trash bag department?''' Whitesell recalled. ``If he really did do this, I think it was a real blow to him to find out that a good little girl was the victim.'' Erin Bower, now 6, now wears an artificial limb to replace the left hand she lost in the blast. She was scheduled this month for a cornea transplant in her left eye, also damaged in the explosion. Her mother, Maureen Bower, expressed sympathy over Swinford's death. ``I'm sorry the boy felt he had to take his life over it. Somehow I think that as well as Erin has done, we could have found forgiveness for him,'' Mrs. Bower told WTHR-TV Tuesday night. While Swinford was withdrawn around adults and was asked to move out of the home following disagreements, his mother and stepfather said he loved children. Mrs. Whitesell said her son would play with the couple's children _ Paula, 4{, and 15-month-old twins, Brittany and Paul. ``There was a point that I suggested he go into something where he could work with disabled children because our boy has Down's syndrome and David always related well with him,'' Mrs. Whitesell said. Whitesell said his stepson never confessed to the bombing. Petersen said there was no evidence Swinford actually placed the bomb on the shelf, and he may have had an accomplice. Swinford knew about bomb-making and electrical wiring from building crude firecracker devices with friends and from working with his stepfather in electronic installation, Petersen said. Despite the evidence announced Tuesday, Whitesell said his family was uncertain whether to believe his stepson had a role in the bombing. ``Sometimes I feel like it's easy to pick on the dead suspect,'' Whitesell said. ``On the other hand, the only way to be sure is for David to come and tell me himself and he can't do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Reopens Investigation of Letelier Assassination
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court has ordered a military court to immediately reopen the investigation into the 1976 car-bomb assasination in Washington of former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier and an American aide. The court's unanimous decision Tuesday follows the recent disclosure of the identity of a women who allegedly was involved in the murder plot. The woman, Luisa Lagos, was quoted by a local newspaper as saying she is a former agent of Chilean secret police, known as DINA, and that she traveled to the United States in 1976 under the assumed name of Liliana Walker. The Supreme Court ordered the military court that handled the case before it was closed to question the woman, who has been under police protection at an undisclosed location since going public last week. The woman said she went to the United States with a DINA agent who prepared the Letelier killing. Letelier and an American aide, Ronni Moffit, were killed Sept. 21, 1976, when his car was destroyed by a bomb in downtown Washington. Letelier was a prominent foe of the Chilean military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The new civilian government of President Patricio Aylwin, who succeeded Pinochet on March 11, has promised ``full cooperation with the courts'' in the case. The lower house of Congress on Tuesday unanimously approved a goverment-proposed bill for the posthumous restoration of Letelier's citizenship. The Pinochet regime had stripped him of citizenship two weeks before his death, accusing him of ``actions against the interests of the Chilean nation.'' Three Chilean army officers, members of the Pinochet regime's secret police, were indicted in the case by a court in Washington, but the Chilean Supreme Court turned down a request for their extraditions in 1979. One of the officers, Maj. Armando Fernandez Larios, slipped out of the country in 1987 and surrendered to U.S. courts, where he admitted to a collaborative role in the plot to kill Letelier. Fernandez is now living in the United States under a new identity after serving a seven-month sentence. The others, retired Gen. Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, who was the director of DINA, and his top aide, retired Col. Pedro Espinoza Bravo, are still in Chile. The United States goverment, which repeatedly complained of what it called lack of cooperation by the Pinochet regime in investigating the assasination, has insisted that Contreras and Espinoza be tried, either in Chile or in the United States. Contreras and Espinoza have said they were not involved in the case. Another DINA agent, Michel Townley, an American, was convicted in the case in the United States and is now living there under a new identity after serving a jail sentence. Two weeks ago, another alleged participant in the plot, Dionisio Suarez, was arrested by the FBI in Florida. Suarez, an anti-Castro Cuban, faces trial in Washington. The U.S. ambassador, Charles Gillespie, discussed the Letelier case Tuesday with Interior Minister Enrique Krauss. After the hourlong meeting, Gillespie said he sees ``a strong will in the new goverment to investigate the case.'' Letelier's sister, Fabiola Letelier, a lawyer, called the court's decision Tuesday ``a positive step.'' However, she said, the family still wants the case transferred from the military court to a civilian court.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Leader Urges Lithuania to Compromise on Timing, Not Goal
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania should be patient about gaining independence from the Soviet Union without compromising on its ultimate goal, advises a leader of Solidarity, the movement that brought democracy to Poland. Bronislaw Geremek, political adviser to Solidarity founder Lech Walesa and the movement's parliamentary leader, urged Western governments to recognize both sides of the tense conflict between Lithuania and the Kremlin. ``First, that the Lithuanians are right fighting for their freedom and national independence and second, one should seek (to find) in what way the Soviet Union can accept and cope with this new situation,'' he said Tuesday in a speech at the National Press Club. Geremek said he admires the Lithuanian independence leaders but added, ``until now they have no experience of compromise, political dialogue and political deal, and they have to learn it as we have learned it within a few months, and I hope that our friends in Lithuania will go the same way. ``It means that one cannot have a compromise concerning values and aspirations, but one can have a compromise concerning the time,'' he added. The forum was sponsored by the Atlantic Council and the German Marshall Fund _ U.S. and West German organizations supporting foreign policy research and international exchange. The Lithuanian conflict confirms the words of Andrei Sakharov, longtime Soviet dissident, a few months before his death last year that ``the very future of the Soviet Union depends on its changing its structure,'' Geremek said. He added that he hopes the Soviet Union realizes this, and that the United States and other Western governments understand both sides of the problem. The visiting Solidarity leader, a historian twice jailed for dissident activity under the fallen communist government, was elected to Parliament last year representing Suwalki, a region on the Polish-Lithuanian border. Democracy in the Central European countries is still very weak, he said, and while communism has no chance for a comeback, ``real danger of a new authoritarian system exists in all Central European countries'' if economic reforms fail. The drastic austerity of Poland's economic reforms is being watched closely by Hungary, Czechoslovakia and other Central European countries as well as the Soviet Union itself and ultimately they might require similar measures, he said. Countries have moved from dictatorship to democracy, but Poland's efforts to ``return from totalitarian economy to market economy never happened in history,'' he said. ``The results of this first experiment will have its importance for other countries in the same situation.'' After 1,000 percent inflation last year, Poland began 1990 with price increases, monetary and other reforms, and inflation dropped from 80 percent in January to 5 percent in March, Geremek said. The ``social cost'' has been high, he said, with ``dangerous recession'' trends including a 30 percent drop in industrial production and unemployment soaring from under 50,000 to 300,000 with promise of much bigger rises by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Miners Find `World's Biggest Opal' in the Outback
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollars figures are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Miners in the small Outback town of Coober Pedy claimed today to have found the world's biggest opal, an uncut rock that weighs 11.6 pounds and is worth an estimated $3 million. Named ``Jupiter 5,'' the stone is a milky-white opal that the miners said was unearthed last July. They did not explain why its discovery was not announced earlier. The miners said the stone is 9.2 inches long and 4.8 inches wide, with a total of 26,350 carats. A mine spokesman said the gem was found 56 feet underground in Coober Pedy, a town in New South Wales state known for its underground homes and motels. Residents dig dwellings into the earth to protect against intense summer heat. The miners also showed pictures today of a polished opal dubbed ``Unnamed Lady'' that they said was about half the size of Jupiter 5 and worth about $1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,564.36, up 62.98 points, or 0.21 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Billboard Legislation Introduced
DOC.TEXT: A quarter century after Congress sought to beautify the nation's highways, billboards still blight the landscape, a coalition of public officials and environmentalists say. Giant billboards on metal posts as much as 150 feet tall have replaced the 15-foot plywood signs that dotted highways in the mid-1960s. And according to a group proposing a ban on new billboards along federal highways, advertisers have used loopholes and amendments in the 1965 highway beautification law to cut down public trees and spend taxpayer dollars to take down old signs. ``The Highway Beautification Act of 1965, despite its good intentions, has not lived up to its expectations,'' Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., author of the billboard proposal, told the Senate Tuesday. The answer proposed by Chafee, several Senate and House colleagues, Houston Mayor Kathy Whitmire and several environmental groups is to take power away from the federal government. The legislation, in addition to banning new billboards on major federal highways, would allow states, cities and towns to remove existing billboards along those roadways. Using a court-tested amortization process, the communities could remove the signs in as little as five years at no cost to taxpayers, according to Chafee.
DOC.HEAD: Cuba Extends Jamming of Radio Marti Past Sunrise
DOC.TEXT: Cuba is now jamming the U.S. government's Radio Marti broadcasts in the morning hours, says a spokeswoman for the Voice of America, which runs the station. VOA spokeswoman Beth Knisley said Tuesday that the agency deplores the action taken against Radio Marti, which began broadcasting five years ago. The jamming denies the Cuban people ``access to uncensored news and information,'' she said. She quoted a Cuban government statement as saying that the jamming was a ``new step toward a definitive solution of the problem.'' She said the broadcast operation can still be heard on shortwave radios. Cuba started jamming the station during the pre-dawn hours last week and then shifted the interference on Tuesday to the post-sunrise period when the audience is much greater. The actions appear to be related to the advent of TV Marti, the televised version of Radio Marti. TV Marti tests began last month during the early morning hours and have been jammed consistently by Cuban transmitters.
DOC.HEAD: Agency Rejects Proposal to Tax Children's Social Security Benefits
DOC.TEXT: The Social Security Administration will not collect income taxes on many Social Security benefits paid to children claimed as dependents by their parents. The agency rejected the proposal, made by the inspector general of the Health and Human Services Department, as ``anti-family'' and contrary to President Bush's goal of a ``kindler, gentler America.'' Inspector General Richard Kusserow recommended, in an audit released Tuesday, that the taxes be paid by most of the 334,000 middle- and upper-income families whose children how receive tax-free benefits. Even as the children were receiving the tax-free benefits, about 4.5 million retirees and disabled beneficiaries and their spouses at the same income levels were paying income taxes on as much as one-half of their Social Security benefits. In a memo included in the report, Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King rejected the proposal, saying she was concerned about how it would be perceived by Congress and the public.

DOC.HEAD: Liz Taylor Showing `Slightest Bit of Improvement'
DOC.TEXT: Her four children from three marriages at her hospital bedside, a pneumonia-stricken Elizabeth Taylor is showing ``the very slightest bit of improvement,'' her doctor says. ``It's the most sick she's been under my care,'' Dr. Michael Roth, a longtime friend and Miss Taylor's physician for 10 years, said Tuesday. The 58-year-old actress has been hospitalized more than two weeks. She has been in the intensive care unit at St. Johns Hospital and Health Center since Friday. Roth said Miss Taylor was ``certainly stable for the moment with the very slightest bit of improvement.'' Miss Taylor was receiving medication intravenously, her breathing is aided by a ventilator and ``her spirits are good,'' Roth said. Among those maintaining a vigil at her bedside were her children, Maria Burton-Carson, Liza Todd-Tivey and Christopher and Michael Wilding. On Sunday, she underwent surgery to remove a piece of lung tissue to determine the cause of her pneumonia, doctors said. Results of the biopsy were expected Thursday. Miss Taylor entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with what doctors said was a persistent fever and sinus infection. When her condition worsened, she was moved April 16 to St. Johns. In a statement after arriving at St. Johns, she denied rumors she had AIDS. Miss Taylor, the winner of best-actress Oscars for ``Butterfield 8'' and ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf,'' has been plagued with health problems for years, particularly back troubles from filming of ``National Velvet'' in 1945, when she fell off a horse. She had a nearly fatal bout with pneumonia in 1961. In 1983 she acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and painkillers. Miss Taylor has been treated for alcohol and drug abuse at the Betty Ford Clinic, and her weight over the years has been up and down.

DOC.HEAD: Has `Twin Peaks' Peaked in the Ratings?
DOC.TEXT: The NBC comedy ``Wings'' landed in the top 10 in the ratings in its debut, while ABC's much ballyhooed ``Twin Peaks'' appears to have done just that _ peaked, that is. Film director David Lynch's nighttime soap opera chronicling sex, violence and junk food in a small Northwest lumber town continues to lose viewers, according to figures released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. After a debut two weeks ago at No. 5, ``Twin Peaks'' plummeted to 28th in the week ended April 22. Debuting against it on Thursday, ``Wings'' was the No. 7 show on television. NBC's ``Cheers'' was the top-rated program for the week. And all the hype in Hollywood failed to attract a major audience for Sunday's Earth Day special on ABC. ``Time Warner Presents the Earth Day Special'' won its time slot, but the celebrity extravaganza finished overall in a three-way tie for 16th place, with an average rating of 14.6. The peacock still struts as the No. 1 network with an average rating of 12.5 for NBC. ABC was second with a 12;, CBS had a 9.6. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. If the humor of ``Wings'' sounded like the banter of the ``Cheers'' bar patrons, it's because three former ``Cheers'' writers wrote the pilot for ``Wings,'' which follows the adventures of two brothers running a commuter airline on Nantucket Island in Massachusetts. ``Cartoon All-Stars to the Rescue'' helped make TV history. The anti-drug simulcast of Bugs Bunny, a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Donald Duck's nephews Huey, Dewey and Louie drew the largest audience ever for a Saturday morning entertainment program. Broadcast by ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox, the ``just say no'' kiddie show netted a 22 average. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 21.9; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 21.7; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 21.1; ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' special repeat, ABC, 20.9; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 20.8; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 19.8; ``Wings,'' NBC, 19; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 18.4; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 16.8, and ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 16.8. In the network news battle, Peter Jennings and ``World News Tonight'' on ABC were No. 1 for the 15th consecutive week with a 10 average. In second place was ``The CBS Evening News,'' with Dan Rather at 8.8. ``NBC Nightly News'' with Tom Brokaw had an 8.3.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Up Slightly, Dollar Jumps
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index recovered from early losses and closed slightly higher Wednesday, while the dollar rose sharply against the yen. The dollar closed at 159.25 yen, up 1.10 yen from Tuesday's close of 158.15 yen. It opened at 158.96 yen and ranged between 158.80 yen and 159.28 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average climbed 62.98 points, or 0.21 percent, closing at 29,564.36. It gained more than 200 points in early trading but was down 42.15 points at the end of morning trading before bouncing back in the afternoon. Traders said buying interest was spurred in the afternoon by the announcement of a land development plan by Mitsubishi Mining and Smelting Co. The Nikkei's fall in the morning session was largely due to a decline in futures prices discouraging market players, they said. Haruhito Ichimura, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co., said many investors were reluctant to buy ahead of the Golden Week holidays that start Saturday and continue through May 6 for many Japanese companies. ``They are trying to stay on the safer side, especially due to uncertainties over foreign exchange fluctuations,'' he said. The dollar's strength reflected its gains in overseas markets. The dollar finished at 158.95 yen in New York overnight, up from 157.55 yen on Monday. Masaaki Tanahashi, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said the dollar gained ground in thin trading focused on cross trading between the yen and the West German mark. Trading was light because the Sydney market was closed because of a national holiday in Australia, he said. In the bond market, the price of benchmark No. 119 No. 10 Japanese government bonds slipped to 85.80 from Tuesday's close of 85.82. That pushed the yield up slightly to 7.41 percent from 7.405 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Sandinista Rule in Nicaragua
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The following is a chronology of important events since the leftist Sandinistas came to power nearly 11 years ago in Nicaragua: _July 19, 1979: The Sandinista National Liberation Front enters the capital Managua two days after longtime dictator Anastasio Somoza flees the country. _November 1980: First attacks by anti-Sandinistas who become known as the Contras, short for the Spanish word for counterrevolutionary. _February 1981: Reagan administration suspends U.S. aid. _November 1982: First reports emerge of covert U.S. aid to the Contras. _May 1, 1985: Reagan announces trade embargo against Nicaragua. _Aug. 13, 1986: The U.S. Senate approves $100 million military aid package passed earlier by the House. _Nov. 25, 1986: U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese says some profits from the sale of American arms to Iran were secretly diverted to the Contras in an operation under Marine Lt. Col. Oliver North. _Aug. 7, 1987: Five Central American presidents sign a regional peace plan. _Feb. 3, 1988: Congress cuts off military aid to the Contras. Non-lethal aid continues. _April 1, 1988: A formal 60-day truce begins following first direct meeting between Sandinistas and Contras. _May 31, 1988: The Sandinistas decide to extend the cease-fire on a month-to-month basis; the Contras say they consider the truce indefinite. Fighting slackens. _Feb. 14, 1989: Five Central American presidents agree the Contras should be demobilized. Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega agrees to hold free and fair elections in 1990. _April 28: President Bush signs a $49 million non-lethal aid package for the Contras that will run out three days after the 1990 elections. _Aug. 7: The Central American presidents formalize the demobilization accord. _Aug. 26: Contra commander Israel Galeano says the rebels will ignore the demobilization agreement and starts moving his troops back to Nicaragua. _Nov. 1: Ortega lifts the 19-month-old cease-fire after several attacks and the infiltration of thousands of Contra troops. Fighting surges briefly. _Feb. 25: Elections monitored by thousands of international observers are held. Ortega suffers a stunning upset at the hands of a nation weary of war and financial ruin, the latter caused in part by U.S. economic embargo. _Feb. 27: The Sandinistas say the Contras have to demobilize before they will hand over control of the police and armed forces. President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro calls on the Contras to disband, saying the elections mean there is no reason to keep fighting. _March 13: President Bush lifts the economic embargo and asks Congress for $300 million in aid, including $45 million to demobilize and relocate the Contras. _March 27: Mrs. Chamorro's coalition, the United National Opposition, and the Sandinistas sign an agreement on transition that calls for depoliticizing the Sandinista army. _April 19: Sandinistas, Contras and the coalition agree on a cease-fire and the immediate concentration of the Contras in security zones. The Contras agree to begin surrendering their weapons on April 25, inauguration day, and to disband by June 10.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Succeed With Market Knowledge and Staff Stability
DOC.TEXT: In the face of declining readership, some newspapers are succeeding by remaining close to their subscribers and by building loyal reporting staffs with authoritative knowledge of the communities they cover. In a report submitted Tuesday at the American Newspaper Publishers Association, a research group dubbed ``The A-Team'' told what made three newspapers more successful than most. Group members said they found different formulas at The Free Lance-Star of Fredericksburg, Va., The Cedar Rapids (Iowa) Gazette and The Press-Enterprise of Riverside, Calif. But one trait was universal. ``They knew their markets cold and were always updating their understanding,'' said Michelle Foster, marketing director of the News-Press of Fort Myers, Fla., and a member of the research group. Seymour Topping, director of editorial development for the New York Times Regional Newspaper Group, said a team approach to running the newspapers helped. He added that each gave its readers a complete paper with local, national and international news. Harold F. Woldt Jr., vice president-circulation of Newsday, of Long Island, N.Y., pointed to a loyal staff as a key to success at all three papers. He stressed that only if core personnel are retained can they know the communities they serve. He said the three papers had unusual stability among their staff, accomplished through publisher involvement, better pay and a sense of institutional commitment to the newspaper. The presentation was chaired by William J. Keating, chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer, who declared the report gave him ``renewed faith that we, the newspaper people of America, can meet the challenge.'' In other events Tuesday at the association's 104th annual convention, the nation's newspaper publishers discussed declining readership, telecommunications developments affecting papers and recycling of newsprint. To build greater reader interest, an advertising consultant advised newspapers to focus on local news, suggesting international issues don't sell advertising. The comments came during a panel discussion titled ``Ozzie and Harriet Are Gone _ Who Do You Think You're Writing For?'' The discussion was moderated by Jeff Greenfield of ABC News. Virginia Dodge Fielder, vice president of research for Knight-Ridder Inc., expressed industry frustration over vanishing readers. ``I wish they expressed more dissatisfaction because if they did we'd know how to tackle it,'' she said. ``What the public is saying is not `I hate you,' but `I don't need you.''' The session opened with video interviews in which subjects were asked if they read a newspaper. ``I don't have time,'' was a common response. Several said TV news was ``easier.'' One man said that since big business had taken over his local paper, he felt less connected to it. The comment echoed a message emphasized by Laurel Cutler, vice chairman of FCB-Leber Katz partners and vice president of consumer affairs for the Chrysler Corp. ``The only specialized thing about a newspaper is its locality,'' she told the audience. ``Localness is what you have to sell.'' But Frank A. Daniels Jr., president and publisher of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C., interjected that ``a newspaper traditionally has been a smorgasbord.'' Ms. Cutler warned against newspapers trying to be ``all things to all people.'' Greenfield suggested that the puzzle of declining readership may not be complex. ``Is it possible that the reason people read newspapers so devotedly in 1940 is there was nothing else to inform them?'' he asked. Publishers and editors on the panel disagreed. ``One thing you may be overlooking is how adaptable newspapers are,'' said C. Shelby Coffey III, editor and executive vice president of the Los Angeles Times. He noted the Times has numerous regional bureaus to keep the paper local but has inaugurated a ``World Report'' section on global developments. ``Research at the Times shows that international news is of great interest to readers,'' he said. Coffey and Gerald Garcia, editor and publisher of The Knoxville (Tenn.) Journal, also urged development of a multi-ethnic reporting force. Publishers were also told they must move to recycle newsprint to stave off government interference. Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Hearst Corp. in New York and chairman of the ANPA Newsprint Resource Task Force, painted a grim picture of vanishing landfills. He said publishers have resolved to double the amount of recycled newsprint used in the coming year, reaching a total of 4.6 million tons. ``We believe efforts to control newsprint can mean efforts to control the press,'' he said. ``The prospect of dealing with a regulated newsprint industry calls up an array of terrifying unknowns.'' He said 35 percent of newspapers are recycled, and publishers aim to bring that up to 50 percent. Bennack said that in 1979 the nation had 18,000 landfills available. Today only 6,500 remain, he said, and by 1995 that figure will diminish to 4,200. Bennack stressed that newsprint makes up only 8 percent of solid waste in landfills. In a separate development, publishers were told they may be close to winning a six-year dispute with the Bell telecommunications companies. Robert M. Johnson, publisher, president and chief executive officer of Newsday Inc. of Long Island, N.Y., reported that Congress is likely to pass a bill soon setting a telecommunications public policy. Citing antitrust laws, U.S. District Judge Harold Greene held that those who control telecommunication lines should not also control the information that goes over those lines, Johnson said. He recounted that Bell companies lobbied for exceptions to the 1984 court ruling on the breakup of AT&T. Johnson said the Bell companies have set aside a $25 million ``war chest'' to fight to publish information on electronic circuits. He said Bell seeks to launch an ``electronic Yellow Pages'' in competition with newspaper ads. An ANPA task force has worked with Congress, Johnson said. ``The result of those long negotiations was a new draft bill,'' he said. ``It is from our point of view the best piece of legislation we've seen.'' The bill has not yet been passed. An appeal of the original federal order has sent that back to Greene for reconsideration.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua-At-A-Glance
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Nicaragua, where Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is to be inaugurated as president today:

THE LAND _ Nicaragua is the largest country in Central America, about the size of Iowa, with 57,000 square miles. A coastal plain rolls from the Pacific Coast to the central mountains, providing the country with rich farmland. Farms and ranches dot the mountains. The eastern half of the country is sparsely populated, crisscrossed by rivers and dominated by the steamy jungles of the Miskito coast along the Caribbean. No road connects the two coasts. A string of more than 50 volcanos runs northwest to southeast near the Pacific coast. One of Nicaragua's two large lakes contains the world's only freshwater sharks. A Dec. 23, 1972, earthquake and fires destroyed the center of Managua. Much of the capital has not been rebuilt and remains a wasteland of weedy lots and skeletons of buildings. Nicaragua is bordered by Honduras on the north, Costa Rica on the south.

THE PEOPLE _ Nicaragua has 3.5 million people, about 90 percent living in the western half of the country and about half under age 16. Managua, the most populous city, has 850,000 residents. Spanish is the official language. English and native Indian languages, mostly Miskito, are spoken by ethnic minorities along the Caribbean coast.

THE ECONOMY _ Exports of coffee, cotton, sesame and beef provide most of Nicaragua's income. From $700 million in 1978, the year before the Sandinistas came to power, exports dropped to $200 million in 1989, at the height of the U.S. trade embargo. Inflation for 1989 was 1,700 percent, according to the government, a figure that many experts think is low. In 1988, prices rose 33,600 percent. The currency, the cordoba, has been steadily devalued in line with inflation. President Bush lifted the 1985 U.S. embargo on March 13 and asked Congress for $300 million in aid, including $45 million to demobilize and relocate the Contras.

HISTORY _ Spain conquered Nicaragua's various Indian tribes in 1552. The country won independence from Spain in 1821. Relations with the United States have long been traumatic. In the 1850s, American adventurer William Walker invaded the country several times, once declaring himself president. Early in the 1900s, U.S. Marines occupied the country, leaving for the last time in 1933. Augusto Cesar Sandino became a national hero fighting the Americans. He was killed in 1934 and the United States installed Gen. Anastasio Somoza, founder of a 42-year Somoza family dynasty. The last Somoza, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, was overthrown July 19, 1979, in a revolution led by the Sandinista National Liberation Front, named after Sandino. Discontent after nine years of war and increasing economic deterioration helped Mrs. Chamorro oust Sandinista President Daniel Ortega in a Feb. 25 vote. Mrs. Chamorro is the widow of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, a Somoza opponent whose assassination in January 1978 consolidated support for the Sandinista revolt.

DOC.HEAD: Donald and Ivana Ink Pact Allowing The A-Word
DOC.TEXT: Donald and Ivana Trump, though not your average flower children, are taking a turn at free love. New York's most-trumpeted couple have signed a two-page agreement allowing them to date third and fourth parties without such action giving either grounds for divorce, the Daily News and the New York Post reported today. ``Trump: The Dating Game'' is good for at least 60 days, at which point either side may cancel the pact, the papers said. The Post and the News quoted sources as saying the pact was drawn up at the request of Mrs. Trump, who yearns to date but doesn't want to diminish any divorce settlement. ``She is basically saying, `I don't want a divorce, and I don't want to become a nun,''' one source told the Post. Stanley Lotwin, one of Trump's lawyers, confirmed the agreement in a statement. ``We're confirming that a very limited agreement was signed, having to do with each being permitted to conduct themselves as if they were single, but having nothing to do with finance,'' he said in the Daily News.

DOC.HEAD: One Worker Killed in Bridge Collapse
LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: A freshly poured concrete support arch on a bridge connecting Minneapolis and St. Paul fell into the Mississippi River, killing a construction worker. Several employees of C.S. McCrossan Construction Inc. were inspecting the arch when a 200-foot piece gave way Tuesday, dropping more than 100 tons of concrete and debris, authorities said. Robert A. Moser, 45, suffered multiple injuries and may have died before he hit the water 90 feet below, said Gary Kaldun, an investigator with the Hennepin County medical examiner's office. At least one other worker plunged into the water but was not seriously hurt, police said. ``They said a sag or a bulge in the form was noted and they were up there inspecting that when it all gave way,'' Kaldun said. The $15.7 million bridge was being built to replace an adjacent span about 100 years old. The two bridges are less than 20 feet apart. State Transportation Commissioner Leonard Levine said the cause of the collapse was not known. He said state engineers would also inspect the old bridge today to determine if it was weakened by the impact of the collapse. The old bridge was closed to traffic. ``It was just like a plane would crash. It even felt like the ground shook a bit,'' said Clarence Stodolka, who was walking near the Minneapolis end of the bridge.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Sharply, Nikkei Edges Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index recovered from early losses and closed slightly higher. The dollar closed at 159.25 yen, up 1.10 yen from Tuesday's close of 158.15 yen. It opened at 158.96 yen following overnight gains in New York and ranged between 158.80 yen and 159.28 yen. The dollar climbed in Tokyo trading as market players bought the West German mark against the yen, said Akiko Baba, a Bank of Tokyo dealer. ``Dollar buying by trading houses also helped strengthen the dollar,'' she added. Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said trading was thin ahead of the Golden Week holidays, which start Saturday and go through May 6 for many Japanese companies. Some $8.68 billion changed hands in spot trading. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average climbed 62.98 points, or 0.21 percent, closing at 29,564.36. It gained more than 200 points in early trading, was down 42.15 points at the end of the morning session and then bounced back in the afternoon. Traders said buying interest was spurred in the afternoon by the announcement of a land development plan by Mitsubishi Mining and Smelting Co. Japan Airlines Co. was also the focus of attention after announcing a 10-for-1 stock split Tuesday that will bring down the stock's par value from $3.14 to 31 cents. Trading in JAL shares was halted when the price reached $106, a gain of $12.60 _ the maximum gain allowed in one day, said Masashi Wakabayashi, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. The split takes effect Aug. 8. ``Recently, market players are targeting individual issues with good performances,'' he said. ``Even when the index is falling, market players are no longer selling actively.'' The Nikkei's morning decline was largely due to a decline in futures prices discouraging market players, said Haruhito Ichimura, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co. He said many investors were reluctant to buy ahead of the ``Golden Week'' holidays. They are trying to stay on the safer side, especially due to uncertainties over foreign exchange fluctuations, he said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bonds was quoted at 85.88 points as of 4 p.m., up slightly from Tuesday's close of 85.82. Their yield was down to 7.395 percent from 7.405 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Former Prosecutor Admits Fabricating Shootout Story
DOC.TEXT: A former hot-dogging prosecutor pleaded guilty to falsely claiming armed drug dealers in a speeding car had tried to assassinate him. Samuel Asbell was barred Tuesday from ever holding public office again and agreed to pay $12,000 to cover the cost of investigating his tale. He faces up to 18 months in prison or a $7,500 fine. No sentencing date was set for the former Camden County prosecutor, who used to accompany detectives on drug raids, toted a gun in a shoulder holster and wore a bushy walrus-style moustache. In pleading guilty to providing false information to police, Asbell told Superior Court Judge Samuel Lenox that he sought counseling and now knows why he concocted the story. He did not elaborate. After court, he refused comment. Asbell in January had claimed at a news conference that he narrowly escaped death at the hands of two drug dealers who chased him through the streets of Camden on New Year's Day and shot out the windows of his car. He claimed he returned fire with a sawed-off shotgun and saw one assailant's head ``explode.'' A state investigation failed to find a body or any witnesses to the chase. Asbell resigned and checked into a psychiatric hospital on Jan. 4 after he was confronted with details of the probe. Investigators said Asbell shot out the windows of his own car to back up his story. Roosevelt Nesmith, vice president of the New Jersey chapter of the NAACP, charged that the plea bargain suggests ``selective prosecution and a double-standard.'' Asbell had said his assailants were black. ``Did he apologize to the black community?'' Nesmith said. ``It shows to me very little or no respect for the black community.'' The NAACP leader has called for the appointment of an independent prosecutor to review Camden County criminal cases overseen by Asbell.

DOC.HEAD: American Newspaper Publishers Association Elects Officers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 3rd in 2nd graf is cq per preference.
DOC.TEXT: Lloyd G. Schermer, chairman and chief executive officer of Lee Enterprises Inc. of Davenport, Iowa, has been elected chairman of the American Newspaper Publishers Association for a one-year term. Schermer succeeds William H. Cowles 3rd, president and publisher of the Spokesman-Review of Spokane, Wash., and the Spokane Chronicle. The election of officers and directors came Tuesday during the 104th ANPA annual convention. Other officers elected to one year terms were: Vice Chairman Robert F. Erburu, chairman and chief executive officer of the Times Mirror Co., Los Angeles; Secretary Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Hearst Corp., New York; Treasurer Donald E. Newhouse, president, The Star-Ledger, Newark, N.J. Directors re-elected to two-year terms were: Frank Batten, chairman, Landmark Communications Inc., Norfolk, Va.; Frank A. Blethen, publisher and chief executive officer, The Seattle Times; Charles T. Brumback, president and chief operating officer, the Tribune Co., Chicago; John J. Curley, chairman, president and chief executive officer, the Gannett Co. Inc., Arlington, Va.; Sandra C. Hardy, vice president, Calkins Newspapers, Levittown, Pa.; Joe Hladky, president and publisher, the Gazette Co., Cedar Rapids, Iowa; Uzal H. Martz Jr., president and publisher, the Pottsville (Pa.) Republican; John G. Montgomery, president and publisher, Montgomery Publications Inc., Junction City, Kan.; James M. Moroney Jr., chairman of the executive committee, A.H. Belo Corp., Dallas. New directors elected for two-year terms were: James K. Batten, chairman and chief executive officer, Knight-Ridder Inc., Miami; Michael W. Johnston, president and chief executive officer, Thomson Newspapers Corp., Toronto; William S. Morris III, chairman and chief executive officer, Morris Communications Corp., Augusta, Ga.; Judith Roales, president and chief operating officer, Independent Newspapers Inc., Dover, Del. Directors whose terms do not expire this year are: Antonio Luis Ferre, president and publisher, El Nuevo Dia Inc., San Juan, Puerto Rico; Charles S. Rowe, editor and co-publisher, The Free Lance-Star, Fredericksburg, Va.; William O. Taylor, publisher, The Boston Globe; Richard J. Warren, president, the Bangor (Maine) Daily News. Immediate past-president Cowles continues on the ANPA board for another year.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Finds `Slight Indiactions' of Track Movement
DOC.TEXT: Investigators said they found evidence a portion of track shifted before an Amtrak train derailed, injuring 95 people. Susan Coughlin, vice chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, and Dave Watson, investigator in charge for the NTSB, said Tuesday there were ``very slight indications'' of movement where the train left the tracks Monday. ``There's ballast underneath that track, and anytime that ballast could shift or the soil could become wet,'' Ms. Coughlin said. ``It's not a static situation out there.'' However, Ms. Coughlin said, ``We are not in a position at this point to interpret any of the findings.'' Amtrak's California Zephyr was headed to Chicago from the West Coast with 396 passengers and a crew of 24 when it derailed on track owned by the Burlington Northern Railroad. About a dozen people remained hospitalized Tuesday, three with what Ms. Coughlin said were serious injuries. An eight-member NTSB team is leading the investigation, which also involves about 40 officials from the Federal Railroad Administration, the state Transportation Department, Amtrak, the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Burlington Northern. The FBI also is investigating the possibility of sabotage, Ms. Coughlin said at a news conference Tuesday night. The 24-member crew was tested for drug and alcohol use and those results were expected in about two days, she said. She also said it appeared the Zephyr had not exceeded the 79 mph speed limit. In addition to checking the stability of the track today, investigators planned to concentrate on a switching device in Batavia and a 1,240-foot stretch of track from where the train passed a grade crossing to where it derailed, she said. Ms. Coughlin said a fireman who was a qualified engineer was at the controls as the train crossed a grade crossing just south of town. ``Approximately 1,500 feet later, the fireman who was operating as the engineer felt the train drag. Up to that point, they detected nothing abnormal in the performance of the train,'' Ms. Coughlin said. ``He looked back and saw that the rear cars were swaying. He put his train then into an emergency braking.'' Ms. Coughlin declined to say whether braking was the correct procedure. Behind the investigators, crews went to work on the twisted rail and gouged right-of-way in this town of 525 people, situated 90 miles southeast of Des Moines. The double-track route was not expected to reopen until late today.

DOC.HEAD: Twenty-Four More Die in Tropical Storms
DOC.TEXT: A series of tropical storms that raged across Bangladesh killed at least 24 people and tore apart about 10,000 mud and straw houses with high winds, heavy rain and hailstones, newspapers said today. Tuesday night's storms injured about 2,000 people and brought the season's death toll from storms to at least 250, the papers said. At lest nine people were killed and 500 injured in the latest storm at Sirajganj, 65 miles northwest of Dhaka, the independent Bengali-language Ittefaq reported. It was the second time in five days that Sirajganj was raked by storms. At least 34 people were killed in storms there on Friday. Nine more people drowned in the Surma River near Sylhet, about 120 miles northeast of Dhaka, when their boat sank during a storm, Ittefaq said. Six people were killed and 1,500 injured in Brahmanbaria, 50 miles east of Dhaka, the government-owned newspaper Dainik Bangla said. The summer storms, which began a month ago, are part of the cycle of natural disasters that batter Bangladesh around the year. Floods, tornadoes and hurricanes kill hundreds and often thousands of people every year in this country that ranks among the poorest on earth. Bangladesh's 110 million people have an average per capita income of $160 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``With the (Hubble Space Telescope) you could see a firefly in Australia from Washington.'' _ Edward Weiler, chief NASA scientist on the Hubble project.

``I expect in this job I'll make plenty of mistakes, but I don't want to make the wrong mistakes.'' _ President Bush, paraphrasing Yogi Berra on his decision not to slap economic penalties on the Soviet Union in response to its crackdown in Lithuania.

``Fortune favored husband with a jackpot, but, because his marriage had not ended, fortune dealt his wife a share.'' Judge Noel Fidel, upholding a judge's ruling cutting Bonita Lynch in for $550,000 of her ex-husband's lottery winnings.

DOC.HEAD: Aylwin Names Panel to Investigate Rights Abuses Under Pinochet
With PM-Chile-Letelier
DOC.TEXT: President Patricio Aylwin has appointed a panel to investigate human rights abuses during the rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who has issued warnings about trying to punish the military for any violations. Observers believe the group's work could lead to a number of rights trials, many involving military officers. That would set the stage for a potentially risky situation for the newly elected civilian government, however. The 74-year-old general stepped down as president last month but remains commander-in-chief of the powerful 60,000-men army, sheltered by a constitutional clause that prevents Aylwin from firing him. There was no immediate comment from Pinochet on Aylwin's announcement, although he has warned in the past that he would now allow any of his men to be touched. Aylwin announced the establishment of the Commission for Truth and Reconciliation in a nationwide radio and TV speech Tuesday night. The group's investigation will also cover cases of terrorism against the Pinochet government, which seized power in a September 1973 coup that ousted the elected Marxist government of Salvador Allende, who died in the uprising. The commission will issue its findings in a report in six to nine months and will be able to recommend ``moral and material'' compensation for victims of abuse. Rights violations constitute ``a wound still open in the national soul that cannot be heeled by trying to forget,'' said Alywin, 71, who took office on March 11. ``Closing the eyes in the face of what has happened, would mean to maintain a permanent source of pain, division, hatred and violence in our society.'' The commission includes three prominent right-wing lawyers who supported Pinochet _ Ricardo Martin, Jose Luis Cea and Gonzalo Vial, a former Pinochet cabinet minister. The other members are considered Aylwin supporters, including Pablo Zalaquet, a former president of Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group; Raul Rettig, a former president of the Chilean Bar Association; and Jaime Castillo, president of the independent Chilean Human Rights Commission. Two women, attorney Laura Novoa, and Monica Jimenez, a social worker, were also included. The commission's secretary is Jorge Correa, a law professor. The commission also will investigate alleged human rights abuses that occurred abroad, which will allow it to look into the 1976 car-bomb assasination in Washington of former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier. After the 1973 coup, the military launched a severe repression of supporters of the ousted leftist government. Thousands were arrested, many were tortured or killed. Hundreds were forced into forced exile abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Black Man Testifies He Carried Bats to White Friends in Racial Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Trial resumes 10 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: A black man testified he helped supply baseball bats to a group of white neighbors just before a black teen-ager was attacked and shot to death in what prosecutors allege was a racial slaying. Joseph Russell Gibbons, 21, said Tuesday at the murder trial of two white men that he and others were carrying bats ``to defend ourselves ... from the 25 guys who were supposed to come'' to their Brooklyn neighborhood that night. Gibbons said he did not see the shooting, but shortly afterward, a white youth came up to him and said, ``Joe Fama just shot a black kid around the corner.'' Joseph Fama, the accused triggerman, and Keith Mondello, the alleged ringleader of the white mob, are on trial, charged with murder in the slaying of Yusuf Hawkins, a black 16-year-old. Hawkins and three of his friends, all black, were set upon by a bat-wielding white mob on the night of Aug. 23 after traveling to Bensonhurst to look at a used car, prosecutors said. Hawkins was shot in the chest, allegedly by Fama, 19. The slaying raised racial tensions to a fever pitch in the city during its mayoral campaign. The trial was scheduled to resume today. In other testimony Tuesday, Luther Sylvester, one of Hawkins' friends, said he and his friends were walking down the street when ``some white boys ran around the corner and surrounded us. ... They were shaking their bats saying, `Is this them? Is this them?''' Within seconds, the high school senior said, he heard gunshots and saw Hawkins on the ground, blood flowing from his chest. The whites fled, he said. Sylvester, who was not hurt, said he saw no gun and could not identify any members of the gang. Gibbons, who has lived most of his life in the mainly white, Italian-American neighborhood, told the jurors that on the night of the attack, Mondello, 19, had come to him for help. Prosecutors say a young woman, Gina Feliciano, had threatened to bring 25 or more of her black and Hispanic friends to her home to celebrate her 18th birthday. ``Keith asked me if I would be there to defend himself because Gina said she had 20 to 25 black and Puerto Rican friends coming down to trash the store and beat him up,'' Gibbons said. Gibbons said that as the whites assembled in a schoolyard and outside a candy store, his best friend, 22-year-old Charles Stressler, asked him to help carry a box of bats from Stressler's home. He testified he carried the box and put it down outside the candy store. ``I didn't see who exactly had the bats,'' he said, but testified that about 30 whites had assembled and about half were wielding bats. Six other whites charged in the attack are to be tried later.

DOC.HEAD: Hyundai Shipyard Workers Strike
DOC.TEXT: Labor unrest mounted today as thousands of workers at the country's largest shipyard went on strike and protests continued to plague a major automaker and the state-run broadcast network.
