About 20,000 union workers at Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. in the southern city of Ulsan walked off their jobs, demanding the release of four union leaders jailed for organizing labor protests earlier this year. Kia Motors Co., the nation's third-largest automaker, was crippled today when 7,000 workers who staged a one-day walkout at its plant just outside Seoul, demanding they be paid for time spent on union activity. The Kia union said the company was trying to suppress labor and that the union would decide later whether to call a general strike. Kia, partly owned by the Ford Motor Co. and Mazda Motors of Japan, produces about 1,500 cars a day. Also today, a workers' protest against the state-run Korean Broadcasting System entered its second week with 5,000 of the network's 7,000 employees demanding the resignation of the system's government-appointed president, Suh Ki-won. The workers say Suh is opposed to reform and stands in the way of greater press freedom. About 3,000 broadcast workers staged a peaceful six-mile march through Seoul this afternoon. Officials of the Hyundai shipyard at Ulsan, 200 miles southeast of Seoul, called the strike illegal and said they were considering a lock-out. News reports said about 3,000 police were deployed at the shipyard a few hours after Hyundai workers began the strike. The shipyard, a subsidiary of the giant Hyundai, is the nation's largest with 24,000 employees. A union leader said by telephone that ``virtually all'' of the union's 20,000 members were taking part in the strike. ``We have no other choice, after last-minute labor-management negotiations broke down,'' said the union official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A Hyundai spokesman in Seoul said the company would try to reopen dialogue with the workers to avert a ``catastrophic development.'' Last year, thousands of riot police, supported by helicopters firing tear gas, stormed the shipyard to end a bitter three-month strike. Today's strike followed two days of work slowdowns by union members demanding the release of four union leaders in jail for involvement in what the company called illegal labor activity. Hyundai said the slowdown cost it $10 million in lost production. The comany said the strike was illegal because it did not go through required legal steps, including a cooling-off period following the breakdown of negotiations. Union leaders said the complexity of labor laws makes it virtually impossible for them to stage a lawful strike. The union was scheduled to begin wage negotiations with the company on Thursday but workers said the release of the jailed union leaders, not wages, was the subject of the dispute. At a rally today, Hyundai workers criticized what they called ``dual government standards'' in handling labor problems. They said the government has treated industrial labor protests differently than the protest at the state-run Korean Broadcasting System network. The Hyundai workers claimed the government was unfair when it kept in jail four of their union leaders while releasing 117 broadcast workers a day after they were arrested for involvement in their labor dispute.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS-Infected Drug Abusers Still Selling Blood, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a quarter of drug abusers contacted in a study said they sold blood plasma to collection centers, raising questions about whether the nation's blood supply is adequately protected against the AIDS virus. ``The continued donation of plasma, and occasionally blood, by intravenous drug users ... is troubling and warrants further attention,'' said the study by researchers at the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health in Baltimore. They study was published in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. The AIDS virus is believed to be spread mainly through sexual intercourse, shared needles and from infected mothers to their babies. A spokesman for plasma collection centers says they are doing a good job of excluding infected drug users and keeping the AIDS virus out of blood products. These products include clotting factor used by hemophiliacs and immune globulin taken by people who need protection against hepatitis. ``The current products that are out there are considered to be 100 percent safe,'' said James Reilly, spokesman for the American Blood Resources Association, the trade group representing the approximately 400 U.S. for-profit plasma-collection centers. ``There are no known cases of (AIDS) transmission from products currently on the market,'' he said in a telephone interview from Annapolis, Md. The study found that more than 23 percent of 2,921 intravenous drug abusers contacted in the Baltimore area in 1988 and 1989 said they had sold plasma or donated blood after they began injecting drugs. Tests revealed 24.1 percent of those contacted were infected with the AIDS virus, researchers said. The Centers for Disease Control says 126,127 adult AIDS cases had been reported as of March 31, including 26,883 cases among intravenous drug users and 8,711 cases among homosexual intravenous drug users. Transfusion associated AIDS cases total 3,040. Since March 1985, all U.S. blood and blood components have been screened to detect AIDS antibodies, which indicate the presence of the virus, the researchers noted. In addition, plasma from commercial centers is subjected to processing designed to kill the AIDS virus, although in isolated cases in other countries the virus has survived in treated plasma products, said Dr. Kenrad E. Nelson, lead researcher. ``This does not mean the blood supply is unsafe,'' Nelson said in a telephone interview. ``But the fact is that there have been cases where hemophiliacs have gotten infected despite screening and heat treatment. I think donor exclusion is vital.'' Efforts so far have paid off, the study found; the prevalence of AIDS infections among blood or plasma donors fell from 17.1 percent in 1985 to 3.6 percent in 1988-89. Most of the subjects said they were paid $10 to $15 for giving plasma, and about 10 percent said they had donated blood at non-profit blood banks. Plasma centers are typically storefront operations that pay people for giving plasma in a two-hour process that separates the liquid part of the blood from the cells and returns the cells to the body. Nelson said commercial plasma centers should consider no longer paying donors in order to further protect the U.S. blood supply. The approximately 2,400 U.S. non-profit blood banks, including those run by the American Red Cross, primarily draw whole blood and rely entirely on unpaid donors.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in calm trading today with traders focusing attention on the West German mark. Gold prices fell. Dealers said the market was dominated by worries about the potential inflationary consequences of West Germany's monetary union with East Germany, slated to go into effect July 2. The concern is pulling the mark down against the Swiss franc and the yen, but is having little impact on dollar-mark trading, they said. One dealer at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt said he expected the dollar to move higher in the medium term, boosted by relatively positive U.S. economic data in recent weeks and deep-seated worries about German monetary union. ``If the GNP figures are good, perhaps that could finally give the market the impetus to push the dollar higher,'' he said. Dealers said gold is trading at late Tuesday's U.S. levels. But they said there could be some spark in the market later in the day or in European dealings Thursday. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.10 yen to a closing 159.25 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 159.15 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6948 West German marks, up from 1.6930 _1.4825 Swiss francs, down from 1.4865 _5.6835 French francs, up from 5.6795 _1.9070 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9100 _1,242.50 Italian lire, up from 1,241.00 _1.1600 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1590 In London, the dollar was unchanged from late Tuesday. It cost $1.6345 to buy one British pound. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $375.25 a troy ounce, down from $378.25 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $374.80. In Zurich, the bid price was $375.25, down from $377.50 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.02 to close at a bid $375.95. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.03 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $5.10.

DOC.HEAD: Subdivision Gets Water for First Time
DOC.TEXT: It's only a single faucet by the side of a dirt road, but it's more than the residents of the Sunny Sky subdivision have ever had in their poor neighborhood. Drinking water flowed for the first time Tuesday to more than 40 residents of the ``colonia.'' The border region is dotted with similar communities of plywood homes and trailers without water or sewage connections. After lawyers used the state consumer protection act to go after the developer, residents gathered Tuesday at the spigot to celebrate. They said they hope one day to have water lines all the way to their houses. ``This is very good, because the children have to be clean to go to school,'' said Eulalio Hernandez, a father of six. Socorro de la Rosa, who has three children, smiled as she watched the water flow into a plastic bucket. ``Let's bathe,'' Ms. de la Rosa said as she carried a neighbor's laughing 5-year-old and washed his face in the water. She said she had worried about people washing with irrigation water from the polluted Rio Grande that flows from pipes near the homes at Sunny Sky. Previously, residents of Sunny Sky had to travel about a mile to gather barrels and buckets of water at another colonia that has potable water. They will continue to use outhouses in their back yards. The water hookup is the work of Al Alvarez, an assistant state attorney general. Alvarez used the state Deceptive Trade Practices Consumer Protection Act to get a court order that directed residents' mortgage payments to his office instead of to the developer. The money went toward water service. The developer ``was telling people there would be water hook-up and soon there would be sewer service,'' Alvarez said. ``He never intended to do that. He knew from the very beginning that this would be an illegal subdivision.'' The developer never plotted his subdivision or registered it with Cameron County, as required, Alvarez said. The developer, Pete Gonzalez Jr. of Brownsville, said he couldn't get a water permit because of local opposition to his low-income subdivision. He also said the plans he tried to submit were rejected. ``I on my own requested water service, but they were never promised water,'' said Gonzalez, who started the development in 1980. ``All I'm concerned about is the people there. I'm a very caring person. The allegations they made about me are not correct.'' The state collected $3,170 in mortgage payments from August until October, when Gonzalez declared bankruptcy, tying up subsequent payments in bankruptcy court. The $3,170 was used to buy a water line to connect with El Jardin Water Supply Corp. A local Knights of Columbus group donated the final $694 the residents needed to purchase the meter and final length of pipe. Alvarez said the consumer protection act has been used about 20 times to stop colonia developers. ``This type of thing makes us feel good about our work,'' said Vicky Guerra, an investigator with Alvarez's office as she visited Sunny Sky.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls in Northwest, Fair Weather Over Much of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell over parts of the Northwest today, while fair weather prevailed across much of the rest of the nation. Today's forecast calls for rain over the Upper and Lower Rockies, from Colorado into Montana and North Dakota, and scattered storms in Texas and the Midwest. On Tuesday, storms rumbled through Louisiana, Illinois, Upper Michigan, parts of the Upper Mississippi Valley, eastern Texas and Oklahoma. Showers and storms developed along a cold front extending from Minnesota to Colorado. Rain also fell over the northern Plains and the southern Rockies. Storms over the Texas Panhandle spawned a tornado and produced golf ball- size hail south of the town of McLean. Forecasters said more severe weather was likely today in Oklahoma after a tornado caused extensive property damage in Shattuck. Fair skies prevailed from the Southeastern states into the Ohio Valley and the mid-Atlantic coast. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 94 at Presidio, Texas. DOC.HEAD: State-backed Gunmaker Under Fire for New Semiautomatic Rifle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 3rd graf, `It also ...' to UPDATE with state House voting to require permits for assault weapons, including Sporter. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Colt Industries ...'
DOC.TEXT: A year after Colt Firearms drew praise for pulling its AR-15 semiautomatic rifle off the civilian market, it is under fire for producing a new version that critics say is virtually the same weapon. The furor over the gun, called the Sporter and produced by the newly created Colt's Manufacturing Co., has renewed debate over the Bush administration's policy on assault weapons. It also has become a political issue for state officials in Connecticut, which put up $25 million in state pension funds earlier this year to help buy Colt Industries' firearms division and end a bitter four-year strike. The state now owns 47 percent of the new company. Late Tuesday in Hartford, the state House voted 96-49 to approve a bill requiring permits for assault weapons, including the Sporter rifle. The bill imposes a 10-year mandatory prison term on anyone convicted of using assault weapons in carrying out a violent crime. Supporters of the bill say they're optimistic that it will be passed by the state Senate, but opponents pledged to bring intense pressure on the upper chamber. ``This is feel-good legislation,'' said Susan Misiora, a lobbyist for the National Rifle Association. ``It isn't going to do anything.'' Rep. Robert Godfrey, one of the bill's chief backers, said chances of getting the bill through the Senate were ``pretty good.'' Other supporters said it was a first step in getting assault weapons, often the gun of choice for drug traffickers, off the streets. ``The Colt Sporter rifle is no different from the AR-15 and it should be on the list,'' said Rep. Christopher Burnham. Colt Industries voluntarily stopped producing for the AR-15, a version of the military M-16 assault rifle, for the civilian market in March 1989, a day after the Bush administration halted imports of similar weapons. At the time, Bush administration drug czar William J. Bennett called Colt's decision ``an act of civic responsibility.'' Last week, the new management of Colt's started shipping the Sporter, a modified version of the AR-15 that the company says is designed for sportsmen and is not an assault rifle. There was no immediate comment from Richard Gamble, president of Colt's Manufacturing; he did not return a telephone call Tuesday afternoon. In interviews last week, he maintained that the new gun differs substantially from the AR-15. But Handgun Control Inc., a Washington-based group, charged that the Sporter is simply a cosmetically altered AR-15. ``It is clear that Colt is trying to bamboozle the public with its claim of producing a `new' gun,'' Handgun Control leader Sarah Brady said last week. ``There is no doubt that this gun is an assault weapon,'' said the wife of James Brady, who was wounded in the assassination attempt on President Reagan. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, agreed with the gun control group. He said the appearance of the new gun on the market highlights the need for a ban on domestic assault-style weapons. In a letter last week, Brady urged Gov. William A. O'Neill to force Colt to stop production of the gun. The characterization of Sporter as an assault weapon is particularly troubling for O'Neill and state Treasurer Francisco L. Borges, supporters of a domestic ban on assault weapons. ``The Colt management has represented to me that the Sporter is not an assault weapon,'' Borges said. ``I am currently taking every step to ascertain the facts.'' At the core of the debate between Colt's and the gun-control advocates is defining an assault rifle. When the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms permanently banned imports of 43 types of weapons last July, it defined the weapons as ``semiautomatic assault rifles.'' The features that lead to such a designation include a folding stock, a night sight, a flash suppressor that could hide a shooter's location at night and prevent the shooter from being temporarily blinded by the flash, an ability to accept a bayonet, a pistol grip and a large magazine capacity. The Sporter cannot be fitted with a bayonet, cannot easily be altered to fire repeatedly as an automatic weapon, and comes with only a five-round magazine, one-fourth the capacity of the AR-15's. Susan Whitmore of Handgun Control said that while the Sporter is sold with only five-round magazines, it can easily accept larger ones and, like all semiautomatic rifles, can be fired as rapidly as a shooter can squeeze the trigger. Handgun Control also points to a pistol grip that allows the Sporter to be fired from the hip. David Conover, a lobbyist for the NRA, said the AR-15 and the Sporter are essentially the same gun, but the NRA doesn't consider either of them assault weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Closes Investigation of DC Delegate Fauntroy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Updates and expands throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department investigation of payroll practices in the office of Walter E. Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's delegate to Congress, is closed, with the government declining to prosecute. Fauntroy, who is running for mayor, issued a statement Tuesday saying he was pleased that ``this will no longer have to divert attention from the real issues _ like drug, crime and housing _ that are facing our city.'' Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said Fauntroy's lawyers were told of the decision Monday by the public integrity section of the department's Criminal Division. The investigation was begun 15 months ago after a report by The Associated Press that Thomas John Savage, son of Rep. Gus Savage, D-Ill., had been on Fauntroy's Washington office payroll while running for the Illinois legislature. Fauntroy said Savage had taken unpaid leave while campaigning and denied any wrongdoing. Asked whether the decision not to prosecute applied to any inquiry into actions by the younger Savage, Runkel said, ``Today's action applies only to Delegate Fauntroy.'' He would not elaborate. Fauntroy and Runkel declined to answer further questions about Savage's employment. ``The congressman will answer no questions today,'' said campaign press secretary Ivan Brandon. ``We just want to get out the good news.'' After the allegations became public, Fauntroy said Savage had worked as Midwest coordinator for legislation to grant statehood to the District, which Fauntroy represents as a non-voting delegate to Congress. Savage, however, said he made few calls and didn't write any statehood material. He said his time was spent sending out statehood material and ``working around'' Capitol Hill. Savage said he had reported for work every day he drew a salary. He earned $21,398 for the period from September 1987 to June 1988. In an interview with The Washington Post in March, Fauntroy's attorney, Abbe D. Lowell, said that Fauntroy ``cannot attest that Thomas Savage was at his desk every day he should have been, but he expects them (his employees) to be professional and do their jobs.'' Lowell said that no one had explained ``what it is that he (Fauntroy) has done wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel OKs Aid to Panama, Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 9 grafs new to include Leahy quotes; picks up 7th graf pvs, Final passage.
DOC.TEXT: An emergency aid package for Panama and Nicaragua will pass the Senate easily and President Bush will be able to sign it soon, a Democratic senator predicted today. The Appropriations Committee gave the president's drive for emergency aid to the two countries a boost late Tuesday by approving a $720 million economic recovery package. On a 15-14 vote, the committee spurned a request by its chairman, Sen. Robert C. Byrd, to cut the aid to Panama and use the extra money for a program to help U.S. businesses compete in the new markets of Eastern Europe. Byrd, D-W.Va., had teamed with Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., in seeking to provide just $300 million to Panama this year and a like amount to Nicaragua. Bush had asked for $500 million for Panama. The committee rejected Byrd's proposal and adopted instead an amendment by Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., boosting the Panama figure to $420 million, the same amount endorsed by the House on April 3. ``I predict that (the aid package) will pass the Senate easily and the president will be able to sign it into law in a short time,'' Leahy said today on NBC's ``Today'' program. The package, swelled to about $3.4 billion by the addition of money for a long list of domestic programs, was expected to come up for debate in the full Senate today. Leahy said the aid to Nicaragua probably would be the first installment in a lengthy program to rebuild that nation's economy. ``We are going to have to be committed to Nicaragua for as many years as we were committed to destroying it with the Contra policy ... I suspect that eventually the United States is going to end up spending billions of dollars in this tiny country,'' he said. Final passage was being delayed until Thursday because some senators were traveling to Nicaragua for the inauguration of the new U.S.-backed president, Violeta Chamorro. The bill is nearly $1 billion more expensive than the version the House approved. Like the House measure, most of the new spending would be financed through cuts in this year's Pentagon budget. Among Senate add-ons to the bill were $110 million for the Census Bureau to help complete the lagging 1990 population count; $165.8 million to increase Head Start rolls by an additional 60,000 disadvantaged children; $8 million to fight grasshoppers in the upper Midwest; $705 million for the food stamp program; and additional money for veterans' pensions and medical care. Another provision would set aside $10 million to build and staff a new U.S. embassy in Lithuania, should the administration decide to formally recognize the independence of the Baltic state. The measure also adds a provision that would allow the District of Columbia to use local funds to pay for abortions, language that brought two presidential vetoes last year. The Appropriations Committee claimed nearly $2.8 billion in savings from the military budget, the first application of a ``peace dividend'' from lessened East-West tensions. The savings included the effects of a freeze on hiring civilian personnel and cuts in military construction, weapons procurement and research. But the committee restored $238 million for construction of a new Army explosives plant in Louisiana, the home state of Democratic Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, a panel member. The money had been deleted in the House version of the bill.

DOC.HEAD: Cause Sought As Crews Clean Derailment Site
DOC.TEXT: Investigators examined a damaged section of railroad tracks as they sought the cause of a 29-car derailment that forced an evacuation and fouled an Allegheny River tributary. Buffalo & Pittsburgh Railroad Inc. and federal authorities on Tuesday investigated the wreck, which toppled and ruptured tank cars Sunday. Officials estimated 100,000 gallons of crude oil and 10,000 gallons of sodium hydroxide were spilled into Buffalo Creek, a popular fishing stream about 45 miles north of Pittsburgh. Much of the material burned off or was caught behind emergency dikes, but an undetermined amount reached the creek, authorities said. Damage to the track indicated the first derailed car may have jumped the tracks some time before the other 28 did, an official said. George Cochran, an investigator with the National Transportation Safety Board, told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette that gouges on the track bed and rails leading up to the crash site indicated the lead car, an open-topped hopper, may have crashed without the crew's realizing it. He refused to speculate on whether such a derailment could have caused the 28 other cars to derail. John Bell, the railroad's vice president and general manager, said company officials and investigators from the NTSB and the Federal Railroad Administration would compare notes today as they tried to determine a cause. ``We'll put all the factors together ... and come up with a determination,'' he said. ``In some derailments, there's a single factor that's responsible. ... Nothing like that has come forward yet.'' Results of drug and alcohol tests on the train's two-man crew were not yet available, Bell said. About 55,000 gallons of crude oil remained in four tank cars still at the scene Tuesday after workers finally extinguished the blaze. Authorities planned to allow the roughly 50 people still evacuated from the area to return to their homes after the fuel is removed from the site, possibly today. The state Fish Commission said the sodium hydroxide, a lyelike chemical used to clean drains, killed thousands of fish and that others caught in the creek may not be safe to eat. Environmental officials tried to assess the threat to drinking water supplies downstream. No sodium hydroxide had reached water plants Tuesday in the densely populated Allegheny River valley, said Betsy Mallison, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Resources. Most of the crude oil had burned off, she said. Authorities as far downstream as Pittsburgh were ordered to test river water, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Battles Rage Between Christian Forces
DOC.TEXT: Artillery battles raged today between Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and Samir Geagea's militia, setting pine forests ablaze as the 3-month-old struggle for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave flared anew. Police said at least two people were killed and 12 wounded. That raised the known casualty toll since the fighting began Jan. 30 to at least 896 killed and 2,411 wounded, most of them civilians. The fighting in east Beirut and other sectors of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north of the capital broke out shortly before daybreak. The exchanges subsided into intermittent mortar and machine gun clashes around 8.30 a.m., but fierce howitzer duels broke out again at midday. The escalation came one day after Geagea imposed a sea blockade on Aoun's makeshift port at Dbaye, north of Beirut, to prevent the general from shipping in ammunition for his artillery and heavy weapons. Dbaye is Aoun's only outlet to the Mediterreanean. All the other ports in the Christian enclave are held by Geagea's right-wing militia. Aoun's headquarters said the blockade by Geagea's gunboats was ``an act of piracy.'' Pillars of flames shot up from the wooded, smoke-shrouded mountain slopes of the Christian hinterland as radio stations broadcast an appeal from Maronite Catholic patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir for a cease-fire. The police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said several shells hit residential districts of Moslem west Beirut, which has not been involved in the Christian fighting. But no casualties were reported there. The Moslem-run Voice of the Nation radio station blamed the escalation on Aoun and noted that the fighting flared after reports that President Elias Hrawi's government will not pay civil servants in areas controlled by the maverick general. Beirut's independent An-Nahar daily said that Hrawi's Syrian-backed government will meet next week to adopt a decision to pay only ``government employees who declare their loyalty to the legal authority.'' Aoun does not recognize Hrawi as head of state. He has also rejected an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war between Christians and Moslems. Hrawi is supposed to implement the accord endorsed by Lebanon's Parliament in Taif, Saudi Arabia, in October. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are Maronite Catholics, the largest Christian sect which has dominated political life in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Civil servants in the Christian enclave have not received their monthly wages since the beginning of the year. The battles between Aoun and Geagea broke out one day before payday in January and Hrawi's government has not transferred funds from the central bank in west Beirut to cover salaries for civil servants in the enclave. Geagea has recognized Hrawi and called on his government to take over public utilities in areas controlled by his militia, which include the Christian hinterland in the Kesrouan and Byblos provinces as well as two isolated pockets in east Beirut. Aoun controls the southeast of the capital's Christian sector, the Metn mountains northeast of the city, and a 3-mile stretch of coast on the northern edge of Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: British Parliament Cuts Abortion Time Limit to 24 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Britain's House of Commons has cut the time limit on legal abortions from 28 weeks, one of the most liberal in the Western world, to 24. Pro-life groups had demanded the time limit be cut to 18 weeks. But the Commons, in a series of votes Tuesday, rejected calls to set the limit at 18 weeks, 20 weeks, 22 weeks or 26 weeks or to retain the 28-week limit. The lawmakers chose a 24-week limit by 409 votes to 152 in a free vote, meaning legislators could vote according to conscience rather than party lines. The new limit will be written into the Human Fertilization and Embryology Bill, which is expected to become law this year. The new limit applies in most routine cases. But in other votes, the Commons allowed exemptions. Abortions now will not be subject to any time limit if an abortion is needed to prevent grave permanent injury to the physical or mental health of the pregnant woman, or if substantial risk exists of the fetus developing into a baby with a serious handicap. On Monday, the House of Commons voted to write into the same bill a provision permitting continued research into human embryos up to 14 days after conception. The 28-week limit, one of the most liberal provisions in the Western world, has been in force since Britain first legalized abortion in 1967. Virginia Bottomley, a minister of state at the Department of Health, backed the abortion law change. She told the Commons: ``Some fetuses of less than 28 weeks gestation, which would at one time have stood little chance of surviving after birth, now have a greater chance of survival.'' Jo Richardson, the spokeswoman on women's affairs for the socialist opposition Labor Party, said the overwhelming majority of people in Britain, particularly women, wanted to leave the limit at 28 weeks. Legislator Ann Widdecombe, a member of the governing Conservative Party and a leading pro-life campaigner, cited the case of a 21-week-old aborted fetus that lived for three hours in a kidney dish, gasping for life at Carlisle General Hospital in northwest England, before dying. ``To any member of Parliament thinking of voting for a limit above the 21 weeks ... it would not have saved the Carlisle baby,'' she said. Conservative legislator Sir Bernard Braine, who supported an 18-week limit, said that since the legalization of abortion in 1967, up to 3 million children had been lost. ``The overwhelming majority ... would have been born fit and healthy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rightist Leader Warns African National Congress to Halt Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with scheduled return of ANC officials; Picks up 2nd graf, `The Citizen ...'
DOC.TEXT: A top right-wing leader says whites are arming themselves and will retaliate unless Nelson Mandela's African National Congress ends its armed resistance, a newspaper reported today. Also, two top ANC leaders, general secretary Alfred Nzo and National Executive Committee member Joe Slovo, were scheduled to return Friday to South Africa after decades in exile. They will be part of an 11-man ANC delegation that is to hold groundbreaking talks May 2-4 with the white-led government. The Citizen newspaper quoted Afrikaner Resistance Movement leader Eugene TerreBlanche as saying white South Africans will never accept a black government. He said the government is headed for collapse that will lead to massive unrest. ``We will not allow our people to be murdered. It looks to me as though the government is on the road to capitulation. We are not prepared to live under an ANC government, which will mean chaos,'' TerreBlanche was quoted as saying. President F.W. de Klerk has expressed concern about right-wing groups that are arming themselves to oppose power sharing with the nation's black majority. Terreblanche and other extremist leaders are forming ``commandos'' of armed followers to resist the end of white-minority rule. The minister of law and order, Adriaan Vlok, told Parliament on Tuesday that the government was concerned about rightists unleashing violence. He said some armed right-wing groups were randomly threatening blacks. ``We must take care that we do not allow organizations to be created that will lead to bloodshed,'' Vlok said. Vlok said police officers would not be allowed to join political parties or groups. Government officials are concerned that some members of the security forces support extreme right-wing groups. TerreBlanche said the ANC must abandon its armed struggle against apartheid and the white-minority government. Mandela has refused to end the armed struggle, even though the group's guerrilla activities have virtually ended. ``My message to ANC is that if it persists with its armed struggle, we will meet it head on,'' TerreBlanche was quoted as saying by The Citizen. TerreBlanche claimed his group was organizing armed white defense units in towns across South Africa. He said the armed groups were ready to step in and impose order if the police and the government lose control. TerreBlanche's movement is thought to number a few thousand activists. But government officials are concerned that heavily armed extreme right-wing groups could pose a serious threat to stability if they resort to violence. Several air force troopers were arrested in Pretoria last week on charges of helping an extremist white group steal dozens of assault weapons and pistols from a military installation. The rightists oppose de Klerk's plans to end white-minority rule and share political power with the black majority. Rightists claim whites are superior to blacks and the two groups cannot live together. De Klerk is to meet with Mandela and other ANC leaders on May 2 to try to clear the way for full-scale constitutional talks on ending white rule. In another development, police said today that two police officers and four protesters were injured in clashes in various parts of the country when officers used shotguns, tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse protesters. Police, who gave few details, said 48 protesters were arrested in various incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Students Occupy Princeton President's Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, `Talks between...', with 3 grafs to UPDATE with student saying another meeting set (for later this morning); spokeswoman saying students could be disciplined. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The students...'.
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-nine Princeton students occupied the university president's office today in a takeover aimed at forcing the school to offer more counseling for victims of sexual assault and harassment. The students invaded President Harold Shapiro's office shortly before 9 a.m. Tuesday. Shapiro left his Nassau Hall office shortly after the students entered. ``We don't know how long this is going to go on. We've stated our demands,'' protester Antonia Merzon said over a portable radio. Talks between the students and university officials were at a stalemate, but student spokesman Matthew Polly said another meeting was planned. Officials said they had no immediate plans to remove the students but that they could not bow to pressure and increase funding for a program in the middle of the school year. School spokeswoman Jacquelyn Savani said the students' names were recorded and the university planned to discipline them. If they end their occupation today, they probably will just get a warning, but they might be suspended if they continue, she said. The students are demanding two full-time counselors at a center for victims of sexual assault or harassment; currently there is one full-time and one part-time counselor. The students argue that from the 1987-88 to the 1988-89 school year, the number of students seeking counseling at the center increased from fewer than 50 to 208. ``Harassment and assault issues are not being taken seriously by the university,'' said a woman holed up in Shapiro's office. She was interviewed via a walkie talkie radio and refused to identify herself except to say that she is a sexual assault victim. ``I think it's both sad and very counterproductive. The university cannot respond and make decisions on this kind of basis,'' Princeton Vice President Thomas Wright said of the sit-in.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Renews Terrorism Charges Against Syria Despite Polhill Release
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 15th graf pvs, bgng, ``I think ... to UPDATE with comments today in Lebanon; picks up 16th graf, The Islamic...
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is ruling out any immediate warming of relations with Syria despite a courtesy call by President Bush and an official pat on the back for assisting in the liberation of U.S. hostage Robert Polhill. ``While Syria has taken certain positive steps since 1986 to combat terrorism, including its role in the release of Mr. Polhill, we continue to be very concerned about the presence in Syria and Syria-controlled areas of terrorist groups,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Tuesday. The groups include Ahmed Jabril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine _ General Command, suspected in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in December 1988 in which 270 people were killed; the Japanese Red Army and the Abu Nidal organization, Ms. Tutwiler said. The first has its headquarters in Damascus; the other two are in the Bekka Valley of Lebanon. ``Syria's current relations with these groups is an impediment to better U.S.-Syrian relations,'' the spokeswoman said. President Bush telephoned President Hafez Assad on Monday to express appreciation for Syria's participation in the release of Polhill on Sunday after 39 months in captivity. Evidently, that personal gesture was the extent of any U.S. move toward Damascus, although Ms. Tutwiler said economic sanctions imposed by the Reagan administration in 1986 were ``under continuing review.'' The sanctions include a ban on certain bank credits, a suspension of commercial flights between the two countries and a travel advisory cautioning Americans against going to the Middle Eastern country. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush told congressional leaders Tuesday that ``he believes Syria had more than a passing role in the hostage release.'' Meeting with the leaders in the Cabinet Room, mostly to discuss Lithuania, the president reiterated that ``goodwill begets goodwill,'' Fitzwater said. But he said Bush added, ``We cannot chip away at this problem on an incremental basis. We want the release of all hostages.'' The spokesman did not say what Syria had actually done to help Polhill. He also hedged on whether Iran helped as well, and ruled out restoring U.S. ties to Iran after a 10-year lapse unless the seven other captive Americans in Lebanon are freed. Fitzwater quoted Bush as saying he thought Iran understood ``our gratitude for any help they may have provided in the hostage release, but they also know that the process of normalization cannot occur until all hostages are released.'' Other U.S. officials told The Associated Press on Monday that Iran and Syria would remain on the State Department's list of countries that sponsor terrorism. In the course of Polhill's release, Syria informed the United States that its ally, Iran, also helped. No details were provided to support the claim. At the White House, spokesman Fitzwater was asked if there were any indications that another hostage would be released. ``I think the most honest answer at this point has to be no, although there are some encouraging rumblings,'' he replied. However, a Shiite Moslem leader in Lebanon today accused the United States of responding to the release Polhill with ill will and urged pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants to continue holding their captives. Hussein Musawi, who played a key role in Polhill's release Sunday, complained that a House of Representatives resolution Tuesday endorsing a united Jerusalem as Israel's capital complicated efforts to release another American hostage. ``The Moslems in Lebanon offered a rose only to get a stone thrown on them,'' Musawi told a group of visiting Western journalists. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which freed Polhill, is believed by the State Department to be holding two other Americans, Jesse Turner and Alann Steen. The Islamic Jihad, meanwhile, has Terry A. Anderson and Thomas M. Sutherland captive. The Revolutionary Justice Organization is holding Joseph J. Cicippio and Edward A. Tracy. All three groups are considered by the State Department to be within the Hezbollah umbrella, under Iranian influence and composed of militant Shiite Moslems. The seventh hostage, Frank H. Reed, is held by Arab Revolutionary Cells, a pro-Libyan group with ties also to Iran, a department official said. Two other American hostages were killed in captivity. William Buckley, held by the Islamic Jihad, was reported murdered in 1985, and Marine Lt. Col. William Higgins, who was kidnapped by the Organization of the Oppressed of the Earth, was reported hanged last year.

DOC.HEAD: Police Search for Gunmen In Slaying of Iranian Opposition Leader
DOC.TEXT: Police searched today for two gunmen who killed a leading opponent of Iran's Islamic government in a Geneva suburb, but there were concerns the suspects might have already fled the country. The rental car used by the assailants was found Tuesday evening at a parking lot near the Geneva airport, shortly after the departure of a direct Iran Air flight to Tehran, said Maurice Gehri, a police spokesman. Kazem Rajavi, 56, who publicized Iranian human rights violations, died instantly around noon Tuesday when his car was sprayed with gunfire in the Lake Geneva town of Coppet, seven miles east of Geneva, police said. Rajavi was driving to his home in the nearby town of Tannay when his car was blocked by another vehicle, and one of the two occupants opened fire with a 9mm bmachine gun, police said. Gehri said police found 12 shells at the site of the shooting. The car used by the assailants had been rented on Sunday by two men who showed foreign identity papers, Gehri said. He refused to specify what kind of identity papers the men had presented to the rental agency. A police source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the killing appeared to be politically motivated. He said that tracking down the suspects in such cases is particularly difficult. The source noted that Swiss police have not captured the gunmen who killed an Iranian air force defector three years ago in Geneva. Rajavi was the brother of Massoud Rajavi, leader of the leftist Mujahedeen Khalq resistance movement. The victim was the Mujahedeen Khalq's Geneva representative and served as a lobbyist to the Council of Europe in Strasbourg, France and Geneva-based international organizations. He often appealed to U.N. representatives to investigate Iran's rights situation and held several news conferences during a February-March session of the U.N. Human Rights Commission. During that session, he denounced as a ``whitewash'' a largely inconclusive report on the situation in Iran released by a special investigator, Reynaldo Galindo Pohl, appointed by the commission. Pohl's report listed the names of 700 people allegedly executed by Iran but also listed 39 people believed killed by the Mujahedeen. The report also cited evidence of torture and other violations along with government denials. In a statement issued from their headquarters in Baghdad, Iraq, the Mujahedeen Khalq charged that Rajavi's killing was ordered by Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. It further alleged that the attack was coordinated by Sirous Nasseri, the head of the Iranian Mission to the United Nations in Geneva. ``Nasseri and the terrorists accompanying him during the February session of the U.N. Human Rights Commission repeatedly threatened to assassinate Dr. Rajavi who was actively engaged ... in the disclosure of the shameful contents of Galindo Pohl's report,'' the statement said. Nasseri was not immediatedly available for comment. A mission aide who declined to give her name said he was not there. Rajavi broke with the Tehran government in 1980 after serving briefly as head of the Iranian Mission to the United Nations in Geneva. He had been an opponent of Iran's deposed Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi and lived in Switzerland with his French-born wife and three children for almost 20 years. He was granted political asylum in 1973. The Mujahedeen were first allied with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in the struggle to topple the late Shah. But in 1980-81, a year after Khomeini took power, he turned on the group and other leftist factions, killing and imprisoning tens of thousands of people. The Mujahedeen and their military wing, the National Liberation Army, receive training and support from Iraq. The group is estimated to have 20,000 fighters.

DOC.HEAD: Tibetan Monks Stage Protest Walkout, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Tibetan monks have walked out of their monasteries to protest a move by Chinese authorities to expel some of their pro-independence colleagues, a Tibet monitoring organization reported today. The London-based Tibet Information Network said about 200 monks at the Sera Monastery and ``a large number'' at the Drepung Monastery in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa staged the walkout last week after Chinese authorities expelled dozens of monks for advocating Tibetan independence. Efforts to reach the monasteries and offices in Lhasa to confirm the report were unsuccessful. Chinese telephone operators often do not connect calls to the remote Himalayan region. Lhasa remains under martial law imposed in March 1989 after nationalist riots, and no journalists have been allowed in recently. The Tibet Information Network said a witness in Lhasa, whom it did not identify, reported that the monks at the Sera Monastery posted a notice on their gate on April 19 announcing the walkout. The notice said Chinese authorities had expelled three monks from Sera on April 16 and otherwise interfered in monastery operations. It declared that Tibet was an independent country and the Chinese should leave. An unspecified number of monks at the nearby Drepung Monastery walked out on April 17 to protest the expulsion of 37 of their colleagues the day before, the network said. It quoted an unidentified witness as saying that only older monks too weak to travel stayed behind. The protesting monks are believed to have returned to their home villages. Chinese authorities also expelled 18 monks from the Ganden Monastery, outside Lhasa and seven from the Jokhang Temple, Lhasa's oldest and holiest religious site, the network said. It said it received unconfirmed reports that more than 150 nuns were expelled at about the same time from four nunneries around Lhasa. Buddhist nuns and monks have led repeated independence demonstrations in recent years and remain loyal to their top religious leader, the exiled Dalai Lama. From India, where he fled in 1959 after a failed Tibetan uprising, the Dalai Lama has criticized China's heavy-handed rule in Tibet and appealed for autonomy or independence. China insists that its sovereignty over Tibet dates back to the 13th century and refuses to accept any weakening of its control. However, there were long periods when Tibet had virtually no contact with China and was ruled by a theocracy headed by the Dalai Lama. In the 1950s and 1960s, the Communists destroyed most of Tibet's monasteries and banned religious worship. Only in the past decade have some temples and monasteries been reopened. Four times since late 1987, Tibetan independence protests have resulted in bloody clashes with security forces. Since the last protests culminated in riots March 5-8, 1989, Chinese authorities have stationed security forces in all the monasteries and begun intensive political education of monks and nuns.

DOC.HEAD: Unification Talks Begin in East Berlin
DOC.TEXT: Delegations from both Germanys today began talks on introducing the powerhouse West German mark into East Germany's faltering economy. The meeting follows an agreement by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East Germany's prime minister, Lothar de Maiziere, on a goal of completing monetaRbreak the breeding cycle. The last Medfly infestation in South Florida was in 1987, when five males were found. The state's last major outbreak affecting commercial groves spread across 28 counties in 1956. Environmentalists in California and here have objected to use of malathion, contending too little is known about the chemical's long-term health effects. ``The bad thing about using these kinds of chemicals is that they wipe out all of the insects in an area _ the good and the bad,'' said Lee Emerson, a member of the Sierra Club. ``It's not the kind of balanced, environmentally sensitive approach we should be taking these days.'' Joette Lorion, a Miami coordinator of Earth Day, said, ``If it's a danger to your car and they're asking you to wipe it off, it must be a danger to your body.'' The mixture of malathion and syrupy bait can damage car paint if not rinsed off quickly. Officials also said that people with health problems, such as asthma or allergies, may want to remain indoors during the spraying. But Conner said of malathion: ``It has not been determined anywhere to be a health risk.'' Medflies could strike a harsh blow to Florida's citrus industry, which was crippled by a Christmas freeze. Medfly larvae hatch inside more than 250 varieties of fruits and vegetables, turning them into mush. Bobby McKown, executive vice president of Florida Citrus Mutual in Lakeland, said Monday the 12,000-member growers' organization supports ``immediate action to control and eradicate the Medflies'' so they don't expand beyond residential areas. The pesticide to be sprayed per acre consists of 2.4 ounces of malathion mixed with sticky bait. Malathion is used in a stronger concentration of 3.1 ounces per acre throughout Florida for mosquito control.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Government's Secret Financing of Jewish Housing Criticized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 5, with other criticism; subs pvs graf 6, Israeli courts, with further background.
DOC.TEXT: The head of the leading pro-Israel lobby in Washington is critical of the Israeli government's secret financing of Jewish housing in the Christian sector of Jerusalem, according to sources. Through an emissary to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Thomas A. Dine, executive director of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), questioned the timing of the move into the Christian quarter of East Jerusalem. He told Shamir the Israeli government was ``doing great harm'' to Israel's standing with the Bush administration and the American public, sources familiar with the criticism told The Associated Press. Although American Jewish groups frequently disagree on a wide range of issues, it is unusual for AIPAC objections to Israeli government action to become known publicly. Another Jewish group, the Anti-Defamation League, also criticized the Israeli government. ``This official support given to Jewish settlers only serves to disrupt the status quo and gives ammunition to those wishing to upset the religious harmony in the Holy city,'' the ADL statement said. The State Department on Monday sharply criticized the Israeli government for financing the purchase of a sublease on a church-owned hospice to be rented to new Soviet Jewish immigrants. About 150 Jews two weeks ago moved on to the site. Israeli courts have ordered the Jews evicted, a decision the Bush administration welcomed. Removal of the settlers has been blocked by appeals. The Supreme Court has ruled that they can stay at least until the next court hearing Thursday. Dine called the move ``a provocation,'' said the sources, who provided information about Dine's statements only on condition that they not be identified. The assertion paralleled the State Department's description of the purchase as ``an insensitive and provocative action.'' The Israeli Housing Ministry, controlled by Shamir's hard-line Likud coalition, contributed about 40 percent of the $1.6 million purchase of the sublease on the property owned by the Greek Orthodox Church. The ministry for two weeks had denied financing the deal before admitting it. Congress has been considering guaranteeing a $400 million loan to help resettle Soviet Jews in Israel. The Bush administration has conditioned its support for the legislation, now before the Senate, on a condition that Israel not use the money to house Soviet Jews in the predominantly Arab sector of Jerusalem or on the West Bank and Gaza Strip, territories occupied in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said this week the assurances had not been received yet, but she noted the legislation was still pending and that Israel was in the midst of trying to form a new government. None of the $1.2 billion in annual U.S. economic aid to Israel is supposed to be used to help Jews living on the West Bank or in Gaza. The Bush administration takes the position their settling the area poses an obstacle to peace with the Arabs. President Bush last month called on Israel not to settle Soviet immigrants in East Jerusalem as well. The AIPAC lobby over the years has demonstrated great strength in Congress and forged winning coalitions among Democrats and Republicans to defeat several American arms sales to Arab countries confronting Israel.

DOC.HEAD: New Burst of Setttlement Activity in West Bank
DOC.TEXT: In a fresh burst of settlement activity, a crane hoisted seven mobile homes onto a rocky hilltop in the Judean Desert today, setting up the core of a new Jewish community in the occupied West Bank. The founding of Alon was the latest move in a campaign that has gained momentum since March when Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir took the reins of a caretaker government without the left-of-center Labor Party which opposes settlement building. Several settler leaders, including Rabbi Moshe Levinger and Pinchas Wallerstein, watched as bulldozers smoothed the rocky ground for the mobile homes. New residents of Alon, which overlooks the Jordan Valley 10 miles east of Jerusalem, raised wine glasses in a toast. ``In five years, there will be a big city here,'' said Eliyakim Haetzni, a parliament member for the pro-settlement Tehiya Party as he pointed to the surrounding, barren hills in a sweeping gesture. Haetzni criticized the U.S. government, which has opposed settlement building on territory captured from the Arab states, including east Jerusalem. President Bush has said such settlements impede efforts to arrange peace talks with Palestinians. ``There are many shades of anti-Semitism. Some are very civilized, such as calling settlements an obstacle to peace,'' Haetzni said. Moshe Waysman, leader of the Alon settlers, said 10 families and a few bachelors would move onto the state-owned land at Alon today, and that six more mobile homes would be added in the next few days. Waysman said the group had no political aspirations, even though it was being assisted by Amana, the settlement wing of the nationalistic Gush Emunim (Block of Faithful) settler movement. ``We want to live together in a pleasant environment, to have some land around our houses and to have a higher standard of living,'' said Waysman, who owns a food processing factory in Jerusalem and immigrated to Israel from Australia 19 years ago. Alon is not included in the coalition agreement of the collapsed Likud-Labor government, which called for eight new settlements to be built by 1992. Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said the construction did not violate the agreement because Alon was merely an expansion of the existing settlement of Kfar Adumim. ``This government has not adopted any new resolutions regarding settlements and only follows what was decided by the national unity government,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Crowd Square in Fourth Day of Anti-Communist Protest
DOC.TEXT: Anti-Communist demonstrators demanding the resignation of interim President Ion Iliescu thronged a central square today, and the government threatened to break up the protest. Nearly 1,000 people crowded University Square by early afternoon in a continuation of the round-the-clock protest that began Sunday. The protest was interrupted briefly early Tuesday, when riot police moved in. Anti-Iliescu protesters also gathered in several other Romanian cities, unconfirmed reports said, but details were not immediately available. Organizers of the Bucharest rally claim Iliescu, a former Communist Party official, continues to believe in Communism despite assertions to the contrary. The organizers say they do not belong to a political party. The Communist Party collapsed in the bloody December revolution that swept dictator Nicolae Ceausescu from power. Iliescu, who became a Ceausescu critic in recent years, helped form the National Salvation Front, which dominates the interim government. The vice president of the Front, Nicolae S. Dumitru, told a news conference today that the anti-Iliescu demonstration was a subversive, ``right-wing diversion.'' The government has tried ``to be patient,'' but it will order the demonstration broken up if it spreads, Dumitru said. On the square, groups of anti-Iliescu protesters said they feared that ballot-rigging would occur in elections planned for May 20. ``Parliament has managed things so that the Front will win the elections,'' said one woman heatedly. ``If the National Salvation Front gets hold of power, we have a disaster on our hands,'' argued a man who held sway over another small group of protesters. Critics of Iliescu say the Front is led by unrepentant Communists seeking to re-establish their party's rule. Also today, a human rights group said there was concern that Iliescu's National Salvation Front had an undue advantage over other political groups readying for the elections. The International Human Rights Law Group, a Washington-based rights monitoring organization, said people fear the Front, ``because of its pervasive relationship with the government, has greater access than other parties to money'' the media and factories. The statement, issued in Bucharest, noted ``widespread complaints'' that newspapers critical of the Front-dominated government were regularly deprived of newsprint and printing facilities, while state television was biased in favor of the government. The group also said they heard reports of violence and intimidation by Front supporters against the opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Damages Business District in Oklahoma Town
DOC.TEXT: A tornado damaged about 30 businesses in this western Oklahoma town, cut off electricity and choked streets with debris. ``It went right down Main Street at least half a mile or more,'' said Chris Lee, a cameraman for KOCO-TV in Oklahoma City. The tornado destroyed a cafe and a saddle shop late Tuesday, but it stayed out of residential areas, police dispatcher Don Jeffrey said. Three or four residents suffered minor injuries, he said. Power came on for the first time since the storm while Jeffrey was speaking to a reporter by telephone about 7:30 a.m. today. Firefighters had to clear debris from the front of the fire department before they could respond to storm calls Tuesday night. ``It took me 25 minutes this morning to drive five blocks, so that tells you how bad it is,'' Jeffrey said. Main Street was expected to remain blocked off today, he said. Ellis County sheriff's dispatcher Yulonda Taylor said that before hitting Shattuck the tornado knocked over utility poles as it crossed a highway about 14 miles southeast of Shattuck. The tornado reportedly stayed on the ground for about 30 miles. It developed from thunderstorms that erupted from the Texas Panhandle into western Kansas, the National Weather Service said. Hail as big as softballs and tornadoes were reported in the eastern Texas Panhandle. A tornado touched down near the Texas Panhandle town of Shamrock, about 70 miles southwest of Shattuck, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or serious damage.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Undergoing Eye Exam
DOC.TEXT: Two prominent eye doctors are examining President Bush at Bethesda Naval Hospital to confirm an earlier diagnosis that he has a mild form of glaucoma, the White House said today. Bush's eyes were being checked today by Drs. Richard Brubaker of the Mayo Clinic and Harry Quigley of Johns Hopkins Hospital, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush's own physicians determined during an annual checkup at Bethesda Naval Hospital on April 12 that he has an early stage glaucoma. Bush began daily medication at that time. Quigley and Brubaker are experts on glaucoma. Fitzwater read a statement from Dr. Burton Lee, the president's physician, saying: ``These experts in glaucoma will conduct a series of tests to confirm our earlier diagnosis and to reevaluate the choice of treatment. I wish to reemphasize that tere are no problems with the president's vision. His vision remains excellent. But I feel that it is prudent to have outside experts assess the treatment strategy.'' Fitzwater said the exam was expected to take 60 to 90 minutes. After the April 12 physical, Bush began putting drops of a medicine called Betagen every 12 hours. His doctors said Bush would need to take the medicine for the rest of his life. Glaucoma can lead to blindness if left untreated. Before the exam, Bush was also attending a 50th anniversary ceremony nearby for the Bethesda-Chevy Chase Rescue Squad. Brubaker is with the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. Quigley is with Johns Hopkins in Baltimore. The president's wife, Barbara, is also under treatment for problems that have interfered with her vision. She has Grave's Disease, which has caused persistent double-vision.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt, Jordan, PLO Condemn U.S. House Vote on Jerusalem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Jordan condemning vote. Pickup 13th pvs, `President Hosni...' Minor editing to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Egypt and Jordan said today that a resolution by the U.S. House of Representatives endorsing a united Jerusalem as Israel's capital complicates Middle East peace efforts. The Cairo representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization also condemned the non-binding resolution, which was overwhelmingly approved by the House on Tuesday by a vote of 378 to 34. In Beirut, Lebanon, a Shiite Moslem leader said the vote will hinder efforts to release another American hostage. Hussein Musawi, who some believe played a key role in Robert Polhill's release on Sunday, said he hoped no other hostage would be freed after ``such a monumental ill-intentioned American response.'' A statement by the Egyptian Foreign Ministry voiced ``extreme concern'' at the passage of the U.S. resolution, which differed with the Bush administration's official position that Jerusalem's status must be determined through negotiations among all parties. Israel annexed east Jerusalem after capturing it from Jordan in the 1967 war with the Arabs and declared the united city _ holy to Christians, Jews and Moslems _ as its ``eternal capital.'' The Arabs and most world nations, including the United States, do not recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital. ``Egypt affirms that adopting such resolutions, which lack a legal basis and ignore basic human rights, does not help in solving the present problems in the region but further complicates them,'' the ministry statement said. Egypt, the only Arab state having a peace treaty with Israel, said attempts to solve regional hostilities should take into account ``the interests and rights of the various parties.'' Jordan's foreign minister, Marwan Kassem, said the vote ``gives Israel the excuse and the legitimacy to continue its aggression against Arabs.'' The vote will harm the U.S. reputation ``as a peacemaker'' in the region, Kassem said in a statement in Amman, the Jordanian capital. The congressional vote came despite arguments by opponents that the resolution would cause resentment among the Arab states. The resolution was identical to one adpted March 22 by the Senate. President Hosni Mubarak today sent a letter to President Bush about recent Middle East developments ``including the situation in Jerusalem and the various views on it,'' the state Middle East News Agency said. Zohdi al-Kodra, the Cairo PLO representative, said Congress does ``not have the right to determine the status of Jerusalem, just as no country in the world has the right to dertermine the status of Washington or New York.'' In comments reported by the Middle East News Agency, al-Kodra said Jerusalem would always be the capital of a Palestinian state and that the Palestinian people would continue their struggle until they formed their state.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian President to Visit Moscow
DOC.TEXT: President Hafez Assad of Syria will visit Moscow at the end of the month, his first trip to the Soviet Union in three years, official Damascus Radio reported today. Assad's visit comes amid a significant shift in Moscow's relations with Syria, its closest Arab ally, and a reported cutback in aid. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms and efforts to establish better relations with the West have carried over to the Middle East. Moscow has been edging closer to Israel and is urging radical Arab states such as Syria to moderate their stand and support the Middle East peace process. The exact date of Assad's visit was not announced, and no other details on it were available. The announcement said that ``in response to an official invitation by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, President Assad will undertake a working visit to the U.S.S.R. at the end of April.'' The radio said the invitation was delivered to Assad by Soviet officials who visited Damascus, the Syrian capital, last month. The visit will be Assad's first to Moscow since April 1987. The Syrian announcement gave no hint about what will be on Assad's agenda in Moscow. But the Syrian leader, who has been in power since 1970, last month decried the reformist wave sweeping Eastern Europe as a boon to Israel and called for a holy war ``as long as time'' against the Jewish state. As the Eastern European countries adopt democratic reforms, they are improving their ties with Israel. He also denounced Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel, reflecting growing Arab fears that tens of thousands of Jews will settle in Israel in the next few years and set back the fragile Middle East peace process. Arab countries fear that many new arrivals will be settled in occupied territories, where the Palestine Liberation Organization wants to form its own state. The expected influx of Soviet Jews follows Moscow's relaxation of travel restrictions. Despite his criticism, Assad stressed in his March 8 speech marking the ruling Baath Socialist Party's 27th anniversary in power that ``the relationship between Syria and the Soviet Union is as firm as ever.'' However, the Soviets have been stressing to Assad that he abandon his drive for strategic parity with Israel and have reduced the volume of advanced weapons it had traditionally supplied Damascus. Western military analysts and diplomats say this cutback, for economic as well as political reasons, has forced the Syrians, who have severe economic problems of their own, to look elsewhere for military hardware.

DOC.HEAD: Musawi Objects To Second Hostage Release, Flays U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1 graf for 2nd pvs, `Hussein... and 1 for 28th, `Polhill, who...' to clarify that Musawi believed to have played role in Polhill's release and to UPDATE with Polhill leaving for home Thursday. Pickup 29th, `In addition...'
DOC.TEXT: A Shiite Moslem leader today accused the United States of responding to the release of an American hostage with ill will and urged pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants to continue holding their captives. Hussein Musawi, who is believed to have played a key role in Robert Polhill's release Sunday, complained that a U.S. House of Representatives resolution Tuesday endorsing a united Jerusalem as Israel's capital complicated efforts to release another American hostage. ``The Moslems in Lebanon offered a rose only to get a stone thrown on them,'' Musawi told a group of visiting Western journalists, including The Associated Press. He said the United States' intentions were demonstrated by the congressional resolution, which is non-binding. Musawi said the hostage-holders have been repeatedly urged to prove goodwill by freeing a captive. ``So they did and released Polhill,'' he said. ``But upon that release we heard the news of the House of Representatives resolution on Jerusalem. If every release will be matched by such a monumental ill-intentioned American response, why then should any hostage be freed?'' ``We hope that no other hostage will be released,'' said Musawi, reputed mentor of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, the group that held Polhill and continues to hold two other American educators. Sunday's release of Polhill after 39 months in captivity raised hopes that another Western hostage could be freed. Kidnappers are believed to be holding 17 Western hostages, including seven Americans. Asked about persistent reports that a second American hostage would be released during Eid al-Fitr, the three-day feast that begins Thursday to mark the end of Islam's holy fasting month of Ramadan, Musawi said: ``There is plenty of talk about such a move. I don't think Eid al-Fitr means anything to the Americans, and I don't think there's an atmosphere of such an early release.'' Musawi said the release of Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners held by Israel and its militia ally, the South Lebanon Army, was ``essential'' for any progress toward freeing the remaining Westerners. ``The release of the prisoners with Israel and its surrogates is a foremost issue and should be simultaneous with the release of the hostages,'' he said. Meanwhile, the leader of the South Lebanon Army canceled plans for a holiday prisoner release because of publicity linking such a move to Western hostages, sources said today. Antoine Lahad, a retired Lebanese army general who heads the 2,500-member force, refused to act on amnesty requests from the prisoners' families. He had allowed releases for the past two years to mark the end of the Ramadan holiday. His army holds 300 mostly Shiite Moslems in the al-Khiam jail just north of the Israel border. One source speaking on condition of anonymity said Lahad's decision was affected by publicity suggesting the release would be a concession to the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, which is believed to be linked to groups holding hostages in Lebanon. Israel radio quoted Lahad as saying the release was turned into an international affair for no reason. ``To my regret, there will be no releases this year because of the press and (President) Bush,'' he was quoted as saying by the radio. ``Releasing them now would be seen as an American payment to the Hezbollah through Israeli agents.'' The South Lebanon Army said Tuesday that four Lebanese had been freed after being investigated on suspicion of belonging to a terror group. Sources close to the army said the release took place last week and was unrelated to the holiday or the release of Polhill. South Lebanon Army sources had said earlier that they expected Lahad to free 10 or 11 prisoners for the holiday, and a report in London suggested more than 30 would be allowed to go home. Israel radio said Shiites in southern Lebanon were ``embittered'' by Lahad's decision. In Damascus, Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk Al-Sharaa received a letter Tuesday night from his Iranian counterpart, Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, the official Syrian News Agency reported today. Officials did not disclose the contents of Velayati's letter beyond saying it dealt with developments in Lebanon and the Middle East. Velayati said Monday that information from Lebanon indicated another Western hostage could be released within days. Iran has demanded goodwill gestures such as the release of Arab prisoners held by Israel and its militia ally as a way to encourage further hostage releases. Israel holds about 9,200 Palestinians in connection with the 28-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. Shiite militants also have demanded the release of 15 radicals imprisoned in Kuwait for bombing the U.S. and French embassies in Kuwait in 1983 before making ``another goodwill gesture,'' Beirut's independent An-Nahar daily said Tuesday. In Tehran, Iran's radical Parliament Speaker, Mehdi Karrubi, said today U.S. officials were more spiteful of the Islamic republic now than when Washington launched a failed military operation in April 1980 to free 52 U.S. hostages in Tehran. Polhill, 55, of New York; and fellow U.S. educators Jesse Turner of Boise, Idaho; and Alann Steen of Boston were abducted in Beirut on Jan. 24, 1987, by a group known as Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. Polhill, who was taken to Wiesbaden, West Germany, after his release, underwent more questioning today about his three years in captivity and about other Western hostages possibly held in the same building. He was expected to leave for the United States on Thursday. In addition to Turner and Steen, kidnappers in Lebanon are believed to be holding five other Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. The longest-held hostage is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Sharp-Tongued LBJ Flays FDR, JFK
DOC.TEXT: John F. Kennedy may have been fondly remembered as a president by many people, but to his successor, President Lyndon B. Johnson, he was ``a Joe College man'' who never had a clue as a congressman. In a vitriolic 1965 interview with historian William E. Leuchtenburg, LBJ also derided Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, ripped the credibility of The New York Times and The Washington Post, and claimed his administration was the most productive in U.S. history. Excerpts of the previously unpublished interview appear in the May-June issue of American Heritage magazine. Johnson, speaking of FDR's New Deal, compared the four-term president to ``the fellow who cut cordwood and sold it all at Christmas and then spent it all on fireworks. It all went up in a bang.'' ``He did get things done. There was regulation of business, but that was unimportant,'' said Johnson. He said Social Security and labor law changes amounted to something, but ``none of it compares to my education act.'' As to Kennedy _ his running mate just five years earlier _ LBJ asserted that ``no man knew less about Congress than John Kennedy.'' Kennedy was in the House of Representatives in 1947-53, but Johnson said his mentor, House Speaker Sam Rayburn, never knew Kennedy. ``The only way Rayburn thought of him at all was as a very young man who might be going to die of malaria. He was a Joe College man ... and Congress felt that he didn't know where the ball was,'' Johnson said. Kennedy contracted malaria during World War II. Leuchtenburg says he spent 90 minutes with LBJ, asking just two questions during the lengthy harangue, and emerged from the White House meeting stunned by the president's egomania. But he had agreed before the interview not to quote LBJ directly until the president's term was finished. And the historian says deputy press secretary E. Hayes Redmon told him 95 percent of the interview could not be used, ``especially about Kennedy.'' While Johnson was negative about Roosevelt's New Deal, he sang the praises of his own Great Society. When Leuchtenburg suggested the then-current Congress was arguably the most significant in history, LBJ quickly cut him off. ``No, it isn't. It's not arguable. Not if you can read,'' Johnson said. ``You can perform a great service if you say that never before have the three independent branches been so productive. Never has the American system worked so effectively in producing quality legislation.'' Johnson went on to attack the media, singling out the Times and the Post. ``When I came on as president, the Times said one thing sure to happen is that we would have a closer election in 1964. If the livelihood of The New York Times depended on its accuracy, they would be shot at sunrise,'' said Johnson. ``One day last week The Washington Post had eleven lies. They talk about well-informed sources. That just means what they want to say,'' said Johnson. ``Someday, we'll pass a law stopping them from using `well-informed.'''

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Explosion Kills Five Police Officers in Medellin
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded today near a truck carrying anti-terrorist policemen in the city of Medellin, killing five officers and wounding five, the Defense Ministry said. An unspecified number of civilians were killed or injured, and the roofs of several nearby buildings collapsed, the Caracol radio network reported. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack. However, the Medellin drug cartel, one of the nation's largest, has pledged to kill police officers as part of its terrorist campaign aimed at forcing the government to halt its efforts to crack down on the cocaine trade. The police officers belonged to a special anti-terrorist unit sent to Medellin to fight drug traffickers, a communique issued by the ministry said. The car bomb exploded as the truck was taking the officers to their posts in the city, 160 miles northwest of Bogota. It was the second major car bomb attack this month aimed at police in Medellin, a drug-trafficking center. Caracol said that several bodies could be seen lying in the street in the city's commercial district after the bomb exploded today. It said the dead included workers in a nearby shoe store. The explosion caused the roofs of the shoe store and several small factories in the area to collapse, a Caracol reporter on the scene said. He added that the blast destroyed several vehicles. On April 11, a car bomb containing nearly 500 pounds of dynamite exploded on a busy highway in the city, killing 20 people, including eight police officers from the anti-terrorist police unit. Police blamed the Medellin cartel and its leader, Pablo Escobar, for the explosion, but no claim of responsibility was received. After that blast, police sent 300 additional members of the anti-terrorist unit to join the search for Escobar and those responsible for the bomb attack.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Steen Denies Hearing From Polhill About Husband's Reported Escape Try
