DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Mrs. Steen denying discussing escape attempt; CORRECTS day Polhill was freed to Sunday sted Monday; CORRECTS where Mrs. Steen lives to Clark Lake sted Jackson, Mich.
DOC.TEXT: The wife of American hostage Alann Steen today denied a published report that freed hostage Robert Polhill had told her that her husband was beaten after a failed escape attempt in 1987. ``I have no idea where this is coming from,'' Virginia Rose Steen said in a telephone interview from her home in Clark Lake, Mich. She spoke after today's Boston Herald quoted her brother-in-law, Craig Steen, as saying that Polhill had discussed the reputed escape attempt with her. Craig Steen was quoted as saying that Mrs. Steen was told that her husband had escaped from his captors in 1987 and that he also was seriously ill for a time after his capture. ``When you're captured by an enemy, in a declared war anyway, one of your primary jobs is to try to escape,'' Steen said. ``Evidently, he saw an opportunity and went for it.'' Mrs. Steen said she talked to Polhill by telephone from Wiesbaden, West Germany, ``just a couple of minutes'' Monday, the day after he was freed by Moslem extremists after 39 months in captivity in Lebanon. They didn't get much chance to discuss specifics, she said. ``We did not talk about that, about the kidnapping stuff,'' she said. She said she and her husband had been good friends of Polhill and his wife since 1983. ``It was wonderful to find out (how good Polhill's) spirit is. He's a wonderful, brilliant man. ... He said Alann was OK when he left.'' Polhill, Steen and a third hostage, Jesse Turner, were colleagues at Beirut University College when there were kidnapped in January 1987. Mrs. Steen said Polhill had told her that the three had stayed together throughout their 39 months in captivity. Craig Steen did not immediately return a telephone call to his home in Orlando, Fla., seeking further comment. Newsweek reported in November 1988 that Steen had escaped but was recognized quickly in a Beirut suburb and recaptured. Reportedly he was beaten so badly after his recapture that fillings were knocked from his teeth. Newsweek attributed its story to anonymous sources. Mrs. Steen said she was aware of the Newsweek report. Craig Steen was quoted as saying that ``Virginia talked to Polhill himself, and she gave me some information, but he asked that the other things that he told her not be released until he is debriefed.'' He said the conversation between his sister-in-law and Polhill was relatively short and included no direct message from Alann Steen.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prime Minister: Need Direct Ties with Soviet Enterprises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 8th graf, `Some Lithuanians ...' with further supplies cut off, inserts reference to Western journalists; ADDS 1 graf at end with Ryzhkov comments today. Subs 2 grafs for 20-21, `President Bush...congressional leaders.' to UPDATE with Baker comments.
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania is urgently seeking direct trade links with Soviet regions and factories as a way around the Kremlin's suffocating economic blockade, a spokesman for the Baltic state's parliament said today. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania is proposing the direct links in the hope that regional leaders sympathetic to the secessionist republic will come to its aid, spokesman Paul Pauparus said. The Kremlin began cutting off natural gas, oil and other supplies to Lithuania one week ago, stepping up its pressure on the republic's leaders to rescind laws promoting their March 11 independence decree. ``Lithuania's economy is on the brink of collapse,'' the Soviet newspaper Selskaya Zhizn, or Rural Life, reported today. Lithuania's parliament set up a special ``anti-blockade commission'' Tuesday, naming Prunskiene as its head. She has sought economic aid from several European countries but has reported little success. Lithuanian officials have estimated that the republic can only hold out about two to four weeks without fuel from the Soviet Union, its sole supplier. Pauparus said democrats who have come to power in Moscow and Leningrad, as well as other regions, might be willing to deal with Lithuania, but their supplies might not be able to reach the republic along Kremlin-controlled train and truck routes. Some Lithuanians have suggested that the republic, which produces more meat and milk than it consumes, could trade those items for needed supplies. Eduardas Potashinskas, a Lithuanian activist who monitored today's parliament session, said speakers announced that the Kremlin decreed a stop Tuesday to Soviet supplies of paper and wood products to Lithuania. The Kremlin has barred Western correspondents from Lithuania, although it allowed about two dozen journalists to visit its capital, Vilnius last weekend. The KGB said on Tuesday that it had reinforced its units on the Lithuanian border and increased patrols offshore. Lt. Anatoly Parakhin of the KGB, whose forces are responsible for Soviet borders, did not specify in a Moscow briefing what goods the secret police were looking for, but he indicated weapons were on the list. ``Control has been established over possible contacts between Soviet and foreign ships in territorial waters and within the borders of the economic zone of the U.S.S.R. to avert the transfer of weapons and ammunition to Lithuania,'' Parakhin was quoted by Tass as saying. ``The movement through the border of all cargo and means of transportation is being most carefully controlled,'' he said. He said the stepped-up control was justified by the discovery on April 12 of 240,000 rounds of hunting ammunition aboard the Soviet ship Marat Kozlov, which was sailing to Lithuania from West Germany, Tass said. Pauparus contended the load of hunting ammunition was a normal annual shipment, and said the KGB implication of something sinister was ``nonsense.'' He also denounced a Tass report that a shot had been fired at an army barracks in Vilnius on Monday night. The shot came through an open window and shattered an opposite window, injuring no one, the state-run Soviet news agency reported. ``This is once again a provocation or nonsense,'' Pauparus said. On Tuesday, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis denounced the United States for failing to impose economic sanctions in retaliation for the embargo. ``Can the freedom of one group of people be sold for the freedom of another? What then is the idea of freedom itself?'' the Lithuanian leader said in a statement released by his press office in Vilnius, the republic's capital. ``This is another Munich,'' Landsbergis said, referring to French and British appeasement of Nazi Germany that culminated in the 1938 Munich Pact that sacrificed much of Czechoslovakia to Germany. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today that the Soviet Union must allow Lithuanians to exercise self-determination. But Baker told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee in Washington that the Bush administration still was not prepared to impose economic sanctions on Moscow to force negotiations with Lithuanian leaders. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania in 1940 along with the other two Baltic states, Latvia and Estonia. A Lithuanian delegation remained in Moscow today trying for a second day to meet with Kremlin officials, but the republic's representation in the Soviet capital said no meetings had been set as of this morning. Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his advisers have repeatedly rebuffed Lithuanian attempts to discuss a possible solution to the crisis. The Soviet president has demanded that the Lithuanians first declare themselves willing to adhere to the Soviet Constitution, which calls for a referendum on secession and a waiting period of up to five years. Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov spoke informally today with a group of Lithuanian parliamentarians and journalists about the Lithuanian dispute. He reiterated previous demands that Lithuania repeal its independence-oriented laws, journalists reported.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Salvadoran Religious Objectors Eligible for Asylum
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court says two men who fled to this country may not be deported and are eligible for asylum because El Salvador's threat to imprison men who refuse military service on moral grounds is religious persecution. The 2-1 ruling Tuesday by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overruled the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which had rejected the asylum applications. The two Salvadorans are Jehovah's Witnesses, a church whose members refuse to bear arms. The INS said El Salvador's refusal to exempt men with moral objections to war from military service was not religious persecution because it applied to everyone equally. But the appeals court cited the United Nations refugee agency's handbook, which interprets international refugee treaties as allowing asylum claims by conscientious objectors from countries that do not recognize that status. ``A conscientious objector is one whose actions are governed by conscience, and persecution arises whenever that conscience is overcome by force or punishment meted out for the refusal to betray it,'' said the opinion by Judge Eugene Wright. The INS could appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court. Lawyers for the agency did not return telephone calls to comment. Lawyers supporting the Salvadorans and representatives of Amnesty International and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said it was the first appellate decision in the nation to grant refugee status to aliens who fled their home country because it did not recognize conscientious objections to war. The case before the court involved Oscar Canas-Segovia and his older brother Jose, who fled El Salvador at ages 16 and 17 in 1985 because their religion's objections to military service would not be recognized. They were arrested two days after entering the United States. The brothers fled their homeland after seeing friends taken by soldiers from street corners and forcibly conscripted into the military, said their lawyer, Karen Musalo. At their immigration hearing, they also offered evidence from a human rights expert, clergy and others in El Salvador about torture and murder of those who refuse to join the armed forces. Ms. Musalo said the brothers now live in the San Francisco area. The 9th Circuit ruling said the threat of imprisonment or other punishment for refusing military service out of ``genuine political, religious or moral convictions, or other genuine reasons of conscience'' was an act of ``religious persecution'' under U.S. and international law. The court also called the threat political persecution, saying ``voluminous and convincing evidence'' showed that Salvadorans who refused the draft were often viewed as enemies of the government and faced a risk of torture or death. The court quoted an immigration judge as saying El Salvador was one of 40 nations that refuse to grant conscientious objector status. Judge Procter Hug joined the opinion. Judge Edward Leavy agreed on the finding of political persecution but dissented on the religious issue, saying an intent to persecute must be shown.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Meets With Workers in the Hinterland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev saying laborers must change attitude toward work. Pickup 3rd pvs, `The Soviet...' Minor editing to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told workers at an industrial center in the Ural Mountains today that his economic reforms will not be successful unless people change their attitude toward work. The 59-year-old leader, making his first domestic trip in his expanded post of executive president, said the country has a powerful industrial base, scientific potential and educated people. But he said workers ``don't have enough incentives or responsibility.'' ``On the one hand, incentives are needed so a person has a different attitude to matters. On the other hand, incentives don't appear so easily, for psychology is formed over decades,'' Gorbachev told workers on the shop floor of the gigantic UralMash machine-building complex in the city of Sverdlovsk. His comments were reported by the official Tass news agency. Soviet television showed Gorbachev gesturing with his hands in animated conversations with UralMash workers. The TV correspondent said the chats touched on some of the sore points in the city, such as shortages of meat, milk and fruit. About 11,000 of the workers are living without adequate housing, the reporter said. Tass said Gorbachev made the trip to find out if workers will tolerate tough reforms needed to save the economy. ``The Soviet leader well knows how difficult his conversations will be with workers of the Urals cities with the background of empty store shelves,'' Tass said as the president left Moscow. Gorbachev will try to gauge how the workers ``will take new social shocks in the near future,'' the news agency said, referring to a plan to shift the Soviet Union to a market economy. No decisions on the new reform effort have been reached yet, and some reports say the plan will be less ambitious than originally planned because of fears of major social unrest. Foreign reporters were not allowed to accompany Gorbachev to Sverdlovsk, a closed city known as the home ground of maverick Communist politician Boris N. Yeltsin and a center for rock music, which was officially frowned upon until Gorbachev's glasnost program of greatern openness. Soviet spokesmen did not specify why Gorbachev chose Sverdlovsk for the trip. The Soviet leader has made a habit of staging walking tours in various parts of the country to get a sense of public opinion. Sverdlovsk residents have taken to the streets several times over the past months, including a pre-New Year's protest over a shortage of vodka. Party officials stopped the protests by flooding the stores with reserves of vodka, but many of the city's 1.4 million residents remain unhappy about the lack of other rationed items, including meat, sugar and butter, the Soviet press has reported. Sverdlovsk is also one of several Russian centers where Communist Party members recently ousted their local chief and replaced him with a more progressive leader. Members of the anti-communist Democratic Union plan to picket the sites of Gorbachev's visit, member Tatyana Karelina said today in a telephone interview. She said signs would read ``Gorbachev, Hands Off Lithuania,'' and ``Gorbachev is a Political Turncoat,'' among other slogans. Sverdlovsk is also known under its former name, Ekaterinburg, as the site of the murder of Czar Nicholas II and his family in 1918 by the Bolsheviks. The house where the Romanov family was shot has since been demolished.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Impressed With Polhill's Recollection of Captivity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 21 grafs to UPDATE with Polhill meeting schoolchildren, joking with sons, plans to leave Thursday, Steen's wife denying newspaper report, new quotes and color; Picks up 17th graf, `He is...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Hostages Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Robert Polhill underwent more questioning today about his three years as a hostage in Lebanon, clowned with his sons and hugged American kindergarteners who sent him a welcome home card. U.S. military authorities said Polhill and his family would leave for the United States on Thursday. They gave no further details. American officials said on Tuesday that Polhill shared a room with fellow U.S. academics Alann Steen and Jesse Turner and was probably in the same building as some of the other Western hostages held in Lebanon. A source, speaking on condition he was not identified, said today that the U.S. debriefing team was impressed with Polhill's observant recollection of the conditions and surroundings in which he was held. The source said officials had learned more from him than they had from previous hostages. But it was not immediately clear whether Polhill had provided information that would help U.S. officials determine where the other 17 Westersn hostages are being held in Lebanon or what kind of physical condition they are in. The Boston Herald reported today that Steen had briefly escaped in 1987 but that he was was recaptured and beaten. The newspaper quoted Steen's brother, Craig Steen of Orlando, Fla. Craig Steen said Polhill had conveyed the information in a telephone call on Monday to Alann Steen's wife, Virginia Rose Steen, at her home in Jackson, Mich. Mrs. Steen later denied the newspaper's account. U.S. military authorities in Wiesbaden said in a brief statement that Polhill, a 55-year-old professor, spent a second ``restful night'' at the U.S. Air Force hospital in the German city ``and continues to eat well.'' Wiesbaden City Manager Reinhold Edel visited Polhill in the hospital and formally welcomed him to this city along the Rhine River, presenting him with a case of local German wine. Displaying the sense of humor that doctors say helped him survive 39 months in captivity, Polhill told Edel he hoped there was a reorder blank with the wine, according to U.S. military authorities. Polhill, freed Sunday in Beirut, told the mayor that he, Steen and Turner talked often about coming to Wiesbaden and hoped it would be around the time of the annual autumn festivals celebrated in many German towns, the authorities said. Polhill also posed for pictures on a hospital balcony that was lined with American flags and draped with a banner saying: ``Welcome Home! Pray For The Others.'' Cheered by a crowd of about 75 servicemen, nurses, doctors and fellow patients, Polhill waved and clasped his hands over his head, kissed and hugged his wife, Feryal, and bantered with sons Stephen, 26, and Brian, 23. ``I'm funnier than he is,'' shouted Brian, wearing a camoflauge jacket. Polhill then pointed to himself and gave a thumbs up, then to his sons and gave a thumbs down. ``He says I'm not but I am,'' Brian shouted to reporters and photographers about 30 yards away. ``He says you're making him feel really wonderful _ thanks.'' Polhill also met with 14 American kindergarteners whose parents are stationed at the U.S. military base. The children had made him a welcome home card. Each child gave Polhill a yellow flower, and one girl handed him pictures drawn by her class. Smiling and obviously touched, he hugged several of them and patted two on the head. ``I told him that it was nice to have him back,'' said 6-year-old Ricky Houser III from Youngstown, Ohio. He was among the youngsters who drew and signed the card, which featured a large teddy bear. ``I feel real sorry for him. The people that don't like Americans always kidnap them _ and that's what I don't like,'' he said earlier. Medical director Col. Kenneth R. Koskinen said Tuesday that Polhill was intellectually sharp although malnourished and suffering from a loss of muscle tissue. ``He is essentially emptying our kitchen, to say the least,'' Koskinen told a news conference. ``He's eating four meals a day and ravenously enjoying all the food we're giving him.'' Koskinen said the professor was very concerned about the other hostages and very aware ``that if he says something negative that it might have a negative impact.'' ``His major concern that he relates to us is that `I'm going to do all I can to help them be free,''' the doctor said.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Premier Says No Pro-Democracy Protests This Spring
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng, on the first visit by a Chinese head of government to the Soviet Union in 26 years, said today there will be no repeat of last spring's pro-democracy demonstrations in China. However, Li did acknowledge ``minor unrest'' in the far western province of Xinjiang, where Xinjiang TV reported 22 people were killed in rioting April 5-6. It was the first such admission by the Beijing government of the riots, which the regional television blamed on Moslems trying to start a holy war. In a news conference, Li called his visit to Moscow a success because both nations agreed to reduce military forces along their border and continue ``good-neighborly, friendly relations.'' Yet in a clue that the two longtime Communist rivals could not resolve all their differences, Li said there would be no joint communique. Such a document is customary for summit meetings. Li said no joint statement would be issued because his four-day visit was so short and ``more time and effort would be needed'' to work out a communique. He said that each side's concluding statement would have ``no radical differences.'' Li said he saw no problems with perserving the ``political stability'' in China this spring. A year ago, student-led protesters clamoring for democracy overshadowed the visit to Beijing by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Soviet visit ended three decades of strained relations. ``Some believe that in April, May or June of this year, more disturbances will affect China, but I am sure that nothing of that sort will happen,'' Li said. Li emerged as a dominant hard-line force during the turmoil, in which the army killed hundreds and perhaps thousands of protesters on June 3-4 in Beijing, and since then he has tightened controls over Chinese society. ``I believe that a year ago the situation in China could not be compared to what we have today in China,'' he said. ``Last year, this time around, I concentrated on handling these very delicate issues. Now I am on an official visit to the Soviet Union, which means that the political situation in our country is stable.'' When asked whether Chinese handling of the demonstrators in Tiananmen Square could be a model for Gorbachev on handling the separatist Baltic republic of Lithuania, Li refused to answer. ``I think this question was directed to the wrong address. It's of him that you should ask such questions,'' Li said. The Chinese premier, in answer to another question, acknowledged the unrest in Xinjiang. He did not give a casualty toll but said the situation has stabilized. ``A certain number of criminals there, some thugs, were the instigators of the unrest, and the settlement was reached in accordance with the current legislation in China. Now the situation there is back to normal,'' Li said. China agreed to provide state credits to the Soviet Union to pay for import of Chinese consumer goods, although Li did not say what goods. The Soviet Union suffers from chronic shortages of basic consumer goods and has been going abroad for help. The Soviet Union will provide a credit to China to build a nuclear power station. The military agreement provides for the mutual reduction of armed forces along the two countries' 4,350-mile border.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. April 24 The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, Miss., on hostages: The release of Robert Polhill is welcome news and the United States should encourage terrorist groups to release the 10 _ including seven Americans _ still held captive. But the West cannot condone any ``reciprocal moves,'' as Iran requests, without condoning hostage-taking. At worst, Polhill's release is a cynical terrorist bet that the political advantage of holding hostages is waning. They are trying to eke what they can with these human beings they view as mere bargaining chips. At best, they are showing an unlikely change of heart. In any case, the Bush administration's stand of ``no deals'' appears to be working and should remain intact. It may appear hard-hearted to show no response to what is being touted as a ``humanitarian gesture'' by Iran in calling for release of Polhill and at least one more hostage. But that hard-heartedness pales beside the barbarism of kidnapping. To show reconciliation toward Polhill's tormentors would only make the West an after-the-fact accomplice to that crime. The road Polhill took to Damascus and freedom was long. We hope fervently that the road will be cleared for the remaining captives. But we cannot reward cruelty cloaked as magnanimity.

April 20 The Buffalo (N.Y.) News on global warming: If there is any hope to be found in results from the White House conference on global warming, it is that several nations appear ready now to reduce pollution and prevent the devastating consequences that eventually could result from a heightening of the ``greenhouse effect.'' Unfortunately, the Bush administration _ which hosted the conference _ does not want to include the United States in that group of forward-thinking nations. Instead, in speeches that sounded like they were written by his chief of staff rather than his environmental chief, Bush lectured the attending ministers on the ``economic factors'' involved and called for more study. In fact, the president _ bound by a no-tax pledge and exhibiting a caretaker mentality _ sounded like he might just ``study' this problem for the rest of his tenure. He could then drop it in the lap of his successor _ much as his predecessor did with the problem of acid rain. It is a disappointing response not only from someone claiming to be an environmentalist, but from someone claiming to be a leader.

April 19 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on Lithuania: Mikhail Gorbachev's admirers in the West are concerned that slamming the iron fist on Lithuania might jeopardize the considerable reservoir of goodwill that exists here for the Soviet president. They have every right to be concerned. Not since the Russian Revolution has a Soviet leader seemed so promising to the outside world _ and yet, all that hope is now jeopardized by the independence crisis in Lithuania. ... Because Gorbachev is such an improvement over every one of his predecessors, we in the West have tended to emphasize _ perhaps exaggerate _ his qualities as a statesman. ... We should ask: Is he intent upon a Russian counter-revolution, as many of his partisans in the West believe, or are his reforms mostly cosmetic in nature, a change of some names and reshuffling of bureaucracies? ... We do reserve the right to punish ... Gorbachev for betraying his expressed ideals. ... Why put off the inevitable? It is far better for all concerned to talk to the Lithuanians than to threaten them with reprisals.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: with reprisals.
DOC.TEXT: April 20 The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel on Lithuania: The Soviet Union is showing inexcusable stubbornness in dealing with Lithuania's bid for independence. Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev has now punished the Baltic republic by cutting off its oil and natural gas supplies. The most frustrating part of this affair is that it still could be resolved through negotiation. At least President Bush finally is letting ... Gorbachev know that he has gone too far. For weeks, the White House had been woefully mild in its criticism of the Soviets' handling of the Lithuanian crisis. The Soviet Union needs to understand that there will be consequences if its bullying of Lithuania continues.

April 22 Green Bay (Wis.) Press-Gazette on Earth Day: Twenty years ago, Gaylord Nelson came up with the idea of having a national environmental ``teach-in.'' The event Nelson dreamed up became known as Earth Day, and more than 20 million people joined him in observing it. With a worldwide audience making Earth Day 1990 an even greater phenomenon than the original, Nelson is again in the spotlight. And his message is similar to the one we heard from him in 1970: We can do better. Nelson could tout his role in Earth Day and the environmental movement. He could dwell on important environmental legislation he pushed as a U.S. senator from Wisconsin. But he has more important things to do. He continues to speak out on environmental issues as a senior counselor for the Wilderness Society. He has been a tough grader in assessing the performance of President Bush and other political leaders on environmental matters. Nelson also continues to display the vision that became evident even before the first Earth Day. The most important environmental legislation we could pass, he says, would be to require an environmental education starting in first grade. If we would heed Nelson's advice, future generations would achieve his goal of making every day Earth Day.

April 19 Birmingham (Ala.) Post-Herald on Ralph David Abernathy: It was (the) Rev. Ralph David Abernathy's fate to live most of his adult life in the shadow of a friend who became a legendary figure in the civil rights movement and U.S. history, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. It was not easy to be, in succession, the friend of and collaborator with such a man as he embarked on the course that would change a country and bring international fame, the man's chief aide as success and fame grew and finally, with assassination enhancing the legend, the designated successor who did not have the extremely rare talents found in King. Abernathy, who died (April 17) at age 64, paid a price for not being all that others in the civil rights movement thought King's successor should be. In 1977, he was pressured to resign as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, which he had helped King to create. In the following years, he became increasingly alienated from and criticized by other civil rights leaders, climaxed last fall by widespread denunciations because of what he wrote about King's sex life in his autobiography. But the most important period in Abernathy's life _ and the period for which he should be remembered _ was from Montgomery (Ala.) in the mid-1950s to Memphis (Tenn.) in 1968. ... This country is a better place because of what Ralph David Abernathy did during those years.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: those years.
DOC.TEXT: April 19 The World, Coos Bay, Ore., on teen-age parents: Somewhere, somehow we have to begin breaking the cycle of poverty and welfare that traps the children who have children. Toward that goal, we support new federal rules aimed at encouraging teen-age parents on welfare to finish up their high school diploma or its equivalent. The rules that go into effect in October are part of the welfare reform act. They will cut the child support grants for teen parents by almost half if they can't prove that they are working toward a basic education. That's not harsh; that's encouraging change. In welfare jargon, the action is called a ``sanction'' _ losing part of welfare benefits for not complying with the rules of the system. Sanctions are meant to be constructive, though when they are not applied with some common sense and understanding of personal situations, they can be detrimental. But we can't imagine very many situations when a high school diploma or GED program would not be appropriate for a teen parent. For the most part, the jobs in our society that mean financial security require a basic education. In the case of a teen parent, a decent job means financial security for two young people _ the teen-ager and the young child. More importantly, education and a job would stop the cycle of welfare dependency at a time when the teen parents still have the flexibility to change their future. ... (W)e have to be ready to offer more than just the requirement of an education. We'll have to provide both the education and the other support (like child care) that teen parents will need to make those changes.

April 20 The Post-Bulletin, Rochester, Minn., on children and TV watching: No wonder there are problems in the schools. If youngsters 2 to 5 years old are watching television for 25 hours a week, as American pediatricians report, there is a good reason for problems. The warning is based on a study by the American Academy of Pediatricians. The group cited data from A.C. Nielson Co. which shows that by the time one of today's children reaches 70, he or she will have spent seven years _ one tenth of the life span _ in front of the TV tube. Watching TV is a passive, sedentary activity. As the doctors report, it can lead to obesity in children whose health would be much better served by sports and active play. Much of television's programming is trivial tasteless fare, the equivalent of yesterday's pulp magazines. Spending that much time in such an undemanding pursuit leads also to obesity of the mind. What's to be done? The pediatricians recommend limiting children's viewing to one or two hours daily and encouraging them to spend other time in athletics, reading and hobbies. They also support legislation mandating broadcasting of high-quality programming for license renewal and requiring at least one hour a day of educational programs for children. The real solution lies with parents. They need to recognize the perils of excessive TV viewing and to do something about it.

April 20 The Flint (Mich.) Journal on Clean Air Act exemptions: Talk about a mooo-t point! Analysts are just getting down to reading all the fine print in the massive Clean Air bill. As one might expect, lawmakers have tucked in all kinds of perks or exemptions for special interest groups. Some amendments are udder-ly a-moo-sing. Take, for example, the section on cow exemptions. Cows, like other creatures, generate stomach gas. They burp and make other noises because of that gas. When the gas is released, it is called methane. But farmers don't have to worry, because the U.S. Senate has wisely exempted cows and other farm animals from the requirements of the Clean Air Act. (No, we are not making this up.) Congressional Quarterly reports that the bill, as originally reported out of committee, required a study of various sources of methane, including farm animals, which supposedly are among the nation's largest producers of the gas. As the Senate debated the measure, cows were granted an exemption. The move drew sarcastic comments from Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, who said without the exemption, cows would need catalytic converters to reduce emissions. It is funny, but it is also an example of how silly federal regulators can get sometimes. What if the study had found that cows do produce huge amounts of methane? What could we possibly do about it? Put them on a low-gas diet? Issue cow-sized antacids? Or, as Grassley, suggested, maybe we could install gas collectors or pollution control units on the cows. Is there a market for cow methane? This sort of silliness goes on too often in Washington, and it probably would be funnier if we weren't paying so much for it.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Judge Reduces Sentence for PTL's Dortch
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today reduced the eight year sentence for former PTL official Richard Dortch to 2{ years in return for testimony against others, including ministry founder Jim Bakker. Dortch, 58, was Bakker's former top lieutenant at the Bakker television ministry. In addition to testifying at Bakker's trial, he also appeared as a government witness in the recent perjury trial of former PTL pastor Sam Johnson. Dortch was indicted in 1988, along with Bakker, on 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy for soliciting $158 million from PTL supporters in exchange for false guarantees of free lodging at the ministry's Christian retreat near Charlotte. In his seven-page order, U.S. District Court Judge Robert Potter said the reduction meant Dortch probably would serve between 24 and 29 months, taking into account time off for good behavior. The judge said without the reduction Dortch probably would have served 40 to 52 months. Bakker is serving a 45-year prison sentence in a Minnesota prison on his fraud and conspiracy conviction. Dortch pleaded guilty to reduced charges in return for testimony for the government. Dortch was sentenced to two consecutive four-year prison terms and fined $200,000 by Potter. Potter did not reduce the fine. In his order, Potter said Dortch engaged in serious crimes, including wire fraud, mail fraud and conspiracy. ``Defendant Dortch not only pleaded guilty and expressed remorse, but also has been of great assistance to the government in its prosecutions of other defendants associated with PTL,'' Potter said. ``Defendant Dortch's actions are in sharp contrast with the actions of his co-defendant Bakker, who has refused to bring himself to understand that he has committed the violations charged in the indictments for which he was convicted.''

DOC.HEAD: Angola Announces First Direct Talks With UNITA Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Angola today announced that it would begin the first direct peace talks with the UNITA rebels in the next few days to ``find the path'' to end their 14-year-old civil war. Angola's foreign minister, Pedro de Casto Van Dunem Loy, told a news conference that the talks followed mediation by Portugal, the former colonial power in the African nation. But he said U.S. and South African supplies to the rebels could hinder progress. There was no immediate comment from the rebels, known as the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA in Portuguese. ``In the next few days, direct contacts with the Union for Total Independence of Angola will be beginning with the assistance of the Portugese government, which helped create conditions for the talks,'' the foreign minister said. ``We are convinced the talks will help us find the path to national reconciliation in Angola,'' he said. He said the exact dates or location were not yet decided but would be announced soon. Van Dunem said the United States and South Africa were supplying the rebels with logistical aid, weapons and ammunition. South Africa, he claimed, was sending the rebels military advisers and armed fighters. The military assistance, he said, could sabotage the forthcoming talks ``and hamper (the rebels') willingness to sit down at the negotiating table and find non-military means to resolve the conflict. This military support has allowed UNITA to intensify its military actions.'' The rebel group has fought the Marxist government since soon after Angola became independent of Portugal in November 1975. Under a U.S.-mediated peace pact in December 1988, South Africa was to stop aid to the rebels and Cuban forces were to withdraw. The Angolan minister said the Cuban troops, with had fought the rebels for years, were being withdrawn on schedule, that more than 35,000 had left, and that about 15,000 remained. Angola's leftist government, he said, was instituting major economic and political reforms. He said it was moving toward liberalization and privatization of the economy, joining the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, and implementing their market-oriented prescriptions. Politically, he said, Angola was adopting reforms that would ultimately lead to a multiparty political system and free elections.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Withdraw Savings in Anticipation of Unification
LaserPhoto BER4
With AM-Merging the Money, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East Germans rushed to their banks Wednesday to withdraw their savings, hoping to get the best possible exchange rate with the mighty West German mark. While official delegations from both Germanys met behind closed doors in East Berlin to forge a plan for monetary union, worried people stood in long lines outside their banks, eager to rescue some of their savings. ``If the West German mark doesn't come soon, I'm going to change my job,'' one bank teller who was unnerved by the pushing crowds told The Associated Press. She spoke on condition of anonymity. The high-level negotiations now taking place are based on a Bonn prosposal for a basic 1-1 exchange rate for wages and pensions. However, savings accounts would be swapped 1-1 only up to 4,000 marks. Under the current exchange rate, 4,000 East German marks is worth about $767, while 4,000 West German marks is worth about $2,300. Savings above 4,000 marks would be exchanged at a 2-1 rate. East Germans are well-known savers, having had little to spend their money on in a Communist society beset by shortages. Some of those with more money admit to having worked out schemes to benefit from the exchange. ``I've withdrawn all but 4,000 marks and am putting the rest in the account of a friend,'' said a construction worker on East Berlin's Alexander Square who refused to be identified. ``That way we can both end up with more.'' Aware of the problems, a government spokesman said that the East German government would seek to negotiate a higher ceiling for savings exchange rates. ``I can't deny that the government wants to set the limit somewhat higher,'' East German government spokesman Matthias Gehler said. ``About 70 percent of all East German households have savings of about 5,000 marks,'' Gehler added, indicating that sum may be the government's target as a limit. Monetary union is only one of the problems facing policy-makers from both East and West Germany in their push toward unification. With little more than two months to go before their July 2 deadline, the delegations are also trying to pave the way to an economic and social union of their two very disparate countries. Economic union will mean coordinating budgeting, business and production growth goals even before the countries are fully unified. Social union covers broad areas such as unemployment benefits, health care and education systems. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere appeared for the first day of what promises to be many rounds of tough negotiations. De Maiziere refused to say exactly what would be on the day's agenda. ``I don't want to say anything before negotiations even begin,'' de Maiziere told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Relief Efforts Hampered by Lack of Money, Staff
DOC.TEXT: Medical facilities for victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster are running out of money and may have to shut down, a senior state official warned Wednesday. Compounding problems faced by survivors of the Union Carbide gas leak, banks here say they are not equipped to handle monthly relief payments ordered by Prime Minister V.P. Singh. Treatment and compensation for victims of the world's worst industrial disaster, most of whom are poor shantytown dwellers, have been bogged down in a tangle of bureaucracy, lawsuits and politics for more than five years. ``We will be impelled to close down the hospitals and other health care facilities if financial assistance does not come through soon,'' said S.R. Sathyam, gas relief commissioner in Madhya Pradesh state. He said the state government had sent an SOS to the central government in New Delhi. The Madhya Pradesh government has spent $21 million in state funds since the Dec. 3, 1984 gas leak, Sathyam said in an interview. ``There is now no money to pay salaries to the hospital staff, deliver free milk to children, train the gas victims in various crafts and trades and extend loans to them,'' he added. Meanwhile, banks in Bhopal, the state capital, said the central government's order for monthly relief payments would stretch their staffs too thin. They suggested quarterly relief payments, since they cannot afford to hire extra staffers to process monthly payments. Prime Minister Singh visited Bhopal in January and promised gas victims they would get interim relief payments while his government fights the $470 million settlement reached by Union Carbide and former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. The Singh government says far greater compensation should be paid by Union Carbide, whose international headquarters are in Danbury, Conn. The Supreme Court is reviewing the settlement. Under an interim relief plan announced by Singh's government March 5, a monthly stipend of $11.65 is to be paid to each of 500,000 people living near the now-closed Union Carbide pesticide plant. Bhopal banks say they would prefer to make quarterly payments of about $35. The monthly payments are supposed to start in June, but bank sources said logistical preparations were far from complete. The death toll from the gas leak rises almost every week as people who were exposed to the deadly methyl isocyanate die of respiratory problems and other ailments certified by health officials as gas-related. Last week, the federal government informed Parliament the official toll had reached 3,730. About 20,000 people are officially listed as gas-afflicted, and hundreds of thousands of others have filed damage claims that are still being authenticated. Union Carbide contended the leak was the result of sabotage by a disgruntled employee. The Indian government said it was caused by negligence and filed suit against the multinational and its local subsidiary, Union Carbide of India Ltd. The Gandhi government initially sought $3 billion in damages from Union Carbide. The case dragged on through a series of district and state courts until the Supreme Court assumed complete jurisdiction.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrating Troops Set Off Explosion in Munitions Convoy
DOC.TEXT: Government troops firing flares to celebrate the start of a Moslem religious holiday ignited a convoy carrying weapons and ammunition near the Afghan capital, Western diplomats said Wednesday. There were no casualties in Tuesday night's explosion, which lit up the sky for several hours, said the diplomats. Two trucks in the dozen-vehicle convoy were destroyed, they said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The convoy, also carrying foodstuffs, had parked about four miles from Kabul's international airport, they said. The report could not be immediately verified. Troops manning the garrison camps shot flares into the air for about an hour to celebrate the start of the three-day celebration marking the end of Ramadan, the Moslem month of fasting. Last year, the Soviet-backed government banned its troops from shooting guns or flares into the sky during the celebration, citing safety concerns. The capital is ringed by mountains where Moslem guerrillas are hiding. The guerrillas, known as Mujahedeen or Islamic holy warriors, have been fighting to overthrow the government, which seized power in a 1978 coup.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Hits Southern Japan
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake hit southern Japan on Wednesday morning, but no injuries were reported, the Central Meteorological Agency said. The agency said the quake's epicenter was near Ishigaki Island, 1,140 miles southeast of Tokyo. It occurred at 11:24 a.m. and had a preliminary reading of 5.3 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale measures the magnitude of a quake at its epicenter, according to ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Set Fire to Sydney Prison
DOC.TEXT: Inmates set fire to a prison Wednesday, causing damage estimated at $120,000, officials said. It was the second fire at the maximum security jail in four days. More than 200 inmates at the Parramatta Jail refused to return to their cells after the blaze was brought under control, and tear gas was used to subdue them, said Angus Graham, director-general of the Corrective Services Department. On Sunday, four inmates were injured during a riot at the jail in western Sydney. A fire that day caused more than $100,000 in damage to prison offices. Graham said prison guards had no option but to use tear gas Wednesday. ``They were given the order (to return to their cells) three times, and they knew what to expect,'' Graham said. He said the use of tear gas was an example of the tough measures the department was prepared to take to quell future disturbances. He denied the situation at the jail was out of control. ``Today's incident was contained and well-controlled by trained officers in the face of great provocation,'' he said. ``Any similar outbreaks will be similarly controlled.'' A total of 449 prisoners currently are incarcerated at Parramatta Jail, 15 miles west of central Sydney. The prisoners made no demands during the disturbances, and the motives for the unrest were unknown.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Still Plagued By Fear, Suspicion
DOC.TEXT: Four months after a bloody revolution toppled the Communist dictatorship, an atmosphere of fear and violence remains, fed by the people's suspicion that holdouts from the Ceausescu regime will stay in power. The interim leadership includes many former Communist officials, and some Romanians claim there is a deliberate attempt to keep communism alive, albeit in a less stringent form. ``The reluctance in purging the bureaucracy of Nicolae Ceausescu loyalists has fueled a hysterical distrust among people here, who suffered like nobody else in the Soviet bloc under the harsh Communist ruler,'' said Stelian Tanase, a former dissident writer. This week, hundreds of demonstrators gathered in downtown Bucharest, chanting anti-Communist slogans and seeking guarantees that no former Communists could hold high positions after the May 20 elections. The National Salvation Front says it has fully broken with old-style Romanian communism. The front, a loose coalition of former party members, workers, technocrats and intellectuals that took power in the post-revolution chaos, has taken some important steps, such as allowing demonstrations and letting Romanians travel abroad. It agreed in February to share power with opposition parties in the Council of National Unity, the interim government, and went on record as saying it supports a free market and a multiparty system. But it also has aroused suspicions among traditionally wary Romanians by choosing some top officials with links to Ceausescu. The front leader and the interim president, Ion Iliescu, has praised the ``humane values'' of communism. He is the front's candidate in the upcoming elections. The interim leaders earlier this month withdrew the visa of exiled King Michael, who planned to visit the country he was forced to leave 43 years ago. The front claims some 800,000 members and is widely seen as the main contender in the elections. It draws support mainly from industrial workers, who were promised benefits if the front wins, and from former Communist Party members. ``The front holds a formidable advantage because ... everything that was obtained by the revolution ... was used as electoral capital for its own sake,'' Sergiu Cunescu, chairman of the Social Democratic Party, said in an interview. He said about 90 percent of the front members are ex-Communists. ``People live in fear,'' he said. ``Workers in enterprises are asked to sign (support) for the front, and they do sign, thinking that if they sign they will keep their jobs.'' ``Those who don't sign are told that in case of economic hardships they will be the first to be fired,'' he said. Tanase, the former dissident who returned from exile in France after the revolution, said, ``In other East bloc countries, such as Hungary or East Germany, the Communists lacked any means and resources to hide under something.'' ``In Romania, they succeeded in doing this. The Communist Party has managed to take cover behind the revolution under the mask of this (National Salvation) front,'' he said. ``They won't stay in power too long even if they win.'' Iliescu has rejected allegations his movement operates like the old Communist Party. ``The Front declared a break with the Communist structures,'' he said in a speech this month. ``A return to the past is impossible.'' He said private enterprise should not exploit workers, who need protection from inflation and unemployment through a welfare program. He did not, however, explain how Romania would attract foreign investment, overhaul its outdated infrastructure and have enough cash left for unemployment benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Speak at Falwell's Liberty University, Four Others
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will deliver five university commencement addresses next month, including one at the Rev. Jerry Falwell's Liberty University, the White House said Wednesday. However, Bush has bowed out as the graduation speaker at West Point on May 31 because the date conflicts with his summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush will speak at: _Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, Okla., May 4. _Texas A&I University, Kingsville, Texas, May 11. _University of South Carolina, Columbia, S.C., May 12. _Liberty University, Lynchburg, Va., May 12. _University of Texas, Austin, May 19. Bush and Gorbachev will hold their second summit May 30-June 3. Most of the meetings are expected to be held in Washington, but details have not been released.

DOC.HEAD: Resigned University President in Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Berendzen in hospital; new information and background throughout
DOC.TEXT: Richard Berendzen, who resigned as president of American University during a police investigation of obscene phone calls, is a patient at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, a hospital spokeswoman said today. ``We can confirm that Mr. Berendzen is here at Johns Hopkins. At the request of himself and his family and physicians, we cannot make any further comment,'' said the spokeswoman, Joann Rodgers. Rodgers said Berendzen had been a patient for ``a bit of a while'' but refused to say when he was admitted. The hospital runs a well-known sexual disorders clinic but Rodgers refused to say whether Berendzen was being treated there, as reported by WUSA-TV in Washington. Berendzen resigned April 10. He is being investigated in connection with complaints that he made obscene telephone calls, according to published reports. The calls to women who had advertised baby-sitting services allegedly were traced by Fairfax County, Va., police to Berendzen's university office. Fairfax Commonwealth's Attorney Robert Horan said police were ``looking into certain complaints made against Dr. Berendzen,'' but would not discuss the nature of the complaints. Anita F. Gottlieb, spokeswoman for the university, said it assisted in the investigation of obscene calls after Fairfax authorities approached campus security officials on March 29. Berendzen's resignation surprised the university community, where he had been credited with improving the school's academic reputation and endowment. He was president for 10 years and said in announcing his resignation April 10 that he was quitting because of exhaustion. An unidentified woman interviewed on WUSA-TV Tuesday night told the station that a man identified by the station as Berendzen had made numerous calls to her. She called them ``filthy and frightening.'' She said she called police who placed a ``tracer'' and tape recorder on her telephone. Fairfax Police issued a one-sentence statement saying that Berendzen had not been arrested. Horan said no charges had been filed and none was expected soon. Making obscene calls is a misdemeanor punishable by a $1,000 fine or a year in jail or both. Edward Carr, president of the university's board of trustees, issued a statement Monday that Berendzen was stepping aside because of what Carr called allegations of ``improper behavior'' not connected with his role as president. Berendzen, a former astronomy professor with degrees from MIT and Harvard, came to American University in 1974 as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences. He became provost three years later and president in 1980. One of his major coups as president was to attract a $5 million donation for a new sports center from Saudi billionaire Adnan Khashoggi.

DOC.HEAD: Cut in Aid Foreseen for African Countries Failing to Democratize
DOC.TEXT: African nations that don't move toward democracy can expect cuts in U.S. aid, the State Department's top official on Africa said Wednesday. ``Very important members of the Congress ... are saying we should direct our assistance to emerging democracies,'' said Herman Cohen, assistant secretary of state for Africa. ``Democracy is not a condition of assistance now, but I think it will be in the not-too-distant future.'' In the past, U.S. policy has made little differentiation between dictatorships and democracies in giving aid. Cohen said some officials had been convinced that one-party rule, as it exists in many African countries, could be democratic. Cohen spoke at a meeting sponsored by the Bretton Woods Committee, a private group that supports international aid to the Third World. World Bank President Barber Conable and Managing Director Michel Camdessus of the International Monetary Fund _ the Third World's two biggest sources of aid loans _ also called for more democracy in Africa. ``I fear that many of Africa's leaders have been more concerned about retaining power than about the long-term development interests of their people,'' Conable said. Camdessus said the spread of democracy would be a help to economic reform. ``I realize the risks of political turmoil that the process of democratization can entail,'' he said. ``But I basically believe that a move to a more pluralistic and accountable form of government ... can help reforms to succeed, even if there are temporary costs.''

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Lava Burns Seven More Homes Since Tuesday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with two more homes destroyed. Picks up 3rd graf, `Lanny Nakano...'.
DOC.TEXT: The destructive lava flow from Kilauea Volcano burned five homes in one day and two more this morning, and threatened the only general store in the area, officials said. With the seven houses that have burned Tuesday and this morning, the lava flow has destroyed 98 homes since Kilauea began its current eruption in January 1983. Twenty-two homes have burned this month, and lava continues to spew from the volcano. Lanny Nakano, spokesman for Hawaii County Civil Defense, said other homes in the 120-home Kalapana Gardens subdivision remain in immediate danger, leaving residents in this once-quiet community in shock. ``It's real emotional,'' he said. ``Most people have been very calm, but we still have those who really can't accept it. But they're finally realizing it's here.'' The flow was headed toward a church and the only general store in the area, Nakano said. Loss of the store could seriously inconvenience residents who have not evacuated, and would deal a major psychological blow to the already stressed community, he said. Because the width of the flow is so large, it is difficult to predict where it will strike next, Nakano said. ``It's breaking out at different spots at different times,'' he said. Telephone service was lost to the remaining homes in the subdivision Tuesday evening, and electricity and water service was disrupted. Damage from the volcano is estimated at more than $20 million.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Nicaraguan Aid Package; Quayle Attending Chamorro Inaugural
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 5, Quayle was, to CORRECT ``flower'' to ``flour''. ^By TOM RAUM
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today signed a formal determination that Nicaragua is no longer a Marxist-Leninist country, restored its sugar export quota and provided $2.5 million in medical relief. The aid will help Nicaragua recover from the economic ``shambles'' the Sandinistas left it in, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. The White House announced the aid package for the former Sandinista government as Vice President Dan Quayle was flying to today's inauguration of Violeta Chamorro as Nicaragua's new president. Fitzwater said Quayle was bringing the aid package with him to offer to Mrs. Chamorro. Quayle was both cheered and booed when he arrived at the stadium in Managua where Mrs. Chamorro was to be sworn in. He carried with him a token gift of flour and cooking oil as a symbolic gesture of U.S. aid. The formal determination that Nicaragua is no longer a Marxist-Leninist state will make the Central American nation eligible for Export-Import Bank guarantees and credits. The relief is a down payment on the $300 million emergency aid package for Nicaragua still awaiting approval by Congress. ``Despite the celebration of today, President Chamorro faces a difficult task to restore Nicaragua's economy, which is in shambles as a result of mismanagement and a flawed economic philosophy,'' Fitzwater said. ``This administration will do everything it can to help Nicaragua rebuild.'' Fitzwater said Nicaragua's 2.1 percent share of U.S. sugar import quotas has been restored. The Reagan administration had sharply reduced Nicaragua's share in 1983 and then cut it off altogether in 1985 as part of its trade embargo against the Sandinista regime. The move allows Nicaragua to export 54,328 metric tons of sugar to the United States. Its share had been cut to 6,000 tons in 1983, with the rest reallocated to Costa Rica, El Salvador and Honduras. Bush had earlier lifted the trade embargo. The White House refrained from criticizing Mrs. Chamorro's reported decision to keep Sandinista military chief Gen. Humberto Ortega as defense minister. ``Mrs. Chamorro is the freely elected president of that country and we would not comment on her internal decisions,'' Fitzwater said. The Sandinista general is reportedly staying on for a transition period. ``They're not keeping the same economic philosophy. They're instituting many changes. And I don't think the retention of Humberto Ortega reflects on the economic course that Mrs. Chamorro intends to follow,'' the White House spokesman said. The medical aid will go to replenish supplies at hospitals and public health clinics that have run short of medicine. The grant would represent the first direct U.S. aid to the Nicaraguan government since 1981. Quayle left at sunrise today on a flight for Managua to attend the inauguration of the political leader whose Feb. 25 election ended the reign of leftist Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. But as Quayle made final preparations for the two-day trip that also will take him to Mexico City, Bush on Tuesday scolded the Democratic-led Congress for stalling on his overall $870 million Central American aid package. The plan also would provide aid to Panama. ``I asked that they do that back in March. I asked that the legislation be finished on April 5. And tomorrow, Violeta Chamorro is being sworn in as president and we don't have that,'' Bush complained to a White House audience. He appealed to a group of building contractors to ``please call your friendly senator and tell him to get going and get this legislation passed ... I'd like to have that legislation intact so that our able vice president can report that to Mrs. Chamorro when he goes down there tomorrow.'' Bush's package is stalled in Congress over unrelated legislation. On Tuesday, the Senate Appropriations Committee voted 15-14 to provide $300 million to Nicaragua and $420 million to Panama. Failure to approve the full aid package by Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration should not be seen as an embarrassment, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Tuesday. ``It is a matter of procedures here,'' he told reporters. ``We have procedures that obviously have to go forward, and I think eventually that aid package will be voted.'' The administration's aid request for Nicaragua is designed to help that country, among the poorest in the hemisphere, to recover from a decade of civil war and U.S. trade sanctions. It includes money to meet immediate needs for planting of crops and for fuel. The White House earlier made $3.6 million available to a United Nations group that is seeking to help demobilize and repatriate Contra rebels whose guerrilla battles against the Sandinista government at one time were actively supported by administration of former President Reagan. Officials of the new government have conceded they face a difficult challenge in meeting the electorate's expectations for a better standard of living.

DOC.HEAD: New Drug Combination Prevents Kidney Transplant Rejection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A form of a natural body chemical appears to significantly reduce the complications of kidney transplants, cutting in half the risk that the new organ will be rejected, according to a study. Doctors found that misoprostol, a synthetic version of the substance prostaglandin, reduced the risk of organ rejection from 51 percent to 26 percent. In the comparison study, doctors tested misoprostol in combination with cyclosporine, a medicine that has been widely used since the early 1980s to prevent organ rejection. Prostaglandins are made by tissue throughout the body and serve a variety of purposes. Cyclosporine interferes with the ability of the kidneys to make the substance. The study was directed by Dr. Mark Moran of G.D. Searle and Co., the pharmaceutical firm that makes misoprostol. The medicine is currently approved to prevent gastric ulcers that can occur when people are treated for inflammation. The research, published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, compared 39 transplant patients who took cyclosporine and other standard medicines with 38 patients who also received misoprostol. When rejection occurs, patients must receive extra doses of medicines that suppress their body's disease-fighting immune systems. While this frequently allows them to keep their new organs, it leaves them susceptible to infections. ``It seems likely that prostaglandin will have several uses, because of its ability to reduce rejection and improve kidney function in patients with all sorts of transplants,'' said Moran. ``This also suggests that we may be able to reduce doses of other, more toxic immunosuppressants.'' An editorial by Dr. Charles B. Carpenter of Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston said the work appears to confirm animal studies. He said it should promote more intensive investigation of prostaglandin therapy. In a separate report in the journal, Dr. Jean-Paul Soulillou and others from the National Institute of Health and Medical Research in Nantes, France, tested a different approach to blocking rejection. They gave patients antibodies that attacked one variety of freshly activated white blood cells known as T leukocytes. They said it worked as well as another treatment using antibodies that were not specifically targeted against these cells, but it produced fewer unwanted side effects.

DOC.HEAD: Hosea Williams Hospitalized After Altercation With Abernathy's Son
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Hosea Williams said he missed the funeral of his estranged civil rights colleague, the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, because he was injured in an altercation while trying to visit the ailing Abernathy. Williams and Abernathy's son, state Rep. Ralph David Abernathy III, both acknowledged that an incident occurred the week before Abernathy died April 17, but gave differing accounts. Williams entered a hospital a few days after the incident and remained hospitalized this morning; Abernathy's funeral was Monday. Williams was admitted to Emory University Hospital on April 15 for ``treatment of an arm condition,'' hospital spokeswoman Eve Patterson said this morning. He could be released as early as today, she said. Williams said Tuesday that he tried to visit Abernathy in Crawford Long Hospital on April 11, but Abernathy's son told him that doctors were allowing only family members to visit. Williams, a longtime civil rights activist and former Atlanta city council member, had called Abernathy ``the Judas of the movement'' after Abernathy's 1989 autobiography described alleged sexual indiscretions committed by Martin Luther King Jr. the night before his assassination. Williams said he saw the elder Abernathy sitting in a chair inside the hospital room and tried to enter, when the younger Abernathy ``grabbed me around my waist and shoved me outside. I didn't try to hit the boy. I thought about it, but I didn't do it.'' The younger Abernathy described the incident as a fight. Abernathy said Williams ``busted on through the door and got halfway in'' despite doctor's orders and the family's wishes against visitors. ``He threw up a forearm ... to try to push me out of the way. He hit me across the chest and the shoulder,'' the younger Abernathy said Tuesday. ``So I grabbed him and pushed him back out of the door and against the wall.'' ``I think what happened at the hospital was just Uncle Hosea's guilty conscience eating away at him,'' the younger Abernathy said. Abernathy said his father wasn't aware of Williams' presence until the incident was over and, when told of it, said, ``No, I do not want to see Hosea.'' Asked to comment on Abernathy's version, Williams said, ``I did not try to barge into the room. It was not a physical thing. Look, I could have popped Little Ralph's neck off like a chicken if I'd wanted to. But you just print Little Ralph's version. The Abernathy family has suffered enough.''

DOC.HEAD: 15,000 Gather For Inauguration; Quayle Booed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Quayle at ceremony. Pick up 2nd pvs, `Gen. Humberto...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA1
DOC.TEXT: About 15,000 Nicaraguans today gathered in a sports stadium to witness the transfer of power from the leftist Sandinistas to U.S.-backed President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Some Sandinista supporters chanted ``Assassin!'' when the black limosine carrying Vice President Dan Quayle entered the stadium before the inauguration, and one person threw a rock toward the vehicle. Other Nicaraguans cheered him. On the eve of the ceremony, Mrs. Chamorro infuriated leaders of her political coalition by reportedly deciding to retain the Sandinistas' longtime military chief. Gen. Humberto Ortega, a leader of the Sandinista revolution, is to stay on for a time to promote reconciliation between the pro-U.S. administration and the leftists who ruled Nicaragua for a decade, an administration source said. Nicaragua is emerging from nine years of civil war that claimed 30,000 lives and left the economy in tatters, and Mrs. Chamorro, 60, has promised its 3.5 million people peace. But by keeping outgoing President Daniel Ortega's brother at the helm of the military, Mrs. Chamorro would probably make it more difficult to persuade the U.S.-supported Contra rebels to disarm. The upper-class newspaper publisher also runs the risk of alienating the leaders of the ideologically diverse coalition she led to victory in Feb. 25 elections. ``It is unacceptable that members representative of the FSLN (Sandinista Front) remain in high-level posts in the army, Interior Ministry and other government structures,'' the coalition leadership said in a statement Tuesday. The Sandinistas often treated their political opponents harshly, so it is no surprise that members of the new government wish to see them completely out of government. The leadership of the 14-party United National Opposition coalition, or UNO, has frequently been at odds with the small circle of Chamorro advisers that is putting her government together. A source close to Mrs. Chamorro told The Associated Press that leaving Gen. Ortega in place would be a temporary measure and confirmed a report in the Chamorro family newspaper La Prensa that the president-elect will at the outset assume the post of defense minister. ``There are some extremists (within UNO) that want the Sandinistas wiped out in one fell swoop,'' the source said. ``That cannot be. He (Gen. Ortega) will be eased out, but not for a while.'' The Contras and members of the Chamorro coalition have demanded that the army be purged of Sandinista loyalists. President Daniel Ortega said the United States is exerting ``very strong pressure'' on Mrs. Chamorro to avoid fulfilling a transfer of power protocol and warned that this ``would be chaos for Nicaragua,'' Barricada, the official newspaper of the Sandinista Front, said in today's editions. Gen. Ortega was a member of the Sandinistas' nine-man directorate until he quit Monday to honor an agreement to de-politicize the armed forces. All officers in the army and security forces likewise resigned from leadership positions in the Sandinista Front, presumably making them eligible to stay on after Mrs. Chamorro takes over. The resignations are unlikely, however, to placate many of the thousands of armed Contras in the countryside who say they will not disarm as agreed by June 10 unless the army is purged of Sandinistas. The rebels were to begin turning in their weapons today at specially designated ``security zones'' supervised by U.N. peacekeepers. Discord in the new governing coalition was also evident Tuesday when the new National Assembly was inaugurated. In an internal primary over the weekend, Myriam Arguello of the People's Conservative Alliance won 28 votes from UNO's 51 deputies to win the coalition's nomination for National Assembly president. Alfredo Cesar of the Social Democrats and a protege of Mrs. Chamorro, received 23 votes. But at Tuesday's first session of the new assembly, Ms. Arguello and her supporters did not return from a recess for a secret vote on the the legislative president after Cesar appeared to have won Sandinista support for his candidacy. Cesar was rumored to have agreed to support Gen. Ortega's staying on as army chief in exchange for the votes of the assembly's 39 Sandinista deputies. In Washington, President Bush today signed a formal determination that Nicaragua is no longer a Marxist-Leninist country, restored its sugar export quota and provided $2.5 million in medical relief. The relief is a down payment on the $300 million emergency aid package still awaiting approval by Congress. Even the $300 million would be only just about enough to get Nicaragua through this year. The money already is too late to boost the planting season that begins in a week's time, and agriculture is the backbone of Nicaragua. As one of her first official acts as president, Mrs. Chamorro was expected to place flowers on the grave of her husband, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, whose assassination helped spark the 1979 revolution that brought the Sandinistas to power.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leader Assails U.S., Urges Kidnappers to Hold Hostages
DOC.TEXT: A reputed mentor of pro-Iranian kidnappers urged them to continue holding their Western hostages Wednesday and accused the United States of sabotaging efforts to win the release of other captives. Shiite Moslem leader Hussein Musawi said a non-binding U.S. House of Representatives resolution Tuesday endorsing a united Jerusalem as Israel's capital complicated efforts to free another hostage. ``The Moslems in Lebanon offered a rose, only to get a stone thrown at them,'' Musawi told a group of journalists from Western news organizations, including The Associated Press. Sunday's release of American Robert Polhill after 39 months in captivity raised hopes another Western hostage could be freed. Kidnappers are believed to be holding 17 Western hostages, including seven Americans. Polhill, who was flown to Wiesbaden, West Germany, after his release, plans to return to the United States with his family on Thursday, U.S. military officials said. Musawi is believed to have played a key role in Polhill's release. The bearded, soft-spoken former teacher alluded to his repeated urgings to the kidnappers to show good will by releasing a hostage. ``So they did and released Polhill,'' Musawi said. ``But upon that release we heard the news of the House of Representatives resolution on Jerusalem. If every release is matched by such a monumentally ill-intentioned American response, why then should any hostage be freed?'' ``We hope that no other hostage will be released,'' said Musawi, reputed mentor of the pro-Iranian group that held Polhill, the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. Polhill, 55, a lecturer on accounting, was kidnapped from the campus of the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College with two other American educators Jan. 24, 1987. The other two _ Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho, and Alann Steen, 51, of Boston _ are still held by Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. ``We expect the hostage-holders to complicate matters and we hope they will not liberate any of the hostages. The House of Representatives motion was a maximum ill-intention,'' Musawi said. He stressed the word ``maximum'' in English, and otherwise spoke in Arabic. Musawi heads the Islamic Amal faction within Hezbollah. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for groups holding hostages. Asked about persistent reports a second American hostage would be freed during Eid al-Fitr, the three-day feast that begins Thursday and marks the end of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan, Musawi said: ``There is plenty of talk about such a move. I do not think Eid al-Fitr means anything to the Americans, and I don't think there's an atmosphere for such an early release.'' Musawi said the release of Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners held by Israel and its militia ally, the South Lebanon Army, was ``essential'' toward freeing the remaining Westerners in Lebanon. ``The release of the prisoners held by Israel and its surrogates is a foremost issue and should be simultaneous with the release of the hostages,'' he said. Officials in Jerusalem had said Israel and the Israeli-allied South Lebanon Army planned prisoner releases this week to mark the end of Ramadan. But South Lebanon Army leader Antoine Lahd on Wednesday canceled plans to release some of the 300 mostly Shiite prisoners he holds, sources said. In the past two years he had released prisoners on the holiday. ``Releasing them now would be seen as an American payment to the Hezbollah through Israeli agents,'' he was quoted as telling Israel radio. Most of the seven Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, one Italian and one Irishman are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite factions. The longest-held hostage is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Asked whether the hostages were all alive, Musawi said there was no proof anyone was dead. He also said he believed the various factions holding captives knew one another. In Tehran, Iran's radical parliament speaker, Mehdi Karrubi, said U.S. officials were more spiteful of the Islamic Republic now than when Washington launched its failed military operation in April 1980 to free U.S. hostages in Tehran. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, said Karrubi was speaking on the anniversary of the U.S. mission to free 52 Americans held hostage at the U.S. Embassy in the Iranian capital. The rescue mission was aborted after two U.S. aircraft collided at a desert base south of Tehran and eight crewmen were killed. Karrubi appeared to be pre-empting any possible thawing of relations between Tehran and Washington following Polhill's release. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani has urged that the hostages be released and is believed to favor better relations with the West.

DOC.HEAD: Islamic Jihad Seeks Freedom for Prisoners in Kuwait
With AM-Hostages Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Islamic Jihad has said it will not free the Western hostages it holds until Kuwait releases comrades imprisoned there for bombing the U.S. and French embassies. Seventeen Shiite Moslems were jailed in the emirate for the bombings Dec. 12, 1983, which killed five people and wounded 86. One of the dead was the driver who rammed an explosives-laden truck into the U.S. Embassy. Two of the 17 have been released after serving five-year terms. Of the others, three are under sentence of death, seven were sentenced to life, four were given 15-year terms and one was sentenced to 10 years. Kuwait has refused to free any of the prisoners. Most are pro-Iranian Shiites from Iraq, but among those still held are two Lebanese whose release is believed to be a principal reason for the kidnappings by Islamic Jihad. One of those sentenced to death is Mustapha Youssef Badreddin, a cousin and brother-in-law of Imad Mughniyeh, said to be the leader of Islamic Jihad. Badreddin was convicted as Elias Fuad Saab, the name on the forged passport he used to enter Kuwait. The second Lebanese, sentenced to life in prison, is Hassan Youssef Musawi, a cousin of Hussein Musawi, leader of another Lebanese Shiite faction.
