Islamic Jihad and Musawi's Islamic Amal party are associated with Hezbollah, or Party of God, a Lebanese group loyal to Iran. Mughniyeh is Hezbollah's security chief.

DOC.HEAD: Police Force is with `Jedi' Thief Bandit
DOC.TEXT: A bragging bandit eluded police for weeks, told store clerks he'd never be caught and christened himself ``Jedi,'' after the knights who used a psychic power called ``the Force'' in the ``Star Wars'' films. The Force was with him Tuesday _ the police force, that is. Allen Bonneau, 27, of Pittsburgh, was arrested after a convenience-store robbery, police said. Police charged Bonneau with 15 robberies of fast-food restaurants, shops and convenience stores in Pittsburgh, two in suburban Wilkinsburg and one in suburban Bellevue in an alleged spree that began April 6. Police said he told them he was a ``Robin Hood'' who stole money to give to poor children and buy baby formula for welfare mothers. Bonneau's style ``wasn't appreciated by us,'' said Assistant Police Chief Mayer DeRoy. ``His days of taunting, at least for awhile, are over.'' Clerks of a 7-Eleven robbed early Tuesday quoted ``Jedi'' as complaining: ``I'm not going to rob this store anymore. There's not enough money. I'm going back to New York.'' That afternoon, Bonneau was arrested shortly after the robbery of a Stop-N-Go Foods convenience store, Lt. William Mullen said. ``What happened is that he ran out of there, and he was chased by some people, but he got away,'' Mullen said. Police spotted him after a tip from construction workers. Bonneau tried to escape by running up the steps of a man's home and offering $20 if he would say Bonneau was mowing his lawn, Mullen said. ``He told police the reason he called himself Jedi was `I would rob the stores and jet away,''' Mullen said. Police said the robber told clerks he wanted to steal about $3,000 before leaving the area. The amount ``Jedi'' stole is uncertain, because copycat robbers may have committed some of the holdups, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Closing of Restaurant as Public Nuisance
DOC.TEXT: Pearl's Place, a restaurant that police say served more drugs than food and was the scene of 12 killings during the past six years, has been ordered closed. ``There are a lot of legitimate restaurants, but this just wasn't one of them,'' Detective John Tucker said Tuesday. Circuit Judge Virginia Q. Beverly declared the restaurant a public nuisance and ordered the restaurant closed by 5 p.m. Friday. She also ruled that anyone wanting to operate a business from that building must get special permission from the city. Seven of the killings on the restaurant's corner have been drug-related, and two occurred inside the building, Tucker said. During the past three years, police also have investigated eight car thefts, 29 assaults, 26 other crimes and made 109 drug arrests in the area, records show. The city sued last summer to close Pearl's Place, but the process took until last week to resolve because owner Pearl Williams initially requested a jury trial on the closing. Attorney Joe Farley, who represents Mrs. Williams, said they dropped the request and consented to a hearing before Beverly. Mrs. Williams was charged last year with six counts of selling crack and three counts of conspiracy to sell crack. She has not been tried on those charges. Farley doubted the closing would have any impact on lowering crime in the area. ``I'm sure there's not going to be a registered difference once they close her place down,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Drug `War Bond' Bill Draws Fire
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration and several Democrats lined up Wednesday against a popular bill to have schoolchildren help finance the war on drugs by buying World War II-style savings stamps and bonds. The bill, sponsored chiefly by Rep. Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., carries the signatures of 249 of the 435 members of the House. It would allow the Treasury Department to issue up to $4 billion worth of bonds for education, prisons and other anti-drug programs. ``As in World War II, I am convinced that the war on drugs will not be won until we mobilize the American public,'' Lewis told the House Ways and Means Committee. He recalled how as a child he bought 25-cent savings stamp, then traded in each $18.75 book of stamps for a war bond. The Treasury Department objects to the bill because it does not like special borrowing programs, and department official Michael E. Basham said the ``Drug War Bond Act'' would be expensive to administer. Several Democrats were more pointed in their criticism. ``It's a question of whether we should be borrowing from our children to teach them the dangers of drugs'' when many of the most vulnerable are also among the nation's poorest, said Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., who heads the House committee on narcotics. ``There's another addiction occurring in this country _ an addiction to debt,'' said Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D. Lewis agreed with Rangel that because of federal budgeting practices, the bill does not guarantee that even an additional penny would be available for fighting drugs. The intent, Lewis said, is to draw the public into the war and to make a commitment to finance the fight. A galaxy of entertainment stars has lined up behind Lewis's bill. Actor Dennis Franz, who was a detective on ``Hill Street Blues'' and plays an anti-drug undercover cop on the ``Nasty Boys'' series, promised that entertainers would play a big role in promoting the sale of drug bonds. ``We will be spreading a message to everyone watching, especially our youth, that drugs are not acceptable, that drugs are not `cool' and that drugs are not safe,'' Franz said. Even on that point, there was disagreement. ``There is a perception ... that entertainment and sports celebrities use drugs on a regular basis and encounter few if any negative consequences. Those messages are most damaging when delivered by those who are alleged to be recovering from addiction,'' said Robert J. Hill of Vienna, Va., a former police officer and recovering alcoholic who heads the Coalition for a Drug-Free Community. Dick Herndobler of Ashland, Ore., who directs the Elks national drug awareness program, said the proposed bonds would be a welcome addition. Alice C. Donahue, international president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, agreed. ``By giving individuals an opportunity to do something, even something so simple as buying a bond, we will help to build a consensus that drug abuse ... is a problem in which we can and should become involved in finding a solution,'' she said. Ron Sarasin, president of the National Beer Wholesalers' Association, said his organization will buy the first $100,000 of drug bonds.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
US Reaches Agreeement With Japan on Wood Products
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Japan reached agreement today on removing various barriers to the sale of American forest products in Japan, U.S. officials announced. The conclusion of the negotiations on forest products clears up the final case cited by the Bush administration a year ago when it placed Japan on a trade ``hit list'' of the countries with the most offensive barriers to sales of American products. In recent weeks, officials had announced agreement on increasing sales of American supercomputers and satellites in the Japanese market, the two other products cited. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said that U.S. and Japanese negotiators had resolved the wood products dispute after lengthy discussions in Tokyo. ``We believe this agreement will provide major benefits to U.S. exporters,'' she said in a statement. ``Not only will it result in millions of dollars of U.S. exports, but it will offer lower cost and high quality wood housing to Japanese consumers.'' She said the agreement could increase the sale of U.S. wood products in Japan by as much as $1 billion annually by lowering tariffs and revising Japanese building code standards. The announcement of the successful completion of talks on wood products came as the Bush administration is facing an April 30 deadline for deciding whether to target Japan for a second year in a row as an unfair trader under a tough section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301. Hills said the administration has not made a final decision on the issue, but she gave strong indications in testimony before the Senate Finance Committee today that Japan will not be targeted because of the progress it has made in recent weeks in settling trade disputes with the United States. Several senators, including Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said it would be a mistake for the administration to fail to target Tokyo again, given America's huge $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. But Hills insisted that the Super 301 targeting mechanism was only one of the tools available to force markets open in Japan and that using it again could jeopardize the progress that has been made. ``Our objectives are all the same _ to open the market for American businesses,'' she said. ``I must be allowed some discretion to say which tools should be used.''

DOC.HEAD: Rosarita Food Company Founder Dies at Age 93
DOC.TEXT: Pedro Guerrero, who parlayed a $38 investment in a tamale booth in nearby Guadalupe into the Rosarita Mexican food company, has died of kidney failure. He was 93. Guerrero, a Mesa resident, died Monday. Guerrero and a partner began selling tamales at a Yaqui Indian fair in the Arizona town Guadalupe in 1929. He later invented a trademark, but it was years before he was able to find partners in his venture, which in 1945 became Rosarita. Rosarita went public in 1959 and was bought by Beatrice Foods Corp. in 1961. Guerrero retired in 1972. Survivors include his wife; three sons, and three daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Heart Medicine Appears to Slow Lung Damage in Cystic Fibrosis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A new form of a common high blood pressure medicine appears to slow the life-threatening lung damage of cystic fibrosis and could dramatically improve the lives of people with the frequent inherited disorder. The conclusions were from a preliminary study of the medicine amiloride. The medicine, when inhaled in a spray form, seemed to help clear thick secretions that clog cystic fibrosis patients' lungs. It reduced the loss of lung capacity by 60 percent when compared to a dummy treatment. Cystic fibrosis strikes about one in 2,500 babies born in the United States. Only about half of the victims live to their mid-20s, and almost all of the deaths are from lung disease. Because of an inherited abnormality in people with cystic fibrosis, the cells that line the air tubes in their lungs absorb too much salt and water. This produces a thick mucous that blocks the lungs and makes victims prone to infections and breathing problems. Amiloride, a diuretic, appears to work by reducing the lung cells' absorption of salt and water. In the initial study, doctors tried the treatment on adults whose lungs were already seriously damaged by years of infection. No one has tried it yet on youngsters whose lungs are still relatively healthy, but researchers hope it will significantly change the course of their illness. ``Our fantasy is that it could be much more useful if given early in life over the long haul,'' said Dr. Michael R. Knowles, a developer of the treatment at the University of North Carolina. He cautioned, however, that the diuretic, which is ordinarily used to prevent water retention, could be harmful to children's kidneys or have other unwanted side effects. Dr. Robert Beall, research director of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, said that a study is planned that will test the medicine on youngsters under age 12. ``It could increase life exponentially,'' Beall said. ``We feel that if we can change the environment of the lung so that we don't give bacteria a good place to live, we might add decades to these kids' lives.'' A report on Knowles' initial study, conducted on 14 adults, was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. For two consecutive six-month periods, they used aerosol amiloride or a placebo. While their conditions did not improve, the rate of lung damage appeared to be slowed while taking amiloride. Cystic fibrosis is now treated primarily by giving antibiotics and pounding on victims' chests to loosen the mucous in their lungs. The new approach exploits several years of research into the underlying abnormality in cystic fibrosis. ``What is particularly exciting is that we for the first time have used a therapy that tries to treat the primary defect, which is the abnormal movement of ions across the membranes,'' said Beall. ``We are going to the source of the problem.'' Amiloride has been available in the United States in pill form for five years to treat high blood pressure, congestive heart failure and fluid retention associated with kidney disease. However, the pills are ineffective against cystic fibrosis. Knowles and two other researchers hold the patent on the aerosol technique. The pharmaceutical firm Glaxo has bought the rights to produce the inhaled form of the drug. More testing will be necessary before permission is sought from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to make the treatment routinely available. Until then, cystic fibrosis patients will be able to obtain the therapy only by enrolling in experimental trials of the medication.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Siege Ends
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with prison siege ending. Pick up 8th pvs, `The siege...'
DOC.TEXT: The last five prisoners abandoned the roof of Strangeways Prison today to end a standoff that began with a devastating riot and became the longest prison siege in British history. The prisoners climbed into a crane placed alongside the roof of the cell block, raising clenched fists and holding each other's hands aloft as they were brought to the ground. They were then taken into custody by police in riot gear. The prisoners timed their end of the 25-day siege so that it appeared live on the main British Broadcasting Corp. television evening newscast. Earlier today, squads of prison officers swept into the prison to try to recapture the prisoners. Officials said more than 100 prison officers regained control of all the prison buildings by midmorning, isolating the last inmates on the roof of the grim, Victorian jail. No injuries were reported in the operation. Officers huddled just under the roof, poking their heads through holes made when prisoners ripped out the slate shingles to throw at authorities during the beginning of the siege. During the siege, inmates built and rebuilt barricades and planted booby traps to keep out authorities. The prisoners had ignored a midday deadline. Paul Taylor, 29, the apparent ringleader, stood on top of a chimney stack, dancing and performing a mock striptease. Weeks of patient negotiations brought out all but the last five of the 1,650 inmates. The siege began with a riot April 1 in the prison chapel that spread throughout the jail. About 300 prisoners overwhelmed guards during the Sunday service, took the jail keys and released the rest of the inmates. Running battles raged in the prison in northern England for about four days and prompted unrest and violence in jails throughout the country. Prison officials had hoped negotiations would coax all inmates to surrender. Through hand-painted signs, makeshift megaphones and talks with officials, the prisoners complained of poor food, alleged brutality by prison officials and overcrowding in the prison, originally built to hold 950 inmates. Inmates were held three or four to a tiny cells before the riot, allowed a shower and change of clothes once a week and provided with a bucket instead of a toilet. One prison officer died in hospital during the riot as a result of an existing heart condition.

DOC.HEAD: Smiling Gunman Opens Fire in Mall; Had Been in Mental Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf, `A document...' to UPDATE with governor's comment on gunman's release. INSERTS one graf after 10th graf pvs, `How did...' to ADD state gun law requirements. Picks up 11th graf, `Once inside...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX1
DOC.TEXT: A smiling gunman who killed one person and wounded four at a suburban shopping mall had been released 36 hours earlier from a mental hospital where he had been listed as having homicidal tendencies, police say. The man, wearing a business suit, fired into a lunch hour crowd Tuesday before he calmly tossed the .38-caliber revolver into a trash can and surrendered, apparently at the urging of an elderly man, authorities said. ``You don't know what all these people have done to me,'' James Calvin Brady, 31, was said by authorities to have muttered as he was led away. He was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault and jailed without bail. Two of the wounded were listed in critical condition. During questioning, Brady talked of God and a ``mechanical device'' inside him that controls his actions, police said. ``He's suffering from hallucinations. He was probably having one when he fired,'' said Col. M.F. Ferguson. A document found in Brady's pocket said he was released Monday from Georgia Regional Hospital in Atlanta. He was admitted to the state hospital April 13, but the document did not say why he was released, Ferguson said. Gov. Joe Frank Harris said today that the reason for Brady's release was under investigation, but it was not due to overcrowding at the mental hospital. The state is ``sincere in trying ... to do everything that we can to prevent something like this from happening,'' Harris added. ``In this case, I think it was being done.'' The document ``said he had homicidal and suicidal tendencies, and suffered from delusions,'' Ferguson said. Brady ``can be hostile, threatening, and has a history of alcohol abuse,'' the colonel quoted it as saying. Marchant Roach, spokesman for the state Department of Human Resources, which runs the state hospitals, said the department would not comment on any patient. Officers said Brady bought the snub-nosed revolver and 12 rounds of hollow-point ammunition, a type designed to expand on impact and cause especially severe wounds, for $129 at a pawn shop in Atlanta on Monday. ``How did he get the gun? Why did he get the gun?'' Detective Lt. Rodney Maddox said. ``We don't have a good answer to that and may never know why.'' Georgia law does not restrict the sale of handguns or rifles but requires a license for anyone who carries a concealable weapon. Such a license cannot be obtained within five years of release from a psychiatric hospital. Once inside the mall's food court, Brady appeared to fire at random, police and witnesses said. ``He looked like a businessman with his left hand in his pants pocket,'' said Carol Gravdahl, a store manager at Perimeter Mall, a few miles north of the city. ``His right arm was straight out with a pistol, shooting it off randomly. He was coming around with it until I guess he emptied it _ and he was smiling.'' After firing six shots, Bradhy attempted to reload, but an elderly man apparently talked him out of it, police said. ``There may be a hero in this thing,'' Ferguson said. ``We still don't know who he is, but we'd sure like to talk to him. We'd like to know what he said to him.'' Michael Gregory Musick, 24, of suburban Norcross, was shot in the chest and died at Northside Hospital, police said. Craig E. Bruno, 23, of Roswell, was shot in the abdomen and was listed in stable condition today. Lucille Hughey, 74, of Decatur, was wounded in the side and was listed in critical but stable condition after surgery. Judy Shell, 53, of Roswell, was shot in the legs and listed in stable condition. James McDonald, 30, of Alpharetta, was treated at a hospital for a gunshot wound to the ankle and was released. Rambling, disjointed notes found in an Atlanta apartment from which Brady was evicted Tuesday morning said he had taken crack and then met two people in California who created a machine that would control his mind. ``If I got the public at large outcry and attention of why I became insane, the public would bring these (two people) to accounting,'' the notes said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Protest Mob Killings of Officers
DOC.TEXT: Angry policemen chanting ``Blood for blood!'' called for revenge Wednesday at the funeral of five officers who were beaten to death by mobs earlier this week. ``Stop atrocities on policemen on duty. Hang the home minister!'' shouted about 150 policemen as the remains of the five officers killed Monday were cremated. A total of six officers were killed Monday, but it was not immediately known if the other was cremated separately. Police had been closely linked to the non-partisan government dominated by King Birendra. They have come under increased attack since a new government headed by pro-democracy forces was installed last week. A dusk-to-dawn curfew restricting residents to their homes remained in effect in Katmandu, Nepal's capital. It was imposed after Monday's bloody clashes between police and mobs, who accused officers of having links to a right-wing group opposed to the democratic changes. Hundreds of police officers refused to report to work Tuesday to protest the mob attacks, but many officers reported for duty Wednesday. Birendra on Wednesday appealed for calm to give the country's new multiparty democracy a chance. ``It should be everybody's concern to see multiparty democracy succeed,'' Birendra said. ``His Majesty is confident that all Neounts in Canadian dollars, x-adjusted for stock dividend.

DOC.HEAD: Dinosaur Size May Have Helped Them Cope With Many Climates, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: The sheer size of dinosaurs may have helped them live in a variety of climates without getting too hot or cold, a study of huge turtles suggests. Researchers found evidence that large cold-blooded animals can keep constant high body temperatures by large body size, low metabolic rate and the use of some peripheral tissues as insulation. The study focused on leatherback turtles, which are among the largest living reptiles. They can weigh more than 1,500 pounds. The turtles range from the tropics to near the Arctic circle. They can warm up on land and keep elevated body temperatures in cold seawater, researchers said. Scientists measured metabolic rates of six adult females and mathematically analyzed the turtles' ability to maintain a relatively high internal temperature. Leatherbacks may restrict the flow of blood to the skin to keep warm and increase it to avoid overheating, researchers said. Support for that idea comes in the observation that the turtles' soft skin appears to be flushed with blood while the animal nests, the researchers said. The scientists suggested that their proposed temperature-regulating system for large animals be called ``gigantothermy.'' Such a system may have allowed dinosaurs to live in a wide variety of habitats, including polar regions, the researchers said. The work is reported in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature by scientists from Drexel University in Philadelphia and Purdue University in Fort Wayne, Ind.

DOC.HEAD: Downtown Mall Bans Teen-Agers on Weekday Afternoons
DOC.TEXT: Shoppers are welcome to browse at the downtown ParkFair Mall, but teen-age buyers beware _ because of rowdy behavior, the mall has banned unescorted youths on weekday afternoons. The three-tiered mall has been the site of recent, after-school brawls. Teen-agers assaulted two police officers trying to break up two fights March 30. More than 100 youths were dispersed and four teen-agers were arrested. ``I was here that day and I was scared,'' a woman who refused to give her name said last week. ``It was getting rather treacherous with the kids.'' The often bustling mall was relatively quiet that day. Tables at the ground floor fast-food restaurants were largely empty. ``Our business is down,'' said one fast-food clerk, Naeem Muhammad. ``But the theory is when we get this cleaned up other people will come down.'' Some patrons and shop clerks questioned whether banning an entire group of people from the mall between 2:30 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. was the answer. ``They can come in here and act like ladies and gentlemen,'' said Rose Shaffer, 52, who goes to the mall three or four times a week. ``They shouldn't punish them all.'' One 16-year-old turned away from the mall when he didn't produce any identification said the policy was aimed at blacks. ``They ain't sweatin' it for whites,'' said Ed Young. ``This whole dilemma is strictly racial.'' Police are frustrated by lack of cooperation when trouble occurs. ``We have kids coming out ... yelling racism and police brutality and that stuff,'' Sgt. Garry Gernandt said while on foot patrol around the mall. ``I think basically the problem is you got 10 percent of the kids causing problems for everybody.'' The policy was implemented April 16 and backed up by police foot patrols scheduled for the assignment through this week. Private security patrolled inside the mall. Metro Center Realvest, which owns the mall, said the policy will remain in effect as long as it works. ``It's indefinite at this point,'' Metro Center vice president Michael Wiese said. The March 30 incident was the most recent and most dramatic, Wiese said, but the ``problem of youths congregating and causing problems inside the mall has been ongoing for some time.'' ``We have decided at this point that this is the most appropriate way to restore order to the mall,'' Wiese said. ``We have looked at what we feel are a number of legally permissible options, and this is the one we decided to implement.'' There are no apparent legal problems with the ParkFair curfew, said Dick Shugrue, a law professor at Creighton University in Omaha. ``Age classifications need only be reasonable in a legal setting. In a private setting, by and large, there isn't any constitutional argument you could make,'' Shugrue said. ``The question boils down to whether it's a good business decision.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush: `I Don't Need Any Defense' for Lithuania Inaction
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, bitterly criticized by Lithuania, said Wednesday ``I don't need any defense'' for refusing to penalize the Soviet Union for its economic squeeze on the breakaway Baltic republic. ``The policies, decisions I've taken have had strong support from the American people, and that's who I work for,'' said Bush. The president did not reply when asked by a reporter how Lithuanians view his decision. While Bush has won support from some congressional leaders for his strategy, there also were signs of restiveness Wednesday about the lack of a U.S. response. Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell said Bush should take some action ``to express disapproval and to deter further actions'' against Lithuania. He suggested slowdowns in U.S.-Soviet talks on the environment, taxes, investment or trade but also said Bush was in the best position to decide. For a second straight day, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis denounced Bush's refusal to curb economic ties with the Soviets in reaction to coercion of Lithuania. ``Our people remember how they were abandoned after World War II ... relegated to the Stalinist empire. It just saddens us to see Western nations, especially the United States, being misled by the Soviet Union,'' Landsbergis said in a telephone call with members of Congress. ``The Soviets are strangling (our) nation like a boa constrictor,'' he said, referring to the mounting pressure from Moscow to force Lithuania to drop its drive to secede from the Soviet Union. A day earlier, Landsbergis had charged ``This is another Munich,'' when Bush delayed any economic sanctions. Landsbergis was invoking the infamous memory of French and British appeasement of Nazi Germany that culminated in the 1938 Munich Pact sacrificing much of Czechoslovakia to Germany. The White House said it took no offense at Landsbergis' remark. ``No, we understand his frustrations and his efforts on behalf of his people,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. ``Mr. Landsbergis is fully aware of the president's concern and interest in freedom in his country,'' Fitzwater said. During a picture-taking ceremony at the White House, a reporter questioned Bush about Landsbergis' ``Munich'' comment, asking how he defended himself. ``I don't need any defense,'' Bush said, adding that he enjoyed widespread support for his policies. On Capitol Hill, Secretary of State James A. Baker III told a Senate appropriations subcommittee that the Soviet Union must allow Lithuanians to decide their own future. But Baker said the administration still was not prepared to levy economic sanctions against Moscow to force negotiations with Lithuanian leaders. ``We are involved in quiet diplomacy in an effort to promote such a dialogue _ the only real answer to an effective resolution of this conflict,'' Baker said. ``The Soviets are going to have to allow the Lithuanians to fully exercise their rights of self-determination,'' Baker said. Fitzwater said, ``The president has reiterated time and again our support for freedom of Lithuania and other countries of the world. Indeed, preserving the fragile environment for freedom and self-determination guides our policy.'' The United States has never recognized the Soviet Union's forcible annexation in 1940 of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. But Bush has counseled restraint and dialogue since the Lithuanian parliament declared its independence March 11. Bush has repeatedly cautioned the Kremlin against using force to bring Lithuania into line, but he has also said the Baltic state must recognize ``certain realities'' of its ties to the Soviet Union. As Baker testified, Landsbergis told some members of Congress, ``It appears that the West doesn't want to help Lithuania. ... Our reaction is one of discouragement and disappointment. It feels as if our worst fears are being realized.'' Late Tuesday, the Senate Appropriations Committee inserted in a supplemental spending bill a provision setting aside $10 million to build and staff a U.S. embassy in Lithuania, should the United States formally recognize the Baltic republic's independence. In criticism less restrained than Mitchell's, Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., issued a statement voicing ``mounting outrage and frustration'' at the lack of a U.S. response to Moscow's moves. She said, ``The Soviets have got to get a message from the free world: You cannot keep your empire by the force of your guns.''

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Apartheid Leader: Supporters May Retaliate Against ANC Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a white supremacist group warned that his supporters will retaliate unless Nelson Mandela's African National Congress calls off its guerrilla campaign, a newspaper said Wednesday. Eugene TerreBlanche, head of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement, also told The Citizen newspaper that white South Africans would never accept a black government. He said President F.W. de Klerk's government was headed for collapse and massive unrest. ``We will not allow our people to be murdered. It looks to me as though the government is on the road to capitulation. We are not prepared to live under an ANC government, which will mean chaos,'' TerreBlanche was quoted as saying. In other developments: _Two senior ANC leaders _ general secretary Alfred Nzo and National Executive Commmittee member Joe Slovo _ were scheduled to return Friday to South Africa after decades in exile, the ANC said. Nzo and Slovo will be part of an 11-member ANC delegation to hold talks May 2-4 with the de Klerk government. _ Police said two police officers and four protesters were injured in clashes in various parts of the country when officers used shotguns, tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse demonstrators. Police, who gave few details, said 48 protesters were arrested in various incidents. _ The new military rulers in the nominally independent Ciskei homeland said they would grant amnesty to some prisoners in the tribal reserve. No details were available. The military rulers, sympathetic to the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups, came to power last month in a coup that ousted a conservative, authoritarian leader. De Klerk has expressed concern about right-wing white groups that are arming themselves to oppose sharing power with the nation's black majority. The talks in May are designed to clear the way for formal negotiations on changing the constitution to give blacks a voice in national affairs. TerreBlanche and other extremist leaders are forming a ``commando'' movement of armed followers to resist the end of white-minority rule. His movement is thought to number a few thousand. The ANC, the leading black political organization, has refused to formally halt its armed struggle even though the guerrilla campaign has been largely dormant for the past year. ``My message to ANC is that if it persists with its armed struggle, we will meet it head on,'' TerreBlanche said in the interview with The Citizen, which is pro-government.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Jazzman Dexter Gordon Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. CORRECTS 9th graf, `In 1980' to `In 1960.' Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Dexter Gordon, revered by jazz fans as a pioneering tenor saxophonist and known to filmgoers for his Oscar-nominated performance in the 1986 movie ``Round Midnight,'' died today. He was 67. Gordon died at 12:50 a.m. of kidney failure, said Don Lucoff, spokesman for Blue Note Records in New York. He said Gordon had been in poor health and was admitted to Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia on March 18 for treatment of cancer of the larynx. Nevertheless, Gordon recently had finished filming ``Awakenings,'' a movie with Robert DeNiro and Robin Williams. ``It's very, very difficult to even contemplate that we've lost such a great master of his instrument and icredible human being,'' said guitarist George Benson. ``He was quite a man.'' In the 1940s Gordon helped define the bebop style of jazz begun by Lester Young, Charlie Parker and John Coltrane, and his playing influenced future generations of musicians. Critics hailed his combination of Young's melodic approach with the hard-driving sound and complex harmonics of Coleman Hawkins and Parker. Gordon, born in Los Angeles, began his career with the big bands of America, including those of Lionel Hampton, Louis Armstrong and Billy Eckstine. He fell on hard times in the 1950s as bebop fell from favor and served a two-year prison sentence in California. In 1962 he moved to Paris and spent the next 14 years as part of the expatriate jazz scene that inspired ``Round Midnight.'' In 1960, he acted in a play, ``The Connection,'' and began a series of albums on the Blue Note label that re-established his reputation and brought his sound to a new generation of fans. The movie, about an aging, fading saxophonist in a Paris club whose health and career are revived by a young French fan, was largely based on the life of pianist Bud Powell, but had many parallels with Gordon's life. Gordon _ raspy voiced, world-weary, his 6-foot-5 frame tottering from the ravages of drugs and drink _ was a compelling figure in the film, and he received widespread acclaim. It was the first time in Academy Award history that a musician was nominated for the best-actor Oscar. He managed to record five albums for Blue Note between 1961-65, the most outstanding ``Dexter Gordon'' with its cross section of styles. ``Don't Explain demonstrated his moody range on ballads. Gordon's other records include ``Long Tall Dexter,'' ``Savoy: Our Man in Paris,'' ``Go,'' ``Homecoming'' and ``Swinging Affair,'' ``Dexter Gordon, Swiss Nights,'' ``True Blue,'' ``More Than You Know,'' ``Dexter Quartet,'' ``I Found a New Baby,'' ``Long Tall Dexter, 1946, The Chase, 1947, Doin' Alright, 1961, Dexter Calling, A Swingin' Affair, One Flight Up, Our Man in Paris, 1963, Homecoming, 1976. A memorial was planned for May 6 in New York, Lucoff said.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Eyes Peer Over Horizon With Radar System
DOC.TEXT: A new radar system that will allow military observers to look over the Earth's horizon and get an earlier warning of enemy aircraft or drug-smuggling planes has been turned over to the Air Force. By being able to detect enemy aircraft farther away, the Air Force gets as long as 3{ hours to respond to a threat of an attack, compared with perhaps only a few minutes with conventional radar systems, officials said. The $680 million Backscatter system turned over to the military Tuesday gives the Air Force eyes over a semi-circular, 4.5 million-square-mile swath across the Atlantic from Greenland to Cuba, the Air Force said. The operations center is based in the outskirts of this central Maine city and the antennas are in Moscow _ Moscow, Maine, that is. The Maine system is the first of four that will eventually form an early warning shield around most of North America's perimeter. Its range of up to 1,800 miles is nearly 10 times greater than than of conventional radar. While the over-the-horizon system was designed primarily to give the Air Force more time to spot enemy bombers, it will also be useful in detecting small planes carrying illegal narcotics, said Col. John O. Lenz, the system's program director. Enemy cruise missiles, however, would be ``a very difficult target ... perhaps the most difficult target for this type of radar,'' Lenz said after the Air Force took possession of the Bangor operations center from General Electric Co. The Air Force plans to hire private contractors to run the operations center by mid-1992, although the most sensitive decision-making roles _ such as whether to call for a military response to an errant plane _ will remain in military hands. U.S. and Canadian air force personnel are currently staffing the center. A bank of 16 computer systems collects the required flight plans from all planes that enter the Backscatter system's range, telling technicians whether aircraft represented by blips on their computer screens belong in that airspace. ``If they don't have a flight plan, it enables the operator to say, `I'd better take another look at this,''' said Capt. Alan M. Chilton of the Canadian Air Force. The system gains its extraordinary reach by bouncing radar signals off the Earth's ionosphere, enabling the radar to hopscotch over the planet's curve. That layer of the atmosphere is also responsible for bouncing shortwave radio signals around the world. The radar signal begins its journey from three, 3,600-foot-long antenna arrays in the western Maine town of Moscow. Return signals bouncing back from aircraft are picked up 100 miles away by three receivers, each nearly a mile long, in the town of Columbia Falls. A similar over-the-horizon system with components in California, Idaho and Oregon is 90 percent complete and is expected to come on line in about a year. Its range will be a half donut-shaped area across the Pacific from Alaska to south of Baja, Mexico. The planned central system, with components in North Dakota, South Dakota and Minnesota, will focus on the southern part of the continent. An Alaskan system will point toward the western part of the Soviet Union. The system is not effective directly north of the continent because of electrical disturbances in the atmosphere that produce the northern lights. Conventional radar guards against intruders from the north.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins, But Then Halted, for Man Accused of Lying About Bush, Iranians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4th graf to UPDATE with trial halted after defendant hospitalized. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Assistant U.S...'.
DOC.TEXT: The trial of a man accused of falsely claiming that George Bush sought an arms-for-hostages deal from Iranians 10 years ago was halted today after he was hospitalized with chest pains. Richard Brenneke was in fair condition in St. Vincent Hospital & Medical Center, where he was taken Tuesday night, hours after testimony in his trial got under way. He has a history of heart problems. Brenneke claims then-vice presidential candidate Bush met in Paris with Iranians a couple of weeks before the 1980 election in hopes of freeing the Americans held in the Tehran embassy and boosting Ronald Reagan's presidential campaign. Brenneke, 48, a Lake Oswego businessman, is charged in federal court with one count of lying under oath and could face up to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine if convicted. Assistant U.S. Attorney Thomas O'Rourke said in his opening statement Tuesday that he would show that Brenneke lied when he testified about the alleged meeting and when he said he and another man were contract employees of the CIA. Brenneke's lawyer, Michael Scott, told the jury in his opening statements that Reagan campaign officials ``were scared pea green that President Jimmy Carter would succeed'' in winning freedom before the presidential election for the Americans taken hostage in Tehran in 1979. The Reagan administration years later sold arms to Iran as part of a scheme that benefited the Nicaraguan Contras and resulted in freedom for some hostages taken in Lebanon in the 1980s. But Reagan has denied even that exchange was an arms-for-hostages deal. Brenneke, a reputed private arms dealer who also claims to have knowledge of the Iran-Contra deal, made his disputed allegations while testifying in September 1988 at the federal trial of Heinrich Rupp, a Colorado gold dealer who was convicted of bank fraud. Brenneke claimed he and Rupp had both worked for the CIA and that Rupp flew Bush; the late CIA director William Casey; and Donald P. Gregg, now the U.S. ambassador to South Korea, to Paris for the alleged meeting. Brenneke said it took place Oct. 19-20, 1980. At the time, Casey was Reagan's campaign chairman and Gregg was a Bush adviser and National Security Council employee. At Tuesday's trial, Gregg and several other witnesses said the people allegedly involved in the Paris meeting never left the country at the time it was taking place. Gregg testified that he was vacationing with his wife and daughter at a friend's house at Bethany Beach, Del., at the time Brenneke claims the secret talks were held. Gregg showed snapshots taken during the vacation and said it consisted mostly of ``seafood dinners, swimming, tennis, reading and naps.'' Brenneke's name surfaced from time to time during the Iran-Contra affiar. He told The New York Times in November 1986, about the time the affair first became public, that government sources told him early that year that the Defense Department was planning to use profits from the sale of arms to Iran to help the rebels in Nicaragua. Brenneke's name first surfaced publicly in February 1984 when an advertisement appeared in a Central American newspaper, saying he had arms for sale. He claimed at the time that he had never authorized or placed the ad.

DOC.HEAD: Construction of New Settlement Begins Amid Dispute in Old City
LaserPhoto JRL4
DOC.TEXT: Israel broke ground for a new Jewish settlement Wednesday in the Judean Desert, where bulldozers pushed aside rocks and a crane hoisted seven mobile homes into the clearing on a hilltop. Also Wednesday, officials said Attorney General Yosef Harish's office filed a brief with the Supreme Court urging the immediate eviction of 150 Jewish settlers from the Christian Arab quarter in Jerusalem's walled Old City. Enlisting the support of Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek and Police Commander Rahamim Comfort, the attorney general argued that the continued presence of Jewish settlers could provoke violence. The Supreme Court is expected to rule Thursday on appeals by the settlers to set aside lower court rulings ordering their eviction from a 72-room complex owned by the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate. Settlement activity has stepped up significantly since March 15, when hard-line Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir took the reins of a caretaker government. Previously, the center-left Labor Party had acted as a brake on settlements, but the Labor-Likud coalition collapsed March 15. The settlement campaign has had far-reaching repercussions, straining Israel's relations with the United States and endangering a $400 million housing loan request for Soviet Jewish immigrants. It has brought protests from American Jewish groups and even cast a shadow over the fate of Western hostages held in Lebanon by Shiite Moslem groups. In Alon, Jewish settlers raised glasses in a toast and watched as bulldozers smoothed the rocky ground for the mobile homes. ``In five years, there will be a big city here,'' settler leader Eliyakim Haetzni said, gesturing toward the barren hills surrounding Alon. It is halfway between Jerusalem and the biblical town of Jericho in the Jordan Valley. Another settler leader, Moshe Waysman, said 10 families and a few bachelors would move into Alon on Wednesday and that six more mobile homes would be added in the next few days. ``We want to live together in a pleasant environment, to have some land around our houses and to have a higher standard of living,'' Waysman said. The coalition agreement of the former Likud-Labor government called for eight new settlements to be built by 1992, but it did not include Alon. However, Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner insisted the construction did not violate the agreement, saying Alon is merely an expansion of the settlement of Kfar Adumim. But the sites are a mile apart, and no road connects them. Left-wing legislators, including Dedi Zucker of the Citizens Rights Movement, accused Shamir of exploiting the period of political uncertainty to push through settlement plans. In the past two weeks, the government has authorized construction of the Dugit settlement in the occupied Gaza Strip, and reportedly allowed preparation of four more settlements that were stalled while Labor was in the ruling coalition. In Jerusalem, the police commander warned that continued presence of the settlers in the Christian Arab quarter of the Old City in the face of court-ordered eviction ``may in itself be an inciting factor in this sensitive area.'' ``Every event in the area has influence on the fabric of relations, problematic these days, between members of different religions and faiths,'' Comfort said, according to an official who read portions of the document to The Associated Press. The document was filed with the attorney general's brief. The Old City is on land captured from Jordan during the 1967 Middle East war. It is divided into separate districts for Moslems, Jews and Christians. The settlers moved into St. John's Hospice April 11, claiming they had subleased the four-building complex from an Armenian Christian tenant. The Greek Orthodox Church says the lease is illegal. The church has been supported by two lower courts in its efforts to evict the settlers.

DOC.HEAD: University Bans Frontal Nudes From Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of California State University-Hayward who invited an artist to show her work on campus had no idea she had switched from painting plants to nudes. Audrey Yuen, who has exhibited her work on campus before, planned a three-week show in May at the University Union _ until officials discovered the change. Three paintings of fully nude women were in Yuen's proposed 10-nude exhibit. But the student union had never shown nude pictures before, much less full-frontal nudes. ``To me, it's art,'' the Oakland artist said. ``It's not anything lewd or lascivious.'' ``When they started saying, `We don't want anything below the waist,' it really took me aback,'' she said. ``They wanted me to cover them up. What do you do? Paste something on top? Put little black strips over them?'' In a last-minute compromise, Yuen and student union directors agreed Tuesday to an all-nude show featuring only above-the-waist nudes. University spokesman John Caine defended the compromise, saying the third-floor wall of the student union where Yuen's work will hang ``is not an art gallery by any means.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Demonstration By Striking Nurses
DOC.TEXT: Riot police broke up a demonstration Wednesday by striking nurses who gathered outside the health ministry to press their demands for better wages and working conditions. Several nurses were taken by truck to the central police station in downtown Harare for a talk with police officials, said a police spokesman. The spokesman, who by custom was not identified, denied any of the nurses had been arrested. He said that they had been removed from the health ministry so they could be advised about the legality of their actions. It is illegal for Zimbabweans employed in essential services to strike. Police authorization is routinely required for protests. Junior nurses have been staging a series of work stoppages since April 8, demanding better wages and working conditions. The ministry of health offered unspecified pay increases April 21, but most nurses vowed not to resume work until the raises were confirmed in writing. On Tuesday, armed riot police with dogs forced hundreds of striking nurses off the grounds of hospitals and clinics in Bulawayo, the country's second-largest city. Church officials appealed to the nurses Wednesday to return to work. The call came after mission workers in northeastern Zimbabwe blamed the nurses' action for the death of a man wounded by Mozambique rebels in a cross-border attack. The man allegedly bled to death after being turned away by nurses at a provincial hospital 55 miles northeast of Harare, the capital. Health authorities have disputed the allegations, saying the wounded man was treated by doctors at Bindura hospital and could not have been saved. Last year, scores of doctors were arrested for striking over poor pay and working conditions. They were jailed briefly under state of emergency laws.

DOC.HEAD: Mobutuo Names Former Professor To Head Transitional Government
DOC.TEXT: President Mobutu Sese Seko named a former professor Wednesday to head a transitional government that will oversee this central African country's move to a multiparty democracy, government sources said. The announcement came one day after Mobutu declared that he was lifting a 20-year ban on opposition parties and ending his ruling party's monopoly on power. Mobutu has wielded nearly absolute power since taking over in November 1965. He said the constitution would be rewritten and a transitional government set up to run the country until democratic elections are held within a year. On Wednesday, Mobutu appointed Lunda Bululu, secretary-general of the Economic Community of Central African States, as prime minister of the transitional government, said the government sources. The former professor will oversee the political transition as well as efforts to depoliticize the military, police and other key government branches. Mobutu has come under strong pressure at home and abroad to introduce democratic reforms. In January, he began a personal tour of the country, saying he wanted to determine support for his government. During the tour, many individuals and groups criticized his regime, saying it had allowed widespread corruption and impoverished the country. Opponents also accused the government of repressing dissent. Mobutu had repeatedly ruled out a multiparty system in the past. For almost 20 years, Zaireans were required to be members of the ruling Popular Movement for the Revolution party.

DOC.HEAD: French Airline Bans In-Flight Smoking After Passenger Survey
DOC.TEXT: The French airline Air Inter announced Wednesday it is banning smoking on all domestic flights after a two-month experiment found that 88 percent of passengers favored smoke-free flights. The carrier banned smoking as a temporary measure March 1. The announcement Wednesday said the restriction will be extended indefinitely due to the results of the survey conducted among passengers. The airline reported a poll of 5,500 passengers showed that 88 percent thought smoke-free flights were a good policy, with 96 percent of non-smokers and 72 percent of smokers favoring such a ban. About 36 percent of the airline's passengers smoke, the company said. Air Inter primarily serves domestic routes but has some flights to Rome, Lisbon and London.

DOC.HEAD: Census Counters Head Into the Streets
DOC.TEXT: By RANDOLPH E. SCHMID=

Census workers turn to door-to-door counting Thursday with the bureau facing escalating costs and criticism of its efforts so far this year. Only 63 percent of the nation's households have responded by mail, leaving the census takers the task of driving, riding and walking to the remainder of homes. Original plans had anticipated a 70 percent response, and the shortfall could help add $150 million or more to the projected $1.3 billion cost of the 1990 census. The work beginning Thursday covers more than 100 metropolitan areas across the nation, as counters try to track down folks who either didn't get a census form or failed to mail theirs back. Individual counting expands to an additional 300 smaller communities May 3, Census officials report. In rural areas, which were not included in the mail portion of the count, personal visits by census takers have been going on since March. The national head count began in March with the mailing of more than 95 million census forms. The official counters can be identified by their red, white and blue identification badges and satchels, the bureau reported. Although the house-to-house count is now starting, government officials continue to encourage Americans to mail back forms if they have not done so. Counting Americans at home will continue at least through June, officials report, longer if needed. Members of Congress have been highly critical of the early census effort, noting that large areas of some big cities have been overlooked in the mail count. In addition, a coalition of cities and interest groups has filed suit against the bureau, contending that minorities are being undercounted and seeking to force a statistical adjustment of the final census figures.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Ends After All Night Session
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity ended its national congress Wednesday after an all-night session attended by chairman Lech Walesa, who said the union now is united to face Poland's problems. ``Now we have the mandate. We are organized for when life brings its problems,'' said a proud Walesa from the rostrum as the congress ended at 8 a.m. The seven-day congress, the trade union's second, re-elected Walesa as chairman. It also approved a new charter and program and chose a 96-member national commission, ending long-simmering disputes about the legitimacy of Solidarity's leadership structure after the chaos caused by martial law in 1981. The new program calls for Solidarity to concentrate mainly on trade union issues while not withdrawing totally from its role as a broad political movement. The union retains the option to create its own political party if it sees the need. ``The solutions are not perfect, but in the present situation, perfect solutions do not exist,'' Walesa said. ``The essence of the congress was, when a chance lies ahead for the country, to be united and organized. As a practical person, I am happy about this,'' he said. The congress gave an overwhelming vote of confidence to Walesa's leadership since the union's first congress in October 1981. He has guided the union from its years as an underground organization through the long negotiations that led to its regaining legal status a year ago. The same negotiations opened the door to a Solidarity-led government for Poland, which led the wave of reform in the East bloc. ``The position of Walesa is now really indisputable,'' said one Warsaw delegate, Marcin Przybylowicz. Still, Walesa did come under criticism for his authoritarian style of leadership during the debates. In closing remarks, he appeared to be trying to make amends. ``This congress brought a few surprises. It did not go exactly along with my concept. But I never took the floor _ even though my tongue was jumping out _because I did not want to disturb democracy,'' he said. Many delegates emerged from the meeting convinced Walesa is planning a bid for Poland's presidency, using the union as a base. Walesa has been evasive in discussing his presidential plans. President Wojciech Jaruzelski's term ends in 1995. The congress, however, passed a resolution calling for new parliamentary and presidential elections by the spring of 1991. ``He is citizen No. 1 in this country, and if the alternative is Jaruzelski, of course it is great'' if he runs, said delegate Jan Waszkiewicz of Walesa. But other union members appeared disappointed at the prospect. ``Myself and others would feel cheated if he ran for the chairman of the union with the intention of becoming president,'' said Alojzy Pietrzyk, the miners' leader for the region of Silesia. Walesa and the new national commission were elected to serve a three-year term, and the next national solidarity congress is to be held in one year. The congress took place in a calm atmosphere that contrasted sharply with its last stormy 18-day meeting in 1981. That took place under a barrage of hostile criticism from Communist authorities in Warsaw, Moscow and other East bloc capitals. In 1981, crowds gathered outside the Oliva Sports Hall to be close to the debates. There were no similar displays of enthusiasm this time, with life in Gdansk proceeding normally. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and Deputy Prime Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, architect of Poland's stringent economic reform program, made appearances at the congress. But relations between Solidarity and the government it helped create remained uneasy. A minority of delegates advocated the union make a clean break with the government's painful economic policies and concentrate on protecting workers' interests.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT spelling of rescind. Moves 9th graf pvs `He said ...' to 3rd graf
DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Again For Line-Item Veto
DOC.TEXT: President Bush appealed anew Wednesday for a line-item veto and broader power to rescind funds Congress has appropriated. ``The president needs the power to make the tough calls on spending, take the heat _ and I'm perfectly prepared to do that,'' said Bush, also urging that the Constitution be amended to require a balanced budget. He said seven of his predecessors had requested line-item veto authority, which Congress refused to grant. A total of 43 governors already possess such power. The government this year is running a deficit of $150 billion; Bush has proposed a $63 billion deficit for next year's budget. Bush was surrounded by Republican lawmakers, Cabinet officers and budget chief Richard Darman during a brief White House ceremony at which as he signed messages sending his proposed changes to Capitol Hill. His three-part strategy entails: _A proposed constitutional amendment giving the president line-item veto authority. _Support for a Legislative Line Item Veto Act, which would widen his power to rescind funds already appropriated by Congress. _Endorsement of the balanced budget amendment introduced by Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. Under current law, a president can only veto an entire piece of legislation. The president cannot excise particular expenditures the White House finds objectionable. Bush said he needs a way to avoid ``unnecessary expenditures ... without sacrificing entire legislative enactments.'' The Legislative Line Item Veto Act would strengthen the president's hand in rescinding funds already appropriated by Congress. ``Congress can reject a presidential rescission simply by inaction,'' Bush said, noting a 1974 recission law. ``And that's precisely what's happened to the vast majority of rescission proposals. ``I ask Congress to require an up or down vote on presidential rescissions.''

DOC.HEAD: Social Worker Acquitted in Failing to Report Suspected Abuse
DOC.TEXT: Jurors on Wednesday acquitted a state child-protection worker of failing to report suspected abuse before the death of a toddler who allegedly had been dunked in a toilet for soiling his pants. Shirley Duboise, a former foster care counselor, was among four state Health and Rehabilitative Services workers charged in the July 28 death of 2-year-old Bradley McGee. Despite complaints from the boy's foster parents, Bradley was returned to his biological parents, Thomas and Sheryl Coe of Lakeland, two months before he died. He had been submerged repeatedly in a toilet, authorities said. Never before have Florida child-care workers been charged over their handling of a case. With Wednesday's verdict, two have been acquitted at trial, charges were dropped against one, and the fourth is awaiting trial. The three-day trial that ended Wednesday boiled down to a battle of credibility between the 43-year-old defendant and foster mother Pam Kirkland. Bradley was abandoned as an infant and in foster care most of his life, but was sent periodically to his parents for visits. Mrs. Kirkland testified that Bradley came home from one visit emotionally upset with a cuts on his hand, a cigarette burn and a red mark behind his ear. She said her complaints were ignored. Ms. Duboise testified that the last time she saw the boy, April 26, 1989, she didn't suspect abuse. ``Bradley had a little sore on his hand and a little sore, a splinter or something of that kind, on the tip of his little finger,'' Ms. Duboise testified. ``I had no reason to believe Bradley had been abused either through his behavior or his physical condition.'' After the verdict, Ms. Duboise criticized the prosecutors, saying they had not fully investigated the case. She had rejected a plea bargain on the misdemeanor that was punishable by 60 days in jail. Ms. Duboise resigned her post shortly after the boy died. Bradley's parents were charged with first-degree murder in the case. Mrs. Coe was sentenced last week to 30 years in prison after pleading guilty to a charge of second-degree murder. Coe's trial is scheduled for July.

DOC.HEAD: Subcommittee OKs Legislation to Allow Food Giveaways
DOC.TEXT: A House Agriculture subcommittee Wednesday approved a foreign trade section of the 1990 farm bill that would allow food giveaways to needy countries. The legislation is similar to the Senate measure on foreign trade approved in committee earlier this month. The farm bill will set agriculture policy for the next five years. The major difference between the two bills is the way the food aid programs would be managed within the government, according to a House subcommittee spokeswoman. Both bills would allow the president to give food to countries whose governments he wants to encourage, such as those in Eastern Europe. Such assistance now must be in the form of a sale. The bills also allow the United States to forgive the debts of financially strapped countries trying to restructure their economies. Both the House and the Senate followed Bush administration recommendations in writing their bills. Ann Veneman, deputy undersecretary for international affairs and commodity programs, said the chief difference the administration has with either bill is in the language dealing with the Export Enhancement Program. The program offers exporters bonuses for sales of certain products to particular countries and is used to reduce the cost of U.S. goods in the international marketplace. The Senate bill says the Agriculture Department must spend at least $900 million in fiscal 1991 on the program; the House version requires that $500 million be spent. The administration does not want any specific dollar amount named. ``It's a trade-policy tool,'' Veneman said, adding that the amount spent should be the prerogative of the administration.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: The female majority on the Sacramento City Council is inspiring sensitivity to feminist issues _ and so the city's Public Works Department is seeking a synonym for ``manhole.'' Among early candidates: ``person-access chamber,'' plus a few entries involving risque or humorous acronymns. The manager of the department's engineering division, Thomas M. Finley, said Tuesday that the staff decided to seek the change after seeing Mayor Anne Rudin circle ``manhole'' on reports, and hearing her comments. Rudin praised the staff Tuesday for ``keeping up with contemporary standards.'' But Finley admitted: ``Honestly, I don't know if we'll come up with anything of value.'' Civil engineers Randy Witt and Shawn O'Brien jokingly suggested a ``Manhole Terminology Change Contest.'' Finley quickly put them in charge of organizing one. Witt and O'Brien set a May 4 deadline for entries and a May 9 announcement of winners. The prizes? First, a 40-mile all-expenses-paid trip to the foundry to see the new name cast in a cover plate. Second, a rubbing of a new cover plate. Third, the responsibility for changing all references to manhole in the city books.

Feathers will fly again Thursday as a judge wrestles with the age-old question _ which came first, the chicken or the law? Village Attorney Walter Ward has filed a civil suit in the continuing legal effort to force David and Lynda Ashley to stop harboring poultry. The Ashleys say the 17 cluckers are pets with names like Goobette and Nippy. Ward is asking a state judge for authority to remove the chickens from the Ashley property immediately pending a trial on the merits of the case. The request will be heard Thursday at the county courthouse in Waterloo. The case gained widespread attention after the Ashleys refused to obey a village ordinance against the keeping of livestock and poultry. Each served 10 days of 15-day jail sentences imposed by a village justice. The Ashleys have argued that they have a right to keep pet chickens as much as other people keep dogs and cats.

A real estate consultant said he paid for a billboard that states ``Desperately seeking Donald Trump or other developer to hire me!'' after conventional job hunting yielded no results. Bill Riddles, 38, posted the ad on a billboard on a city street last week. He moved here in January from Massachusetts, seeking a piece of the booming south Florida market. The $375-a-week billboard has prompted unusual phone calls, according to operators at Ding-A-Ling Answering Service, which answers the number on the billboard. The messages have ranged from ``This sign is horrible'' to ``We have an opening for a receptionist if you're interested,'' an operator said. One phony caller identified himself as ``the Donald'' and requested that Riddles call him in New York but didn't leave a number. Riddles said it was obvious the call was a fake. ``This is not a frivolous attempt at getting a job,'' he said. ``It is part of an overall strategy. But, the jury is still out as to whether this is an effective way to get a job.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Premier Predicts a Silent Spring
DOC.TEXT: Chinese Premier Li Peng, whose hard-line government cracked down on protesters clamoring for democracy one year ago, said Wednesday he is sure that this spring will be silent. Speaking at a news conference during the first visit to the Soviet Union by a Chinese head of government in 26 years, Li also acknowledged the fall of communism in Eastern Europe. But he said it was ``too early to say'' whether those nations would abandon socialism. He termed his Moscow visit a success because both nations agreed to reduce military forces along their common border and continue ``good-neighborly, friendly relations,'' although there was a hint the two longtime Communist rivals could not reach a complete agreement. A year ago this month, protesters in Beijing's Tiananmen Square set off a push for democracy that led to demonstrations across China. The protests overshadowed the visit to Beijing by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a visit that ended three decades of strained relations. ``Some believe that in April, May or June of this year, more disturbances will affect China, but I am sure that nothing of that sort will happen,'' Li said. The army killed hundreds of protesters on June 3-4 in Beijing. China has since arrested thousands of dissenters and tightened controls on society. ``Last year, this time around, I concentrated on handling these very delicate issues,'' he said. ``Now I am on an official visit to the Soviet Union, which means that the political situation in our country is stable.'' Asked whether China's handling of the demonstrators in Tiananmen Square could be a model for Gorbachev in his confrontation with the breakaway Baltic republic of Lithuania, Li refused to answer. ``I think this question was directed to the wrong address. It's of him (Gorbachev) that you should ask such questions,'' he said. Responding to another question, Li did acknowledge ``minor unrest'' in the western province of Xinjiang, Beijing's first admission of the incident. Regional television has reported 22 people were killed in rioting April 5-6 in the town of Akto, saying it was caused by Moslems trying to start a holy war. Li did not give a casualty toll but said the ``situation has stabilized.'' He said he expects China to maintain relations with the countries in Eastern Europe, ``whether they will abandon socialism or whether they will uphold the principles of socialism.'' Yet in a sign that China and the Soviet Union could not resolve all their differences during the summit meeting, Li said there would be no customary joint communique. No such statement would be issued, Li said, because his four-day visit was so short and ``more time and effort would be needed'' to work out a communique. He said that each side's concluding statement Thursday would have ``no radical differences.'' Li said China agreed to grant state credits to the Soviet Union to buy $333 million worth of Chinese consumer goods, such as textiles and other, unspecified light industry products. The Soviet Union suffers from chronic shortages of basic consumer goods. The Soviet Union will provide a credit to China to build two nuclear power stations that will generate 1 million megawatts each, he said. The 61-year-old premier, who studied engineering in Moscow from 1948 to 1954, said the two nations had economies that ``complemented one another'' and enabled them to reach the agreements. The military agreement provides for the mutual reduction of armed forces and military confidence-building measures along the two countries' 4,350-mile border. The nations have been negotiating the troop reductions for years.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Briefs Shamir on Arafat Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel on Wednesday briefed Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on a meeting he had with the leader of the PLO and offered his help in mediating between Israel and the Palestinians. Shamir, who opposes any dealings with the PLO, did not appear to take Havel up on his offer. Havel, who on his arrival earlier Wednesday became the first Eastern European leader to visit the Jewish state, met with PLO chief Yasser Arafat in Prague this month. ``(Havel) said he has a great interest in this conflict and would like to help. But he knows it is complicated. We did not discuss any specific steps that could be taken by Czechoslovakia in this respect,'' Shamir told reporters. Havel ``told me briefly about his meeting with Arafat,'' Shamir said. He refused to elaborate. Havel, 54, a playwright and former dissident, was quoted by the Hebrew daily Haaretz as saying Arafat assured him that the Palestine Liberation Organization wants Israel to adopt U.S. proposals for starting a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue. Arafat ``stressed repeatedly that he attaches great hopes to my peace mission,'' Havel said, but added he could not vouch for Arafat's sincerity. Shamir's spokesman, Avi Pazner, said no dialogue was possible with Arafat, either directly or through intermediarie. ``What Arafat wants is the disappearance of Israel. Therefore, we don't want to have any dialogue with Mr. Arafat, not direct or indirect,'' Pazner told The Associated Press. Referring to Havel, he added, ``Even if our friend has the best of intentions, we will not take him up on that.'' Havel also met with Foreign Minister Moshe Arens and Shimon Peres, head of the center-left Labor Party. Labor, which supports the U.S. peace proposals, is trying to form a new government. Shamir indicated he asked the Czechoslovak leader to allow Prague to serve as a transit point for flights of Soviet Jewish immigrants bound for Israel. ``We discussed our interest in the help from Czechoslovakia in the efforts to resolve the questions ... of the immigration of Jewish people from the Soviet Union to Israel,'' Shamir said without elaboration. Yosef Govrin, a senior Israeli foreign ministry official, said talks are under way on air connections and that flights could start by summer. Czechoslovakia has said it has been unable to serve as a transit point because it was unable to provide the necessary security. Arab militants have threatened to disrupt flights through East Europe to block the influx of Soviet Jews to Israel. Czechoslovakia and other Eastern European states, with the exception of Romania, followed the Kremlin's lead in cutting ties with Israel after the 1967 Middle East war, in which Israel seized land from Moscow's Arab allies. But Israel now has full diplomatic ties with Romania, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia as well as low-level ties with the Soviet Union. Negotiations are under way with East Germany and Bulgaria.

DOC.HEAD: Would-Be Congressman Told Tall Tale To Get Lukens' Campaign Advice
DOC.TEXT: An underdog Democrat told a tall tale to get campaign advice from the Ohio congressman he wants to replace, and now he's hoping to pick up votes by revealing the ruse. Ricky Lee Mattox, 28, admits he posed as an inquisitive college student to get Republican Rep. Donald ``Buz'' Lukens to offer an insider's insights on running for Congress. ``He confided in me tactics about his first and second campaigns that I thought were brilliant,'' the political neophyte said. With just two weeks to go before Ohio's primary elections, Mattox said he decided to come clean about the scheme because he felt guilty _ and to attract attention to his low-budget candidacy. The subterfuge occurred in February, when Lukens agreed to meet the undercover Mattox for breakfast to discuss wining campaign strategies. ``I came out of the meeting with a lot of respect for him,'' Mattox said. ``I've never met anyone with as much political knowledge.'' Lukens, who is fighting for his political life after his May 1989 conviction for having sex with a teen-age girl, remembered the tutorial with the 28-year-old. ``He seemed receptive. He seemed like a nice guy,'' the incumbent said. ``I am a little surprised that Ricky would go to that extent,'' Lukens said. ``If he had just told me he was Ricky Mattox I would have given the same advice.'' Mattox wasn't the first candidate to seek his advice, Lukens said. The congressman said he's advised seven or eight candidates over the past year. And in 1986, the eventual Democratic nominee for Lukens' seat went to Lukens before the primary seeking advice, the congressman said. ``It happens more often than you think,'' he said. Mattox, who is making his first bid for elective office, maintained he had nowhere else to turn as a Democratic candidate in a district that had sent Republicans to Congress for a generation. ``I wasn't receiving any advice from the Democratic Party here,'' he said. ``I wanted advice on campaigning. And Buz Lukens, even though people despise him, he's a very good politician.'' As it turned out, Mattox ignored much of what Lukens told him. But Lukens appears to be taking his own advice as he awaits the outcome of his appeal of a misdemeanor conviction for contributing to the unruliness of a minor. Lukens has been visible in his district, making the rounds of service-club breakfasts, farm group meetings and other small gatherings. His mother, Edith, maintains a similar schedule. While in the district, Lukens said, ``We try to average 22 to 27 events a day.'' As for his mother, ``She sometimes has 20 events herself.'' Lukens has steered clear of Republican meetings and candidate forums, since his official stance is that he's waiting for the 10th Ohio District Court of Appeals to rule on his appeal. Mattox made one other pre-primary confession, saying he has been deliberately misleading about the temporary, part-time job he took to make ends meet during the campaign. The former Navy missile technician, a structural engineer by training, routinely describes himself as a database operator for Essenza Corp. He works for an Essenza subsidiary, SDS Pizza, punching ordering information and bad-check records into the pizzeria's computers for $4 an hour.

DOC.BYLINE: GIs, Soviet Vets Meet Again at Point Where WWII Armies United ^By MARK FRITZ
DOC.TEXT: Soviets and Americans met again by the river Elbe on Wednesday, marveling at the imminent unity of Germany exactly 45 years after they helped cut it in two. Under gray skies and a light drizzle, about 100 World War II veterans watched a solemn ceremony as a wreath was laid in the grassy river delta where the armies of two invading nations came together. Soviet and U.S. veterans wearing medals from the historic military campaign clasped hands, embraced and traded war stories in the first Elbe reunion held on free German soil. Both armies invaded Torgau as they drove through Germany from opposite ends, formally linking up April 25, 1945. William Robertson, 66, was credited with leading one of two U.S. Army scout patrols that made the first contact with the Soviet forces. ``To us veterans it's a very big deal, but it probably isn't to most Americans,'' said the retired physician from Culver City, Calif. ``But the Elbe meeting touches something very deep in the hearts of the Soviets,'' he added. The last such reunion was in 1985 and drew about 25,000 people. It was orchestrated by the Soviets and the then-Communist East German government. The United States criticized it as a propaganda extravaganza. The gathering Wednesday was more low-key and attracted a crowd of only about 2,000 people to the river bank on the edge of this aging town 75 miles southeast of Berlin. Veterans marveled at the peaceful revolt that ousted East Germany's hard-line government. The popular uprising opened the way for democratic government and eventual unification with West Germany. The reunion Wednesday was planned in June 1989, when such events were unthinkable. ``It's very confusing for some of us older people. There has been a lot going on,'' said Soviet veteran Nikolai Sagoruko, 76, a former member of a Soviet mine-sweeping force. ``But we think good things are happening and hope it means peace.'' Soviets turned out in their green Red Army uniforms, their chests packed with medals and one little U.S. flag. Americans wore baseball caps and blue-and-white jackets. Two small American scout troops made contact with two small Soviet patrols along the river on that historic day in 1945, but it was the group Robertson led that set up the meeting of commanders from the two armies. ``The others were first, but we got the glory, the newspaper clippings,'' said Robertson. ``They had communications problems and nobody knew they made contact until the next day.'' Retired Lt. Gen. Vladimir Orloe, leader of the Soviet veterans contingent, said conflicting claims also existed between the two Soviet patrols about which was the first to make contact.
