Ivan Krutcheno, 72, said he was part of the first group of Soviet scouts. ``We came here and saw Americans and we thought we were in America, we had traveled for so long,'' he said. The veterans gathered at a cemetery to lay a wreath at the graves of Soviet soldiers killed in Torgau. They later placed a wreath on the grave of Joseph Polowsky, an American soldier who won unusual acclaim in the Soviet Union with his efforts to arrange the periodic Torgau reunions. Polowsky, a New York City cab driver who died in 1983, insisted he be buried at Torgau. ``He just thought it was so beautiful here,'' said Bill Beswick, 65, of West Point, Va., who was a pallbearer at Polowsky's funeral and one of the first soldiers to reach the Elbe. Leonard Addorisio, 66, of Hartford, Conn., said he was amazed at the camaraderie shown by the Soviet veterans. ``Everyone is so good, so friendly, you wonder why there are wars,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister: France Still Honors Embargo Against Libya
DOC.TEXT: France will continue to honor sanctions imposed by the European Economic Community against Libya in 1986, despite Libya's role in the freeing of a French hostage, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said Wednesday. ``The decisions of the EEC are respected and applied,'' Dumas said in response to questions in the National Assembly. ``France is waiting for new decisions to be taken ... before changing its stance.'' The EEC imposed a range of sanctions in 1986, citing Libyan backing for terrorist groups. Frenchwoman Jacqueline Valente, Fernand Houtekins of Belgium and their daughter, Sophie-Liberte, were freed in Beirut on April 10 by members of Fatah-Revolutionary Council, a radical Palestinian group led by Abu Nidal. The group is backed by Libya. France has ``no official contact with the hostage-takers'' and engaged in ``state-to-state negotiations'' in order to obtain the hostages' release, Dumas said. There was widespread criticism in the Western media when Dumas praised Libya's leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi, for a ``humanitarian'' gesture in pushing for the hostages' release. Some French newspapers have asserted that the hostages in fact were seized by Libyan forces and only later turned over to Abu Nidal's group. Dumas rejected as hypocritical the accusations that France is being too conciliatory toward Libya. He asserted that 5,000 Britons were working in Libya's petrochemical industry and said West Germany, Italy, Japan and South Korea all had more economic ties with Libya than France had. Dumas for the first time gave a chronological summary of the contacts that led to the hostages' release. He said the French government in July 1988 asked Morocco's King Hassan II to confer with Gadhafi about the hostages. This led to a meeting in Morocco between French and Libyan representatives. Dumas said France also obtained help from President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who discussed the matter with Gadhafi in February. On April 4, Gadhafi publicly appealed for the release of Ms. Valente and her family. French officials have denied any connection between the hostages' release and France's decision in March to allow the delivery of three French-made warplanes to Libya after a four-year embargo. Libya had purchased the planes previously, but they were back in France for repairs when French officials decided to block their return.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf of 2nd item to UPDATE with publicist declining comment
DOC.TEXT: Two stunt men sued actor Sylvester Stallone and the producers of the movie ``Rocky V,'' claiming their bones were broken while filming fight scenes with a professional boxer. In a Superior Court suit filed Tuesday, Todd Champion and Stephen Santosusso say they had been assured they wouldn't get hurt. The suit claims that pro boxer Tommy Morrison broke Santosusso's jaw during filming March 14. The next day, Champion stepped in and suffered a fractured right eye socket, the suit says. Defendants named in the suit include ``Rocky'' star Stallone, Morrison, director John Avildsen and producers Irwin Winkler and Robert Chartoff. It seeks unspecified general and punitive damages and reimbursement for medical expenses. Dave Fulton, the publicist for ``Rocky V,'' said Wednesday the defendants had not yet been served papers and would have no comment.

DOC.HEAD: FDA to Consider Home AIDS Tests
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration will reconsider its long-standing opposition to home AIDS test kits, officials said Wednesday. ``Some people say it would encourage more people to be tested for AIDS, and if they (test) positive and got into the medical system they could get early treatment,'' said Dr. Paul Parkman, director of the FDA's center for biologics evaluation and research. ``I'm not sure all that will happen, but that's how we want to evaluate the system.'' FDA officials said they were persuaded to rethink their opposition because of medical advances in treatment, such as use of AZT to slow the progression of the disease in its early stages. Parkman said the FDA still has concerns about the home kits, which would enable people to send a small blood sample to a laboratory and get the results by telephone. ``It's not a sure thing. This is not tantamount to saying the FDA is going to approve this,'' Parkman said. ``We're still being cautious. We think it's an area that can be studied to see if the risks outweigh the benefits and whether the product can be used effectively.'' Also Wednesday, the FDA licensed the first test kit that detects antibodies to the human immunodeficiency virus type 2, or HIV-2, a second but rare cause of AIDS. Only 17 cases of HIV-2 infection have been reported in the United States; most HIV-2 infections have occurred in West Africa and Central Africa. The virus is spread the same way as HIV-1 _ primarily through sexual contact with an infected partner, sharing needles with an infected IV drug user and contaminated blood and blood products. Parkman said the FDA isn't requiring blood banks to use the HIV-2 test now because the virus isn't considered a threat to the U.S. blood supply. Blood banks screen blood for HIV-1 antibodies and don't accept blood from immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa. An FDA advisory committee last week recommended the agency lift its ban on blood donations from black African immigrants if a blood bank tests for HIV-2 as well as HIV-1. Parkman said the FDA has accepted one application for a home AIDS test kit, from University Hospital Laboratories Corp. in Bethesda, Md. However, he said a lawsuit filed by the company last month seeking to force the FDA to accept its application had no effect on the decision. The lawsuit was settled April 10, said Elliott Millenson, president of University Hospital Laboratories, which filed its FDA application in December 1987. ``I think our lawsuit forced the FDA to re-examine the issue, but I'm delighted with the decison,'' he said. The FDA has sent letters about the policy change to about 30 other companies that are developing test kits or have expressed interest in doing so, Parkman said. Until now, the FDA has refused to accept home test kit applications because of technical concerns, such as how well people could be instructed with written material to draw their own blood and whether samples could be shipped safely through the mail. The agency also worried about how people using the tests would be counseled about the disease. One technical innovation that has eased FDA officials' minds about home testing is a process by which a small amount of blood drawn with a finger prick can be stored on a sheet of filter paper and sent to a laboratory.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Space Telescope Deployed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs. Recasts lead to include equipment problem.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1
DOC.TEXT: Discovery's astronauts overcame balky equipment to send the Hubble Space Telescope floating free from the shuttle today on a 15-year quest for secrets of the universe. The $1.5 billion telescope began orbiting Earth every 97.3 minutes at an altitude of 380 miles _ high above the atmosphere, which has limited the view of ground-based telecopes. ``Discovery, go for Hubble release,'' Mission Control told the crew at 3:37 p.m. EDT. The event occurred a minute later as the shuttle slowly and carefully backed away. The final hours before its release were a nightmare for ground controllers as they commanded the unfurling of two solar panels that power the telescope's instruments. The starboard panel balked twice as it was being pulled from its reel. Mission Control ordered space-walking astronauts to be ready to go out of the cabin to help. But there was a third try and it was successful. ``We have confirmation that the solar array wing on the starboard side has been deployed,'' the telescope control center in Maryland said. ``So we have good news,'' said Dave Drachlis, of the Hubble control center. The deployment of the two 39-foot panels allowed sun power to flow into the telescope's batteries, relieving worries that they would use up their eight-hour charge. Before astronaut Steve Hawley was able to lift the 12{-ton telescope from the cargo bay with the shuttle's mechanical arm, its instruments had to be disconnected from the shuttle's power and shifted over to the batteries. ``Precisely one day after lifting off from Launch Pad 39B at Kennedy Space Center, the Hubble Space Telescope is ready to fly on its own,'' Mission Control's Jeffrey Carr said. ``The game has begun. The race is on. The clock is ticking.'' Astronauts Kathryn Sullivan and Bruce McCandless put on spacesuits and entered an airlock in order to be ready to walk outside and pull out the array had mechanical deployment of the solar panels failed. Cameras aboard Discovery showed the telescope, being held at the end of a 50-foot crane, reflecting sunlight from its silver surface and a turning Earth in the background. Earlier this morning, Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver maneuvered the shuttle into its deployment position, with its nose pointed toward the sun. That was to put the telescope's solar arrays, once unfurled, at the proper angle to quickly start collecting energy and protect the telescope's fixed star trackers while the instrument was being held above the payload bay. Discovery is in orbit 380 miles above Earth, 70 miles higher than any previous shuttle. The orbit was dictated by the need to put the telescope above the Earth's distorting atmosphere. ``For those technically inclined this morning, I'd like to pass on the quote of the day from the on-board astronomer (Hawley), something to the effect that the big marble sure looks far away today,'' Shriver said. The five astronauts' busy day began on a musical note early this morning as Mission Control played a song called ``Space is Our World,'' written by members of Discovery's training team and a Houston-area group, Private Numbers. Controllers monitoring the telescope at Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland said Tuesday that no problems had been detected so far aboard Hubble, the most expensive and complex unmanned spacecraft ever built. ``Everything has just being going like clockwork,'' said Ron Schlagheck, shift director of orbital verifications at Goddard. ``Everybody is in excellent spirits.'' The Hubble telescope, delayed by technical problems and the 1986 Challenger accident, has waited seven years to take its place in space. It finally got a ride into orbit Tuesday morning aboard Discovery. Hubble will allow astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has taken 14 billion years to reach Earth. It is expected to provide clues to the age and size of the universe, and it may solve the mysteries of quasars, pulsars and black holes and even find stars with planets that could conceivably support life. The 24,250-pound telescope is 43 feet long and 14 feet in diameter, about the size of a railroad tank car. When it is in orbit, it will receive electrical power for its six scientific instruments from two winglike solar arrays. It is named for the late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, whose discovery during the 1920s that the universe is expanding gave rise to the Big Bang theory that the universe was created by a tremendous explosion 10 billion to 20 billion years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Seeks to Ease Workers' Fears About Economy
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev traveled to the depths of Russia on Wednesday to ease Soviets' fears about the transition to a market economy but also got an earful of complaints about empty store shelves. After a day of chats with workers in Sverdlovsk, an industrial center 870 miles east of Moscow, Gorbachev admitted: ``It's apparent that the people's expectations are at their limit. Their patience is at a limit.'' The Kremlin chief said he made the trip, his first since he was elected to the expanded post of executive president last month, to see how people feel about planned economic reforms. Major social unrest, including strikes, are feared if the government carries out a preliminary plan to free prices, establish a stock exchange, close inefficient industries and move toward making the ruble a freely convertible currency. Inflation and unemployment could result from the phasing out of price subsidies and the closure of unprofitable factories. Officials have said an economic safety net will be set up to help low-income families cope with the blows. Gorbachev assured the Sverdlovsk workers no final decisions had been made and won't be until May 10. The changes themselves are six to eight months away, he added. ``Someone is throwing out the idea that somebody at the top wants to raise prices, to introduce `shock therapy.' Don't believe it,''' he told a huge crowd gathered outside the gigantic UralMash machine-building complex. Nothing, he told the crowd, will be done behind their backs. Reports on Gorbachev's first day in Sverdlovsk filled a half-hour of Soviet TV's nightly newscast ``Vremya.'' That ensured a wide audience among this country's 280 million people would see their leader's attempts to soften the blow of radical economic reform. Gorbachev faced a storm of criticism from the crowd surrounding him over the shortages of fruits and vegetables, a TV correspondent said. The region ranks second in production in the Russian federation but 40th or 50th in housing, hospitals, schools and cultural establishments, the reporter noted. About 11,000 of UralMash's workers are living without adequate housing, another correspondent said. Conspicuously absent from the TV coverage of Gorbachev's visit _ and perhaps indicating the leadership's sensitivity to direct criticism _ was footage of the crowd complaining to the president. Such complaints were reported by the official news agency Tass. Tass said UralMash workers also complained that there were no TV sets and refrigerators in local stores and asked Gorbachev why Sverdlovsk residents don't see the goods they produce on store shelves. ``Everything that worries you worries me, too,'' Gorbachev responded. ``Many problems have accumulated. We must undo them soundly, all together. We are approaching that now, introducing structural changes, including every enterprise, every person in the economic reform.'' Gorbachev advised workers to brace for a ``painful stage'' in economic reform and appealed for help. ``We, there, must act more wisely, and you here must work more wisely. Otherwise, nothing will come of it,'' he said. Some workers hung out windows and others jumped in the crowd as they strained to hear their president. Foreign reporters were not allowed toaccompany Gorbachev to Sverdlovsk, a closed city that is the home ground of maverick Communist politician Boris N. Yeltsin and a center for rock music. Sverdlovsk residents have taken to the streets with their complaints several times over the past months, including a pre-New Year's protest over a shortage of vodka. Party officials stopped the protests by flooding the stores with reserves of vodka, but many of the city's 1.4 million residents remain unhappy about the lack of other rationed items, including meat, sugar and butter, the Soviet press has reported. Sverdlovsk is also one of several Russian centers where Communist Party members recently ousted their local chief and replaced him with a more progressive leader.

DOC.HEAD: Conference Debates Court-Ordered Secrecy Agreements
DOC.TEXT: Court-ordered secrecy agreements are helping hide information about dangerous products, environmental hazards, medical malpractice and unfair business practices, according to consumers, lawyers and journalists attending a conference Wednesday. But proponents of the agreements argued that the accords are private and should be maintained, that they are necessary to protect manufacturers' trade secrets and American competitiveness in international markets and that the civil court system is not designed to disseminate information obtained in litigation. Information gathered during a lawsuit can be kept secret through protective orders, confidentiality agreements or judicial sealing of files. Such arrangements prohibit lawsuit participants from distributing information they obtain, limit what can be shared with others not involved in the lawsuit or make all records in a case unavailable to the public. In some cases even the names of people or companies involved in a suit are kept secret, with the court record titled ``Sealed vs. Sealed.'' ``Secrecy buries critical facts ... and the public good is ignored and damaged'' by such practices, said Russ Herman, president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, as he opened the conference. ``In far too many of these cases, we're not talking about irrelevant facts better left in the files of the litigants,'' said Paul McMasters, deputy editorial director of USA Today. ``We're talking about documents and decisions involving unsafe products, dangerous drugs, toxic wastes _ all with potentially devastating effect on people unaware of the danger,'' added McMasters, who heads the freedom of information committee of the Society of Professional Journalists, cosponsor of Wednesday's conference. But James Morris III, a Virginia attorney, argued that the practice ``isn't limited to corporate information.'' ``You're personal papers are also in those files,'' he warned. ``If you can summons my medical records from my doctor, my diary from my psychiatrist or records of design from a company ... privacy goes out the window,'' said Morris. Herman argued that such arrangements ``keep vital health and safety information from the press, the regulatory agencies and the public.'' U.S. businesses are at a competitive disadvantage because international agreements don't force foreign companies to release the same extensive information, countered Morris. Opponents of the practice said the agreements have become a commonly used threat of lengthy legal battle and tactic to ``bribe'' injured people and their families into settlement. ``A compromise is a compromise,'' countered Morris. ``If you sue for $24 million and take $6 million you weren't bribed.'' People who bring lawsuits against companies for potentially dangerous products concede to the agreements because they can't afford to continue litigation and they want to go on with their lives, said Fred Barbee. Barbee's wife, Carol died after an artificial heart valve fractured. He later learned she might have been saved if emergency room doctors had treated her for the fractured valve and not the heart attack they thought she was having. Morris said the agreements are ``private litigation between private individuals and companies'' protected by the First Amendment. ``There is nothing in the First Amendment that says you are entitled to everything in a court file.'' ``How can you call it private unless you can limit it to my family?,'' asked Barbee. A proposal, backed by the Bush administration, to create a uniform federal standard for imposing punitive damages in product liability lawsuits and limit to two years most product liability claims is pending in a Senate subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills Six, Wounds Dozens; National Security Council Meets
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden in a dump truck exploded Wednesday as a military unit hunted for the leader of the Medellin drug cartel. At least six people were killed and nearly three dozen were wounded, police said. Acting President Horacio Serpa called an emergency meeting of the National Security Council. Tuesday night, just hours before he left for Nicaragua, President Virgilio Barco put the military in charge of two towns near Medellin. Scores of troops and armored cars mounted with cannons moved into the towns, Bello and Estrella, on Wednesday. The government has sent about 9,000 soldiers to the Medellin area in its battle against the drug barons. Another town on the outskirts of Medellin, Envigado, was put under military rule last month. The police said they are searching the area for the head of the Medellin cartel, Pablo Escobar. Wednesday's bombing came at 8:30 a.m. as a truck crept by with 20 members of Colombia's anti-terrorist strike force aboard. The blast destroyed a shoe store and a half-dozen automobiles and collapsed the roofs on several small stores and houses. Three bodies were found in the rubble of the shoe store, the Colombian radio chain Caracol said. A high school student waiting for a bus also was killed. The bomb killed four civilians and two policemen and wounded 26 civilians and eight policemen, Medellin Police Chief Col. Humberto Camero said. Many people aboard an old bus packed with passengers were wounded. Commuters, their clothes torn and their bodies bloodied, pleaded for help as they crawled from the bus' shattered windows, witnesses told Caracol. The Medellin cartel has killed 60 Medellin policemen so far this year in its effort to stop the government's policy of capturing drug traffickers and extraditing them to the United States. The cocaine cartel has offered a reward of $4,300 for each policeman murdered. It is believed to be responsible for shipping much of the cocaine that is smuggled into the United States. The bomb was the largest since April 11, when a car bomb exploded on a busy Medellin highway and killed 20 people, including eight members of the anti-terrorist police unit. More than 100 people were wounded. In communiques received by Colombian radio stations in the past month, the cartel has vowed to kill all policemen. Late last year the drug traffickers' bombings keyed on the capital of Bogota, killing about 200 people in scores of bombing attacks. The traffickers apparently have switched to Medellin because the army and police have moved thousands of officers into and around Medellin to try to find Escobar. An anti-narcotics agent, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press that authorities believe Escobar is in the Medellin area. He apparently is trying to hold together his multibillion-dollar drug empire, the agent said. Colombia has extradited 15 alleged cartel middlemen to be tried in the United States. Last December, police killed the man who was the second-most powerful member of the cartel, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. Government security forces have seized alleged traffickers' properties and have said they found nearly $50 million in U.S. cash, gold and platinum buried at confiscated ranches.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christian Forces Exchange Barrages, 13 Killed
DOC.TEXT: Artillery shells slammed into residential districts Wednesday as rival Christian forces exchanged barrages, killing 13 people and wounding 17, police said. Police said the shells fell on both sides of the Green Line dividing the city's Christian and Moslem sectors. Five people were killed and four wounded in Moslem west Beirut. Ambulances sped through the streets as people sought refuge in basements and air raid shelters. West Beirut has not been involved in the fighting between the Lebanese Forces militia led by Samir Geagea and the Christian troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun. However, stray shells frequently have fallen in west Beirut. Police said howitzer shells, rockets and tank cannon rounds also hit residential districts in east Beirut and the Christian hinterland north and northeast of the capital. The clashes raged despite repeated calls by Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir for a cease-fire. Sfeir, in an appeal broadcast by local radio stations, called on both Aoun and Geagea to ``stop fighting immediately. Have mercy on the population which has been suffering for a long time.'' The latest casualties raised the overall toll to 907 killed and 2,418 wounded since Geagea and Aoun began their struggle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave on Jan. 30. A police spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations, said Aoun's gunners concentrated their barrage from U.S.-made 155mm howitzers on sea ports controlled by Geagea's militia. ``The general is trying to impose a sea blockade on the Lebanese Forces, keeping all their ports shut by shellfire,'' the spokesman said. The shelling came two days after Geagea's gunboats blockaded Aoun's sole sea outlet on the Dbaye coast, north of Beirut. Radio stations controlled by the rival Christian forces repeatedly interrupted regular programming to broadcast reports about the duels and to warn civilians. The power struggle between Geagea and Aoun has led to the worst fighting among Christians in the country's 15-year-old multi-sided civil war. It has caused damage estimated at $1 billion. The clashes also have forced at least 400,000 of the 1 million people living in the Christian enclave to seek refuge in safer areas of Lebanon or abroad. Aoun does not recognize the Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi. He also opposes an Arab League-sponsored peace plan because it does not include a fixed timetable for the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon. Geagea has recognized Hrawi as head of state.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Group, Arab Mayor Criticize Israel
DOC.TEXT: Two American Jewish groups and the Arab mayor of Bethlehem are criticizing Israel for financing Jewish housing in the Christian sector of Jerusalem. ``This could be a precedent for more attacks on church property, Christian and Moslem, and I think that was a very foolish act,'' Mayor Elias Freij said Wednesday at a news conference. He also called the move ``a stupid thing.'' Robert J. Lifton, president, and Henry Siegman, executive director, of the American Jewish Congress expressed outrage over the ``clandestine effort.'' In a statement, Lifton and Siegman said the action threatens U.S. support of Israel and complicates the task of raising money from Jews around the world to help refuges from the Soviet Union settling in Israel. The Anti-Defamation League, a Jewish group dedicated to promoting civil rights, said the action ``gives ammunition to those wishing to upset the religious harmony in the holy city.'' The disputed Jewish housing is in the Christian sector of East Jerusalem, the predominantly Arab part of the city Israel captured from Jordanian troops in the 1967 war. Freij called East Jerusalem ``occupied territory'' and said the Israeli government's assistance to 150 new Jewish Soviet immigrants to live in a four-building complex owned by the Greek Orthodox Church ``is going to strain the situation to the extreme.'' The settlement issue is being decided by Israeli courts. Congress has been considering guaranteeing a $400 million loan to help resettle Soviet Jews in Israel. The Bush administration has conditioned its support for the legislation, now before the Senate, on a condition that Israel not use the money to house Soviet Jews in the territories occupied in the 1967 war. Freij, a self-described moderate, also criticized Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir for not accepting U.S. terms for talks with Palestinian Arabs. ``The Israelis are good at war,'' he said. ``They are bad when it comes to peace. They have a complex.'' Freij denied reports he had been threatened by Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat or that he ever called for a halt to the Palestinian rebellion on the West Bank and in Gaza. ``I respect him, he respects me,'' Freij said. The settling of Jewish refugees at St. John's Hospice was criticized Monday by the State Department as ``an insensitive and provocative act.'' David A. Harris, Washington representative of the American Jewish Committee, said Monday his group had expressed ``serious concern'' to the Israeli government over the issue. And Thomas A. Dine, executive director of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, questioned the timing of the move through an emissary to Shamir. Dine told the Prime Minister the Israeli government was ``doing great harm' to Israel's standing with the Bush administration and the American public, sources close to the situation reported. AIPAC is the largest pro-Israel lobbying group and over the years has managed to stop or stall U.S. arms sales to Arab countries hostile to Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Criminal Proceedings Begin on Alleged Iraqi `Super Gun' Project
DOC.TEXT: Customs officials on Wednesday began criminal proceedings against a British man allegedly involved in developing a suspected ``super gun'' project for Iraq. Christopher Cowley was charged with involvement in the attempted illegal export of equipment, a customs spokesman said. Sheffield Forgemasters, which made the eight giant tubes that the government claims are part of a gun, has identified Cowley as its main contact on the project. Cowley was employed by Space Research Corp., based in Belgium, which was founded by cannon designer Gerald Bull. Bull, a Canadian-born American citizen, was murdered in Brussels last month. Bull's son, Michel Bull, has said that Cowley left the company in 1988. The family announced last week that the company was going out of business. Customs said Cowley was charged with ``being knowingly concerned in the attempted illegal exportation of equipment with intent to evade a prohibition in force by virtue of the Export of Goods Control Order 1987-1989.'' Earlier Wednesday, the Trade and Industry Committee of the House of Commons said it would hold an inquiry into the alleged gun project. British customs officers seized eight sections of steel pipe April 12 at the port of Middlesbrough, and Foreign Office minister William Waldegrave said there is little doubt the cargo was intended to be part of a gun. The Iraqi government and Sheffield Forgemasters said the tubes were intended for a petrochemical plant. Sheffield Forgemasters said it had government permission to sell the pipes to Iraq. The parliamentary committee said its inquiry would cover export controls ``in relation to Iraq.'' The British government imposed an arms embargo on Iran and Iraq during their eight-year war and has not lifted it because no formal cease-fire has been signed. Customs officers have said the tubes built by Sheffield Forgemasters could be assembled to make a 131-foot-long gun barrel with a bore of about 39 inches. The company has said that 44 sections of tubing have already been delivered to Iraq. A second British company, Walter Somers Ltd., has also been involved in the investigation. Trucks carrying steel forgings from Somers were stopped in Turkey and Greece, and Greek authorities arrested a British driver. Somers has confirmed its order also came from Space Research in Brussels. Both companies have said they approached the government Department of Trade and Industry in 1988 for clearance.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Brings Token and Real U.S. Gifts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs new material after 9th graf pvs, The vice
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle brought symbolic gifts of flour and cooking oil, the first installment of $24 million in U.S. food aid, for Wednesday's presidential inauguration of Violeta Chamorro. He also brought word that President Bush, earlier in the day, approved $2.5 million in medical supplies because he ``recognizes the suffering of the people of Nicaragua.'' Bush also signed a formal declaration that Nicaragua is no longer a Marxist-Leninist country, restored its quota for sugar exports to the United States and made businesses wishing to invest in the Central American nation eligible for low-cost government loans. Quayle, the highest ranking U.S. official to visit Nicaragua sice then-President Carter in 1979, said Mrs. Chamorro faces ``herculean economic problems'' as she takes over from Daniel Ortega. Still, Quayle called Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration after his 11-year presidency ``the miracle of Managua.'' Talking with reporters as he flew to Managua, the vice president said, ``Many people thought this day would never happen. Many people thought democracy would never come to Nicaragua, and yet it has.'' Stopping his motorcade as it headed into the capital from the airport, Quayle told several boys waiting at a dilapidated bus stop that ``the U.S. wants to help you.'' The motorcade passed several buildings with anti-American slogans scrawled on their sides. As his limousine entered a baseball stadium for the inaugural, an object, apparently a piece of trash, was hurled toward his car and shouts of ``murderer'' arose from sections of the stands where Ortega's Sandinistas were seated. The vice president briefly shook hands with Ortega and later smiled tightly as Ortega, in his last speech as president, denounced ``close-minded politicians'' in the United States and called on Washington to ``stop dictating policies to Nicaragua.'' The vice president said afterward that he had ``only heard one-third'' of Ortega's speech, claiming a lot had been lost in the translation, which was provided by a State Department translator as Ortega spoke. As to Ortega's assertion that the United States had dictated policies to Nicaragua, Quayle said: ``We're not dictating our policies to Nicaragua. The people of Nicaragua determined their policy and their destiny.'' Earlier, Quayle said that if he had the chance to talk with the defeated leader, he would ``congratulate him for turning over power in a peaceful way'' and ``discuss how a responsible opposition conducts itself _ not engaging in intimidation and violence.'' The bags of flour and cooking oil Quayle carried with him on Air Force Two were to be followed later in the day by 1,000 tons of food being ferried into the country aboard 24 relief trucks. The food shipments, initially flown to a U.S. base in Honduras, were approved by Bush shortly after Mrs. Chamorro defeated Ortega in February. Some $21 million of the aid was transferred from other government relief efforts. In addition, $1.7 million in foodstuffs was designated for orphans and Nicaragua will receive aid from the Food for Progress program. Quayle also brought word that Bush had restored the 54,000-ton quota for sugar shipments to the United States, suspended by then-President Reagan in 1983 as part of an economic embargo against Ortega's government, and had approved the dispatch of medical supplies to hospitals and public health clinics that had run short of medicine. The aid Quayle announced Wednesday would be dwarfed by $300 million in recovery aid Bush has asked Congress to approve for this nation of 3.5 million people. Even if that assistance is approved _ it has been stalled in the Senate in a dispute over unrelated legislation _ Quayle said much more is needed to bring the Nicaraguan economy to its feet. ``She's got herculean economic problems. People are not only out of work, but they are pessimistic. It will take an international effort to rebuild Nicaragua.'' But he called Mrs. Chamorro's victory ``a moment of triumph and recovery'' and predicted she will be ``a symbol of unity.'' He declined to criticize Mrs. Chamorro's decision to retain Gen. Humberto Ortega _ the outgoing president's brother _ as head of the armed forces. ``It shows she is trying to reconcile the differences in her country. It's her decision and I'm certainly not going to second guess her,'' he said, adding that Gen. Ortega ``could be helpful in recapturing some of the arms they passed out to the Sandinistas during the transition.'' Expounding on her election, Quayle told a small crowd that welcomed him at the airport: ``The walls are crumbling everywhere as people are saying, `No more dictators. No more poverty. No more militaries.''

DOC.HEAD: President Honors 7 Crime Fighters
DOC.TEXT: President Bush honored seven citizens Wednesday who have struck back against crime, saying their grassroots efforts show Americans will do ``whatever it takes ... to take back the streets.'' They included John Walsh, creator of television's ``America's Most Wanted'' show, which Bush called the ``video version of the old post office `wanted' posters.''' Walsh, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., became an advocate for missing and abused children after the abduction and murder of his own son, Adam. Bush said that in less than two years on the air, ``America's Most Wanted'' has helped nabbed more than 100 criminals. That shows ``the people of this country are prepared to do whatever it takes for as long as it takes to take back the streets,'' said Bush. The others honored for helping victims of crime were: _Howard and Constance Clery, of Bryn Mawr, Pa., who founded a lobbying group called Security on Campus following the 1986 murder of their daughter Jeanne in her Lehigh University dormitory. _Milton Cole, of Jamaica Plain, Mass., founder of a community patrol in a Boston housing project. _Sandra Heverly, of Las Vegas, who became an activist for Mothers Against Drunk Driving in 1983 after a family tragedy caused by a drunken driver. _Dean G. Kilpatrick, of Charleston, S.C., credited with pioneering research on the impact of crime on victims and establishing a rape crisis center. _Emelia Olson, of Fort Thompson, S.D., who has helped channel victim assistance and services for Sioux Indian children on the Crow Creek Reservation. Bush also signed legislation designating this week as National Crime Victims' Rights Week.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Closes Investigation of DC Delegate Fauntroy
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department has declined to prosecute Walter E. Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's delegate to Congress, following a lengthy investigation of payroll practices in his office. Fauntroy, a Democrat who is running for mayor of the nation's capital, disclosed the Justice Department's decision in a statement that was released Tuesday. The Justice Department also confirmed that it had closed the investigation of Fauntroy's employment of Thomas John Savage, son of Rep. Gus Savage, D-Ill., at a time records indicated the younger Savage was living in Chicago. The Justice Department's decision removes a cloud that had been hanging over Fauntroy's campaign to succeed Mayor Marion Barry. The mayoral race was thrown wide open earlier this year when Barry was arrested on cocaine possession charges. Barry subsequently was indicted on charges of lying to a federal grand jury by denying previous drug use. The mayor's arrest in an FBI sting operation came just days before he was to announce his candidacy for a fourth term. Barry has since said he will not announce his decision about seeking re-election until after his trial, set to begin June 4. The Fauntroy probe was begun after The Associated Press reported in December 1988 that the younger Savage earned $21,398 working for Fauntroy between September 1987 and June 1988 _ a period Illinois records show he was living in Chicago to meet residency requirements for running for public office. Savage swore on election documents filed in connection with his unsuccessful campaign for the Illinois legislature that he was living in Chicago during the period in question. Asked whether the decision not to prosecute Fauntroy applied to any inquiry into actions by the younger Savage, Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said the ``action applies only to Delegate Fauntroy.'' He would not elaborate. Following the initial stories, Fauntroy denied any wrongdoing and said Savage worked as the Midwest coordinator for legislation that would grant statehood to the District of Columbia. Savage said he worked every day that he drew a salary as a member of Fauntroy's staff. The 15-month investigation examined the younger Savage's financial records to determine if he returned any of the money he had earned to Fauntroy or to his father, according to law enforcement sources. A federal grand jury subpoenaed records and took testimony as part of the investigation. Fauntroy was informed Monday of the Justice Department's decision to close the investigation, said his campaign press spokesman, Ivan Brandon. On Tuesday, Fauntroy issued a statement that he was ``pleased that this matter has been closed and that this will no longer have to divert attention from the real issues _ like drugs, crime and housing _ that are facing the city.''

DOC.HEAD: Block Wants to See Material from FBI Spying of Him
DOC.TEXT: Felix Bloch, the U.S. diplomat suspected of spying for the Soviet Union, wants to suppress information from FBI electronic surveillance of his activities, according to court papers. Bloch, who is fighting State Department efforts to fire him, was notified March 12 that the government would offer in his termination proceeding ``certain information derived from electronic surveillance,'' according to a Justice Department filing. Bloch asked the State Department to suppress the data ``on the ground that this electronic surveillance was unlawful,'' said the court papers filed by Justice Department attorney Richard Stearns. At the same time, Bloch is demanding from the government ``all audio, video or other recordings made of Mr. Bloch'' and all materials relating to the court authorization of surveillance of Bloch ``or any member of his family,'' according to a State Department document filed in the case. The government is seeking a ruling from U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Harris that the court-authorized electronic surveillance was legal. The government also opposes Bloch's demands for additional surveillance recordings and documents used to authorize the FBI activity. Surveillance in the Bloch matter was approved by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, a panel of federal judges. The Justice Department court papers, dated April 17, were filed as a civil case Tuesday in U.S. District Court. Bloch's lawyer was furnished copies of the audio tapes and transcripts of the electronic surveillance the government plans to use, said the Justice Department. In addition, Bloch was offered access to the monitoring logs of the surveillance operation. ``He has received information concerning the dates on which his conversations were overheard, as well as the fact that this electronic surveillance was authorized'' by the intelligence court, said the Justice Department. ``Accordingly, no further classified national security information need be released to Bloch or his counsel.'' Under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, Harris must decide the legality of the surveillance without an adversary hearing and based on FBI data, which Bloch must not be allowed to see, the government asserted. A secret FBI exhibit filed with the judge ``contains sensitive information concerning United States intelligence sources and methods and other information relating to United States efforts to conduct counterintelligence investigations,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in an affidavit. Having an adversary hearing or disclosing to anyone besides the judge data in the FBI exhibit and concerning the surveillance ``would harm the national security of the United States,'' said the attorney general. Thornburgh authorized the State Department to use information from the electronic surveillance in its employment termination proceeding against Bloch. The State Department announced Feb. 8 that Bloch had been suspended, his annual salary of $80,700 was being withheld and steps were being taken to fire him. The administrative hearing in Bloch's case is scheduled to begin May 7 before a three-person Foreign Service review board, which has the option of reinstating him. Bloch is a 30-year foreign service officer who the State Department put on paid leave June 22, 1989. Soon after, the State Department announced the FBI was investigating him for ``illegal activities'' involving ``agents of a foreign intelligence service.'' No criminal charges have been filed against Bloch.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Says Consumers Like Beef Labeling Change
DOC.TEXT: A change in federal labeling for lean beef has gone over well with consumers, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The labeling took effect in November 1987 after consumers and industry petitioned USDA for a name change in official federal beef grading, said Jimmy Wise of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service. ``Consumers told us they wanted a more positive description of leaner meat available in grocery stores, and they got it,'' he said. The change involved scrapping the 60-year-old ``USDA Good'' label and substituting a ``USDA Lean'' label on supermarket cuts. Many nutrition-conscious consumers wanted the name change because they felt the ``Good'' label misled buyers into thinking the beef was mediocre. When the label was established in the 1920s, it described the amount of fat, or marbling, in a cut of beef. A common consumer view was that less fat was more healthful and that the ``Good'' label wasn't very descriptive.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jews Protest Israeli Absorption Failures
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Jewish immigrants demonstrated Wednesday near Israel's parliament, accusing the government of failing to come up with a clear plan of absorbing the flood of Soviet Jews. A senior official at the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, which helps handle immigration, said meanwhile that absorption failures may lead to an ``historic mistake'' of stopping the expected Soviet Jewish influx, Israel radio reported. ``There is no system of decision-making and I don't see it being formed tomorrow morning,'' agency treasurer Meir Shitreet said in a broadcast lecture. The immigration has been spurred by growing anxiety over the Soviet Union's future and the spread of anti-Semitism there, as well as by U.S. visa restrictions. It is expected to total 100,000 this year. About 24,200 Soviet Jews have arrived so far this year, according to figures released by Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz and cited by Israel radio. The wave has caused housing shortages and the immigrants also face Israel's increasing unemployment rate and bureaucracy. The Housing Ministry is expected to present to the parliament on Thursday a program of building 32,500 apartments for Soviet Jews, Israel Television said. It said the program does not include plans to build housing in the Israeli-occupied territories. The Arab world, especially, has complained that Israel plans to settle Soviet Jews in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, lands seized from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war.

DOC.HEAD: Replantings in National Forests a Record
DOC.TEXT: A record 492,000 acres of national forest land was replanted with trees last year, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Forest Service Chief F. Dale Robertson said the acreage was the most since the national forest system was created in 1905. Robertson said last year's effort was due in part to rehabilitation work in areas burned by the major fires of 1987 in California, Oregon and Washington, and to high levels of reforestation in areas of 1986-88 timber harvests in the national forests. Of the total area reforested in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, about 307,000 acres were directly seeded or planted with trees. The remaining 185,000 acres were reforested through natural regeneration, by seed falling from nearby trees onto areas prepared by the Forest Service, or through sprouting. Robertson said the previous record was 434,000 acres reforested in 1980. An estimated 460,000 acres will be reforested this fiscal year, he said. A spokesman said that on the average four or five trees are planted for each one harvested. That takes into account attrition from drought, fire, disease and other causes as the trees grow. The Forest Service manages 191 million acres of forest and rangeland.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Advises Americans To Leave Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 3rd graf with new ambassador
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Wednesday advised Americans to leave Liberia because of increased fighting between government and rebel forces. The department also authorized U.S. government personnel and their families to leave Liberia if they wish. President Bush, meanwhile, said he will nominate a career diplomat, Peter Jon de Vos, to be the U.S. ambassador to Liberia. The nomination of De Vos, now principal deputy assistant secretary of state in the Bureau of Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs, must be approved by the Senate. The decision comes at a time of growing tension between the two countries following the deaths of two Americans in recent weeks, Liberia's worsening human rights record and its failure to repay its debts. The United States has been cautioning Americans to defer non-essential travel to Liberia since fighting broke out last December when the government attacked some 200 rebels it accused of trying to overthrow President Samuel Doe. U.S. officials say some of the rebels were trained by Libya. Thousands of Liberians fled the fighting to neighboring Ivory Coast, and witnesses described indiscriminate attacks by government troops against innocent civilians. Western diplomats reported hundred of Liberians were killed. The United States, in an effort to control the government troops' actions, sent two military advisers from the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia to Nimba Province to monitor the crackdown on the rebels. The advisers were later withdrawn. The embassy recommended this week that Americans leave the country ``until the situation stabilizes,'' the State Department said. Those who must travel to Liberia should not leave the capital and should register with the U.S. Embassy upon their arrival, the statement said. U.S. officials estimate there are about 10,000 Americans in Liberia, most of them missionaries and businessmen. The country was established in 1847 by former African slaves who left the United States. A U.S. missionary and his British wife were killed several weeks ago in Nimba, where most of the fighting is taking place, when their car was ambushed as they drove to Monrovia. Another American died two weeks ago from a leg wound after being shot by Liberian troops at a roadblock in Monrovia. The two incidents, as well as a suspicious fire at two embassy warehouses in Monrovia last month, raised tensions to one of their highest points since Doe took power in a bloody coup 10 years ago. The administration has proposed cuts in aid to Liberia _ from $8.9 million this year to $7.5 million for fiscal 1991, citing human rights abuses and corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Cancels Visit by Reputed Soviet Anti-Semites
DOC.TEXT: Two Montana stops on a U.S. government-funded tour by a group of Soviet writers has been canceled because some are reputedly anti-Semitic. The Montana Council for International Visitors on Monday canceled the group's scheduled appearances after the host of one, Little Big Horn College on the Crow Indian Reservation, said it wouldn't receive the writers. College president Janine Pease-Windy Boy said she hadn't known of the reputed anti-Semitism when she agreed to the eight-member group's visit. She said the college and the community believed that Indians, as minorities themselves, could not appear to condone bigotry against others. The writers had been scheduled to visit the college and Billings on May 6-9. Council Director Wendy Lewis said the organization doesn't ``screen visitors for their political opinions.'' But, she said, the controversy surrounding some of the writers' views had destroyed the chance for meaningful dialogue. Lewis added that she was ``in full agreement'' with the Crow Indian leader. Pease-Windy Boy complained that the U.S. Information Agency, which is sponsoring the tour, told her that the delegation included Soviet dissidents who were controversial. She said she only later learned of the reputed anti-Semitism. ``They seemed to think it was inconsequential,'' she said. The agency has defended the tour as a means of exposing the Soviet writers to democracy in action. Spokesman Frank S. Johnson Jr. has said, ``I don't know that they are anti-Semitic; I don't know that they are not, either. ... We feel very strongly that pluralism in this country is worth talking about and observing.'' Johnson said the writers were picked by officials in the U.S. Embassy in Moscow who were seeking to bring conservative Russian nationalists to the United States. He did not immediately return a call Wednesday seeking comment on the Montana developments. The American Jewish Committee has complained that the tour gives known anti-Semites legitimacy and prestige. Semyon Reznick, a Soviet Jewish emigre whose studies were used by the committee, said some writers in the group ``exuded the myth of a Jewish-Zionist conspiracy, an old Russian hatred'' in their work. Reznick said that Stanislav Kunyaev, as editor of Nash Sovremenik (Our Contemporary), wrote an article praising the long-discredited ``Protocols of the Elders of Zion'' as ``written by very clever people who understand the history of mankind.'' The notorious protocols purport to be an account of a meeting of Jewish leaders plotting to control the world. Their 19th century origin is obscure, but they have been used by anti-Semites including Hitler and the czar's secret police before the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. Reznick said Kunyaev also had written that ``not Bolsheviks but Jews'' had killed the victims of the revolution. He said another tour member, Olveg Mikhaylov, wrote of the 18th century Russian writer Gavril Gerzhavin as a ``victim of a Jewish plot.'' The group also includes Pavel Gorelov, Svetlana Selivanova, Leonid Borodin, Viktor Likhonosov, Svyatoslav Rybas and Ernst Safonov. The April 14-May 13 tour also scheduled visits to Washington; Pittsburgh; Iowa City, Iowa; Urbana and Kansas, Ill.; Oxford, Miss.; San Francisco, and New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Solicitor General Reviewing Probe of Gray Leak
DOC.TEXT: Solicitor General Kenneth Starr is reviewing the results of an investigation into the unauthorized disclosure of a criminal investigation involving Rep. William H. Gray III, officials said Wednesday. Justice Department spokesman Daniel Eramian said Attorney General Dick Thornburgh asked Starr to review the results of the criminal investigation of the news leaks and a separate report by the department's Office of Professional Responsiblity. The investigation, supervised by the Justice Department's criminal division, concluded that Thornburgh's spokesman, David Runkel, played a role in confirming to CBS reporter Rita Braver that the FBI was investigating alleged financial irregularities in Gray's office. In a statement last week, Thornburgh defended Runkel, saying his spokesman was following standing orders not to mislead reporters when he did not steer Ms. Braver off a story obtained from other sources. Eramian refused to say why Thornburgh had asked Starr to review the issue, but acknowledged that the referral came after discussions with the chairmen of the House and Senate judiciary committees. Thornburgh discussed the case Friday with the two chairmen, Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, and Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., Eramian said. The report about Gray was aired last spring while the Pennsylvania Democrat was running for House majority whip and sparked charges from House Democrats that leaks about the investigation were politically inspired. Outrage from Capitol Hill prompted the Justice Department to say that Gray was not a target of the investigation. The leak investigation subsequently ordered by Thornburgh was concluded late last year without any criminal charges being brought. Thornburgh reported to Congress that he found no basis for disciplining any Justice Department employees. Under pressure from lawmakers, Thornburgh earlier this month asked the Office of Professional Responsibility to review the findings and make recommendations. The report by Michael Shaheen, head of the department's internal watchdog unit, concurred with the criminal division's finding that there was no basis for criminal charges, according to a source. Shaheen did not recommend any discipinary sanctions, said the source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Secretary Details Food Donations
With AM-Nicaragua and AM-Quayle-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The United States will donate $10.8 million worth of agricultural commodities to Nicaragua, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday. Yeutter said the donations under a Food for Progress arrangement include $5.1 million worth of corn, about 44,000 metric tons; $1.4 million worth of inedible tallow, about 5,000 tons; and $4 million worth of vegetable oil, about 6,500 tons. Under the Food for Peace program, Nicaragua will get 800 tons of wheat flour, 200 tons of vegetable oil and 95 tons of a wheat-soy blended food product. Those products are valued at $350,000. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds, about 10 percent larger than a U.S. short ton of 2,000 pounds. Additional donations are being considered, Yeutter said. The Food for Progress program ``is intended to support development of free enterprise elements in the agricultural economies of recipient countries,'' the announcement said. The Food for Peace donations will be distributed immediately to needy people by private voluntary charitable organizations, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Experimental Aircraft Touches Down Next To U.S. Capitol Building
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf: ``Welcome to,'' to CORRECT that Oberstar from Minnesota, not Ohio.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto WX21
DOC.TEXT: An experimental vertically landing aircraft plunked itself down on the Capitol grounds Wednesday, sending spectators scurrying up the steps of the Capitol with its prop wash and setting off praise from members of Congress as the greatest thing in aviation since jet engines. Some members also denounced plans of the Pentagon to stop development of a successor plane, the V-22 Osprey, after spending $2 billion. Members of the House Public Works aviation subcommittee, in a series of statements at a hearing, showed nearly unanimous support for the Osprey's potential to serve cities with congested airports and airways and small towns without conventional airports. The plane that landed at the Capitol actually was a 12-year-old XV-15, predecessor to the V-22 made by Boeing Helicopters and Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. Only two XV-15s were made. Pentagon contracts call for six Ospreys, two of which have been delivered. The XV-15 and the V-22 are powered by two turboprop engines which tilt up so their propellers, normally pulling the plane forward, act like helicopter rotors for take-off and landing. In forward flight, its 340 mph top speed is significantly faster than most helicopters. Only Rep. John J. Duncan, R-Tenn., raised a negative note, asking why, if the plane has such great potential, aircraft manufacturers and airlines are not paying to develop it. Supporters said it often is necessary for expensive new aircraft to begin as military hardware. ``Let's give it to the Marine Corps and let them try to break it'' before its developed for commercial use, said Rep. Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa, who said he has piloted a tiltrotor and is sold on its potential for civilian use. The Marines sought the Osprey for use as an assault transport, to carry 24 troops or weapons and supplies from ship to beachhead in amphibious landings. But the Defense Department argues that helicopters already are doing the job and money for the Osprey can be better used elsewhere when budgets are tight. Rep. Peter DeFazio, D-Ore., brought applause at the hearing when he said, ``I can count on less than one hand the the new military weapons systems I will support, but this is one of them.'' ``Welcome to the dawn of a new age in aviation,'' said committee chairman Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., who told the committee it took everything but a papal decree to allow the XV-15 one-day landing rights on the east side of the Capitol. ``This is the most significant contribution to civilian aviation since the dawn of the jet age,'' Oberstar told reporters on the Capitol lawn after making a similar declaration to open the hearing in a nearby office building. Joseph Del Balzo, head of systems development for the Federal Aviation Administration, said the Japanese are working on a tiltwing aircraft, possibly to be built in Texas, but would likely be interested in taking up the tiltrotor technology if the United States abandons it. Del Balzo told the committee the FAA will continue to spend about $7 million a year over the next three years to research and prepare for tiltrotor aircraft, whether U.S. or foreign built. Use of an aircraft similar to the Osprey to ferry passengers around the busy Northeast corridor could increase the number of passengers carried by from five million to eight million per year, Del Balzo said.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Polio To Be Disappear From Western Hemisphere This Year
DOC.TEXT: Polio probably will be stamped out by the end of the year in the Western Hemisphere, according to public health experts who say health workers are making surprising progress against the crippling disease in Latin America. When the Pan American Health Organization in 1985 set 1990 as a goal for eradicating polio in the Americas, ``we all said this is going to be tough ... that probably is optimistic,'' D.A. Henderson, dean of the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, said in an interview Wednesday. ``Then suddenly this program began to move and polio has vanished at a pace we could not believe,'' said Henderson, president of the Association of Schools of Public Health, which met in Washington this week. ``At the moment we're having a hard time finding the virus at all,'' he said, crediting efforts that included health workers going door-to-door with the vaccine in urban and other high risk areas. Last year, 22 cases of infection from the virus were reported in Central and South America, with most occurring in areas along the western coast of Mexico and the Andean countries of Peru, Ecuador and Colombia, Henderson said. Before the polio vaccine was introduced in 1954, thousands of people in the United States were paralyzed by the disease every year. The last cases of polio in the United Sates were reported in the late 1970s. Worldwide, there were about 250,000 cases of polio last year, the shortened name for poliomyelitis, which is caused by a virus in contaminated water or food. The biggest problem areas are in India, Bangladesh, Pakistan and sub-Saharan Africa, Henderson said. The Pan American Health Organization has set the year 2000 as the goal for global eradication of polio. But ridding the world of polio is proving more difficult than the campaign that eradicated smallpox in 1977, Henderson said. The polio vaccine must be kept refrigerated until it is administered, and this has posed a problem in getting supplies of the vaccine into areas of developing nations, he said. Also, surveillance was easier with smallpox since those infected with the virus had a rash. Polio infection is evident when an infected person becomes paralyzed, but only one in 100 people infected with the polio virus become paralyzed. In the others, the infection is silent and immunizes the carrier from further infection for life, Henderson said. Freeing the Western Hemisphere from the crippling disease will be a big step toward the global goal, but ``it will be more difficult'' to eradicate the disease in the Eastern Hemisphere, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Terry Anderson Honored by Journalism Students
With AM Hostages Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Journalism students at Southern Illinois University tied yellow ribbons around trees Wednesday to remember kidnapped journalist Terry Anderson, the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon. The students, who have been wearing black and yellow armbands this week, held the ceremony to increase awareness of the plight of Anderson and six other American hostages, said Jackie Spinner, president of the student chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists. Seventeen Western hostages are held in Lebanon. ``We can't bring Terry or any of the other hostages home by wearing black armbands, selling bumper stickers or tying ribbons around trees,'' she said. ``But we can remind ourselves that the free flow of information is not possible in all parts of the world.'' The chapter designated Wednesday as Terry Anderson Day and celebrated it as part of journalism week activities. Proceeds from sales of armbands and bumper stickers will be donated to the Journalists Committee to Free Terry Anderson. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, has been held since March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Record Heat In East, Wet In Central States
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered across the central part of the nation Wednesday, dampening some drought-plagued areas, and temperatures were unseasonably high from the upper Mississippi Valley to the central East Coast. Record highs included 82 at International Falls, Minn., the border town in the North Woods that likes to call itself the nation's icebox. At midday, rain and thunderstorms extended across eastern Wyoming, central and eastern Colorado, western North Dakota, South Dakota, western and southern Nebraska, western and central Kansas, western and central Oklahoma, and from north-central Texas to the Texas Big Bend. Farmers in southwestern North Dakota rejoiced at the steady rain, which forecasters said could continue through the weekend. ``It's great. It's beautiful. If it keeps up for two days, everybody will be well,'' said Lyle Donner of Reeder. North Dakota is entering its third straight year of drought, and Gov. George Sinner declared the state a drought disaster area Tuesday. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 0.98 of an inch at San Angelo, Texas, and 0.86 at Abilene, Texas. From Tuesday night into early Wednesday, Texas had severe storms that spawned tornadoes and dumped 13 inches of rain in Burleson County and 9 inches in Mathis. In eastern Texas, 10 oil field workers who were stranded by floodwater surrounding an oil lease south of Caldwell were rescued by boat Wednesday morning. Caldwell itself was cut off by flooded roads after 13.04 inches of rain fell in 10 hours. Inmates were evacuated from the Burleson County jail. A Red Cross spokesman said all local motels were full and 15 stranded motorists spent the night in a shelter at the First Baptist Church Family Life Center. Several families were forced from their homes, the spokesman said. A tornado damaged a truck stop outside the town of Shamrock in the Texas Panhandle. About 70 miles from Shamrock in western Oklahoma, a tornado cut a three-block swath through the town of Shattuck, destroying three mobile homes and 10 businesses, causing major damage to about 17 homes and businesses and minor damage to 41 homes, said Della Stump, executive secretary of the Red Cross in Woodward. Five to six people suffered minor injuries during the storm, the Red Cross said. Other record highs were 87 at Alpena, Mich.; 87 at Chicago; 86 at Cleveland; 80 at Duluth, Minn.; 86 at Flint, Mich.; 84 at Madison, Wis.; 86 at Milwaukee; 87 at Pittsburgh; 84 at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich.; 88 at Toledo, Ohio, and 86 at Youngstown, Ohio. South Bend, Ind., tied its record of 86. Elsewhere, showers were scattered over central and southern New England, New Jersey, eastern Pennsylvania and south-central Pennsylvania. In the Northwest, rain fell across Washington state as well as northern and western Oregon. Winter-like weather lingered in the Northwest. Snow fell over the northern and west-central mountains of Wyoming and over La Veta Pass in Colorado, and a snow advisory was issued for the Washington Cascades. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 23 at West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 36 at Laramie, Wyo., to 92 at Goldsboro, N.C.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota, Dakotas Seek Government Aid for Grasshopper Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota are going to Congress and the Environmental Protection Agency for help in battling a looming invasion of grasshoppers. The Senate Appropriations Committee late Tuesday added $6.8 million to an emergency spending bill to help control the infestation expected in the drought-parched region this summer. The extra money could be used for spraying both crops and land set aside for conservation purposes. The Agriculture Department budget this year contained just $8.7 million for control of both grasshoppers and Mormon crickets, primarily on grasslands. Severe grasshopper outbreaks are expected in the three states this summer, with some areas reporting 1,000 or more grasshoppers per square yard, said Sen. Quentin Burdick, D-N.D., chairman of the agricultural appropriations subcommittee. ``Just eight grasshoppers per yard can cause economic losses, so we have a disaster developing,'' Burdick said. In the meantime, EPA scientists are meeting this week to decide whether to approve a emergency request from the three states to let farmers use the pesticide Asana-XL on grasshopper eggs. EPA ecologists are concerned because seven states altogether are seeking exemptions for the pesticide. If all of them were approved, the pesticide would be used 400 times as much as it is now, EPA spokesman Al Heier said Wednesday. He said he did not know when a final decision would be made. The pesticide currently is registered on some crops but not on small grains or on land enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Program. ``There is a very large acreage involved here and a high usage rate so we have to be careful with risks like this,'' said Stephanie Irene, deputy director for the EPA's registration division.

DOC.HEAD: House Begins Debating Democratic Budget for 1991
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with House debate under way. Picks up 10th graf pvs `Democratic leaders ...' SUBS penultimate graf pvs `A final ...' to UPDATE with vote expected Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: The House began debating a guns-for-butter Democratic alternative to President Bush's 1991 budget Wednesday as a leading Democrat gave a cold shoulder to formal talks with the White House. Democratic leaders predicted passage of their $1.24 trillion package, despite widespread opposition from the Republican minority. Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said congressional budget work would proceed without waiting for formal deficit-reduction talks with the administration. Congressional Republicans, White House officials and some Democrats have called for such bargaining for months, saying it's the only way to realistically craft a way to shrink the budget shortfall. ``I don't foresee an official, high-level, extraordinary summit'' on the budget, Gephardt told reporters before debate began. However, Gephardt conceded that it would be ``unrealistic'' to expect Congress to do all of this year's budget work without some kind of input from the administration. The Democratic plan would give the Pentagon $8 billion less next year than Bush wants. At the same time, it would spend $5.6 billion more than Bush on efforts ranging from the fight against AIDS to highway construction. Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the budget panel, said the Democratic plan's defense cuts would never be enacted, calling the proposal ``a dream, a letter to Santa Claus.'' Democrats said their package spelled out a clear difference between their goals and those of Bush, who they said has responded insufficiently to the weakening of the Soviet bloc. ``The greatest test of our nation's leadership in the '90s is not military, but rather the challenge of competing economically in an increasingly complex world economic environment,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Democratic leaders said they expected to get enough support from the House's 40 conservative Democrats to pass the measure. Last week, conservatives expressed concern that the package was too stingy to the military. The package allocates $295.5 billion for defense spending next year, compared with Bush's request for $303.8 billion. The House figure is $11.5 billion below the amount the military would need to stay abreast of inflation. It claims to reduce the deficit by $36 billion, to $63.8 billion _ just within the $64 billion shortfall target required for next year by the Gramm-Rudman law. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. Besides the defense cuts, it relies on $13.9 billion in new tax receipts, the same amount Bush wants. The Democratic plan, however, does not specify which taxes should be increased. Instead, in deference to Bush's oft-repeated opposition to a major tax increase, the proposal says no tax legislation will move through Congress ``unless and until ... there is a bipartisan agreement with the president of the United States on specific legislation'' to raise taxes. The Democratic budget also calls for a $3.8 billion slowdown in the growth of benefit programs, including Medicare, and $1.4 billion in user fees. In addition, it seeks $9.3 billion in savings proposed originally by the administration but derided by Congress as unrealistic, such as $2.5 billion by improving Internal Revenue Service efficiency. A final House vote on the spending plan was tentatively planned for Tuesday. The Senate Budget Committee planned to begin voting on its own budget Thursday. The panel conducted little business when it met briefly Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Object to Keeping Stello in Weapons Post
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a successful campaign to block Senate confirmation of Victor Stello Jr. as head of nuclear weapons production criticized the administration Wednesday for keeping Stello in the weapons program. ``The administration is pulling a fast one on Congress and the public,'' said Stephen Schwartz, legislative coordinator for Greenpeace U.S.A., which said Stello's work as a civilian nuclear power regulator was tainted by a lack of commitment to safety. The Energy Department announced Tuesday _ exactly nine months after Stello was nominated to be assistant secretary for defense programs _ that Stello had asked President Bush to withdraw the nomination. It said Stello would be given a lesser position in the weapons program that did not require Senate confirmation. The department released copies of a letter Stello sent to Bush last Friday in which he said he was withdrawing because he saw no chance of gaining confirmation ``in the foreseeable future.'' Greenpeace said Stello, who started working for the department last summer after taking temporary leave from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, should not be allowed to continue working on the nuclear weapons program. Department spokesman Tom Olson said Stello's responsibilities would include overseeing the restart of nuclear material production at the Savannah River reactors in South Carolina. ``Retaining Stello to manage these critical tasks sends a message that, despite all the fine rhetoric, the fundamental priorities of the DOE have not changed,'' Schwartz said. In a joint statement, Sen. Samm Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, and Sen. John Warner, R-Va., ranking Republican on the panel, said Bush had formally withdrawn the nomination and that the matter was closed. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, who urged the committee to confirm Stello last fall, has made no public comment on the withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Opponents Appeal to Rehnquist
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant appealed to the nation's top judge Wednesday to interrupt start-up of the plant pending court appeals. In a petition to Supreme Court Chief Justice William Rehnquist, the opponents repeated arguments about the safety of the plant and the alleged inadequacy of evacuation plans. But those arguments have failed to persuade the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the U.S. Court of Appeals. A full federal appeal is scheduled for Sept. 18, but by that time, opponents argue, Seabrook will already be operating at full power. The petition, filed by Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon, the Seacoast Anti-Pollution League and the New England Coalition on Nuclear Pollution, seeks an immediate stay on the Seabrook license granted March 1 by the NRC. The filing said a radioactive plume from the plant could reach inhabited beach areas in as little as one hour, whereas it would take six hours to 10 hours to evacuate the some 250,000 tourists and seasonal residents who flock into the Seabrook emergency zone during the summer months. Rehnquist issued no immediate response to the petition. Seabrook spokesman Ron Sher said ``We received the license from the NRC because we earned that license. Seabrook station is a safe plant.'' The Seabrook reactor is operating at about 8 percent power. Full power operation is expected by early summer.

DOC.HEAD: More Evacuations Ordered Four Years After Chernobyl Disaster
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf `After years...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with telethon under way, raises at least $4.8 million. Pickup 9th pvs, `Protesters demand...'
DOC.TEXT: Another 200,000 people will be resettled from areas irradiated in the Chernobyl nuclear power plant explosion in a $26 billion program adopted by the Soviet legislature on Wednesday, the eve of the fourth anniversary of the disaster. Many members of the legislature, the Supreme Soviet, criticized the plan as inadequate to deal with the health, agricultural, economic and environmental aftermath of the Ukraine accident. Legislator Yuri Scherback estimated 250 billion rubles ($405 billion) are needed over the next 10 years. Official reports say 31 people were killed when one of four reactors at Chernobyl caught fire and exploded April 26, 1986. Unofficial reports say 250 died. The blast spewed cesium, strontium and plutonium across much of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia and sent a cloud of radioactive gas around the world. After a day of debate, including charges of an official cover-up of the disaster and bungled evacuations, the Supreme Soviet endorsed a program drafted by the three affected republics and the central government for dealing with Chernobyl from 1990-92, Tass news agency reported. About 180,000 to 200,000 people still living in contaminated areas will be resettled. About 116,000 people were evacuated in the months after the accident, and some Soviet scientists and politicians have been campaigning since then for further resettlements. They say 4 million Soviets are living on contaminated land. Wednesday's resolution also provides for stepping up medical aid to residents of the contaminated zone and stabilizing radiation levels. Many residents have complained of inadequate medical care. Cases of anemia, leukemia and cancers have been reported rising among people living on irradiated land. Many residents still eat irradiated food because alternatives are not available. After years of passivity, the people suffering have been staging demonstrations this week. Further protests are planned Thursday, the fourth anniversary, in Byelorussia and the Ukraine.
