A 24-hour world telethon for Chernobyl victims began in Moscow Wednesday night and had raised $4.8 million in the first few hours, Tass reported. CNN showed live scenes of the telethon to U.S. viewers. Many of the donations came from the United States, Japan and Western Europe, Tass said. Protesters demand trials for the officials who concealed the extent of the danger and delayed evacuating contaminated areas; better medical care for victims; and the import of radiation-free food. Dealing with the larger questions posed by Chernobyl, the Supreme Soviet directed the government to draft a bill on the use of nuclear energy and nuclear safety, and to phase out the Chernobyl power plant. The plant's three remaining reactors are still operating. The Ukrainian legislature wants the plant closed by 1995. Several other nuclear power projects around the country were canceled because of heightened safety concerns generated by Chernobyl. Scherbak, from the Ukraine, told a news conference Wednesday a parliamentary commission should be set up to examine decision-making in the Chernobyl disaster, and to determine which high government officials were responsible for slow reaction to it and the cover-up. Fellow legislator Yuri Voronezhtsev, from Byelorussia, told reporters the commission is needed to single out officials still standing in the way of a full accounting and cleanup. ``The main thing is not to bring criminal charges against people ... but there are people who have not acknowledged their mistakes who are braking things today,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Asks Congress to Increase Fraud-Fighting Powers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 2 grafs with Dingell reax
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Wednesday asked Congress to strengthen the Food and Drug Administration's authority to act against companies that abuse or defraud the agency. The legislation was submitted in response to the generic drug scandal in which drug manufacturers were found to have misrepresented their products and bribed FDA officials to win approval to market their drugs. ``We must have the legal tools to move quickly and decisively against anyone who seeks to mislead or subvert the FDA,'' said Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. The measure would authorize the FDA to debar anyone the agency considered a threat to the integrity of the agency's product review process and to refuse to review or approve any products submitted by a debarred company. Also, the FDA would be able to withdraw improperly approved products and could suspend for two years approvals of other products granted to a debarred company during the period when illegal activity occurred. The FDA also could impose fines in cases of bribery, fraud or other illegal acts committed during an FDA product-approval process, under the legislation. Under current law, the FDA can only ask a drug manufacturer to remove a product from the market, unless the product is a threat to public health. Otherwise the agency must go through the courts to remove a product if a company refuses a request for a recall. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich. and the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee that uncovered much of the evidence of fraud and abuse in the generic drug scandal, said the legislation ``is well intentioned, but we're going to continue working on our own.'' One source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the administration's proposal presents practical difficulties in winning passage this year because it is so sweeping, affecting anyone whose product requires FDA approval.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Settle In, Ask For Transcripts, Blackboard and Pads
DOC.TEXT: Jurors tried to report they were deadlocked Wednesday at the bank fraud trial of U.S. Rep. Harold Ford, but a federal judge told them to keep deliberating. ``It is far too early for you to report that you are hopelessly deadlocked,'' U.S. District Judge Odell Horton said. After seven hours of deliberations over two days, jury foreman H.O. Robinson told Horton that the jury was deadlocked. Horton stopped him from continuing and held a conference at his bench with prosecutors and defense lawyers. The judge then told the jury to return Thursday and resume its deliberations. Ford is accused of taking payoffs disguised as bank loans from banking brothers Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr. Also standing trial are former Butcher accountant David Crabtree and lawyers Karl Schledwitz and Douglas Beaty. The Memphis Democrat, first elected in 1974, is charged with conspiracy and fraud. Ford, the state's only black congressman, has complained that he is the victim of racist prosecutors, an allegation the government has denied. After the jury was dismissed, Ford met with his attorneys in a small room off the court, emerging later and professing his confidence as he pushed through a crowd of reporters. ``We still anticipate a unanimous vote for acquittal,'' Ford said. Earlier Wednesday, the jury asked for transcripts, notebooks and a blackboard but Horton refused the transcripts, which would be voluminous and could take as long as 30 days to provide. The other items were provided. The jury began deliberating Tuesday after hearing 2{ months of testimony and arguments. Jurors asked for and received all 170 exhibits from the trial, including bank documents, tax returns and records of Ford's personal finances. Prosecutors called 29 witnesses and outlined a complicated series of Butcher loans to Ford from 1976 to 1982. The defense called no witnesses, and Ford said he decided not to testify because he regarded the government's case as weak. The government says Ford drew more than $1 million in Butcher loans, bouncing them from bank to bank with few, if any, payments made until the Butcher banking empire collapsed in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Specialists Say Bush Can Discontinue Eye Drops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with White House saying Bush may discontinue eye drops for now. Picks up 9th graf pvs `The president's ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two prominent eye doctors confirmed Wednesday that President Bush has a mild form of glaucoma, but said he can discontiue using prescription eye drops. ``Extensive testing of the eye, including detailed photographs, once again revealed no abnormalities and no visual loss,'' said Dr. Burton Lee, the White House physician. ``It was decided to stop the Betagan eye drops and follow him closely for now, on no treatment.'' Other physicians earlier prescribed the drops every 12 hours and said Bush would have to use them for the rest of his life. Stephen Hart, deputy White House press secretary, said the decision to take the Bush off the medication was ``simply a difference of opinion'' with the other doctors. ``There is no progression or regression'' in the glaucoma, Hart said. ``There is no change in his eyes.'' Bush flew by helicopter to Bethesda Naval Hospital in nearby suburban Maryland for the checkup by Dr. Richard Brubaker of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., and Dr. Harry Quigley of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. Both physicians are experts on glaucoma. The president spent about an hour in the hospital. Wearing dark glasses as he left, he flashed a thumbs-up sign to reporters as he was driven past in his limousine. During Bush's annual checkup April 12, physicians found the president has an early stage of glaucoma. If untreated, glaucoma can lead to a gradual impairment of sight that can result in blindness. Lee said earlier Wednesday that ``there are no problems with the president's vision. His vision remains excellent. But I feel that it is prudent to have outside experts assess the treatment strategy.'' The president's wife, Barbara, also is under treatment for problems that have interfered with her vision. She has Grave's disease, which has caused persistent double-vision. Before the exam, Bush attended a 50th anniversary ceremony for the Bethesda-Chevy Chase Rescue Squad near the hospital. In a separate outing, he visited the Capital Area Food Bank, which collects donated food and distributes it to soup kitchens, shelters, day-care and senior centers and other groups that help the needy. It was the food bank that accepted 5 tons of broccoli shipped to Washington after Bush declared that he didn't like the vegetable. ``It's nice to know that all the broccoli that my wife loves so much found a good home,'' Bush said. ``And I'm told that it was well-received.'' On a more serious note, he hailed volunteers who work at the food bank. ``This effort makes a difference. ... You inspire me, you inspire my wife and you inspire the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Stronghold Laments Revolution's Demise
DOC.TEXT: While most of Nicaragua celebrated Wednesday's inauguration of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro as the dawn of a new era, this Sandinista bastion lamented the demise of the leftist revolution it embraced. The closest thing to inauguration festivity on Esteli's sunny streets was Gustavo Altamirano Lanuza's tying a pole carrying the blue-and-white national flag to one of the bars protecting his front window. ``It would not be prudent to celebrate here,'' said the 62-year-old farmer and rancher, who now administers his son's wholesale rice business. The night after a 14-party United National Opposition coalition drubbed the Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections, a mob of disgruntled leftists stormed the campaign headquarters of the victorious alliance. The one-story building, its facade painted the blue-and-white party colors, stands along the corner from Altamirano's home. Shattered desks, overturned benches and the charred remains of shelves and documents litter the floor. ``SOB Dogs'' is scrawled in red paint across the facade. Esteli, 60 miles north of Managua with a population of about 120,000, was the only good-sized city carried by the Sandinistas _ but only by 200 ballots out of 40,000 cast. Evidence of unvanquished leftist fervor greets a visitor at almost every turn. Many of the pastel-painted buildings are still pocked by bulletholes from fierce combat during the revolutionary war. Part of downtown was demolished by bombs and rockets delivered by dictator Anastasio Somoza's warplanes in 1979. Some walls are patched. Not a few display colorful murals of militant men and women brandishing arms, Sandinista doctors administering vaccines, young militants teaching peasants to read and other gains of what began in 1979 as a social experiment hailed throughout the hemisphere. A block from UNO headquarters, in the state-run telecommunications corporation office, is the ``gallery of heroes and martyrs.'' The photographs of 18 telephone company workers, young men and women killed in the revolution or the war against the U.S.-funded Contras, look down from a wall decorated with plastic flowers and strings of Christmas tree lights. The largest portrait is a classic view of Argentine-born Cuban revolutionary Ernesto ``Che'' Guevara in his beret. Along the corner, several long-faced young men sat on a stoop across from the firehouse. They were all Sandinistas, and though in civilian clothes, all wore army boots. One had a 9mm Soviet-made automatic pistol stuck in his belt. ``We're determined to defend the achievements of the revolution. But by civic means,'' said 25-year-old construction worker Oscar Blandon. He said Sandinista opposition to Mrs. Chamorro's administration would be marked by ``temperance and moderation.'' Two women passed by wearing yellow Sandinista campaign T-shirts bearing the obsolete slogan, ``Ganamos'' (We Win). ``Maybe because we in this city suffered more than anyone we've been the ones to more completely understand what the revolution meant,'' said Rafael Chavarria, an accountant waiting for a bus at the central plaza. Chavarria, the son of peasant farmers, identified with the Sandinistas but is not a party member. ``It's clear that since the revolution, more poor people have been able to overcome their circumstances and make for themselves a better life than their parents' lives,'' he said. ``Now our role must be one of constructive criticism, to call the new government's attention to what goes wrong, but always by civic means.'' Altamirano, a supporter of UNO who lost land and cattle confiscated by the Sandinistas, said it would have been nice to have some sort of public celebration of the transfer of power. ``After all that would be nothing more than the exercise of a democratic right,'' he said. ``But the important thing is not the celebration or whether we won or lost in Esteli. ``What is important is that this is an historic change from a totalitarian to a democratic system.''

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Leader Complains of U.S. Reluctance to Invest
DOC.TEXT: A leader in Romania's revolutionary government complained Wednesday that Americans have been over-cautious about investing in his country despite its offer to allow foreigners to own all the stock in new companies they organize. John Manzatu is head of the Republican party and one of the three vice-presidents of the Council of National Unity. The council has been acting as a parliament pending an election May 20 to choose a president and an assembly which will write a new constitution. ``I'm very sorry that the United States is not as yet involved,'' he said at a news conference. ``I want to change that very quickly.'' ``Romania has given up communism and socialist economies forever,'' he said. The South Korean Gold Star group has made definite offers of business projects and there has been some interest from France and West Germany, Manzatu said Manzatu, a professor of biophysics and biotechnology, declined to predict what kind of government the election will bring. ``We will do our best,'' he said. His added that his own party would go much further than the provisional government has already done to promote private enterprise. Manzatu estimated that of nearly 4 million Communist members last fall, 80 percent had no sympathy with the party. He said he had been a member until he was expelled in 1982, but had only joined because he was threatened that his daughters would not get an education unless he did. ``The Ceausescus _ were they real communists?'' he asked. ``They were real thieves.'' Dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife were executed on Christmas Day last year.

DOC.HEAD: Stabbed Politician One of West Germany's Top Political Figures
With AM-Germany-Stabbing
DOC.TEXT: Oskar Lafontaine, the victim of a Wednesday assassination attempt, is one of West Germany's most colorful politicians and was picked to lead his opposition party in December's national elections. Lafontaine has a reputation for making bold and brash statements and seems to enjoy his role as a gadfly politician. He consistently argues against the large-scale NATO troop presence in West Germany, and has long been a critic of West Germany's policy of giving open access to East Germans. He has also predicted that in the future West Germans could have a standard work week of as little as 20 hours. Wednesday night, Lafontaine was stabbed in the neck by a woman who presented him with an album of poetry and a bouquet of flowers. There was no known motive for the attack. The stabbing severed an artery and Lafontaine was reportedly in serious condition in a Cologne hospital. Lafontaine was at the forefront of politicians who argued that despite West Germany's wealth, the nation could not afford to absorb the influx of the more than a half-million East Germans who have flooded into West Germany since last fall. Lafontaine, unlike many other West German politicans, played only a cameo role in the hectic campaigning before East Germany's free democratic elections on March 18. His Social Democratic Party advocates gradual German reunification and this is believed to have contributed to the relatively poor showing of its East German sister party. The East German Social Democratic Party finished second in the balloting, far behind a conservative coalition that closely follows West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's push for quick reunification. But a recent poll of East German voters by the West German Bild am Sonntag newspaper this month said 46 percent of those questioned would back Lafontaine as chancellor of a united Germany. Only 24 percent opted for Kohl. There has been speculation Lafontaine could unseat Kohl in the Dec. 2 national elections. Lafontaine is governor of the tiny Saarland state that borders France and Luxembourg. It is one of the poorest regions in West Germany. The divorced Lafontaine is known to have an active social life, which has featured prominently in West Germany's tabloid press.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania's President Says U.S. Giving in to Kremlin `Blackmail'
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president on Wednesday accused the White House of succumbing to Kremlin ``blackmail'' by failing to impose sanctions against the Soviet Union in response to Moscow's economic blockade of the breakaway republic. ``The logic in this is hard to understand, but blackmail does not require logic,'' the Lithuanian leader, Vytautas Landsbergis, told lawmakers. His remarks were released by the parliamentary press office. Lithuanian leaders have expressed frustration with the failure of the United States and other Western nations to come to the republic's aid. It has been locked in a standoff with Moscow since President Mikhail Gorbachev rejected its March 11 declaration of independence. The United States has never recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania and the neighboring Baltic states Estonia and Latvia in 1940. However, it has refrained from any strong criticism of Gorbachev's handling of the matter. President Bush has called for dialogue to resolve the dispute. In Washington, Bush responded Wednesday to critical remarks by Landsbergis a day earlier: ``I don't need any defense.'' He said the U.S. public supported his stance. The Kremlin cut off oil supplies to Lithuania on April 18, and then curtailed shipments of natural gas and other raw materials to try to pressure the Lithuanians into rescinding their declaration of independence. Yevgeny Primakov, a member of Gorbachev's advisory board, hinted Wednesday that some Soviet officials had sought stronger action against Lithuania. ``President Gorbachev, frankly speaking, has had to restrain many people,'' Primakov, a member of the Presidential Council, told the official news agency Tass. It was not clear whether he meant the Soviet military, which has already used force to round up Lithuanian army deserters and occupy a printing plant. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said the republic is trying to get around the Kremlin's cutoff of supplies by setting up direct trade links with Soviet regions and factories, according to spokesman Paul Pauparus. Lithuania produces more meat and milk than it consumes, and Pauparus said sympathetic officials in Moscow, Leningrad and elsewhere might be willing to barter those supplies for fuel and other necessities. However, the shipments would have to travel by Kremlin-controlled train and truck routes. Conditions in Lithuania, meanwhile, were said to be worsening. ``Lithuania's economy is on the brink of collapse,'' the Soviet newspaper Selskaya Zhizn reported Wednesday. Lithuanian Deputy Prime Minister Algirdas Brazauskas estimated Wednesday the republic's oil reserves would last until May 20. The Soviet Union is Lithuania's sole supplier of fuel. Brazauskas also said shortages of grain, sugar, salt and margarine had developed, according to Eduardas Potashinskas, a Lithuanian activist who monitored the parliament session. Potashinskas said speakers at the parliament also said the Kremlin had cut off Soviet supplies of paper and wood products to Lithuania. Brazauskas suggested if the blockade continued, Lithuania should ``re-examine its policy of continuing to supply food products'' to Soviet buyers according to existing contracts. It has already ceased supplying cement to the Soviet Union, he said. In Moscow, Soviet Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov spoke informally Wednesday with a group of Lithuanian parliamentarians and journalists. He repeated previous Soviet demands that Lithuania would have to repeal its independence declaration before the Kremlin would lift its blockade, journalists reported. The talk took place in the lobby of the Supreme Soviet chambers during a break in the legislative session.

DOC.HEAD: Potter Reduces Sentence for PTL's Dortch
DOC.TEXT: The prison sentence of former PTL official Richard Dortch was reduced to 2{ years Wednesday by a judge who said he must do jail time despite testimony that sent ministry founder Jim Bakker to prison. U.S. District Judge Robert Potter did not follow the suggestion of Dortch's attorneys that he be placed on probation. The judge said Dortch likely would serve from 24 to 29 months, taking into account time for good behavior. Dortch had been sentenced to eight years, which meant he would have spent from 40 to 52 months in prison, Potter said. Dortch is currently serving his term in the federal prison at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida. Dortch, Bakker's former top lieutenant at the multimillion-dollar PTL television ministry, also was fined $200,000 after pleading guilty to fraud and conspiracy. Potter did not reduce the fine Wednesday. The judge wrote that the sentence reduction means ``Dortch will receive due consideration for his cooperation with the government, but simultaneously also will be required to serve a meaningful period of incarceration.'' ``Defendant Dortch's actions are in sharp contrast with the actions of his co-defendant Bakker, who has refused to bring himself to understand that he has committed the violations charged in the indictments for which he was convicted,'' Potter wrote. ``I'm not disappointed,'' said one of Dortch's attorneys, Mark Calloway. ``It was a fair and realistic reduction in the sentence.'' Dortch and Bakker were indicted in December 1988 on 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy for soliciting $158 million from PTL supporters in exchange for bogus guarantees of free lodging at the ministry's retreat in nearby Fort Mill, S.C. In August, Dortch entered into a plea agreement that called for him to cooperate with the government, including testifying against his former boss and other indicted PTL officials. Dortch testified at length at Bakker's trial, which began Aug. 28. Bakker was convicted in October on all 24 counts. He was sentenced by Potter to 45 years in prison and fined $500,000. Bakker, 50, is serving his sentence at a medium-security federal prison in Minnesota. Dortch also testifed earlier this month at the perjury trial of former PTL pastor Sam Johnson. Potter threw the charges out, saying the government's case was weak. On April 12, Dortch cried as he asked Potter to show mercy and reduce his prison time. Assistant U.S. Attorney Jerry Miller told the judge that Dortch made ``an honest and sincere effort to be truthful and straightforward.'' Dortch's attorneys asked Potter to place their client on probation. They said he has medical problems and has been spending his days in prison handing out clothing. Calloway said he spoke by phone Wednesday morning with Dortch, who asked that the attorney not describe his reaction to the judge's order. ``He simply wants to serve his sentence as quietly as possible and get on with his life,'' the attorney said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel's Peres Says He Will Abandon Attempts to Form Government
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres said Wednesday he failed in his attempts to form Israel's next government. Peres had been trying to put together a new governing coalition since his center-left party engineered the collapse of a Labor-Likud government on March 15. Peres' decision to abandon his attempts came after a key prospective defector from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc said he would stay with Likud in spite of Labor's efforts to lure him into a coalition. ``I have decided to go to a Likud-headed coalition,'' Economics Minister Yitzhak Modai announced in a nationally broadcast Israel Television interview. Modai blamed Labor's negotiating team, which he said torpedoed his agreement with Peres and other party leaders. His statement ended two days of intensive negotiations with both Peres and Shamir and brought Israel's two major parties back to square one of their political deadlock. Each controls 60 seats in the 120-member Parliament. Shamir's 15-month Cabinet fell last month over Likud's refusal to accept a U.S. formula for arranging Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Peres had a Thursday midnight deadline for presenting a government. He told reporters he will give back his mandate to President Chaim Herzog. Herzog may then hold another round of negotiations with Israel's political parties or immediately give Shamir the task of fashioning a coalition. Peres said he doubts that Shamir would be able to form a government, ``and if he succeeds it would be an unsuccessful government. We talk about an extremist, right-wing government the like of which Israel never had.'' Likud officials said they were encouraged by Modai's decision. ``Mr. Peres has no possibility of forming a government. I hope we are now beginning to get out of the political crisis and I hope that Yitzhak Shamir would form and head a government,'' Cabinet minister Ehud Olmert said. Shamir seemed less certain, acknowledging in an Israel Radio interview that ``in a political crisis, everything is possible.'' Israel Television said ``another political turnabout is possible even tomorrow,'' before Peres heads for Herzog's residence. Labor's ruling bureau also meets Thursday, and Peres' old party rival, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, is expected to attack Peres' failure in coalition negotiations. Israeli media reports said Rabin might demand a new coalition with Likud and even seek party leadership. Likud leaders have ruled out an alliance with a Peres-led Labor, but did not reject a union with Rabin, a Labor hawk.

DOC.HEAD: Moluccans Hurl Bricks, Firebombs at Indonesian Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Police in riot gear used water cannon Wednesday to disperse hundreds of Moluccan demonstrators who hurled bricks and firebombs at the Indonesian Embassy, Dutch television reported. The report said 10 protesters were arrested and 28 police officers injured in the clash, which came on the 40th anniversary of a proclamation of a Republic of the South Moluccas. The Moluccas archipelago west of New Guinea was incorporated by Indonesia in 1950 when the Netherlands' colonial rule over the former Dutch East Indies came to an end. Moluccans maintain Indonesia illegally occupies the islands and say the Dutch government owes them an independent homeland. The violence came after about 600 marchers split off from peaceful demonstration by 1,500 people and broke through a police cordon around the embassy, the television report said. Police had said earlier Wednesday only several dozen demonstrators were involved in clashes. At least two of the injured police officers were hospitalized, but there was no immediate word on their condition, according to police spokeswoman Bernardine MacLean, who said the main demonstration was allowed to continue peacefully. In the 1970s, Moluccan terrorists seized the Indonesian Consulate in Amsterdam, two trains and a kindergarten, holding dozens of people hostage. There have also been several clashes with police at the Camp Lunetten facility in Vught, where about 220 Moluccans have been resisting eviction attempts for years.

DOC.HEAD: State Officials Defense Release Of Man Day Before Shooting Spree
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Joe Frank Harris defended state mental health officials Wednesday in the case of a man who was released from a state mental hospital the day before he opened fire in a suburban shopping mall. One person was killed and four were wounded in Tuesday's attack. James Calvin Brady, 31, had been released from Georgia Regional Hospital, a state psychiatric facility in Atlanta, on Monday, said James Ledbetter, commissioner of the Department of Human Resources. Psychiatrists had judged that he was not harmful to himself or others, Ledbetter said after reviewing records in the case. ``It looked to me like all the procedures, rules and regulations were followed, and the clinical decision was made to release him,'' Ledbetter said. ``It's a very difficult decision to predict future behavior, and that's essentially what our staff is called on to do. ... We are not perfect,'' he said. Harris and Ledbetter said Brady's release was not due to overcrowding. The governor said the state is ``sincere in trying ... to do everything that we can to prevent something like this from happening. In this case, I think it was being done.'' The gunman, smiling and wearing a gray suit, fired a handgun into a lunch-time crowd at Perimeter Mall. After throwing his gun into a trash can, Brady surrendered just outside the mall's main entrance, police said. DeKalb County police said the gunman carried documents from the hospital in Atlanta, indicating he had been diagnosed as having homicidal tendencies. A DeKalb County judge Wednesday ordered the mental hospital to turn over Brady's records to police. Ledbetter said the Department of Human Resources was seeking judicial guidance on what exactly can be disclosed without intruding on doctor-patient privilege. Police said Brady was taken late Tuesday to Central State Hospital at Milledgeville, another state-run mental facility. Officers said Brady bought the revolver and 12 rounds of hollow-point ammunition, a type designed to expand on impact and cause particularly severe wounds, for $139 Monday at Avondale Pawn Shop in an eastern Atlanta suburb. Detective Lt. Rodney Maddox described the gun as ``a cut-down barrel version of a large-frame revolver and said it ``looked pretty worn.'' ``How did he get the gun? Why did he get the gun?'' Maddox said. ``We don't have a good answer to that and may never know why.'' Georgia law does not restrict the sale of handguns or rifles but requires a license for anyone who carries a concealed weapon. Such a license cannot be obtained within five years of release from a psychiatric hospital. Harris said Wednesday the shooting spree ``makes a very strong statement'' for stronger gun laws in Georgia, but he acknowledged that public sentiment ``has just not risen in support enough to pass something of that nature.'' Rambling, disjointed notes found in the apartment Brady had been living in said he had taken crack cocaine and then met two people in California who created a machine that would control his mind. ``If I got the public at large outcry and attention of why I became insane, the public would bring these (two people) to accounting,'' said the notes. Brady was a native of Anniston, Ala. His relatives in Alabama expressed shock over the incident. His stepmother, Sadie Bolton, said Brady seemed fine when she last saw him around Thanksgiving. Brady's half-brother told The Times of Contra Costa County, Calif., that Brady had a drug problem and was ``talking crazy'' before he left the San Francisco area two months ago. ``He was talking stupid,'' said the half-brother, who asked that his name not be used. ``He said that there were some people who were controlling this box in his stomach.'' One of the wounded people remained in critical condition Wednesday at Shallowford Hospital and one was in stable condition. A third was treated and released and the fourth was expected to be released after treatment for leg wounds.

DOC.HEAD: 25-Day Prison Siege Ends With Last Prisoners' Surrender
DOC.TEXT: The longest prison siege in British history ended Wednesday when the last five inmates at Strangeways prison abandoned their rooftop stronghold. The five prisoners gingerly walked down the slippery slate roof and stepped into a hydraulic lift that carried them the 150 feet down to the prison courtyard, where they were taken into custody. The surrender was shown live on the British Broadcasting Corp.'s main evening newscast. Prisoners had taken over the grim, overcrowded Victorian prison in a riot that began April 1 during Sunday chapel services. About 300 prisoners overwhelmed guards, took the jail keys and released the rest of the inmates. Running battles raged in the prison in northern England for about four days and prompted unrest and violence in jails throughout the country. In the weeks of negotiations that followed, inmates complained about conditions in the prison, where they had been held three or four to a tiny cell, allowed a shower and change of clothes once a week and provided with a bucket instead of a toilet. During the siege, inmates built and rebuilt barricades and planted booby traps to keep out authorities. But nearly all of the 1,650 prisoners had surrendered by the time more than 100 officers in riot gear moved in Wednesday morning. The final five holdouts were trapped on the roof, and a sixth inmate was captured in the sweep. Home Office spokesman Mike Gander said prison guards were going through the scorched and wrecked jail to search for bodies. ``We are confident there are no bodies to be found,'' Gander said. One prisoner died as a result of injuries in the riot, and one prison officer died in the hospital during the riot because of an existing heart condition. Another was slightly injured when the facility was being retaken Wednesday. Home Office Minister David Mellor on Wednesday rejected criticism of the authorities' strategy of drawn-out negotiations with the inmates. ``Would you prefer that we'd knocked them off the roof and people would have seen them falling head first down five stories?'' Mellor said in a television interview. The riot's apparent ringleader, Paul Taylor, 29, serving a three-year sentence for burglary, was the last to board the crane, fists clenched in the air. ``If I could get my hands on him I'd give hm a damned good hiding,'' Taylor's grandmother, Helen Smythe, told reporters at her home near Liverpool. ``He's been an absolute disgrace _ they should have thrown him off the roof.''

DOC.HEAD: After Seven Months, St. Louis Sun Calls It Quits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details, quotes. No pickup. ADDS byline. A version also moved on business wire.
DOC.TEXT: The St. Louis Sun, which hoped to be the first major metropolitan newspaper to make a successful launch in this country since World War II, unexpectedly folded Wednesday after only seven months. At a news conference, Ralph Ingersoll II, editor in chief of the new newspaper, said the St. Louis Sun had published its last edition Tuesday night. ``Closing the Sun was a decision the St. Louis marketplace made for us,'' said Ingersoll. Since launching the paper Sept. 25, 1989, the newspaper had published 213 editions. ``It is clear that we could not achieve sufficient circulation to make this enterprise viable and so, we have concluded that there is no longer room in St. Louis for a third newspaper in addition to our own Suburban Journals and the Post-Dispatch.'' The Sun struggled to overcome higher-than-expected costs, revolving-door circulation, limited advertising and a murky image. The newspaper also had troubles developing everyday readers. On April 1, the newspaper had a circulation of 109,000, up from a low of 80,000 during the winter, aided by the start of a new ``Bingo'' promotion. Ingersoll had guaranteed advertisers circulation of 105,000 for the first six months of 1990. The Sun also was criticized by some as sensationalizing stories for its coverage of a politician involved in a sexual assault and of the five-year anniversary of an accident in which a man was nearly sawed in two. The newspaper was further chided for running photos of new women's swimsuits and lingerie. But the Sun was praised for its coverage of the effort to build a new domed stadium downtown and of the troubles facing St. Louis' major air carrier, Trans World Airlines. Some critics derided the Sun's flood of promotions, fluorescent green billboards and contests, but Sun executives defended those practices as the best way to encourage people to give their paper a try. In making the surprise announcement, Ingersoll was flanked by poster-size blowups of various pages of the Sun. Also on hand were publisher Tom Tallarico, who left the Post-Dispatch to join the Sun, and Robert Jelenic, president of Ingersoll Publications Co. Lorraine Orlandi, a reporter who joined the paper when it was launched, said the 4 p.m. announcement came as a shock, and some employees cried, but within about two hours staff members had brought cases of beer into the newsroom. ``We were putting out a newspaper today. I had just returned from City Hall with a couple of stories to write,'' Ms. Orlandi said. ``The people here are not gloomy. People are in shock,'' she said. ``There were no visible signs that we were shutting down, or even cutting back. There were renovations going on.'' In an interview earlier this month, Ingersoll said the two main problems facing the Sun were higher-than-expected circulation costs and a whopping turnover rate among home subscribers. Ingersoll said at the time the company had been forced to spend $5 million more than planned to distribute the newspaper because twice as many readers as expected wanted their newspapers delivered. ``Advertisers consider that to be very good, but it's much more expensive than we planned for,'' Ingersoll said. But home subscribers also were cancelling their subscriptions at an extremely fast rate, making it difficult for the Sun to sign up enough new subscribers to keep circulation from falling.

DOC.HEAD: Saxophone Dreams Never Die: Remembering Dexter Gordon
With AM-Obit-Gordon
DOC.TEXT: ``Drum on your drums, batter on your banjos, sob on the long cool winding saxophones. Go to it, O jazzmen.'' _ Carl Sandburg, ``Jazz Fantasia'' (1920).

Dexter Gordon walked out on the stage at Avery Fisher Hall, a tall man with a devilish smile whose body bent with a sickly gait. He plugged his horn between his lips and blew reedy dreams. And when he was done, he accepted the applause. But not alone. When Dexter bowed, he always stepped back and gave the stage to his star _ his tenor saxophone. He had a way of presenting it to the audience, like a sacred offering to a very special priesthood. Dexter Keith Gordon had come home 14 years after he left the prejudices and restrictions of his homeland for Europe. A man of musical genius and personal humility, he died Wednesday at the age of 67 of kidney failure. Like B.B. King and his sweet Lucille, Gordon's saxophone was always his much-appreciated co-star. With it he helped define and refine an important musical legacy: bebop. As the last of this century's great saxophone geniuses _ Lester Young, Charlie Parker, John Coltrane _ Gordon had a reputation as a strikingly original jazz soloist. The style he developed had a strong influence on younger saxophonists of the '60s and '70s and is influential even today. But as important as he was to jazz, he never placed himself before the music. The bebop he championed may have been brash, but Gordon wasn't. He embraced humility. ``One of my greatest compliments came in 1982 when he said I was his favorite guitarist,'' said Kenny Burrell. ``He was an amazing personality. He was a good person,'' said drummer Art Blakey, who had played with Gordon back in the '40s with Billy Eckstine's band. ``I'd see him and I'd say, `Come on up here and stand by my big cymbal. Don't just be a silent movie star.''' There was nothing silent about his horn. What he spun out was the stuff of which dreams were made. And Gordon was a dream merchant of sorts. Listen to the breathy sax pulls on the moody ballad ``Who Can You Turn To.'' Or the sensual underpinnings and samba chases of ``Manha de Carnaval.'' Finger-pop and toe-tap to the cool smoothness of ``Coppin' the Haven.'' Enjoy the lively cool of ``Tanya.'' ``He was something else. He had a style of his own,'' Blakey said. Gordon came along at a time when the icon of the tenor sax was Lester Young, whose lyrical style was the starting point for up-and-coming horn players including Charlie Parker. But Gordon carved a new approach for the tenor sax and influenced many of Young's proteges _ John Coltrane, Stan Getz, Sonny Stitt. Gordon assimilated Parker's musical inventions and added his own furious harmonics and multitextured tones. Sonny Rollins and Coltrane used Gordon's style as a base and created their own. Years later, Gordon updated his own sound by learning from them. ``Dexter Gordon was one of the pioneers of the modern saxophone,'' Burrell said. ``His distinct and very personal style plus his strong knowledge of music caused him to be both an influential figure among saxophonists and an inspiration to many other musicians. Gordon at an early age went to jazz concerts with his father, who was Duke Ellington and Lionel Hampton's doctor. When he was 13, he became to study music theory and clarinet. At 15 he switched to alto sax, studying with Lloyd Reese, who had taught the bassist-composer-pianist Charles Mingus. Two years later, Gordon was performing in night clubs on tenor sax. He traveled a rough and craggy road. There was booze _ lots of it. There were too many drugs. There was jail. But the anguish with which he lived in no way diminished the sweetness that came from his saxophone. Nor did it intrude upon his unblinking love of jazz. When he was nominated for an Academy Award in 1987 as best actor for his portrayal of a tragic jazz musician in Bertrand Tavernier's ``Round Midnight,'' Gordon responded to the news like a high school jock who'd been made quarterback. He had been watching the ``Today'' show with his wife, Maxine, and his stepson while on vacation in Cuernavaca, Mexico. There were giggles and one-word punctuations. Wow. Yeah. Awright. ``The film was dedicated to Bud (Powell), and I broadened that concept to include Ben Webster, Coleman Hawkins ... and people like that who were expatriates, including myself,'' he said at the time in an interview with The Associated Press. ``That's why I broadened the character as much as I could to touch as many people as possible. I wanted to open up my world to them and make them aware of all the giants and unsung heros of the past they weren't aware of.''

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Blow Up Bridge in Guatemala
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas blew up a bridge near a northern town Wednesday, interrupting traffic on the main highway leading from the capital to the Mexican border, an official said. The predawn blast broke the bridge in two and sent a pickup truck plunging into the Nil River, but the driver was not hurt, Communications Minister Sigfrido Mendizabal told reporters. The 150-foot-long bridge is near El Asintal, a town about 120 miles northwest of Guatemala City. On Dec. 11, the rebels blew up a 200-foot-long bridge over the Coyolate River, on the same highway, about 60 miles from the capital. The guerrillas, which have been fighting for power for more than three decades, signed a preliminary agreement March 30 in Oslo, Norway, with President Vinicio Cerezo's administration to start talks on ending the war.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela Provides Mrs. Chamorro with Commando Protection
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Security for President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is being provided by a team of Venezuelan commandos rather than Nicaragua's own security forces. A dozen commandos trained in the United States were sent by Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez four days ago and set up shop in Mrs. Chamorro's suburban home, installing rocket launchers on her roof. They have been providing round-the-clock security, following Mrs. Chamorro's car in jeeps at high speed while hanging out open doors. ``We have to take very good care of this lady. There are many who don't wish her well,'' one commando told a reporter. Mrs. Chamorro, inaugurated president Wednesday, had her own private security during the campaign before the Feb. 25 election. Public security forces are run by the Interior Ministry, which was controlled by the Sandinista party and still has many Sandinista sympathizers in its ranks. The commandos are to provide security for Mrs. Chamorro for six weeks until June 10, the date the anti-Sandinista Contra guerrillas have agreed to disarm and disband.

DOC.HEAD: Brother of Slain Iranian Activist Attacks Swiss Security
By HANNS NEUERBOURG
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: A mujahedeen leader assailed the Swiss Wednesday for failing to prevent the assassination of his Iranian activist brother, saying authorities were told years ago that death threats made special protection mandatory. A burst of submachine-gun fire killed Kazem Rajavi when his car was blocked Tuesday near his home at Coppet, a lakeside town seven miles east of Geneva. Police said they were looking for two men who fled in a blue Volkswagen Golf. The car was found in a parking lot near Geneva airport six hours later, shortly after a direct IranAir flight left for Tehran. Police spokesman Maurice Gehri said two foreigners hired the car last Sunday. He declined to give details. Rajavi, a member of the Iraq-based Mujahedeen Khalq resistance movement, obtained political asylum in Switzerland in 1973 and focused on publicizing human rights violations in Iran. His brother, Massoud Rajavi, is chief of the organization. In Bern, government spokesman Achille Casanova promised authorities would do their utmost to apprehend the killers and have them tried by a Swiss court. Federal police joined local authorities in the manhunt. At a news conference in Paris on Wednesday, Mujahedeen Khalq spokesman Behzad Naziri reiterated the group's claim that President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran ordered the assassination. Massoud Rajavi said he sent a telegram to Swiss President Arnold Koller expressing ``surprise and regret'' at what he described as ``insensibility'' by Swiss authorities. He said they were warned years ago that his brother required special protection, and he renewed allegations that Iranian diplomats were behind the crime, acting on Rafsanjani's direct orders. Kazem Rajavi's French-born widow and mother of his three children told a news conference he fought for a ``just cause and the fight will continue.'' A third brother, Dr. Saleh Rajavi, a cardiologist practicing in France, said Kazem Rajavi was ``threatened with death many times'' in the presence of others who were ready to testify. Kazem Rajavi fled Iran in 1957 to join the resistance against Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlevi. After the overthrow of the shah in 1979, he served for one year as head of the Iranian Mission to the United Nations in Geneva, but broke with the new leadership when the mujahedeen (holy warriors) went underground. Mujahedeen spokesman Naziri told reporters in Paris that a U.N. human rights report on Iran was partly to blame for Tuesday's killing. He said the report ``neutralized'' the crimes of the Iranian regime and ``encouraged'' terrorism. The killing placed a ``heavy responsibility'' on the United Nations, he said. Massoud Rajavi demanded Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar send a new team to Iran, accompanied by resistance members, to reassess the human rights situation.

DOC.HEAD: Victim's Mother Lobbies for AIDS Bill
DOC.TEXT: The mother of AIDS victim Ryan White said Wednesday that every family risks losing a member to the fatal disease because sex is a fact of life. ``It can be your brother, your sister, your mother, your father,'' Jeanne White, 42, said in an interview on Capitol Hill. ``It could be a loved one, a friend.'' Mrs. White, of Cicero, Ind., said the disease is inevitable because among the ways it is spread is through sexual contact. Her son, a hemophiliac, died April 8 after contracting the disease through infected blood five years ago at the age of 13. Ryan's funeral two weeks ago drew 1,500 friends and admirers, including celebrity musicians Michael Jackson and Elton John. Ryan was diagnosed with acquired immune deficiency syndrome in December 1984. His court battle to be allowed to stay in public school called attention to the plight of all AIDS sufferers. Mrs. White spent the day Wednesday lobbying senators for passage of a bill that would provide $600 million to help fight AIDS. The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee voted 16-0 to approve the legislation on April 4 and dedicated it to Ryan. Mrs. White met with the two main sponsors of the bill, Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, as well as Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. She also met with other senators, trying to get them to add their names to the bill, and planned further meetings Thursday. ``I think they felt like they can relate,'' she said. ``Especially if you have kids.'' But Mrs. White said she wants the bill passed for everyone who has AIDS, not just children. ``I am in contact with a lot of gay men who have the disease, a lot of mothers who maybe are HIV positive from their hemophiliac husbands _ some have lost their husbands even _ and the wife is HIV positive. I just keep in constant communication with all types of people.'' The disease is passed through sexual contact, through contaminated blood and hypodermic needles and from a mother to a child while it is still in the womb. ``I think AIDS is here to stay,'' she said. ``I think that, because we would all have to quit having sex completely. I think that's the main issue. ... Somebody is going to be giving it to someobdy through sex. And if we don't have sex we don't have children. I just feel this is a subject that people don't like to talk about. It is spread that way.'' She said Ryan harbored no ill feelings, and all he cared about was finding a cure. But she did say progress toward fighting the disease would have been quicker had President Reagan and his wife met Ryan sooner. ``Ryan met Ronald and Nancy Reagan a week before he died,'' she said. ``And I felt like Ryan made a very emotional impact on them. ``And I think had they maybe met him four years ago or three years ago, I think they would have related more to the issue of AIDS.''

DOC.HEAD: Antingua Prime Minister's Son Quits Cabinet in Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The eldest son of Prime Minister Vere Bird Sr. temporarily resigned his Cabinet post Wednesday after being accused of helping divert Israeli weapons to Colombia's powerful Medellin cocaine cartel. His father said on government-run radio that Vere Bird Jr., was stepping down as public works minister pending completion of a judicial inquiry. The son has denied any wrongdoing. The scandal has plunged the government into one of its worst crises since Bird, 80, first came to power in 1956 on this tiny Caribbean island, 250 miles southeast of Puerto Rico. The announcement followed an emergency Cabinet meeting in which ministers discussed a diplomatic letter from the Israeli government linking 54-year-old Bird Jr. to the arms shipment made a year ago. A copy of the letter was obtained by The Associated Press and the letter was also read on the radio. It said Bird Jr. ordered Israeli-sold weapons delivered here last year for use by the Antiguan Defense Forces. He assured Israel the weapons ``will not be passed, sold or given to use to any third party,'' according to the letter. Despite the commitment, Israel said, the weapons ``were found in the possession of private individuals in other countries.'' The letter was dated April 23 and delivered to Antigua through the Israeli Embassy in Santo Domingo, capital of the Dominican Republic. Bird Jr. ordered the weapons in his capacity as minister of national security, according to the Israeli letter. His Public Works Ministry, however, gives him no responsibility for national security. Investigators have placed no money value on the arms shipment. The letter did not state the ultimate destination of the weapons, but Colombia says they wound up in the hands of the Medellin cartel. The cartel's bombings and shootings have killed hundreds of people since the Bogota government began a crackdown last August. According to Colombian authorities, soldiers found 232 Israeli-made weapons during a February search of Colombian ranches seized from Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a major drug trafficker killed in December in a gunbattle with police. The weapons included assault rifles, shoulder-fired rockets and infrared night scopes, the Colombians said. A preliminary investigation found the arms shipment passed through Antigua on April 24, 1989, and arrived in Colombia five days later. The twin-island state of Antigua-Barbuda, with a population of 80,000, gained independence from Britain in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Member Enters Plea Agreement, Agrees to Hand Over Notes
DOC.TEXT: A former member of a religious cult tearfully admitted Wednesday that he switched on a chain saw to mask the sounds of a family of five being bound and shot. Gregory S. Winship, 29, made the admission during a plea bargain hearing in which he agreed to cooperate with prosecutors _ including turning over notes he kept of cult activities. Winship had faced a trial set for Monday on five counts of complicity to aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. Under the deal, if he is a cooperative witness in upcoming trials of other cult members, including leader Jeffrey Lundgren, he will be sentenced on guilty pleas he will enter to five counts of complicity to murder. All 13 members of the cult have been indicted for either killing or complicity in killing the family. Winship, of Independence, Mo., was freed on a $150,000 surety bond. He had been held in Lake County Jail since he was extradited from Kansas City in February. Lake County Prosecutor Steven C. LaTourette said Winship was a Lundgren follower from 1986 through at least April 18, 1989, when the cult fled the county. ``I think it's fair to say he took extensive notes during the course of the classes that were conducted by the group,'' LaTourette said. ``It's more a collection of loose leaf pages that contain what was talked about, who was present, the Scriptures that were used during each class.'' Investigators in January, acting on a tip, found the bodies of Dennis Avery, 49; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their daughters, Trina, 15, Rebecca, 13, and Karen, 7, buried in a barn in Kirtland, about 30 miles east of Cleveland. All five had been bound with duct tape and shot. The barn is on a farm once rented by Lundgren, a defrocked lay minister for the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. Authorities say Lundgren was a domineering, fundamentalist leader of a cult that lived as a commune on the farm. Lundgren, who faces trial July 9, is charged with five counts of aggravated murder, five counts of kidnapping and one count of complicity to attempted aggravated murder. The last charge stems from an alleged plan to kill worshippers of his former church. Lake County Common Pleas Judge Paul H. Mitrovich asked Winship to explain his role the day the Avery family died. In a near-whisper, Winship replied: ``I assisted Mr. Lundgren, who was in the barn, by doing whatever he told me to do _ namely, that being, operating a chain saw just outside the barn to muffle noise.'' ``And what was done by Mr. Lundgren at the time while you were operating the chain saw?'' Mitrovich asked. ``The murder of Dennis Avery was committed, sir,'' Winship said. He made similar statements for each of four other counts of complicity to murder, each pertaining to another Avery family member. LaTourette said complicity to murder carries a possible sentence of 15 years to life in prison. Complicity to aggravated murder carries 20 years to life. Co-defendant Richard Brand, also 26 and also of Independence, pleaded guilty March 7 to five counts of murder and agreed to testify for the prosecution. He had been charged with five counts each of aggravated murder and kidnapping.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets $100,000 Bond for Son of Former Panamanian President
DOC.TEXT: A federal magistrate set bond at $100,000 Wednesday for a former Panamanian president's son who is charged with threatening to kill President Bush. ``This is a serious, serious offense,'' said U.S. Magistrate J.Q. Warnick, ending a two-day detention hearing for Otto Lakas. Prosecutor Paulina Jacobo, contending Lakas is a risk to leave the country and a threat to Bush's life, said she would appeal the bail decision. Lakas must remain in jail until the appeal has been heard, Warnick said. Officials in the U.S. attorney's office did not immediately know the hearing date. The Secret Service arrested Lakas on April 17 after he was quoted telling a local pawnbroker he was planning to ``blow Bush's (expletive) head off.'' The 21-year-old architecture student at Lubbock Christian University is the son of Demetrio B. Lakas, who was president of Panama during 1972-78. He was indicted Tuesday on a charge of threatening to kill the president. If convicted, he faces a 3-year prison term or a $250,000 fine, or both. After posting bail, Lakas must pay for and wear an electronic tracking device to monitor his location in Lubbock, Warnick said. And if any one under Secret Service protection comes to Lubbock while Lakas is free on bail, he will be confined to a local Salvation Army halfway house, Warnick said. Lakas has no previous criminal record, police said. Tommy Turner, Lakas' attorney, said he was disappointed with the decision. ``This whole thing is ridiculous,'' Turner said Wednesday. ``I am satisfied the judge listened to our case and judged fairly. But the underlying facts in this case illustrate that this was not a serious threat.'' Lakas told The Associated Press on April 19 he ``was not serious'' when he told Lubbock pawnbroker Stacy Nichols that he ``had a bullet with Bush's name engraved on it.'' Warnick listed five presidents' encounters with assassins during his lifetime and recent threats against some U.S. judges to substantiate his argument that ``this is a very serious matter.'' Lakas' brother, Basilio, who flew to Lubbock from Panama City for the hearing, testified Wednesday his brother was ``incapable of shooting anybody.'' ``Sometimes Otto shoots his mouth off,'' Basilio Lakas testified. ``Once he said he was going to `kick Noriega's butt,' but he wasn't serious.'' Gen. Manuel Noriega was removed from power in Panama during a December invasion of the country by U.S. troops. Stacy and Tracy Nichols, twin brothers who help manage their parents' Exect Pawn Shop, said they talked to Otto Lakas April 4 for more than three hours while Lakas considered buying a .357-caliber revolver. Stacy Nichols said Lakas voiced anger about the invasion of Panama, for which he blamed Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Watermelon Rinds and Riot Police: Inauguration No Black-Tie Affair
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Marimba music blared from loudspeakers. The former first lady wore a baseball cap. And the new president made her entrance to a hail of water balloons. The inauguration of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, held in a Managua baseball stadium Wednesday, was hardly a solemn and decorous affair of state. The scene was 21,000-seat Rigoberto Lopez Perez stadium, named after the poet who assassinated the first of the Somoza family dictators. Sandinista loyalists filled the stands between center field and the third base line. Wearing the party's colors of red and black, the Sandinistas cheered representatives of nations like Cuba and the Soviet Union, while booing envoys of disliked nations. ``Assassin, assassin,'' they chanted when Vice President Dan Quayle went by. El Salvador's rightist president, Alfredo Cristiani, got the same greeting. Outgoing President Daniel Ortega entered on foot, along with his wife, poet Rosario Murillo, who was dressed in skintight denim pants, high boots, a red and black shirt, huge silver earrings and a red baseball cap. Partisans of the United National Opposition pelted them with watermelon rinds and blue-and-white UNO flags, and police quickly charged into the stands. Mrs. Chamorro, still on crutches with a broken knee, entered five minutes later, standing in the back of a white pickup, dressed in white. Sandinista crowd lobbed water-filled plastic bags at the silver-haired widow, drenching several of her police escorts and splattering her skirt. The 60-year-old president dodged the missiles, kept her footing and waved as her truck reached friendly territory, the side of the stadium where a mass of blue-and-white UNO and national flags waved. Applause rang out as she made her way up the stairs to the ceremonial platform, a crutch under one arm and her hand on the railing, and took her place beside Ortega. The stadium began filling hours before the ceremony began under a hot blue tropical sky. With marimba music going full blast, the Sandinistas chanted militaristic party slogans. Finally, a Sandinista waving a huge party flag dashed onto center field, to cheers, whistles and applause. Several UNO supporters, in turn, made a dash for center field with their flags. They were tackled by police. Riot police streamed out and took up positions on both sides of the field about an hour before the dignitaries began arriving. However, the carnival atmosphere calmed when Mrs. Chamorro began her speech. As she spoke, the Sandinistas fell silent, and many quietly filed out of the stadium.

DOC.HEAD: Times-Mirror, Knight-Ridder Merge National Ad Sales Operations
DOC.TEXT: Times Mirror Corp. and Knight-Ridder Inc. said Wednesday they would merge their national advertising sales operations June 4 into a single company called Newspapers First. The new company will represent newspapers reaching about 20 percent of the U.S. adult newspaper readers, the companies said. ``Newspapers First will represent papers from coast to coast and in many of the largest metropolitan areas in the country,'' said Reg Murphy, chairman of Million Market Newspapers-Times Mirror National Marketing, a Times Mirror marketing company. MMN-TMNM, based in New York, sells space in more than a dozen newspapers to national advertisers. Knight-Ridder Newspaper Sales Inc., also based in New York City, serves 26 newspaper markets. Newspapers First will have its headquarters in New York. Additional offices will be located in Chicago, Detroit, Miami, Dallas, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Minneapolis and Atlanta. Times Mirror publishes the Los Angeles Times and Newsday, among other newspapers. Among Knight-Ridder's publications are The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Miami Herald.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Hears of Another Fama Jailhouse Confession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A con man who has admitted repeatedly lying to prosecutors and judges testified Wednesday that the accused gunman in a Brooklyn racial killing admitted committing the crime while they were in jail together. Robert Russo testified he was in protective custody at the Brooklyn House of Detention with Joseph Fama in September when the 19-year-old murder defendant told him about killing 16-year-old Yusef Hawkins. ``He said he popped him because he was a nigger. Fama said he popped him _ Hawkins,'' Russo testified, under questioning by Assistant District Attorney Edward Boyar. Russo said another murder defendant, Keith Mondello, also told him about the incident when they met in jail. But because Russo was called as a witness against only Fama, Justice Thaddeus Owens of Brooklyn state Supreme Court would not permit Russo to repeat Mondello's alleged statements. Another inmate, Charles Brown, testified last week that Fama also confessed to the killing to him. Fama and Mondello, also 19, are being tried on murder and other charges for the Aug. 23 slaying of Hawkins in the Bensonhurst neighorhood of Brooklyn. The black youth was murdered when he and three friends, also black, crossed paths with a mob of whites wielding basebll bats in the mostly white neighborhood. Fama is accused of being the triggerman while Mondello allegedly was the ringleader of the attacking gang. One of the teen-agers with Hawkins, Claude Stanford, 18, told the jury, ``All of a sudden we were surrounded by some guys,'' many carrying bats. Stanford said he didn't see the gunman, but he said Mondello, whom he picked out of a lineup a few days later, was standing before him with a bat. Under questioning by Fama defense lawyer David DePetris, Russo, a cocaine user who has been in and out of jail since 1972, admitted to being a career confidence artist and to repeatedly lying to judges and prosecutors to get out of jail. ``I have a problem that I turn to conning when things get rough,'' Russo said. Russo, sentenced last fall to 4{ to 9 years in jail on robbery charges stemming from a scheme in which he persuaded taxi drivers to give him cash to invest, said he hoped to cut his jail time by testifying against Fama. He said he ran his schemes to cover a $100 to $200 a day cocaine habit, and while in jail often provided information to law enforcers. At one point, when DePetris showed scorn for him, Russo said: ``Did you expect an angel to sit on this stand?'' Russo said he easily gained the confidence of Fama and Mondello because he grew up in Bensonhurst and knew some of the same people they knew.

DOC.HEAD: Angola, UNITA Say Peace Talks Are Set
DOC.TEXT: Angola's foreign minister on Wednesday announced his government would soon begin direct peace talks with the UNITA rebels. Pedro Van Dunem said the talks would begin within a few days, but that the exact dates or location had yet to been agreed upon. ``We are convinced the talks will help us find the path to national reconciliation in Angola,'' he said. A UNITA spokesman in New York, Abel Chivukuvuku, described the planned talks as preliminary and said they were likely to take place in Lisbon, where a UNITA team was already in place. Angola gained independence from Portugal in November 1975. Van Dunem complained the United States and South Africa were resupplying the rebels with logistical aid, weapons and ammunition, and warned that such aid could hamper the talks. But Aubrey K. Dwyer, spokesman for the South African mission, said South African aid to the rebels had stopped under a 1988 agreement. ``So far as we know factually, we are not giving any physical support to UNITA,'' he said by telephone. UNITA spokesman Chivukuvuku also denied the Angolan assertion of fresh South African military aid being given to UNITA, which is the Portuguese acronym for the National Union for the Total Liberation of Angola. The Angolan minister also said Cuban troops, which had fought UNITA rebels for years, were being withdrawn on schedule. He said more than 35,000 had left and about 15,000 remained. He said Angola's leftist government was instituting major economic and political reforms, including implementing the market-oriented economic prescriptions of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. The minister also said Angola was laying groundwork for free general elections, and that the creation of separate executive, legislative and judiciary branches was under discussion.

DOC.HEAD: Balky Telescope Released into Space, Starts 15-Year Voyage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 24th graf, ``Wojtalik said...,' to RESTORE first reference to Wojtalik.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1,6,9
DOC.TEXT: After years of delay and a last-minute snag, the Hubble Space Telescope was freed from the shuttle Discovery on Wednesday and, glinting in the sunlight, drifted into orbit on its 15-year search for new worlds. Mission specialist Steven Hawley released Hubble from the end of the shuttle's 50-foot-long mechanical arm after a delay in getting one of the telescope's solar wings unfurled. ``The first of NASA's great observatories is now on station at 330 nautical miles above the Earth,'' Mission Control's Jeffrey Carr said. ``The telescope really looked great as we flew away from it, and we sure hope it does good work,'' Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver said later. The $1.5 billion telescope was released at 3:38 p.m. EDT as the shuttle entered its 20th orbit of Earth, nearly two hours and one orbit later than planned. The shuttle then backed away. ``Thank you very much for the ride,'' said Mike Harrington, director of orbital verifications at Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan had been in the shuttle's airlock, ready to walk inspace to free the solar panel. That proved to be unnecessary. ``Close but no cigar, but better for the Hubble that it went the way it did,'' Sullivan said. She and McCandless had trained for nearly five years to make such a rescue mission. The first solar array unreeled from its mast at midday Wednesday as the shuttle passed 380 statute miles, or 330 nautical miles, above South America's eastern coast. It started providing power to the telescope's batteries, which otherwise had only eight hours of charge. Deployment of the starboard panel, however, was more troublesome. It wouldn't budge when latches were first released, then moved about a fifth of its 39-foot length, and stopped again. A third attempt rolled the panel out all the way. ``Houston, we see motion,'' Commander Loren J. Shriver reported. Hawley began the long process of releasing Hubble shortly after 7 a.m. EDT when he grasped it with Discovery's 50-foot-long mechanical arm and carefully hoisted the 12{-ton telescope high above the shuttle. Hubble was taken off shuttle electrical power just before it was lifted out of the cargo bay and was operating on its own nickel-hydrogen batteries. ``At one day, seven minutes into the flight of Discovery, Hubble is now on its own internal power,'' Carr said. ``The game has begun. The race is on. The clock is ticking.'' Worries that the telescope's instruments would be starved for electricity eased after the first solar panel was stretched out. Television cameras aboard Discovery showed the first array as it was pulled from its reel slowly but steadily, the sun reflecting off the gold-colored panel and silvery telescope. Discovery was 380 statute miles above Earth, 70 miles higher than any shuttle has ever flown. The orbit was dictated by the need to put the telescope above the Earth's distorting atmosphere. Discovery's five astronauts were awed by the view. ``I'd like to pass on the quote of the day from the on-board astronomer something to the effect that the big marble sure looks far away today,'' Shriver said of Hawley. Astronomers have waited seven years for Hubble to take its place in space. The telescope originally was scheduled for launch in 1983, but technical problems and the Challenger explosion pushed it back. The mission was delayed another two weeks when a faulty power unit on Discovery forced the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to halt the first launch attempt four minutes before April 10's scheduled liftoff. On Tuesday, Discovery finally blasted into space, transporting Hubble out of this world and in search of others. The telescope's 10-foot aperture door is to be opened Friday, exposing the finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight. Discovery was following Hubble in case the door does not open properly. If a problem develops, McCandless and Sullivan will be prepared once again to walk in space. Fred Wojtalik, Hubble project manager, said the telescope would be tested Thursday for its ability to maneuever before the aperture door is opened. ``We want to be in full control so we don't ever endanger the Hubble by putting the aperture door close to the sunlight,'' he said. The telescope cannot focus into the sun because of the sensitivity of its five instruments. If all goes well, the crew will land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. NASA expects to release its first image from the telescope _ of an open star cluster in the constellation Carina _ on Tuesday. Data will follow in a month or two. Astronomers hope to look back to almost the beginning of the time, studying stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. They expect to determine precisely how and when the universe was formed, currently estimated at 15 billion years ago. The telescope is named for the late American astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who discovered during the 1920s that the universe was expanding. He also was responsible for helping to form the Big Bang theory of creation.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Drops Two Midseason Series
DOC.TEXT: ABC's new low-rated ``Capital News'' and ``Sunset Beat'' are being taken off the air for a ``hiatus,'' but there will at least one more ``Elvis'' sighting next month, ABC said Tuesday. ABC's shuffle of the shows, all of them midseason replacements, came a day before the start of the key April 26-May 23 ratings ``sweeps'' that help determine advertising rates for local television stations. ``Sunset Beat,'' about undercover cops in Los Angeles, got the hook after only one broadcast, its premiere Saturday. It will get one more showing this Saturday, with its future to be announced later. It will be replaced on May 5 by two half-hour episodes of the low-rated ``Elvis'' series based on the early career of Elvis Presley. That new show was yanked by ABC last month when it failed to hold its strong Sunday lead-in from the hit ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' ``Capital News,'' a Washington newspaper series that premiered April 9, will leave ABC's schedule after its broadcast next Monday. A film comedy, ``Ruthless People'' will replace it May 7. The two-hour movie also will preempt ``China Beach'' that evening, ABC said. The network will say later what will replace ``Capital News'' on Mondays, said ABC spokesman Tom Mackin. He said the show will return at a later date. Four episodes will have been shown when it leaves the schedule. Nine more episodes have been filmed.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Announces Plan to Cut Gov't Employees, Sell Public Property
DOC.TEXT: The government announced Wednesday that it will fire thousands of public workers and sell off hundreds of official mansions, apartments and vehicles. The month-old administration of President Fernando Collor de Mello, trying to slash hyperinflation and a huge government deficit, already has drastically limited bank withdrawals and plans to sell billions of dollars worth of publicly owned businesses. Secretary of Administration Joao Santana said the reforms, made out of economic necessity, will save Brazil $860 million this year. However, it is only half the cuts Collor promised during his campaign. Santana told a news conference the government identified 11,354 workers holding more than one public job, accounting for 25,740 federal positions. They will have 30 days to justify their situation or lose at least one of their jobs, he said. Santana said the government expected to save $34 million a month by doing away with double job-holding, bonuses for top employees and high-security job categories. The reforms are the most radical in Brazil's history. They are aimed at reducing a bloated, inefficient bureaucracy and cutting expenses considered largely responsible for Brazil's 2,700 percent inflation last year. Santana, who is in charge of the reform program, also said 23 state companies were being eliminated and 12,000 workers with less than five years on the job would be fired. Congress has approved the cuts. Brazil has more than 700,000 federal employees. A new constitution enacted in 1988 gives workers job stability after five years. The government also announced the sale of nine mansions and 9,391 apartments that were reserved for ministers and high functionaries, as well as 2,500 cars and planes, tugboats and 350 dredges. Santana said the money saved could pay for 87,000 low-cost houses, or pay the salaries of 151,775 teachers or 88,000 doctors. But, he added, ``the government must eliminate its budget deficit, and these funds will enter the National Treasury to cover gaps.'' The savings from the austerity measures still are far below what Collor promised when he took office Mar. 15. He predicted spending cuts of $1.75 billion, equal to about 2 percent of Brazil's $350 billion gross domestic product. The next step in the government's plan is a National Privatization Program that calls for the sale of many of Brazil's 188 state companies, which have a combined debt of $62 billion. The Brazilian Congress has authorized the sale of most government companies except for the oil monopoly Petrobras, the postal service, the telecommunications giant Embratel, development banks and the Bank of Brazil, the country's largest commercial bank. Foreign capital can acquire only 49 percent of stock in ``privatized'' companies and 33 percent of voting capital.

DOC.HEAD: Uncertainty Over Soviet Aims Requires Strong U.S. Defense, Cheney Says
With AM-US-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Defense Richard Cheney said Wednesday the United States is obligated to remain strong militarily because of the Soviet Union's past abuses of power and uncertainty over its commitment to reform. ``The new openness has not yet transformed hope into the reality of a freer government,'' Cheney said. ``And that reality is what we need to see, to allay the fears of the rest of the world about the Soviets' enormous military power. ``Until that happens _ until we are confident that Moscow will not again use its military capability to conquer and intimidate _ Soviet glasnost will only be a partial answer to our defense concerns,'' said Cheney, addressing the American Newspaper Publishers Association's annual conference. He said that Moscow's response to Lithuania's fight for independence is a ``lead indicator'' of future Soviet developments. ``If the solution that ultimately develops is based on peaceful action, not coercion ... then confidence in Soviet reform will grow,'' Cheney said. ``But we will draw very different conclusions if this issue is resolved by military force and intimidation _ the tactics of empire and not of reform.'' Cheney, after giving a litany of past Soviet aggressions, said he remains skeptical about Soviet intentions. He said that despite Soviet promises to reduce troops, nearly a half-million Soviet soldiers remain in Eastern Europe. He cited a report from a group of Soviet officials this week that the CIA had underestimated the percentage of Soviet GNP devoted to the military. ``They said the CIA was overly optimistic about developments inside the Soviet Union. It seems to me I've had the same problem,'' he said. Cheney acknowledged that reforms are under way, but he said the ``transformation of Soviet society is just beginning.'' ``Overall, the world is looking for open political arrangements among the peoples of the Soviet Union based on democratic values, not coercion,'' he said. The Bush administration, optimistic that such change is possible, is working with the Soviet Union to reduce strategic and conventional armaments and restructure U.S. military forces to lower defense costs, Cheney said. ``But we have to remember that there is a point below which we can go and still provide the global defense we need in the years ahead,'' he added. ``Security threats were not invented by the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, and threats will remain long after that party has gone out of business,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Dismissal Motion, Hondurans Plan Protest
DOC.TEXT: A judge rejected a motion Wednesday to dismiss murder charges against a man accused of torching an illegal social club and killing 87 revelers. Defense attorney Richard W. Berne had asked for the dismissal on grounds that he had not had access to a videotaped statement taken from Julio Gonzalez by police before a grand jury indicted him. Gonzalez has pleaded innocent to 174 counts of murder. State Supreme Court Judge Burton R.
