Roberts rejected Berne's motion and set May 30 for Gonzalez' next court appearance, when it was expected that a psychiatric report would be available. Gonzalez, 36, has been held in a prison ward at a psychiatric hospital since his arrest in the pre-dawn fire that killed 87 people at the Happy Land social club March 25. He faces charges of murder by arson and murder by depraved indifference for each of the victims, plus two counts of arson and one count each of assault and attempted murder. Police say Gonzalez, a Cuban immigrant, admitted setting the fire after an argument with a former girlfriend who worked at the club. She was one of five people known to have escaped the fire. Most of the victims were Honduran immigrants. Meanwhile, a group of Hondurans said they would appeal to Roberts to reconsider his position that Gonzalez, a Cuban immigrant, could draw only one maximum 25-year-to-life sentence even if convicted on all counts. That could make him eligible for parole in 25 years. Roberts has said New York law provides for concurrent rather than consecutive sentences in cases where multiple deaths result from one criminal act. ``We feel that this is too narrow an interpretation of the law,'' Jose Velasquez, a civil engineer, said outside the courtroom after Wednesday's hearing. Velasquez said a petition drive among an estimated 50,000 Hondurans living in the city would be conducted by a newly formed group calling itself the Federation of Honduran Organizations in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Pulls Advertisement After Readers Call It Ethnic Slur
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper has pulled advertisements featuring Polish leader Lech Walesa speaking in broken English after Mayor John O. Norquist and others complained the ad amounted to an ethnic slur. The Milwaukee Journal used newspaper, television and radio advertisements featuring Walesa and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to promote the newspaper's new page designs, unveiled this month. The Walesa newspaper advertisement shows a photo of the Nobel Prize-winning founder of Poland's Solidarity movement with the words: ``Very long I have hoped for changes so significant as those in new Milwaukee Journal.'' The Thatcher ad pictures the prime minister with the words ``Why yes, the American colonies have progressed. Consider the recent changes in your Milwaukee Journal.'' Both ads involved contrived quotes. Robert Dye, spokesman for the Journal, said the ads were intended to be ``lighthearted spoofs'' and both were pulled this week. ``I guess it just didn't click,'' Dye said. ``It didn't have the impact we intended. The original intent was that it be fun. As soon as we realized it wasn't working, we pulled the ads.'' The quarter-page Walesa ad ran in Monday's Journal editions. It drew an immediate letter from Norquist, who complained the use of the broken English ``shows an obvious lack of respect for Walesa and for Polish culture.'' ``I'm sure that since English is not his native language, he probably does not speak it as well as you do,'' Norquist wrote to Journal Editor Sig Gissler. ``At the same time, I wonder how well you speak Polish.'' The head of the city's annual Polish ethnic festival charged the television advertisement featuring Walesa was even more degrading to Poles. ``I thought it rather demeaning to the Polish ethnic groups,'' said Richard Gralinski, executive director of Polish Fest. ``I certainly thought it was an ethnic slur.'' Milwaukee, a city of about 600,000 people, has more than 180,000 residents of Polish ancestry, Gralinski noted.

DOC.HEAD: Herds Build Up After Years of Poachers' Slaughter
DOC.TEXT: While poachers have decimated wild animals throughout most of Africa, a crackdown on illegal hunters in Uganda has boosted herds of elephants in wildlife sanctuaries, the government said Wednesday. The elephant population in Ruwenzori National Park has swelled from 450 three years ago to 700, Uganda National Parks director Eric Edroma told reporters. The reserve was home to 3,000 of the animals in the 1960s. After Uganda's independence from Britain in 1962, government troops, guerrillas, poachers and hungry villagers combined to slaughter thousands of pachyderms throughout the country, Edroma said. Most were gunned down when former dictator Idi Amin ruled the east African nation from 1971 to 1979, mainly by soldiers with machine guns who smuggled the ivory to the Middle East and Asia. By 1980, a year after Idi Amin was toppled in a military coup, only 150 elephants were roaming Ruwenzori park in western Uganda. When President Yoweri Museveni seized power in 1986, he vowed to protect wildlife and mounted a nationwide sweep against poachers. Today, apart from 450 elephants that remain within the 1,200-square-mile sanctuary, 250 migrants divide their time between Ruwenzori and the Virunga National Park in neighboring Zaire. The elephant population throughout the continent has plummeted from 1.5 million in 1978 to as few as 400,000 because of widespread poaching, often with the connivance of politicians, bureaucrats and security chiefs.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Appeal to Cyprus to End Soviet Travel to Israel
DOC.TEXT: Arab diplomats asked Cyprus' Parliament on Wednesday to restrict Soviet Jewish emigrants from using Cypriot ports as they travel to Israel. A government announcement said the heads of Arab diplomatic missions in Cyprus called on Vassos Lyssarides, president of the House of Representatives, to protest the use of the island as a transit point for Soviet emigrants. Lyssarides is serving as acting president until President George Vassiliou returns from a trip abroad. Also Wednesday, several Greek Cypriot newspapers criticized the government for not ending the travel. ``How can we appeal for international support against the colonization of our land by Turkey, when we ourselves facilitate the colonization of the occupied territories of other states,'' the right-wing Agon wrote. The northern section of Cyprus is occupied by Turkish troops, and thousand of mainland Turks have been moved into the area. The newspapers also said the government was risking terrorist attacks by Arab groups that have threatened to strike against facilities used by Soviet Jewish immigrants on their way to Israel. In a press statement issued Monday, the Arab diplomats aluded to terrorist threats made by Arab extremist groups, which have threatened to attack facilities and carriers used by the Soviet immigrants. The diplomats ``expressed surprise at the facilities offered by Cyprus to the Soviet immigrant Jews,'' particularly in view of the ``dangers they pose to its national security.'' Cyprus has stepped up security precautions at both Larnaca airport and the port of Limassol. The Soviet embassy's press attache in Nicosia, Vladimir Chizhov, told a press conference Tuesday that Soviet Jews travelling to Israel via Cyprus were tourists with return tickets. He said some did stay on in Israel, but added that the Soviet Union could not restrict their freedom of travel. Hundreds of Soviet Jews have been arriving at Larnaca the past few weeks aboard Soviet Aeroflot jets. They complete their journey to Israel by sea from Limassol. Larnaca has long been used as a stopover by Soviet tourists arriving in Israel to visit family. There is no direct transit between the Soviet Union and Israel. The inflow has sparked an outrage in the Arab world, which fears that some of the newcomers could settle in the Israeli-occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip and that the mass immigration will strengthen the Jewish state. Monday, Israeli officials said that 25,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants arrived this year. Israeli officials say the number is expected to reach 100,000 by the end of the year. Only about 200 Soviet immigrants have settled in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: DC-3 Crashes Near Military Cemetery, Killing Six
DOC.TEXT: A DC-3 plane carrying 22 passengers and crew crashed Thursday near a military cemetery in Manila, killing at least six and injuring 16, officials said. The aircraft crashed near the Hero's Cemetery at Fort Bonifacio, headquarters of the Philippine army. The cemetery is the burial place for Filipino war heroes and other prominent national figures. The sprawling military complex also includes housing for soldiers and a U.S. military cemetery. Diosdado Santarin, a spokeswoman for the airport emergency services, said some of the victims may have been residents of military housing areas near the cemetery. Santarin said the propeller aircraft, owned by the private Manila Air Transport System, reported engine trouble shortly after takeoff from Manila airport and tried to make an emergency landing at the military complex, a few miles northeast of the civil airport. The aircraft was headed for Roxas, 250 miles southeast of Manila. Pilot Anastacio Maravilla, who suffered minor injuries, told a local radio station he could not return to the airport for an emergency landing due to poor weather conditions and because the plane was losing power too quickly.

DOC.HEAD: After Seven Months, St. Louis Sun Calls It Quits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to include that Sun was 7-day, morning tabloid, give Ingersoll's position as head of Ingersoll Publications, UPDATE the decision made Sunday, 194 jobs to go, Ingersoll saying problem was single-copy sales, paper's owner. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `On April...'; ADDS 6 grafs with Post-Dispatch comment, Ingersoll's junk-bond troubles at another company. A version also moved on business wire.
DOC.TEXT: The St. Louis Sun, which hoped to be the first major metropolitan newspaper to make a successful launch in this country since World War II, unexpectedly folded Wednesday after only seven months. At a news conference, Ralph Ingersoll II, editor in chief of the new newspaper, said the St. Louis Sun had published its last edition Tuesday night. ``Closing the Sun was a decision the St. Louis marketplace made for us,'' said Ingersoll, who is also chairman and chief executive officer of Princeton, N.J.-based Ingersoll Publications Co. Since launching the seven-day morning tabloid Sept. 25, 1989, the newspaper had published 213 editions. ``It is clear that we could not achieve sufficient circulation to make this enterprise viable and so, we have concluded that there is no longer room in St. Louis for a third newspaper in addition to our own Suburban Journals and the Post-Dispatch,'' Ingersoll said. The Sun struggled to overcome higher-than-expected costs, revolving-door circulation, limited advertising and a murky image. The newspaper also had troubles developing everyday readers. The decision to stop the presses was made Sunday, Ingersoll said, but apparently few people knew until hours before the news conference. He said the closure, which will cost 194 employees their jobs, stemmed from a failure to build single-copy sales through vending machines and retail outlets, and wasn't based on any pressure from advertisers or investors. ``It had nothing to do with money, you'll have to take my word for it,'' Ingersoll said. ``It had to do with single copy sales.'' The Sun is owned by Ingersoll Newspapers, which owns 77 other papers and is part of Ralph Ingersoll II's newspaper holdings. On April 1, the newspaper had a circulation of 109,000, up from a low of 80,000 during the winter, aided by the start of a new ``Bingo'' promotion. Ingersoll had guaranteed advertisers circulation of 105,000 for the first six months of 1990. The Sun also was criticized by some as sensationalizing stories for its coverage of a politician involved in a sexual assault and of the five-year anniversary of an accident in which a man was nearly sawed in two. The newspaper was further chided for running photos of new women's swimsuits and lingerie. But the Sun was praised for its coverage of the effort to build a new domed stadium downtown and of the troubles facing St. Louis' major air carrier, Trans World Airlines. Some critics derided the Sun's flood of promotions, fluorescent green billboards and contests, but Sun executives defended those practices as the best way to encourage people to give their paper a try. In making the surprise announcement, Ingersoll was flanked by poster-size blowups of various pages of the Sun. Also on hand were publisher Tom Tallarico, who left the Post-Dispatch to join the Sun, and Robert Jelenic, president of Ingersoll Publications Co. Lorraine Orlandi, a reporter who joined the paper when it was launched, said the 4 p.m. announcement came as a shock, and some employees cried, but within about two hours staff members had brought cases of beer into the newsroom. ``We were putting out a newspaper today. I had just returned from City Hall with a couple of stories to write,'' Ms. Orlandi said. ``The people here are not gloomy. People are in shock,'' she said. ``There were no visible signs that we were shutting down, or even cutting back. There were renovations going on.'' In an interview earlier this month, Ingersoll said the two main problems facing the Sun were higher-than-expected circulation costs and a whopping turnover rate among home subscribers. Ingersoll said at the time the company had been forced to spend $5 million more than planned to distribute the newspaper because twice as many readers as expected wanted their newspapers delivered. ``Advertisers consider that to be very good, but it's much more expensive than we planned for,'' Ingersoll said. But home subscribers also were canceling their subscriptions at an extremely fast rate, making it difficult for the Sun to sign up enough new subscribers to keep circulation from falling. William Woo, editor of the Post-Dispatch, said the Sun had set out on a difficult mission. ``We are saddened for the people who worked hard at the Sun and we are saddened for those in St. Louis who depended upon the paper,'' Woo said in a statement. The Post-Dispatch's circulation is about 375,000 Monday through Friday, and 565,000 on Sunday. The announcement came five days after Ingersoll had a setback in his effort to resolve problems with junk-bond debt at another of his companies, Community Newspapers Inc. Ingersoll offered to buy back at cut-rate prices more than half of the company's $240 million in junk bonds, which it used for expansion. But no bondholders signed up to sell their bonds back to Ingersoll, even though the bonds have been trading at an even lower price, about 40 cents on the dollar, than what he offered. If the company can't agree with bondholders on a buyback, it could be forced to more than double the interest rate on some of the bonds this June to a rate of more than 26 percent. Ingersoll said those problems were unrelated to the Sun.

DOC.HEAD: Students End Occupation of Princeton President's Office
DOC.TEXT: Princeton University students ended a 32{-hour occupation of President's Harold Shapiro's office Wednesday after officials agreed to expand programs dealing with sexual harassment and assault. University officials refused to meet the specific demands of the 30 students who invaded the office early Tuesday. But they agreed to devote more resources to expand the programs to include graduate students. If the counseling center needs more staff to do so, the university will provide it, Vice President Thomas Wright said in a statement. The students had demanded that center staff be doubled to three full-time therapists. ``The administration is delighted that we've resolved this issue without violent confrontation ... without having to result to the use of force,'' said Princeton spokeswoman Jacquelyn Savani. The university also agreed to create a task force to design the new programs, and to hold a forum in the fall to address the center's needs. The protesters say 208 students sought counseling at the center during the 1988-89 academic year, up from fewer than 50 the year before. Wright had said Tuesday that the administration could not increase funding for a program in the middle of the school year. He told the students to follow formal channels and appeal to the Priorities Committee, which meets in the fall and makes budget recommendations for the following school year. The students said conventional channels had provided little satisfaction. Shapiro left his office shortly after the students arrived at about 9 a.m. Tuesday, officials said. He then left campus for several days of meetings in Washington. Talks between the students and other officials deadlocked Tuesday. About 50 student sympathizers held an all-night vigil outside the building, said student spokesman Matthew Polly. The Sexual Harassment@Assault Advising, Resources and Education center serves about 2,300 students, largely new freshmen. According to its annual report, of the 208 people who sought counseling during the 1988-89 school year, 71 said they were victims of sexual harassment or assault, incest or violence within a relationship. In all but eight cases, the victims were women. In all but one case, the alleged assailants were men.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Prison Revolts End, Reforms Planned
DOC.TEXT: About 100 convicts at Sofia's central prison and dozens of prisoners in other cities ended a weeklong standoff after officials promised reform and freed some people held in investigative custody, the Justice Ministry said Wednesday. Two Sofia inmates were hospitalized after trying to set themselves on fire last week, but no other injuries were reported. Angel Djambozov, first deputy minister of justice in charge of prisons, said seven Sofia prisoners still refused to get off the roof eight days after the protest began, the state BTA news agency reported. Some inmates had threatened suicide if their reform demands were not met. About 80 inmates had climbed onto the prison roof in Pazardjik, 60 miles east of the capital, on April 17. BTA said 52 ended their protest voluntarily and the other 30 were ``returned to their cells.'' It did not elaborate. Similar protests reportedly began the same day in Varna, Plovdiv and Vraca. Djambazov said the prison strikes were settled without violence, BTA said. The ministry official said seven people were released from Sofia prison because they were kept longer than the prescribed six months for investigative custody. Djambozov told a news conference he would visit all of Bulgaria's prisons as part of a plan to improve living conditions and solve other problems, BTA reported. The government has begun instituting reform since hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov was ousted in November after 35 years in power.

DOC.HEAD: Shattered Window in Judge's Car Was Probably Accident; No One Hurt
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge whose colleague was assassinated last year was being driven to work by U.S. marshals when the car's rear window shattered, launching a police sweep that found it was likely an accident. The sedan was carrying 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge J.L. Edmondson from his suburban home to the Atlanta court around 8:30 a.m. when the rear window broke, authorities reported. No one was hurt, and after several nervous hours investigators said it was likely that no one was meant to be, despite initial police reports that someone had fired a gun at the car. ``There is no reason for anyone to assume at this point there was any effort to injure the judge,'' said Stephen Boyle, spokesman for the U.S. Marshals Service in Washington. ``There is no evidence to suggest there was a projectile of any sort intended to cause harm.'' Investigators surmised that a defective window simply shattered, or that an abrupt temperature change in the car broke the glass. Security has been tight around 11th Circuit judges since Judge Robert Vance, of Alabama, was killed Dec. 16 by one of four mail bombs sent to judicial and civil-rights targets in the Southeast. The U.S. Marshals Service has been escorting the judges to and from work. On Dec. 18, another of the mail bombs killed a Savannah civil rights attorney, Robert Robinson. Soon after the car window broke Wednesday, Gwinnett County police spokesman Larry Walton reported that an ``unknown individual'' had ``apparently ... shot at the vehicle'' as it rolled through the city of Lawrenceville. A helicopter began searching, and Lawrenceville Police Chief Robert Sutton said officers had converged on a possible suspect in a nearby subdivision. Police cordoned off and swarmed into the area, alarming local workers, but found no suspect. And at midday, federal investigators said they had been unable to confirm that any object was fired at the car. FBI spokesman Dan Eramian in Washington said no projectile was found in or around the vehicle. ``Police were on the roof, everywhere _ 20 to 30 of them,'' said Rita McMahon, an employee at the Finamart store a block away from where the window broke. The judge's car pulled into the parking lot of a nearby county school system building, and police ordered employees not to leave the area, said schools spokeswoman Berney Kirkland. And workers locked themselves in an office in nearby Button Gwinnett Hospital, where spokesman Gary Morris said police and news helicopters were landing and taking off all morning.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrities Come out for Preservation of Walden Pond
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd to last graf to CORRECT 1st word of quote to `Thoreau,' sted `Walden.' ^By DANA KENNEDY
DOC.TEXT: Inspired by Henry David Thoreau's 19th-century homage to Walden Pond, a group of celebrities launched an international fund-raising campaign Wednesday to buy historic land slated for development around it. The leader of the group, singer-songwriter Don Henley, displayed a check for $250,000 in announcing plans to save Walden Woods, the once-unspoiled forest that Thoreau retreated to more than 130 years ago to write his classic ``Walden.'' Seated in two neat rows at historic Faneuil Hall and sipping individual bottles of Evian water were such celebrities as Don Johnson, best known for his role as a cop on ``Miami Vice,'' Ed Begley Jr., who recently played a philandering husband in the film ``She Devil,'' Bonnie Raitt, whose latest hit is titled ``Thing Called Love,'' and Dana Delany, who plays the tough Army nurse on ``China Beach.'' ``When I was 17 and went to school in Andover, I went to Walden Pond and went skinny dipping there,'' said Delany, dressed in a black leather jacket and black stirrup pants. ``I was understandably aghast when I heard what was happening there.'' ``Henry David Thoreau was 150 years ahead of his time,'' said the 42-year-old Henley, wearing a suit with a slicked back ponytail and glasses. ``His writing presaged the environmental movement and it seems appropriate to save his lands.'' The money was raised from ticket sales to two concerts headlined by Henley, Raitt, Bob Seger, Glenn Frey, John Cougar Mellencamp and others at the Worcester Centrum this week. Henley organized the benefits after seeing a report on Cable News Network earlier this year about the proposed development of a condominium project and office park near Walden Pond. The plan of the Walden Woods Project is to raise the estimated $8 million needed to buy the lands from developers Mortimer Zuckerman and Philip De Normandie. Henley said Wednesday that Zuckerman has donated $100,000 to the project. The celebrities' plan also calls for the construction of affordable housing farther away from Walden Woods. Others involved in the project include Michael Kennedy, son of the late Sen. Robert F. Kennedy and co-chairman of the Walden Woods Project with Henley, novelist E.L. Doctorow, former U.S. Sen. Paul Tsongas, and various state officials and environmental leaders. ``These places of refuge are going to become paramount,'' Johnson said. ``It's up to us to take a stand if we're going to have a place to go and contemplate and know the Earth as it once was.'' Doctorow, author of the best-selling ``Ragtime,'' said: ``Thoreau was an Everyman and he chose Walden to be his Everywhere. Walden is a book that could only be written by an American. We wouldn't exist as a people without this book. We have to be able to say, `you read the book, now see the place.''' Walden Pond is a 62-acre body of water in a 333-acre state reservation on the edge of Concord, an affluent town of 12,500 about 20 miles from Boston. The pond, however, is far less pastoral than when Walden lived by its shore in a tiny shack in 1845. It lies less than a hundred yards from a highway and is adjacent to a garbage dump.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Flats Official Says Plutonium in Air Ducts Could Kill
DOC.TEXT: Sixty-two pounds of plutonium lodged in the air ducts at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant could cause a radiation leak that could kill some workers, plant operators say. But the conditions under which that could happen are unlikely to occur, and EG&G Inc. is working to eliminate all risk of such an incident, said Phil Warner, Rocky Flats manager, on Tuesday. More than 100 people packed into a meeting of the Rocky Flats Environmental Monitoring Council to hear Warner discuss the plutonium, which has accumulated in the ventilation ductwork at the plutonium processing buildings. Warner said plant officials haven't decided whether to remove the plutonium, or when the plutonium processing operations at the plant will resume. ``The plutonium is contained within the pipes,'' Warner said. ``When you start talking about removing it, there's the possibility of plutonium getting in the atmosphere in the building. Removing ducts is not easy.'' Rocky Flats, which is operated by EG&G for the federal Department of Energy, manufactures plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. Plutonium processing operations were shut down at the plant last fall so EG&G could implement new safety and environmental monitoring programs. Energy Secretary James Watkins has said he wants the operations to resume by the end of June. The plutonium buildup in the air ducts was discovered during a survey of the plant. Federal investigators have said employees using gloveboxes to manufacture plutonium triggers often bypassed air filters or poked holes in them rather than change them in order to get more work done. That practice allowed plutonium dust to escape through the filters into the air ducts, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors: Elizabeth Taylor Nearly Died
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Miss Taylor...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with physician saying she did not have nfections common with AIDS, other details.
DOC.TEXT: Oscar-winning actress Elizabeth Taylor nearly died of pneumonia last weekend, but is responding well to treatment, although ``she is not out of the woods,'' her doctor said Wednesday. A biopsy revealed that the 58-year-old Academy Award-winning actress has viral pneumonia to which she is responding, Dr. Bernard Weintraub, a pulmonary specialist. ``She is awake and alert and progressing nicely at this time,'' he said. Dr. Patricia Murray, an infectious disease specialist, told reporters Miss Taylor was pleased her physicians took her off a ventilator that had been aiding her breathing. ``She was very happy the tube was out,'' Murray told reporters at St. Johns Hospital and Health Center. ``She said she'd come out and wave to you but she's not in her balcony attire.'' Weintraub said he believed Miss Taylor would survive. ``I believe her life was in jeopardy over the weekend and I believe that has now passed,'' Weintraub said. But, he added, ``She is not out of the woods.'' Miss Taylor entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 for what was described as a persistent fever and sinus infection. When her condition worsened, she was transferred April 16 to St. Johns. In a statement after arriving at St. Johns, the actress denied rumors that she was suffering from an AIDS-related condition. ``There was no suggestion of either cancer or infections commonly seen in AIDS,'' Weintraub said. Miss Taylor was moved to the intensive care unit of St. Johns on Friday, her physicians said. With the actress Wednesday were her four children, Maria Burton-Carson, Liza Todd-Tivey and Christopher and Michael Wilding. Also present were several close friends, Weintraub said. The friends were not identified. The hospital released a statement on Miss Taylor's behalf thanking fans and friends for their cards and letters during her hospitalization. ``Since she was admitted to St. Johns on April 16, Miss Taylor has received many letters and cards from supporters, and along with her family appreciates their prayers and concern,'' the hospital said. Miss Taylor has been plagued with health problems for years, particularly recurring back troubles from the filming of the 1945 movie ``National Velvet,'' when she fell off a horse. In 1983 she acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and pain killers prescribed for a wide range of health problems. Miss Taylor has been treated for alcohol and drug abuse problems at the Betty Ford Clinic in Rancho Mirage. During a nearly fatal bout with pneumonia in 1961, Miss Taylor underwent a tracheotomy, in which an incision was cut into her windpipe to help her breathe. She appeared at the 1961 Academy Awards with a bandage over her tracheotomy scar as she accepted her Oscar for ``Butterfield 8.''

On the eve of her inauguration, President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro infuriated leaders of her political coalition with her apparent decision to retain the Sandinistas' longtime military chief. Gen. Humberto Ortega, a leader of the Sandinista revolution, is to stay on for a time to promote reconciliation between the pro-U.S. administration and the leftists who ruled Nicaragua for a decade, an administration source said. Nicaragua is emerging from nine years of civil war that claimed 30,000 lives and left the economy in tatters, and Mrs. Chamorro has promised its 3.5 million people peace. But by keeping outgoing President Daniel Ortega's brother at the helm of the military, Mrs. Chamorro could be making it more difficult to persuade the U.S.-supported Contra rebels to disarm.

The Bush administration is ruling out any immediate warming of relations with Syria despite a courtesy call by President Bush and an official pat on the back for assisting in the liberation of U.S. hostage Robert Polhill. ``While Syria has taken certain positive steps since 1986 to combat terrorism, including its role in the release of Mr. Polhill, we continue to be very concerned about the presence in Syria and Syria-controlled areas of terrorist groups,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Tuesday. The groups include Ahmed Jabril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine _ General Command, suspected in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in December 1988 in which 270 people were killed; the Japanese Red Army and the Abu Nidal organization, Ms. Tutwiler said. The first has its headquarters in Damascus; the other two are in the Bekka Valley of Lebanon. ``Syria's current relations with these groups is an impediment to better U.S.-Syrian relations,'' the spokeswoman said.

Home ports under construction in New York, Alabama, Mississippi, Texas and Washington state are among 34 military installations the Navy is considering for possible closure. A three-page list of Navy recommendations for closure, realignment and consolidation surfaced Tuesday during a hearing by two House Armed Services subcommittees. The list drew immediate criticism from a lawmaker who released the document, and a Navy statement that it was a preliminary compilation and not a ``hit list.'' The Pentagon ``politically wants us to open and close bases at the same time,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., who opposes continued spending on new home ports nationwide.

After more than 50 years, the United States is ready to pursue normal diplomatic relations with Albania despite its reputation as one of the world's most rigid police states. The State Department responded favorably on Tuesday to a statement last week in which Albanian President Ramiz Alia expressed interest in establishing diplomatic ties. He made the same overture to the Soviet Union. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler, in a statement, referred only indirectly to Albania's human rights record. ``Establishment of diplomatic relations would create the opportunity for dialogue through which we would be able to communicate our concerns and encourage respect for human rights in Albania,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Fashion Update: Clothes That Go From Office to Opera
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Toss out those boring ball gowns, tedious bows, gargantuan shoulder pads and thigh-high hemlines. Style 1990 is sumptuous but simple, sedate without being dated. ``When the world is feeling quiet, like it is when it has a lot of things to address, designers are feeling that, too,'' said Andy Basile, vice president and fashion director at Bergdorf Goodman. Fashion experts say designers reflect the national mood, particularly the current economic climate, in the clothes they make. That means a return for fall to more classic looks customers are sure to want. ``There is a certain nervousness about what will sell because of the retail environment and economic times,'' said Patrick McCarthy, executive editor of Women's Wear Daily. ``People are playing it safe.'' In their fall 1990 collections, presented in recent weeks in Seventh Avenue showrooms and ritzy hotel ballrooms, designers sought to strike a balance between safe and special. The result was a quieter look. The fabrics are sumptuous, both in their richness and their simplicity. Beaded and sequinned silks parade alongside cashmeres and wools that look soft enough to swaddle a baby. The line is clean and minimal. The silhouette is kind to the body _ not too tight and not too loose. In his show in the Plaza Hotel's ornate ballroom, Oscar de la Renta said goodbye to the ball gown. Instead, he showed long evening skirts with multicolored jeweled jackets, simply cut from dazzling rich fabrics. Collection colors include greens and gold, but no loud neon-sign hues here. Hemlines show the knee, but the legs are covered in hosiery the same color as the outfit, unitards, tights or leggings. A favorite theme running through the shows was a touch of evening elegance in day wear, and sporty day accents for night. Donna Karan jazzes up daytime cashmeres with black sequin scarves. Her basic unitard becomes a sexy evening outfit when done in velvet and worn under a sheer, floor-length organza blouse. The blurring between day and night has a very practical side. A little mixing and matching makes an item of clothing wearable around the clock. Designers also have latched onto outdoor wear, like parkas and anoraks, and transported them from ski slopes and fishing streams to exclusive Upper East Side restaurants and Metropolitan Opera openings. De la Renta showed a quilted floral silk parka striped in gold over a silk charmeuse blouse and multicolored sequinned skirt. Calvin Klein, a master of quiet, understated clothes, came up with lots of turtleneck sweaters worn over short skirts with tights. One of his best was a forest green fisherman's sweater with a spruce and black plaid wrap skirt and loden and gray shawl. In her review, Bernadine Morris of The New York Times called his collection, ``quiet, wonderful and just about perfect.'' But WWD gave him a ``B'' in its review and commented, ``It's .. . unfortunate that Calvin, one of America's most important and most prosperous designers, plays it so safe.'' No one could have been bored at the Geoffrey Beene show. Beene's sculpted clothes are pared down to the simplest shapes, perfectly proportioned. His streamlined catsuits, two-piece tweed suits and long monastic dresses are accented by triangular inserts, asymmetrical belts, stand-up collars and slim leather halters that slip over one shoulder. His colors, often somber, can be vibrant. A high-collared, long-sleeved monastic gown is regal in a floral pattern of hunter green and gold. The result is ultramodern clothing that would be at home in a Star Trek vessel.

DOC.HEAD: Revision Of Broadly Endorsed Bible Out In May
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: ``And he went out from Pharaoh in hot anger.'' So reads Exodus 11:8 about Moses in the Revised Standard Version of the Bible. A new, clearer rendering reads, ``And in hot anger he left Pharaoh.'' That's a sample of the clarifying changes made in the New Revised Standard Version reaching bookstores in May after 15 years work by an interfaith team of Scripture scholars. Seeking greater accuracy, clarity and more natural, intelligible and flowing English, the revision refines phrasing in what has been America's most broadly endorsed version of Scripture, the RSV. That 38-year-old version holds approval of most major Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox denominations. It's the first version to gain that common acceptance, says the Rev. Gerald Knoff, veteran Christian educator. The revision of it, the NRSV, produced by a 30-member group of Protestant, Roman Catholic, Eastern Orthodox and Jewish scholars, draws on older original manuscripts for correctness and also sharpens the English wording. ``Those that were sent went,'' reads Luke 19:32 in the old RSV, but the NRSV puts it more smoothly, ``Those who were sent departed.'' An instance of greater precision is Amos 6:5, which in the old wording cites those who ``like David invent for themselves instruments of music.'' Now, it says those who ``like David improvise on instruments of music.'' The Rev. Bruce M. Metzger of Princeton Theological Seminary, the courtly and learned Bible scholar who headed the translation team, calls the new version both ``the newest and oldest.'' He said the aim was to be ``as literal as possible'' in adhering to the ancient Hebrew and Greek texts but also ``as free as necessary'' in making the meaning clear in graceful, understandable English. The NRSV was produced under auspices of the National Council of Churches, which also sparked production of the RSV in 1952. The translation team worked without charge, unlike translators of many other versions. Six different publishing companies are putting out various editions of the revision, some including the deutero-canonical or apocryphal books between the Old and New Testaments, as wanted by some denominations. The Rev. Arthur O. Van Eck, head of the council's division of education, calls the new revision a ``Bible for our time.'' In keeping with growing liturgical usage, the revision replaces the former uses of ``thee'' and ``thou'' in addressing God with ``you.'' Metzger noted the original texts use the same pronoun in addressing God and people. Despite some pressures for more sexually inclusive terms, Metzger said that was done only when the text allowed it concerning people. Pronouns remain masculine in referring to God and Jesus. There was ``no tampering with the gender of deity,'' Metzger said. ``God remains `Our Father,' and Jesus Christ is the `Son of God'.'' However, he said English, unlike Hebrew and Greek, lacks a common-gender, third-person pronoun, leading to a masculine bias to male pronouns about people in past translations although the original text is more inclusive. For instance, in the RSV, John 2:l0 reads, ``Every man serves the good wine first,'' but the text doesn't specify ``man''. Consequently, the revision reads, ``Everone serves the good wine first.'' Other corrections of unnecessary masculine renderings include Matthew 4:4, which in the RSV reads, ``Man does not live by bread alone.'' ``One'' replaces ``Man'' in the revision. In the Song of Solomon, Metzger said that in the sentence, ``I am black but beautiful,'' the conjunction, ``and'' replaces ``but,'' which had implied black isn't beautiful. He said the change also conforms with the usual translation of the Hebrew word,``wa'' which 49 out of 50 times is translated as ``and,'' not ``but''. Samples of other changes: Deuteronomy 29:5 _ RSV _ ``Your sandals have not worn off your feet.'' NRSV _ ``Your sandals have not worn out on your feet.'' Hebrews 11:16 _ RSV _ ``God prepared for them a city.'' NRSV _ God prepared a city for them.'' Psalm 50:9 _ RSV _ ``I will accept no bull from your house.'' NRSV _ ``I will not accept a bull from your house.'' First Samuel 24:11 _ RSV _ ``Though you hunt my life to take it. ..'' NRSV _ ``Though you are hunting me to take my life...'' Second Corinthians 6:11 _ RSV _ ``Our mouth is open to you, Corinthians; our heart is wide.'' NRSV _ ``We have spoken frankly to you Corinthians; our heart is wide open to you.'' Psalm 98:8 _ RSV _ ``Let the hills sing for joy together.'' NRSV _ ``Let the hills sing together for joy.''

DOC.HEAD: Just Trying to Hold the Union Together _ Said Lincoln, Says Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, vacationing.
DOC.TEXT: The voice was reedy, high-pitched, solemn. It belonged to Abraham Lincoln, delivering his first inaugural address, trying desperately to preserve a union. But the sentiment could come these days from Mikhail Gorbachev. ``In your hands (said Lincoln addressing the South, or could say Gorbachev, addressing Lithuania) and not in mine, is the momentous issue of the civil war. The Government will not assail you. (But) I hold that, in contemplation of universal law and the Constitution, the Union of these States is perpetual. ... No state, upon its own mere action, can lawfully get out of the Union.'' The parallel _ between Lincoln, seeking to preserve the Union, and Gorbachev, seeking to preserve the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics _ has occurred. At least, it occurred to Yuri A. Reshetov. He runs the Soviet Foreign Ministry's department for international humanitarian cooperation and human rights. At a news conference on April 9 he sought American forbearance by comparing Lincoln's and Gorbachev's struggle to preserve their unions. Reshetov said he had visited the Lincoln Memorial the previous day. ``Abraham Lincoln saved the American Union,'' he said. ``We (the Soviets) have been together with Lithuania, with Estonia and with Latvia for many, many years,'' he said. ``I still hope that what unites us is much stronger than what is capable of leading to dissolution of our union.'' All of which draws a deep, hooting laugh from Harold Hyman, a Rice University professor and expert in both constitutional and American Civil War history. ``Let me call it a strained analogy, a kind of twistery instead of history,'' says Hyman. Says Mary K. Bonsteel Tachau, a constitutional historian at the University of Louisville, ``I appreciate his position but I think his analogy is unhistoric. ... He is obviously grasping.'' William M. Wiecek, son of an immigrant, professor of law and of history at Syracuse University, attacks the analogy most succinctly. He points out that the original 13 states of the American union voluntarily formed and ratified the union and the other 37 states petitioned to be admitted. Lithuania, by contrast, was taken over by the Russians under the terms of a secret pact between Stalin and Hitler, which Wiecek calls ``one of the most loathsome agreements of modern times.'' In both instances, the people of the seceding entity, through their elected representatives, voted to secede. However, in the case of the South, no one polled the vast numbers of residents who happened to be black and in bondage. Those who held the whip were those who had the vote. And yet, Wiecek is willing to grant Gorbachev _ and Reshetov _ a point: the Soviet leader perhaps has the right and duty to try to oversee a smooth secession rather than a chaotic one. Says Wiecek: ``As a historian, it is always misleading to argue from parallels drawn from completely different civilizations. With that qualification in mind, I think there is something to be said for the Soviet official's idea in the sense that the chief executive officer of any modern state has a responsibility, if not to prevent secession, at least to manage a change in relations so that the interests of the state itself and the seceding entity are preserved.'' ``What would George Bush do,'' he asks, ``if Alaska attempted to secede?'' So the Reshetov attempt to bend American history into a Soviet parallel doesn't work, but anarchy doesn't work either. No one, not Soviets, not Lithuanians, not Americans, wants to see the price _ half a million lives _ that was paid on American soil to establish the anti-secessionist principle that Lincoln laid down and Reshetov would adopt as his own.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has covered the news in Washington for 22 years.

DOC.HEAD: Milken: Prison, but No Paparazzi
DOC.TEXT: By pleading guilty to financial crimes, Michael Milken has exposed himself to years in prison but avoided another ordeal _ a daily run through the gantlet of cameras outside Manhattan's federal courthouse. ``He's always hated to have his picture taken,'' says Allan Sloan, a financial columnist who has spoken with Milken many times. ``It's not really a phobia. It's part of his control thing.'' If so, the prospect of following in the steps of Leona Helmsley, Imelda Marcos, Bess Myerson and other celebrities who have stood trial in New York must have seemed particularly depressing. Because there are only a few routes into the courthouse, criminal defendants must pass a battery of cameras each day. Although some enjoy it, for most ``It's a pain in the neck,'' said Jules Ritholz, a prominent defense lawyer. Milken's suspicion of the lens is considered legendary. It is said that he steadfastly refused to be photographed for Drexel Burnham Lambert's annual report, even though he created and ran the firm's vaunted junk bond department. He also sought to control who photographed him, how the photos would be shot and where they would go. When photographer George Steinmetz arrived at Milken's Beverly Hills office in 1987 to shoot the financier, he was handed a contract giving Milken all rights to the photos. Steinmetz signed it. That was only the beginning, Steinmetz later recalled in an interview with The New York Times. ``I wanted to shoot him at his desk, surrounded by all his traders. But they said they didn't want others to be in the picture. So I suggested photographing him alone at his desk in the morning before anyone came in. They said that would make him look too much like a loner.'' Steinmetz's request for a photo of Milken arriving at work in his chauffeured car was rejected because it would make the financier look too pampered. So finally the photographer had to settle for a picture of Milken outside his house posed awkwardly in a staged game of basketball with some neighborhood kids. In 1987 Sloan, then a writer at Forbes magazine, got an interview with Milken. But getting a photo to accompany the article was something else. ``We had endless trouble over it,'' Sloan recalls. ``We couldn't buy any pictures because he had all the rights. Finally I had to call him up and ask him (to cooperate.) I spent an awful lot of time trying to get a photo.'' Milken's indictment and his required appearance before a congressional committee ended the photo famine. He also appeared at a few flattering photo opportunities arranged by his public relations consultants, but ``you could see he hated doing it, and he wasn't good at it,'' Sloan says. To placate the hordes of paparazzi still clamoring for his visage, Milken allowed a photographer to shoot a set of official photos, which were made available to the news media. Still, Milken's distaste for photography certainly was no help to his lawyers as they negotiated a pretrial settlement with prosecutors, legal experts said. ``Fear of photography is one of about 40 reasons why you don't want to go to trial,'' says Ritholz. ``You've got to factor it into your decision.'' ``But I wouldn't make too much of that,'' said Stephen Gillers, a New York University law professor. ``I don't think someone is going to make a plea bargain decision based on his dislike of being photographed. You'd have to be Howard Hughes, and I don't think Milken's in that league.''

DOC.HEAD: IRA Trick: Roll Over and Play Debt
DOC.TEXT: Need cash fast? Borrow from yourself _ and pay no interest! However strange that come-on may sound, the proposition it embodies can be workable for someone who has accumulated a nest egg in an individual retirement account. But beware. Like many other types of short-term, emergency financing, it can be a tightrope walk that imposes severe penalties if you take a misstep. The rules governing IRAs make it clear that the government didn't intend these long-term savings vehicles as any source of readily available credit. They state expressly that if you borrow from an IRA _ or even if you pledge money in your account as collateral on a loan _ you will be considered to have made a withdrawal subject to taxes. For people who have not yet reached age 59{, that usually means a 10 percent penalty tax in addition to any regular income tax obligations you incur. Elsewhere in the dense tangle of IRA regulations, however, there is a loophole of sorts that permits people of any age to tap their accounts, once a year, for no-interest ``loans'' lasting up to 60 days. When you do this, you technically do not borrow the money at all. Instead, you withdraw it from an account with one custodian to roll it over into another, with a time limit of no more than 60 days from the date when you receive the money from the first custodian. Before your time runs out, what you do with the money is up to you _ buy a car, take some speculative fling, whatever you wish. Of course, if you want to preserve your hard-earned IRA savings and avoid costly tax bills, you need to be very sure that you will be able to pay yourself back in time. ``The device of `borrowing' from an IRA should only be considered in situations where it is clear that the funds will be available to complete the rollover within the 60-day period,'' says the Research Institute of America in a current bulletin on the subject. The institute suggests that it may not be assurance enough to simply have what businesses call an account receivable _ a payment somebody owes you that may or may not come in on schedule. Theoretically at least, you could take your IRA money to the bank and buy a 58-day certificate of deposit, pocketing whatever interest the CD earns, and then put the principal amount back in a new IRA. But if the bank's payment to you got held up for just three days or so, because the mail wasn't delivered or the computer went down, you'd be out of luck. The IRS takes the position that the time limit is a time limit, leaving little or no room for excuses or exceptions. This IRA-to-CD-to-IRA deal would also have a couple of other angles you might want to take into account. First of all, the CD interest, unlike investment income earned in an IRA, would be subject to current taxation. Secondly, while you had the use of the money, it wouldn't be earning anything at all for your IRA savings. On top of all that, while avoiding taxes in an IRA rollover you could incur other costs, such as withdrawal fees at the old custodian or setup fees at the new one, that would work against any net benefit to you. Considering all the pitfalls involved, many IRA savers might be reluctant ever to plan an actual rollover to get at their cash. At the same time, however, they might view it as a nice cushion to have in reserve.

DOC.TEXT: America ``has slipped into moral and spiritual complacency,'' said the National Day of Prayer Task Force in urging widespread observance of the day Thursday. This is the 38th consecutive year for the National Day of Prayer since Congress authorized it in 1952. In 1988, Congress set a permanent date for it on the first Thursday of May each year. The task force, headed by actor Pat Boone and Mrs Bill Bright, wife of the leader of Campus Crusade for Christ, urged prayers of thanks for ``blessings our country has received'' and for ``personal and corporate renewal of moral values.''

A Moslem for the first time has been elected to the executive board of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. He is Aly Y. Massoud, an Egyptian-born New York attorney. The NCCJ for a half a century has worked for better interfaith understanding and cooperation.

The president of the United Methodist Council of Bishops has commended President Bush for his dealing with Lithuania's dispute over independence with the Soviet Union. Commending Bush's ``sensitive restraint'' in the situation, Bishop Jack M. Tuell of Los Angeles said in a letter to Bush: ``We recognize with you the legitimate desire of the Lithuanian people for independence, and are grateful for your support of that principle. But we also recognize how dangerous the situation is in the Soviet Union, and that adopting confrontational tactics or laying down ultimatums could severely damage the emerging possibilities of peace in the world.''

The Religious Public Relations Council has honored journalists at NBC News, Newsweek magazine, The Charleston (W.Va.) Gazette, The Detroit News and Detroit Free Press for ``outstanding communication of religious values.'' They received ``Wilbur'' awards, named for a longtime leader in religious public relations, the Rev. Marvin C. Wilbur.

Christian influence helped provoke the dramatic overturning of communist regimes in Eastern Europe, but the secular media took ``little note'' of that religious component, writes Time newsman David Aikman in Christian Herald, a 112-year-old bimonthly.

London bookmakers are offering 2-1 odds that Archbishop Robin Eames, the Anglican primate of Ireland, will be the next archishop of Canterbury. The present occupant of that office, Archbishop Robert Runcie, has announced he will retire in January 1991. London betting houses traditionally give odds in the ``Canterbury stakes'' when that office becomes open. Eames, considered a doctrinal conservative, would be the first non-English bishop to head the worldwide Anglican communion of 70 million members in 28 national branches, including the U.S. Episcopal Church.

DOC.HEAD: New Rendering of Widely Used Bible Version Now Ready
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: An interfaith team of Scripture experts led by a gentle-mannered Princeton scholar has worked for 15 years producing what's likely to become the most widely used Bible in American churches. The New Revised Standard Version, put out by six publishers in various editions, is being distributed in May to bookstores. It has been authorized and commended by most of the nation's major denominations. ``It offers greater accuracy, clarity and naturalness of expression,'' said the Rev. Bruce M. Metzger, chairman of the 30-member translation committee that turned out the new rendition. Drawing on older, more exact manuscripts and changes in meanings of current English, the work is a fine-tuning of the Revised Standard Version, completed in 1952, and the most broadly endorsed version in the years since. Metzger, 76, a Presbyterian and courtly, zestful Scripture scholar of Princeton Theological Seminary, applied this rule in the new rendering of the ancient texts: ``As literal as possible, as free as necessary.'' That demanded that the content adhere to what the original Hebrew and Greek manuscripts actually say, while phrasing it in understandable and graceful English. ``We never tampered with meanings,'' Metzger said in an interview. But many archaic usages and sometimes ambiguous or obscure passages are clarified in the revised translation. For example, Zechariah 3:3, previously rendered as ``Now Joshua was standing before the angel, clothed in filthy garments,'' becomes: ``Now Joshua was dressed with filthy clothes as he stood before the angel.'' The NRSV was produced under auspices of the National Council of Churches, which also holds the copyright on the predecessor RSV, endorsed by most major Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches. Despite the contemporary proliferation of Bible translations, Metzger said the RSV has been the mostly widely used ``modern speech translation.'' In its 38 years, it has sold more than 45 million copies. Revising of it was done by a translation committee of Protestant, Roman Catholic, Eastern Orthodox and Jewish scholars. Biblical scholars these days ``approach each other in terms of scholarshilp,'' not denomination, Metzger said. ``There's a homogeneity in biblical scholarship the likes of which we had not seen before. ``The differences are in theology, not in biblical studies. Irrespective of denominational affiliations, matters of theological interpretation fall into the background. So far as the book goes, we are essentially one.'' Most teams producing Bible translations are paid for their work, but the NRSV group labored at their task since 1974 without pay or share in royalties. It's ``a contribution'' to the churches, Metzger said. Formal publication date and church celebrations of it were scheduled in September, but a May 1 start was authorized for distribution to stores. While some feminists pressed for more sexually inclusive language in the new translation, Metzger's criteria required adherence to the texts. However, many terms previously rendered as male were originally inclusive. He said that masculine pronouns or the words ``man'' or ``men'' often were used previously in passages in which the original text allows for more generic usage such as ``one'' or ``people.'' For example, Matthew 6:30 previously was rendered ``O men of little faith,'' but now is rendered, ``you of little faith.'' Metzger said the word for man wasn't present in the original. Similarly, John 12:32 previously was rendered, ``And I when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all men to myself.'' The latter phrase now becomes, ``...draw all people to myself.'' However, pronouns referring to God and Jesus remain masculine. ``We were not authorized to change them,'' Metzger said, adding that there was no ``tampering with the gender of deity. ``God remains `Our Father,' and Jesus Christ is the Son of God.'' However, uses of ``thee'' and ``thou'' in addressing God are changed to ``you.'' ``In the Hebrew and Greek texts the same form of the second person pronoun is used in talking to God and people,'' Metzger said. He calls the new translation both ``the newest and oldest version'' since the translators used ancient texts only recently discovered, such as the Dead Sea scrolls providing much older manuscripts of the Old Testament. Some previously rendered passages that sometimes drew snickers in church readings were changed to correct possible misunderstandings. For instance, Psalm 50:9, that previously read, ``I will accept no bull from your house,'' becomes, ``I will not accept a bull from your house.' Also, Paul's letter in Second Corinthians ll:25 previously read, ``Once I was stoned.'' It now reads, ``Once I received a stoning.'' Publishers distributing the NRSV are Cambridge University Press, Thomas Nelson Publishers, Inc., Holman Bible Publishers, Oxford University Press, World Bible Publishers, Inc., and Zondervan Corporation. In addition, the American Bible Society has been authorized to offer the NRSV as part of its program, and Collins Ltd., is publishing an edition in Great Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Considers Radical Idea: Paying Bills by Mail
DOC.TEXT: The Post Office is proposing a revolutionary idea _ that the 150 million people of Latin America's largest country pay their bills by mail instead of standing in line. Brazil is modern in many ways, but you still cannot write a check for your electricity bill, put it in a stamped envelope and drop it in a mailbox. Virtually all bills are paid at banks, which are clogged with long lines of grumbling, sweaty people holding stacks of electricity, gas, and water bills; school, department store, health insurance and credit card accounts, auto license fees and statements of income or property taxes. A specialized commercial culture has sprouted around the practice. Companies and wealthy individuals hire young men, universally called ``office boys,'' to do their standing and paying. One company's office boy presented a check to pay the telephone bill, but the bank insisted on cash. He went to the company's own bank, which said it would take a check but must have a new one naming the bank as payee. In desperation, the office boy returned to the first bank, where the manager finally made an exception and accepted the check. The Post Office wants to make things simpler. Its press spokesman, Jose Valfranio Medeiros de Oliveira, said in an interview: ``There's nothing easier than paying bills by mail, and we want to make life easier for our citizens.'' Some newspapers have begun, rather timidly, to support the program. ``Yes, there is a long tradition here of not paying by mail,'' Oliveira said, ``but we have the infrastructure, we have credibility. There's no reason this won't work.'' This month, he said, the Post Office will run a test program allowing people in the northeastern state of Bahia, population 11.6 million, to pay telephone bills by mail. If that goes well, the experiment will be extended to other states and to bills for water, gas and federal taxes. ``All Brazil's 4,000-plus townships have post offices, whereas one-third don't have banks,'' Oliveira said. ``In addition, there are 22,000 public mailboxes and 3,000 rural collection points on farms and ranches. Post offices have longer hours than banks. Some post offices are open on weekends.'' Brazil's largest commercial bank, the government-controlled Banco do Brasil, announced plans for a ``Citizens' Comfort,'' a program that would allow even people without accounts at the bank to mail it their checks for water, electricity, gas and federal tax bills. Alberto Policaro, the bank president, said that would make life easier for Brazilians and ``free bank workers from receiving bills and let them get on with the bank's real business _ taking in deposits and making loans.'' Public acceptance of such a departure is far from universal. Luis Sant'Anna Mendes, a Rio teletype operator who used to work for the Post Office telegraph service, said: ``I'd rather wait in line at a bank. That way you have confirmation that you paid.'' At a bank, you get a stub with a machine stamp showing the amount paid. Oliveira said post offices could provide the same kind of receipt. That means bill payers would have to line up at the post office, of course, but the press spokesman said: ``Our lines move faster than bank lines.'' Surveys by Brazil's largest private polling company, known as IBOPE, indicate the Post Office is Brazil's most trusted public institution, but skepticism persists. ``You just don't know if the letter really will get there,'' Mendes said. Another problem is that Brazilian banks do not return canceled checks; they keep check records on microfilm. In the case of a disputed payment, the payer would have to line up at the bank to see his account record. ``There are technical details to be worked out,'' Oliveira acknowledged, ``but if you can pay bills by mail in the United States and Europe, there's no reason you can't do it in Brazil too.''

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Builds More Bomb Shelters
DOC.TEXT: Much of the world plans reductions in military spending, but Singapore, a thriving city-state with no apparent enemies, is building more bomb shelters. About 200 shelters and the same number of air raid sirens will be completed in the next year and Singapore should be ready for its first nationwide drill in 1992, Home Minister Shanmugam Jayakumar said. ``The more shelters, the better,'' he declared. ``This will mean more protection for the public.'' Protection from what? Southeast Asia has been among the world's more stable regions recently, but government leaders insist security remains a problem despite the improvement in U.S.-Soviet relations. That will not change even if the superpowers reduce their military forces in the region, said Lee Hsien Loong, 37, eldest son of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Lee addressed Parliament as second defense minister. He also has the trade and industry portfolio and is widely viewed as a future prime minister. ``If the United States significantly cuts back its military forces in the region, this will not be a signal for Singapore also to reduce our forces,'' he said. ``It will be reason for concern over a potentially destabilizing change in the regional balance of power.'' Singapore is the only country in the region that openly backs continued U.S. military presence. Officials in several other capitals express private support and public non-alignment. ``Except for Singapore, the nations of Southeast Asia think the American security shield will stand forever, regardless of what they do,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, leader of a House Armed Services Committee delegation that toured the area recently. ``They can boast of their non-aligned purity while reaping the harvest made possible by the American military,'' the Colorado Democrat said. If the United States cannot renew the leases on Philippine bases and is forced to leave, it will need help from friends in the region, she said. Singapore has offered greater access to its air and naval facilities. In his speech to Parliament, Lee said the government would not cut defense spending, reduce the armed forces or end compulsory military training, whatever the United States did. Singapore is about the size of Chicago, with no natural resources except a strategic location between the Pacific and Indian Oceans and the skills of its 2.6 million people, 76 percent of whom are ethnic Chinese. The army, navy and air force have 55,000 regulars and conscripts plus about 200,000 reservists. Analysts rate the Singapore armed forces among the best trained and equipped in the region. Because it is so small, Singapore often holds major military exercises in Brunei, Taiwan or elsewhere. It conducts bilateral maneuvers with other members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations _ Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei and the Philippines _ but ASEAN as a whole does not function as a military alliance. ``No other ASEAN country is slashing its defense expenditures, demobilizing its armed forces or acting on the assumption that it no longer faces any external threats,'' Lee told Parliament. ``It would be foolhardy for Singapore to do so alone.'' Diplomats from ASEAN countries said the countries awaited resolution of two regional problems: the search for a peace formula in Cambodia and negotiations on the U.S. bases. Singapore is in the Five Power Defense Agreement with Australia, Britain, Malaysia and New Zealand. The 1971 pact provides for consultation and cooperation among members if Singapore or Malaysia is attacked or threatened. Defense spending is about 6 percent of Singapore's gross national product, which means the equivalent of $1.9 billion in the current budget. U.S. defense spending in 1988 was 6.1 percent of the gross national product, or $293.1 billion. Some defense funds go to a domestic arms industry that has grown so fast it now seeks export orders and diversification. It was started less than 20 years ago and includes more than 40 companies under the Singapore Technologies umbrella. The government-backed companies evolved from making small arms under license to designing howitzers and upgrading jet fighters. Singapore's ``total defense'' plan was drafted in 1983, while Vietnamese military forces occupied Cambodia, and aims to involve the civilian population with the military in a national emergency. The first air raid drill sent 3,000 volunteers swarming into a new subway station in 1988. Nine underground stations have been fortified to shelter 100,000 people. Shelters also are being built in schools, hospitals and other public facilities. Other civil defense training covers rescue methods, blood donation, mobilization of private motor vehicles and emergency distribution of food and water.

DOC.HEAD: There's Something About the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival
DOC.TEXT: Kid Sheik is one cool gent. The dark glasses rest just so on the bridge of his nose, and his rings sparkle. Never mind that he's old. Just get him talking about music, or better yet playing it, and the years slip away. He seems as young as the notes from his trumpet. ``Music must keep you young. I started my first band when I was 15, started playing that horn long before that. I used to go around to these yard parties where all the bands would be playing or down to some music spot and before you knew it, I was hooked,'' he said. George Colar is 81 now and he's slowed down some, but his alter ego, Kid Sheik, is still going strong. ``I drank hard in my day, but I haven't had a drink in 20 years now. I used to smoke 15, 20 cigars a day. Not anymore. I'd be out every night. I don't have the energy for that running around now. My music hasn't changed though. I still have the same memories. The same feelings. I still hear the same tunes inside,'' he said. The Kid Sheik Band, of which he is the leader and the youngest member, plays two nights a week at Preservation Hall in the French Quarter. They tour several months a year and they never miss the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. ``We were at the first Jazz Fest down in Congo Square and we haven't missed one yet,'' he said. Kid Sheik, who is featured on this year's Jazz Fest Poster, will be one of almost 3,000 musicians performing on the 11 open-air stages during the 10-day event April 27-May 6. ``It's grown and that's a fact,'' he said. ``Seems like now everyone in the world goes to Jazz Fest. People come from all over. A lot of folks from Europe will be here.'' This is the 21st Jazz and Heritage Festival, expected to draw 300,000 people, mostly to the fair that runs weekends at the historic Fair Grounds racetrack in downtown New Orleans. The music is continuous from noon to dark _ not just the traditional New Orleans sound that Kid Sheik plays, but Cajun, gospel, rhythm and blues, bluegrass, contemporary jazz, African, Caribbean and more. The stages and tents are separated by food booths and craft tents, and this year the racetrack's grandstand will be opened for special displays and events. Kid Sheik will play the festival on Saturday, April 28. He says he got his name from his style of dress. ``In my younger days I was always a chic dresser. I was known for my chic clothes and so they just started calling me that.'' Never mind the spelling of ``chic.'' That was in the days when he was out and about every night learning to play his trumpet and having fun. ``There were so many greats then. Wooden Joe Nicholas, Chris Kelly. Chris Kelly would play those blues and the women would throw their pocketbooks at him. He'd play the blues and make you cry,'' he recalled. He still plays the old songs, always opens with ``Yes Sir, That's My Baby.'' ``It's become sort of my theme song. We play them all. You know they call it New Orleans Jazz, but it's really New Orleans music. It's the way we play music down here,'' he said. Kid Sheik's seven-piece band has been playing at Preservation Hall since before it was Preservation Hall, he said. ``We used to go there and play for just what we collected. Then the union heard about it and said, `You can't do that, they have to get a salary.' So they started paying us, but we made less than when we were just getting tips.'' The band still gets tips for special requests. It's $1 for a song, unless it's ``When the Saints Go Marching in.'' ``We play that so much we charge more for it. That one's $5,'' he said. ``That's one reason I'm glad to see people coming to something like Jazz Fest. I think they think all we do down here is play `Saints' and eat red beans and rice.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-AP Arts: Jazz Festival
The Frogman Is Still Hopping
DOC.TEXT: Clarence Henry was 18 years old when he sent his tired fingers across the piano keys and told a red-eyed group in a New Orleans night club he didn't have a home. ``It was back in 1955 at the old Joy Lounge,'' he said. ``I'd been working since 7 o'clock that night and it was 7 in the morning and I was tired. I wanted to go home. I struck a little rift and said `I ain't got no home.' That's how I wrote the song. We recorded it the next year right here in New Orleans and it's been going ever since.'' That lonely boy is 53 now and still singing, sometimes, as he says in the song, ``like a frog.'' On Saturday, April 28, Henry will sing ``Ain't Got No Home'' for maybe the millionth time at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. ``People always ask for it. They wait for it,'' he said of his trademark tune. ``Ain't Got No Home'' catapulted Henry to fame and gave him his stage name as well. ``I was looking for a good one,'' he said. ``I couldn't be `Fats.' That was taken. But people would ask for the frog song by the frog man, and this disc jockey, Poppa Stoppa, said to me `That's your name. The Frogman.''' The song was featured in the movie ``The Lost Boys.'' ``There's been millions of copies of that song sold. It still sells today, but I'm still waiting for the money,'' Henry said. ``It's a mess. Everything's changed hands so many times I don't know who owes me what anymore. I made a few thousand dollars on it, but the real payoff is that it brought me fame.'' The Frogman has performed at 20 of the 21 Jazz Fests in New Orleans. A kind of one-man repertoire of rhythm and blues, Henry sings many of the songs made famous by other New Orleans artists. During the year, he now does from 10 to 30 gigs, he said, ranging from a New Year's Eve Party with only nine guests to another music festival in Sweden. Henry toured with the Beatles on their American run in 1964. ``I did 18 shows with them. That was really something,'' he said. He played for the Rolling Stones at a party they threw on a riverboat after their 1982 performance in the Superdome. At Jazz Fest, though, he just plays to the crowd. He sizes them up and does what he thinks they'll like _ some fast songs, some slow, some blues. He also does his old hits: ``I Don't Know Why I Love You But I Do,'' ``You Always Hurt The One You Love'' and, of course, ``Ain't Got No Home.'' ``I'm getting old now. I can't do it as well as I used to. My voice has changed. It was easy when I was young to do the frog singing or to sing like a girl. Now I have to work for it. It still gets people, though. It's something to see when they all start wooing along with me.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, April 27

DOC.HEAD: Crystal Bernard's Near Miss: Harbinger of Being Cast for NBC's `Wings'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A real trouper is one who, despite a near-fatal gassing, can rebound almost immediately to audition for a good part. Crystal Bernard fits that description. It's why she's now a co-star of NBC's ``Wings,'' playing Helen Chappel, an aspiring cellist who runs the lunch counter at a small airport on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. Bernard, whose character is the long-time friend of Timothy Daly and Steven Weber, cast as owners of a one-plane commuter airline, considers herself lucky in more than one way. She was working on the TV movie ``Without Her Consent'' on a day when filming was delayed because of lighting problems. ``I went to my trailer to lie down and I passed out because of carbon-monoxide poisoning,'' she said. ``They found me in the trailer's toilet about three hours later. I was paralyzed. I couldn't move. They rushed me to one hospital, then to another, where I was put into an oxygen chamber. ``I was very close to dying. When I was released from the hospital, I had to have someone watch me at night to see that I didn't have a seizure. When I woke up the next morning, I found a script on my door. It was `Wings,' and I went down immediately to read for it. I know that's ludicrous, but I loved it so much.'' ``Wings'' was created by three former producers and writers for ``Cheers'' _ David Angell, Peter Casey and David Lee _ and follows ``Cheers'' on Thursdays. The show, which runs for seven episodes, has gotten mixed reviews from critics, but Bernard, who spent five years on the syndicated comedy ``It's a Living,'' is convinced it's going to make it despite tough competition from ABC's ``Twin Peaks.'' Bernard spent a year on ``Happy Days,'' had a recurring role on ``My Two Dads'' and has appeared several times on ``Paradise'' as a school teacher. She co-starred with Michael J. Fox in the TV movie ``High School U.S.A.,'' and earlier this year was seen in the movie pilot ``Chameleons.'' ``Wings'' had been delayed for several months because the producers had not been able to cast the part of Helen, which originally was conceived as a fiery Greek woman. After Bernard was cast, she had to complete work on ``Without Her Consent'' and wait out a commitment to an ABC pilot called ``Hot Prospects.'' Production was postponed until January, when she became available. Her character on the show is, like herself, from Texas. But unlike Bernard, she's a woman who has struggled to shed 60 pounds. She's also fiery and outspoken. ``Helen has a weight problem, and I kind of figure that's why she's fiery,'' Bernard said. ``People would comment on her weight, and she'd fire back. Nobody has her number ...'' Bernard says she has been cast in every comedy role she's auditioned for, but not every venture has been a success. Once, on a visit to Los Angeles for a religious concert with her father, she tried to get the president of NBC on the telephone to tell him she wanted her own variety show. ``I had my costumes and everything,'' she said. ``He didn't take my call.'' Later, when Bernard moved to Los Angeles the only name she knew was modeling agent Nina Blanchard's. ``I'd seen her on `The Merv Griffin Show,''' Bernard said. ``She said I was too short (5-foot-2). I went back and barged into her office. She was puffing on a cigarette and said, `Honey, you're a midget, but I think you're going to be a star.' ``She signed me to a commercials contract, and I got a job the next day. I'd spent a day and a half as a waitress and I was terrible. I went from making $3.50 an hour as a waitress one day to $1,400 a day for four days' work on a commercial. I thought I'd struck oil.'' Bernard grew up singing and performing all over the country with her father, Jerry Wayne Bernard, a Southern Baptist evangelical minister. Her older sister, Robin Bernard, is on ABC's ``General Hospital,'' and another sister, Scarlett, was in the movie ``Jack in the Box.'' Her youngest sister, Angelique, is a student at Baylor University, which Bernard attended before striking out for Hollywood. ``I've wanted to be an actress since I was 3,'' she said. ``I started imitating Cher and Barbra Streisand and Jeannie C. Riley. By the time I was in the fifth grade, I had a Cher act I did all over Houston for the Rotary, Elks, and other clubs.''
