DOC.HEAD: A Lifetime of Waiting for the Bogeyman to Reappear
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In 7th graf, `Last Monday...,' date is April 23.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When they found 11-year-old Billy Ruff hanged from the big maple tree he loved to climb, innocence died in the hearts of his brothers and sisters. They saw his killer everywhere, in anyone. The surviving Ruff children _ five living when Billy died 33 years ago, three born later _ lived with a fear so deep it darkened every waking moment, terror inspired by a real-life bogeyman who preyed on happy, fresh-faced kids who loved raisin cookies and baseball. Kids like Billy. Kids like them. ``All of us, at one time or another, didn't think we'd reach the age of 11,'' said Tim Ruff, who was 3 when Billy died. Then one day three years ago, Christopher Ruff glanced up at the bulletin board in the police station where he worked and into the face of the man who killed the brother he never knew. ``Mom and I knew, as soon as I called her,'' said Chris, at 24 the youngest Ruff, born eight years after his brother's death and two months after his father's. ``We both started to shake and say, `This is it.''' Last Monday, he saw the man again _ in Albany County Court, where he was sentenced to life in prison for Billy's murder. It was not murder, however, that put Billy's killer on a wanted poster; it was a sex abuse charge involving a girl about Billy's age. The awful secret his family had hidden was that Billy Ruff had been sodomized before he died. ``This sort of thing wasn't spoken about,'' Mildred Ruff said, sitting in her living room surrounded by six of her children. ``People wouldn't talk about child molesting. It was a hush-hush thing.'' Smith Avenue, in the northwestern suburb of Albany where the family lived, was a street full of children in a rural landscape of fields and trees the day Billy Ruff disappeared. He was last seen at 4:30 p.m. Saturday, Aug. 31, 1957, his pocket full of raisin cookies, in his hand a length of frayed clothesline he planned to use to steer a homemade go-cart. He didn't show up for dinner. Mrs. Ruff remembers wrapping his plate of lamb chops, boiled potatoes and corn on the cob in wax paper and putting it in the fridge. At 9 p.m., she called her husband at work, and he began a search that lasted until dawn. In her fitful sleep that night, Mrs. Ruff had a dream or a vision, she wasn't sure which: ``I saw Billy, on his knees, hanging by a rope.'' That's the way he was found the next day by a friend's daughter _ hanged with his own clothesline in a densely wooded lot where all the kids played, and played for years after. Police interviewed hundreds of people. ``They didn't care how many hours they put in,'' said Raymond Rasmussen, one of the first state police detectives put on the case. ``We got to feel very close and very compassionate for the family and what they'd been through.'' What they could not know was that the killer was there, among them; then, in the noise and confusion of grief and of police work, he was gone. ``The night of the wake, a priest friend of ours said it may take 20 years, but nobody can keep this thing to themselves,'' Mrs. Ruff said. ``And I said, if it takes 20 days, I'll lose my mind.'' Instead, she found strength and faith, enough to last her family through Billy's death, the death of her husband eight years later, and her own current fight with cancer. For years, she carried in her apron pocket a rosary her husband had given her. The black beads wore to brown from constant fingering. Twenty days became 20 months. The investigation died down. The police stopped coming by with mug shots of child molesters. Seven years passed. The police came around one last time to tell the family a forensics expert had decided Billy's death was accidental. His family scoffed; they knew the truth would surface, a belief that never wavered as 10 years became 20, then 30. ``We know what it's like to have a lot of unanswered questions,'' said John, born four years after Billy's murder. ``But in the back of our minds, there was always the hope.'' There was also fear _ of the dark, of being alone, of getting too close to people. ``Everybody grew up with a paranoia,'' Chris said. ``We couldn't have a normal childhood because we were so damn scared. There's not one time we can walk into an empty house and feel safe. Not one of us.'' Regina, the oldest, 13 when Billy died, and Tommy, who was 5, told their mother they knew there was a bogeyman because he got their brother. All the Ruffs _ Regina, Tom, Tim, Joe, Lisa, Jay, John and Chris _ worried he was out to get another of them. ``We'd stand at the window, stand there and watch when people weren't home on time,'' said Lisa, who was 8 months old when Billy was murdered. ``I remember standing at my bed in the back bedroom, looking out the window and knowing I was doing the same thing as Mom was. We were always scared.'' The fear became something they lived and breathed. In time, they would pass it on to their spouses, to their children. ``I was terrorized by nightmares most of my life,'' Regina wrote in a recent letter to her mother. ``I had to force myself to go anywhere. I was afraid of the dark and of the daylight. ``All this destruction, all this fear _ and I am only one of eight. Multiply the damage to me by every other life this touched.'' While Billy's brothers and sisters struggled with demons, his killer was finishing a stint in the Air Force and spending short periods as an Albany police officer and an ironworker. He married three times and fathered two children by a fourth woman. In the 1970s he wandered the streets, a homeless alcoholic. ``I think he was a man that had this on his mind all that time,'' Rasmussen said. ``Maybe that caused him to become what he was.''

DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken, the billionaire financier who reshaped Wall Street in the 1980s but fell in its biggest scandal, pleaded guilty to breaking federal securities and tax laws and agreed to pay a record $600 million in penalties. Milken, 43, broke down and sobbed Tuesday before a packed Manhattan courtroom as he finished a lengthy statement outlining his crimes, which included illegal tradin with stock speculator Ivan Boesky and others from 1984-86. Milken faces a maximum 28 years in prison at his scheduled Oct. 1 sentencing, although legal experts expect a term of around five years.

Orders for durable goods in March posted their best showing in more than a year, but analysts gave the government report a subdued review. ``It's pretty much in line with what we have been seeing all quarter,'' said Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc. in Washigton. ``The economy is picking up.'' The Commerce Department said Tuesday that orders for durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ jumped 6.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted $128.8 billion.

Americans' pay and benefits shot up 5.5 percent over the last 12 months, the largest jump in six years, the government said. Health insurance costs alone rose 12.1 percent. One economist called the continued surge in wages and medical care costs reported Tuesday ``a big negative on the inflation outlook.'' Others agreed, saying inflationary problems can't be explained away by citing temporary factors, such as December's frigid temperatures.

Mid-April sales of North American-made cars and trucks plunged 17.7 percent compared with the same period last year, when consumers flocked to showrooms to take advantage of incentives, automakers said. Incentives were in effect during the period this year, but they weren't nearly as generous as last year. The 10 major car and truck makers with plants in North America reported Tuesday they sold an average of 34,071 vehicles a day during the April 11-20 period this year, compared with a daily average of 41,380 last year. Car sales were down 19.1 percent and truck sales were off 15.1 percent.

Savings and loan bailout officials delayed action on a proposal to speed the sale of repossessed real estate after a top regulator said he feared the plan could hurt struggling institutions. The board of the Resolution Trust Corp. was set to vote Tuesday on a new policy that would have allowed the agency to sell properties as much as 20 percent to 30 percent below their appraised value. However, it agreed to delay a vote for two weeks after Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke said he feared the effect of cut-price sales on financial institutions operating in fragile real estate markets.

Four major corporations and a computer software company said they formed an alliance to develop software that will allow them to better manage ``corporate knowledge,'' or the skills and know-how of their employees. The five companies _ Digital Equipment Corp., Ford Motor Co., Texas Instruments Inc., U S West Inc. and Carnegie Group Inc., a Pittsburgh-based software company _ said Tuesday they contributed $10 million to the initiative, which they began in 1988 but did not announce at the time.

Ames Department Stores Inc. maintained silence on its financial woes, refusing to comment on a report that it has hired a bankruptcy specialist to prepare a court filing to protect Ames from creditors. William Roberts, an Ames spokesman, said Tuesday the retailer would not comment on a report in The Hartford Courant that said Ames has hired Michael Cook, a bankruptcy specialist at a prominent New York law firm, to begin the paperwork for a filing under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Act.

Quaker Oats Co. announced plans to spin off its troubled Fisher-Price toy division to Quaker shareholders, leaving the parent company free to concentrate on its food business. Quaker also released its quarterly financial results Tuesday, reporting a 60 percent drop in net income for the third quarter of its fiscal year. The results included a Fisher-Price operating loss of about $25 million.

Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere named July 2 as the day for economic and social union of the two Germanys, a West German spokesman said. Bonn has proposed a basic 1-1 exchange rate of East German marks for West marks for wages, salaries and pensions in East Germany. The social and economic unification date was announced Tuesday. Political unification would come later.

The stock market stumbled Tuesday when a late round of computer-triggered selling wiped out initial gains. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 12.17 to 2,654.50. Bond prices finished mixed. The dollar declined against all major currencies except the Japanese yen. Gold prices finished lower. Precious metal futures prices fell, copper futures rose sharply, grains and soybeans retreated, and energy, livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Guilty Plea Marks Holy Grail in Government's Anti-Fraud Crusade
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Three years, five months and 10 days after Ivan F. Boesky promised to hand over other Wall Street cheaters, investigators corraled the biggest name he dangled before them: Michael R. Milken. The emotional guilty plea in federal court Tuesday by the former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s famed junk bond department was the Holy Grail in the government's crusade to weed out financial crime. Milken, 43, admitted to six counts of violating federal securities and tax laws and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. He faces up to 28 years in prison at a scheduled Oct. 1 sentencing. The admissions, despite Milken's previous avowals of innocence, ``demonstrate that he stood at the center of a network of manipulation, fraud and deceit,'' said SEC Chairman Richard Breeden. After Boesky pleaded guilty on Nov. 14, 1986, the ex-speculator provided information that led to Milken as well as to several Wall Street investment bankers, takeover artists, arbitragers, bond dealers and trading assistants. But with the exception of one case widely considered ironclad _ the fraud conviction and four-year prison term for Florida investor Paul Bilzerian _ the government has been criticized for bringing weak prosecutions on technical violations. Now the government has succeeded in getting its main target, a man who built a $200 billion market for high-risk paper and helped used to money to feed a takeover boom. His plea including a record fine against an individual and a potentially long prison term. ``They put an end to a criticism that probably was bothering them a good deal,'' Columbia University securities law professor John C. Coffee Jr. said. ``The idea that this was a witch hunt tends to fade pretty quickly when the witch pleads guilty.'' Milken supporters maintained he was persecuted because of the enormous power he wielded over the nation's financial markets from his X-shaped trading desk at Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., office. Nevertheless, Milken pleaded guilty before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood to conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud, helping others violate federal securities regulations and assisting in the filing of a false tax return. He broke down as he read an 11-page statement detailing the charges and apologizing for his actions. His voice cracked as he admitted he was, ``Guilty, your honor.'' The charges included illegal stock parking arrangements with Boesky involving the 1984 takeover target Fishbach Corp., stock manipulation in MCA Corp. in 1985, illegal trading with client David Solomon in 1985 and 1986, and illegally helping Solomon skirt tax laws. A constant in the deals was that Milken promised illegal quid pro quos apparently to help clients or Drexel turn a profit. Still, the charges were lighter than the most serious allegations in the 98-count indictment handed up in March 1989. ``The charges are a far cry from the lurid, irresponsible and prejudicial accusations against Michael that have been made by anonymous sources to the press for the past 3{ years,'' Milken attorney Arthur Liman said. ``The charges do not involve (racketeering) or insider trading, nor do they reflect the fundamentals of the junk bond market,'' he said. ``They involve instances in which Michael went too far in helping clients ... which is not to minimize the plea.'' Milken emphasized that junk bonds weren't involved in the charges, telling the court his plea was an admission of personal responsibility ``and not a reflection of the underlying soundness and integrity of the capital markets in which we specialized.'' The plea deal bars Milken from the securities industry forever and requires him to assist the continuing investigations related to the insider trading scandal. The government dropped all charges against Milken's brother, Lowell. Milken widely is regarded as the most important American financier since J.P. Morgan Jr. in the early 1900s. He came to symbolize the bounty and excesses of a booming Wall Street and amassed a personal fortune that is believed to exceed $1 billion. He pioneered the use of high-yield debt securities known as junk bonds, giving small companies access to billions of dollars in capital and making possible the wave of hostile corporate takeovers that characterized the dog-eat-dog 1980s. His downfall began after he was linked to an insider trading network by Boesky, who received a three-year prison term and was fined $100 million in November 1986 to settle his own case. Boesky also led prosecutors to stockbroker Boyd Jefferies, GAF Corp. executive James Sherwin, speculator Sandy Lewis and arbitrager Robert Freeman, but they received prison terms of only three to six months or just probation. Milken vigorously maintained his innocence after he was indicted, saying he planned to fight the charges at trial. He reversed course last week and agreed to the plea bargain, avoiding a long courtroom confrontation and the prospect of a much stiffer prison term. Under the settlement, which also resolves civil charges, Milken will pay $200 million in fines and place $400 million in a Securities and Exchange Commission account to compensate defrauded investors. He still can be sued by private investors, however. The Milken plea comes just two months after Drexel began liquidating when its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection. Drexel itself pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $650 million to settle related charges.

DOC.HEAD: Important Dates in the Michael Milken Case
With PM-Milken Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of major developments in the prosecution of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond chief Michael Milken: Nov. 14, 1986 _ Stock speculator Ivan Boesky pays $100 million to settle charges of insider trading on information supplied by investment banker Dennis Levine in 1985 and 1986. He also agrees to cooperate with investigators and to plead guilty to a single criminal charge. Boesky later is sentenced to three years in prison. Late 1986 _ Published reports link Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. high-yield bond financier Michael Milken to an illegal insider trading network led by Boesky. Sept. 7, 1988 _ The Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Drexel, Milken and three others of violating a wide range of securities laws, most of them in connection with Boesky. Dec. 21 _ Drexel agrees to plead guilty to six felonies and pay a record $650 million in fines and restitution to settle the biggest securities fraud case in history. Drexel also must settle related SEC charges and cooperate with the government investigation. March 29, 1989 _ A federal grand jury indicts Milken, his brother, Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Lee Newberg on 98 counts of racketeering and fraud largely based on information supplied by Boesky. Potential penalties and fines under the counts amount to about $12 billion plus possible prison terms. April 7 _ The Milkens plead innocent. Newberg enters an innocent plea later. April 13 _ Drexel and the SEC announce a settlement of the civil fraud case that subjects the firm to federal monitoring for three years and forces it to sever ties with Milken. June 15 _ Milken resigns after 19 years at Drexel to form his own consulting firm. Lowell Milken quits to return to practicing law. Sept. 11 _ Drexel pleads guilty to six felonies and begins paying more than $650 million in fines, penalties and interest. Feb. 13, 1990 _ Drexel's parent company files for federal bankruptcy court protection after failing to meet short-term debt payments. The securities firm, once the nation's fifth-largest, starts laying off its 5,400 employees. March 19 _ Prosecutors promise to bring a new indictment with broader charges against Milken by the week of April 16. April 4 _ Boesky is released from federal custody after completing two years of a three-year term. April 19 _ Four months of negotiations intensify between the government and Milken for a possible plea bargain to settle the case as a deadline looms for the new indictment. April 20 _ Sources say Milken agrees to plead guilty to six felony counts and pay fines and restitution totaling $600 million under a plea agreement with prosecutors. April 24 _ Milken pleads guilty to six criminal charges and agrees to pay fines and restitution totaling $600 million to settle his case. The charges of securities and tax law violations are much less serious than the insider trading and racketeering counts brought against him in the government's indictment.

DOC.HEAD: A Selection of Quotations on Milken Plea
With PM-Milken Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a selection of quotations on Michael Milken's guilty plea to six felonies Tuesday in the nation's worst securities scandal. Milken agreed to pay $600 million in penalties and faces up to 28 years in prison.

Milken, from his statement in court, on his admission of guilt: ``I am here today because in connection with some transactions, I transgressed certain of the laws and regulations that govern our industry. I was wrong in doing so and knew that at the time and I am pleading guilty to these offenses.'' On his relationship with disgraced stock speculator Ivan Boesky, who led federal investigators to Milken: ``We were not social friends, and had little in common. The relationship started as an arms-length and correct one. Unfortunately, however, certain of our transactions involved reciprocal accommodations, some of which violated the law.'' On his personal ordeal: ``I realize that by my acts I have hurt those who are closest to me. I am truly sorry.''

Lowell Milken, Michael's brother who was previously indicted but cleared Tuesday of any charges, from his statement issued after the hearing: ``I can take no satisfaction that the charges against me are being dropped. They never should have been brought in the first place, because I have done nothing wrong. ... I am proud of my brother and nothing that has happened here today has changed that.''

Assistant U.S. Attorney John K. Carroll, from his statement to the court: ``We believe that this prosecution and the fact that Mr. Milken has admitted to guilt will send the right message to the financial community.''

Richard Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, from a news conference in Washington: ``The key question is always `Does the penalty fit the crime?' In this case we are extremely pleased with the result. We're extremely pleased with an admission of six felonies and the potential here that the perpetrator of these crimes will face up to 28 years in prison. We think that's a good settlement.''
Lorraine Spurge, who worked with Milken at Drexel and was among the family members and friends in court: ``I believe there was an injustice done. I believe he is a very brave man.''

Arthur Liman, Milken's defense attorney, in a statement after the plea: ``The charges are a far cry from the lurid, irresponsible and prejudicial accusations against ichael that have been made by anonymous sources to the press for the past 3{ years.'' ``It is Michael's hope that ... history will see his violations in context and judge him not just on the basis of his lapses but on the basis of the contributions that he made to the economy and to the American people.''

Ira L. Sorkin, a former SEC administrator now in private practice, in a comment to The Associated Press: ``The fact of the matter is Mr. Milken is a convicted felon. Federal prison, minimum or maximum, is not a very pleasant place.''

DOC.HEAD: Mid-April Sales Tumble
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and trucks tumbled 17.7 percent in mid-April, indicating that incentives aren't drawing the crowds like they did a year ago. ``It's just a lot tougher fight,'' said Alan Helfman, general manager of River Oaks Chrysler-Plymouth in Houston. Part of the fight Helfman and other dealers are facing is coming from vehicles made in the United States by Japanese companies, the so-called ``transplants.'' Sales of cars and trucks made by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. were down 20.5 percent during mid-April while sales of transplant vehicles rose 23.6 percent. The 10 major U.S. car and truck makers reported selling an average of 34,071 vehicles a day during the April 11-20 period this year, compared with a daily average of 41,380 last year. Car sales were down 19.1 percent and truck sales were off 15.1 percent. For the year to date, domestic car and truck sales were down 3.5 percent, with car sales falling 4.3 percent and truck sales dropping 2 percent. Auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Services, Inc., in New York said it was tough to gauge the demand for new cars and trucks. ``I don't see much of a pattern,'' she said. ``It's very jumpy.'' Automakers have relied on incentives to increase otherwise slow showroom traffic. But Helfman said sales have tapered off this month compared with March despite the continued presence of incentives. ``I'm not losing any sales,'' he said, ``I'm not getting them either.'' Chrysler took the hardest beating of the Big Three, as its combined car and truck sales fell 36.2 percent. Once again, as it has in other recent 10-day reporting periods, Chrysler's trucks outsold its cars, this time 20,393 to 18,692. ``I think they (Chrysler executives) are trying to figure out where the Imperial, the New Yorker and the Landau are,'' Helfman said of the company's luxury cars. ``We're selling some of each, but not to any great magnitude.'' GM and Ford posted significant but less drastic declines in their mid-April sales. Sales of GM cars and trucks were down 15.9 percent during the period and Ford sales were off 19 percent. The mid-April period of 1989 was among the strongest of last year. In late March and early April last year, the Big Three sweetened their incentive packages by offering bigger cash rebates and slashing interest rates. As it did last year, Chrysler this month offered interest-free financing on two-year loans for some of its Jeeps and cars, and reduced financing rates on longer-term loans. It was too early on Tuesday to tell if the new incentive program was having an effect on the company's sales. Chrysler's car sales during mid-April fell 38.4 percent compared with a year ago and truck sales were down 33.9 percent. Sales of GM cars were down 18.9 percent and its truck sales fell 9.6 percent. Ford's car sales were down 22.7 percent and truck sales dropped 13.1 percent in mid-April.

DOC.HEAD: Study Accuses Lender of Gouging Billions from Consumers
DOC.TEXT: A new study says the nation's mortgage lenders are requiring homeowners to keep billions of dollars of excess funds in escrow accounts to fatten the lenders' profits. ``Many of the nation's mortgage lenders systematically have broken the law,'' says the report, compiled by attorneys general from seven states and released Tuesday. They said the violations have been taking place for more than a decade and called on federal officials to tighten enforcement of laws limiting the amount lenders can set aside in escrow accounts. ``Our study concludes we need a national solution to this problem,'' said Iowa Attorney General Tom Miller, one of those sponsoring the report. ``We must have change throughout the industry so we don't penalize individual companies or individual states who insist on legal escrow cushions.'' The study estimates that the average amount of excess escrow could be as much as $150 for every mortgage, which would amount to several billion dollars nationwide. The report says it is routine for lenders to hold more than twice as much as the law allows in escrow accounts. A spokesman for one bank cited in the study denied any wrongdoing. Escrow accounts are kept by lending institutions to make payments for property taxes, insurance and other items which borrowers must pay. Extra money in escrow accounts hurts consumers and is a bonanza for lenders because they get to use the money for free or pay only a very low rate of interest on the funds. About two-thirds of the nation's home mortgages involve escrow accounts. In many cases lenders ignore the contracts they sign with consumers when they make loans, the report said. ``Thus, the total dollar amount over-escrowed is likely to be even larger than the states' analysis,'' the report says. Federal law limits lenders to keeping a two-month ``cushion'' in escrow, or enough money to make payments for two months. The cushion allows lenders to make tax and insurance payments even if the consumer is late making a monthly payment. ``Right now, cushions sometimes amount to three to five months of the annual tax and insurance bills and that's not fair to consumers,'' Miller said. ``The excessive cushion can't be justified as protecting the lenders' investment. It simply gives them more of the consumers' money to earn bigger profits.'' The report called on Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp to tighten enforcement of the law. ``HUD has the power to end these industry-wide violations once and for all,'' the officials said in a letter to Kemp. The study was conducted by attorneys general in Iowa, California, Florida, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New York and Texas. The attorneys general have complained to Kemp about the issue since 1988. ``This important issue, involving billions of consumer dollars, remains in administrative limbo,'' the report concluded. The two-year study focused on big lenders who operate nationwide. A survey of four of the largest _ Citibank, GMAC Mortgage Corp., Fleet Mortgage Corp. and Lomas Financial Group. _ ``indicated that lenders may be holding excessive and illegal cushions in more than 70 percent of escrow accounts.'' Susan Weeks, vice president of public affairs for Citicorp, parent of Citibank, said the New York-based company was ``a little surprised by the announcement.'' She said Citicorp has been working with New York Attorney General Robert Abrams for more than a year on the matter. ``We've explained to him we're in compliance,'' she said. She said the law allows the bank to hold funds in escrow to pay for expenses on the account, and permits a two-month cushion on top of that. ``If there is anything in excess of that, we automatically return it to the consumer. And then we recalculate what that escrow payment should be each month,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Fisher-Price Lost Focus: Analysts
DOC.TEXT: Fisher-Price's ill-fated attempt to broaden its line of toys is a textbook case of how a company can get into trouble by ignoring its basic business in a drive to expand, analysts say. Fisher-Price's troubles became too much for Quaker Oats Co. The food company said Tuesday it would spin off its toy division to shareholders. Quaker also reported a 60 percent drop in its fiscal third quarter net income. The results included a $25 million operating loss at Fisher-Price. Consumers long have associated the Fisher-Price name with sturdy, simple, imaginative toys for pre-schoolers. But the company's attempts to transfer that name recognition to toys aimed at older children did not work out well, said John G. Taylor, who follows the toy industry for L.H. Alton & Co., a San Francisco brokerage. ``They took their eye off their basic business,'' Taylor said. That enabled Hasbro's Playskool division, Rubbermaid's Little Tikes division and Mattel's Disney-character toys to make inroads into Fisher-Price's traditional market. Fisher-Price's electronic car and electronic guitar, two products introduced in 1989, reportedly hit production snags that delayed shipments to stores in the critical months before Christmas, hurting their sales. And in the hit-driven toy industry, a pricey product that fails to live up to expectations can have severe repercussions. ``If you lose your focus on your staple, predictable product line, you can get into real trouble if your hit toys turn out to be not such big hits after all,'' said analyst Carol I. Palmer at Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. Fisher-Price remains the world's largest maker of infant and pre-school toys such as the Pull-A-Tune xylophone and the Little People farm. But fierce competition and its costly attempts to expand have cost it millions of dollars and precious market share points. Still, Taylor said the company has a potent name. ``People will say `I'm going to buy a Fisher-Price toy,''' he said. ``That's a unique kind of thing to have. ``If they can focus on reinforcing that reputation for quality and play value that they've had in the past, they ought to be able to get back on track.'' Quaker Chairman William D. Smithburg said Fisher-Price should fare better as an independent, publicly owned company. ``In the long term, a Fisher-Price which is not part of a larger company should be a more focused organization, which should enhance its competitiveness and facilitate the attraction, retention and motivation of its management and employees,'' Smithburg said in a statement. Quaker's stock rose 62{ cents to $49.25 a share Tuesday in composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Chicago-based Quaker had been rumored for several months to be considering selling Fisher-Price, which posted an 11 percent decline in operating income in fiscal 1989 and last month closed a manufacturing plant in its headquarters city of East Aurora, N.Y. Quaker spokesman Ronald Bottrell said the company had received ``some unsolicited expressions of interest'' in Fisher-Price but ultimately decided a spinoff would provide the greatest value to shareholders. Pending approval by the Internal Revenue Service, Quaker said it expects to complete a tax-free distribution of Fisher-Price stock to Quaker shareholders by the first quarter of 1991. The new company's board will elect its own chief executive, Quaker said. Paul E. Price, Fisher-Price's interim president and chief operating officer, will return to his responsibilities as Quaker's chief financial officer. Founded 60 years ago, Fisher-Price was acquired by Quaker in 1969 and saw its sales grow from $32 million to $800 million during the past 20 years. It employs about 7,400 people worldwide. Price said in February that Fisher-Price's market share in young children's toys had dropped in 1989 to the high 8 percent range from 10 percent. Bottrell said Fisher-Price had an operating loss of about $25 million, including $10.7 million in plant-closing costs, for the three months ending March 31, compared with income of $9.2 million in the third quarter of 1989. Quaker's overall net income fell to $25.6 million, or 32 cents a share, from $64.1 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 5 percent to $1.3 billion from $1.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Dismisses Call for Larger Farm Price Supports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is dismissing a prediction that his proposed cutbacks in farm program payments would cause a financial crisis in agriculture. The president reacted Tuesday to concerns raised by Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., who wants the Senate Agriculture Committee to approve price supports of $12 billion a year for five years under the 1990 farm bill. Kerrey said farm economy has improved considerably since the early 1980s. However, he told a meeting of the National Association of Agricultural Journalists, ``If you don't provide this level of funding, in two years you are going to see this recovery vanish.'' ``There are many things I respect about Senator Kerrey,'' said Bush told the same group later in the day. ``Sometimes we have a philosophical difference of opinion. I have a different view on this.'' Bush is seeking $10.2 billion in price supports for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. His proposals envision further cuts in government support over the years and more prosperity for farmers in the open market. But Kerrey said failed farming operations brought on by insufficient government support would cost more taxpayer money in the long run than the annual $12 billion he is advocating. The crops protected by the government subsidies are the big money crops _ wheat, corn, cotton, soybeans and rice. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who appeared with Bush, said farm income need not be dependent on the government. ``There's a market out there,'' said Yeutter. ``All of us are concerned about farm income.'' Yeutter and Kerrey, both Nebraskans, have been wrangling for months over how much government support should be provided to farmers. The agriculture secretary said he could not predict support payments for the remaining four years of the farm bill because international trade talks _ known as the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT _ are not yet complete. The administration has been working through GATT to open the international marketplace by removing subsidies, which Yeutter and other officials say distort prices. Rep. Richard Armey, R-Texas, who also spoke to the agricultural journalists, said he would like to see government out of the farm business altogether. He said he is putting together a coalition in Congress to oppose the support programs being devised by the agriculture committees when the bill gets to the floor.

DOC.HEAD: Deficit Widens Sharply, Pound Plummets
DOC.TEXT: Britain's merchandise trade deficit soared in March to $3.6 billion, the second-worst gap on record, the government reported Wednesday. The widening from $2.3 billion in February sent the pound plummeting and prompted the Bank of England to intervene to support the British currency. The government blamed the shortfall largely on higher imports of oil and of erratic items such as civil aircraft and precious metals. Imports hit a record during the latest month. The pound fell to $1.6265 by about noon local time from $1.6345 just before the trade report was released. The Bank of England intervened to support the pound by selling dollars, sources familiar with the intervention said. The Bank of England declined to comment on the reported intervention, as is its practice. ``It was pretty disastrous numbers,'' said Jeff Earnshaw, deputy head of foreign exchange trading at Natwest Moneycenter. He said the bad trade news could easily spark a prolonged slide in sterling. A Treasury spokesman, who wasn't identified, in accordance with British practice, said: ``The deterioration is almost entirely the result of higher imports, not lower exports.'' But dealers said the news could seriously shake the financial markets' recent confidence that the country's trade position was improving. The current account deficit also soared to $3.6 billion from $2.3 billion, the Central Statistical Office said. The current account deficit equals the merchandise trade deficit plus so-called invisible trade, such as services, overseas investment earnings and official transfer payments. The markets had expected deficits of $2.2 billion. The statistical office said the deficits were the second worse on record after a $3.9 billion merchandise trade gap and a $3.8 billion current account shortfall in August 1989. Exports totaled $13.6 billion in March, down from $13.7 billion in February. Imports totaled a record $17.2 billion in March, up from $16 billion. Since the beginning of the year, the merchandise trade deficit has grown to $9.1 billion, compared with a shortfall of $9.8 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Lingering Questions About Milken Plea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT that first part of original quote was a paraphrase.
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken's switch from defiant defendant to humble felon has aroused responses ranging from sympathy to scorn to skepticism over whether justice was served in the billionaire financier's plea bargain. Following Milken's tearful admission of guilt Tuesday, defense lawyers and friends said they understood the pressure he faced in capitulating to a government deadline to cooperate or face a more devastating prosecution on charges of racketeering. ``I can't in my memory think of an individual who has been so hammered, through leaks, through allegations, through innuendo, without having the opportunity to stand up,'' said attorney Ira L. Sorkin, a former Securities and Exchange Commission administrator now in private practice. Milken's former employer Drexel Burnham Lambert, also tainted by Wall Street scandal and now in a bankruptcy-court supervised liquidation, expressed sympathy for the man who once made Drexel a powerful investment firm. ``Michael Milken was highly esteemed for his contributions in creating a new capital market and today's events are a tragedy for him, his family and for those who were associated with him,'' Drexel said in a statement. But others said Milken's guilty plea amounts to a wrist-slap for enormous criminality and means the public may never know the true extent of possible wrongdoing, particularly in ``junk bonds,'' the high-yield, high-risk securities on which Milken and Drexel built their fortunes. Milken admitted guilt to six counts of breaking securities and tax laws, for which he faces a maximum 28 year prison term and must pay $600 million in fines and restitution. That still will leave him enormously wealthy. ``The government's agreement with Mr. Milken raises more questions than it answers,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, who monitors the securities industry and has frequently criticized its alleged transgressors. ``The fines assessed amount to less than a year's compensation for Mr. Milken, according to the most conserviative estimates,'' Dingell said. `Ironically, the man known as the junk-bond king was not charged with any violations with respect to his junk bond transactions.'' The plea capped an ordeal that had dogged Milken and Drexel since stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky began feeding incriminating information about them to authorities in 1986. Despite Milken's cathartic admission that he was a felon, some said his apology masked the reasons he violated the law in the first place and insisted for more than three years that he was innocent. ``Milken was clearly a genius who achieved a lot on the merits,'' said Thomas Dunfee, ethics professor at the prestigious Wharton School, where Milken earned an MBA degree. ``Why he couldn't stop is a mystery to me. Why didn't playing by the rules provide enough satisfaction? If we can get an answer to that it would help us to better understand attitudes about the law.'' Others argued that Milken still believes he was innocent but was bludgeoned into confessing by prosecutors who abused the racketeering law, which shaped the original 98-count indictment against him. ``I've always thought that to put racketeering counts on businessmen for money crimes was a misuse of the law,'' said James Linn, a prominent attorney who has represented other defendants in the Wall Street scandal. ``I think it's always wrong to use that as a threat to hang over a defendant's head to make him take some lesser counts.'' Some said the relatively few charges in the plea agreement did not mean the government had let Milken off easily. Many believe Milken will have to do some prison time. ``It's silly to play the game of who got the better deal,'' said Sorkin. ``The fact of the matter is Mr. Milken is a convicted felon. Federal prison, minimum or maximum, is not a very pleasant place.'' Others said the government benefited enormously from Milken's plea because it will eliminate a costly trial that could take years. ``Pleading guilty to six counts is really quite serious,'' said Arthur Miller, a Harvard Law professor. ``The truth is he is guilty and he will have to carry that stigma for the rest of his life.'' On Wall Street, where the Boesky-Drexel-Milken scandal has become folklore, news of Milken's guilty plea provoked little sympathy. Many securities industry workers believe the scandal played a role in eroding the public appetite for stocks in recent years. John Eric Smith, a brokerage official at the New York Stock Exchange, said the Milken case was like a cleansing process that should restore investor confidence. ``If you're caught doing something wrong, you've got to pay for it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Laura Ashley Suffers Loss
DOC.TEXT: Laura Ashley Holdings PLC, the British retailer famous for its flower print dresses and English country look, said Wednesday it suffered a $16 million net loss in its latest fiscal year. The company cited disappointing clothing sales in the United States and declining fabric and wallpaper sales in Britain. The loss for the year ended Jan. 27 compared with net profit of $13.7 million in the previous year. Sales rose 18 percent to $483.5 million from $411 million. Laura Ashley said it was embarking on a major cost-cutting and streamlining program that ``might include the disposal of certain businesses or assets, the reduction of stock and the restriction of new shop openings.'' It currently operates 481 stores. Richard Ratner, a retail analyst with the London investment firm Kitcat and Aitken, said: ``They should've done that ages ago. It'll be too little too late.'' Laura Ashley is suffering from weak management and manufacturing difficulties, analysts said. Its debt is large enough to offset strong sales, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Koito Raises Dividend, Following Demand From Pickens
DOC.TEXT: Koito Manufacturing Co., which has been resisting advances by T. Boone Pickens Jr., announced Wednesday it has raised its dividend following a demand from the Texas oilman. The auto parts maker said it would add an extra 2 yen, the equivalent of 1 cent, to its regular dividend of 8 yen a share for the fiscal year that ended March 31. Koito initially had rejected Pickens' demand for a larger dividend. Pickens became the largest stockholder in the company last year after buying a large holding from Kitaro Watanabe, the owner of Azabu Motors and other Japanese companies. Japan's Finance Ministry has ruled Watanabe violated securities regulations by buying and reselling his shares to Pickens in too short a period, and ordered him to pay Koito the 1.1 billion yen, or $6.9 million, he reportedly made in the transaction. In his demand last September for increasing dividend payments by 3 yen a share, Pickens said the money received by the company from Watanabe should be distributed to its shareholders. Koito management has viewed Pickens' stock purchases as threatening, and has refused his demands for a seat on its board and a chance to review its books. The company has expressed concern that Pickens would return a portion of his extra dividend to Watanabe, who it said ``twice sought to greenmail Koito with the shares he later transferred to Mr. Pickens.'' Greenmail is the practice of buying up stock in a company and forcing the company or a friendly affiliate to buy back the shares at a higher price. Pickens later pledged in a letter to Koito that none of the increased dividends would be channeled back to Watanabe. A Koito official said the decision to increase the dividend ``had some connection'' with Pickens' demand. ``But the decision wasn't based only on that,'' he said. ``The committee, after studying the issue, decided that it was appropriate to distribute the money among all the stockholders.'' The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Koito remained concerned that a portion of Pickens' share might go to Watanabe, ``but we want to believe in his promise.'' Pickens now holds 26.4 percent of the company's stock, or nearly 42.4 million shares, up from 32.4 million shares a year ago, the official said. Pickens has testified in the U.S. Congress that his failure to win management rights in Koito shows that Japan is closed to U.S. investors. But Koito officials say they are reluctant to give him management power because of his reputation as a corporate raider. Pickens earlier this month also asked Japan's Fair Trade Commission to investigate what he said were violations of the Anti-Monopoly Law resulting from the close relations between Japanese automakers and parts suppliers. Commission officials said they would study his claims and decide what action to take. Toyota Motor Corp. is the second-largest stockholder in Koito, with about 19 percent of the company's shares.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Striking Eastern Pilots Forming New Union
DOC.TEXT: A group of Eastern Airlines pilots is forming a new union to unseat the Air Line Pilots Association as its bargaining agent and prevent ALPA from reclaiming jobs held by replacement pilots since the Eastern strike. ``Our statement t o ALPA is: `You don't represent us anymore,''' said Steve Glasgow, a veteran Atlanta-based pilot who is among the organizers of the union, Eastern Pilots Association. The group must get approval from 50 percent of eligible pilots. The National Mediation Board then must certify the results and oversee formal voting. A majority vote would end ALPA's presence at the troubled airline and give the new union negotiating power. Many of the new union's organizers never joined the March 1989 pilots' walkout and have renounced their ALPA memberships. They are joined by replacement pilots worried that their jobs could be sacrificed in any new agreement between ALPA and court-appointed Eastern trustee Martin R. Shugrue Jr., who has talked of achieving ``labor peace.'' Tom Cooper, a 28-year Eastern veteran and temporary chairman of the new union, said about 100 pilots attended recent organizational meetings in Miami. He said the group plans to spend about $200,000 on the organizing effort and will hire a law firm to help. Eastern spokesman Robin Matell declined comment. E.J. Breen, a spokesman for ALPA's Eastern members, called the movement ``counterproductive'' and hinted at legal challenges. ``The enemy has been Frank Lorenzo,'' he said, referring to the Texas Air Corp. chairman, whose control of Eastern was given to Shugrue by a bankruptcy judge. ``Now it looks like some self-serving individuals on the inside want to start a new war,'' Breen said. Eastern has about 1,800 working pilots. About half crossed picket lines or refused to honor the strike, and half are replacement hires.

The stock market turned upward today, bidding to reverse a week-long decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 111.27 points over the past five sessions, rose 9.91 to 2,664.41 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange issues, with 695 up, 303 down and 457 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.44 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said prices appeared to have fallen far enough in their recent slide to attract some buyers looking for ``bargains.'' But they questioned how far a rally could go without signs of a significant easing in upward pressure on interest rates. Yields on government bonds, which tend to influence the over-all level of long-term interest rates, have climbed lately to near 9 percent, the highest they have been in nearly a year. That development has dampened hopes that corporate profits might improve in the months ahead. Among actively traded blue chips, General Electric rose [ to 64{; American Telephone & Telegraph [ to 40; International Business Machines { to 109], and Philip Morris [ to 41}. The NYSE's composite index of more than 1,500 common stocks gained .70 to 343.82. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .07 at 343.82. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.17 to 2,654.50. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 3 on the NYSE, with 833 down, 652 up and 506 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 137.36 million shares, up from 135.15 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Orders Medfly Spraying to Protect Citrus Industry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, The first ..., with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Calif. spraying, misgivings, edit for transition. Picks up 6th graf, Three other ... A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Florida has ordered aerial pesticide spraying to protect the state's $1.4 billion citrus industry from an infestation of Medflies. Spraying of malathion has worked in past infestations of the Mediterranean fruit fly and there's no reason to change methods now and ``run into the grave risk of getting into the predicament California is in,'' state Agriculture Commissioner Doyle Conner said Tuesday. In Southern California, aerial spraying of malathion in suburban neighborhoods has caused an uproar, while the pest has spread into orange and grapefruit groves in some of the region's richest farmland. And while expanded spraying over a 52-square-mile area of Los Angeles and San Bernardino counties was ordered Tuesday, scientists admitted that malathion spraying there may be a failing strategy. ``It's clear that we're not doing the job with the current approach,'' said Jim Carey, an entomology professor at the University of California, Davis and member of the state Medfly Science Advisory Board. The Medfly infestation is ``bordering on being out of control, if not out of control.'' The first Florida spraying against Medflies begins Thursday in a 16-square-mile zone covering areas northwest of downtown Miami and near Miami International Airport. That's where six of the pests have been found since April 16. Three other sprayings will follow over the next several weeks. After four weeks, millions of sterile Medflies will be released to break the breeding cycle. The last Medfly infestation in South Florida was in 1987, when five males were found. The state's last major outbreak affecting commercial groves spread across 28 counties in 1956. Environmentalists in California and here have objected to use of malathion, contending too little is known about the chemical's long-term health effects. ``The bad thing about using these kinds of chemicals is that they wipe out all of the insects in an area _ the good and the bad,'' said Lee Emerson, a member of the Sierra Club. ``It's not the kind of balanced, environmentally sensitive approach we should be taking these days.'' Joette Lorion, a Miami coordinator of Earth Day, said, ``If it's a danger to your car and they're asking you to wipe it off, it must be a danger to your body.'' The mixture of malathion and syrupy bait can damage car paint if not rinsed off quickly. Officials also said that people with health problems, such as asthma or allergies, may want to remain indoors during the spraying. But Conner said of malathion: ``It has not been determined anywhere to be a health risk.'' Medflies could strike a harsh blow to Florida's citrus industry, which was crippled by a Christmas freeze. Medfly larvae hatch inside more than 250 varieties of fruits and vegetables, turning them into mush. Bobby McKown, executive vice president of Florida Citrus Mutual in Lakeland, said Monday the 12,000-member growers' organization supports ``immediate action to control and eradicate the Medflies'' so they don't expand beyond residential areas. The pesticide to be sprayed per acre consists of 2.4 ounces of malathion mixed with sticky bait. Malathion is used in a stronger concentration of 3.1 ounces per acre throughout Florida for mosquito control.

DOC.HEAD: Intel Sues Advanced Micro Devices Over Rights To Chip Code
DOC.TEXT: Intel Corp., in the latest dispute between chip industry giants over intellectual property, has sued Advanced Micro Devices Corp., accusing its rival of copyright infringement. Intel, Silicon Valley's largest chipmaker, accuses AMD of illegally copying software imbedded in Intel chips to produce AMD's new line of accessory mathematics chips. The suit, filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court, asks the court to block the sale of the AMD products, impound any illegal copies of the software, and award unspecified damages. Advanced Micro Devices, based in Sunnyvale, called Intel's suit unfounded and said it has the right to copy the embedded software, known as microcode, under a 14-year-old technology-sharing agreement with Intel. Intel, based in Santa Clara, once allowed AMD and other companies to make chips based on Intel designs. Intel believed that alternative sources would help a prorietary chip design win acceptance in the market. But in an attempt to protect its right as the exclusive maker of newer chips, Intel has filed several suits against competitors. Intel also is involved in a private arbitration proceeding with AMD over rights to Intel's important 80386 microprocessor chip. Two other chip makers, Motorola Inc. and Hitachi Ltd. of Japan, have been embroiled in a 16-month legal battle over trade secrets that centers on some of their most popular chips. The two companies formerly were partners in chip development.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 419.18 down .01 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: GM Expected to Move Camaro-Firebird Production to Canada
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is expected to move production of its sporty Camaro and Firebird cars to Canada from California, clearing the way for a new kind of GM factory in the Los Angeles area, a company official said today. A news conference was set for this afternoon in Ste. Therese, Quebec, where GM's Canadian subsidiary now makes the Chevrolet Lumina coupe and sedan and Oldsmobile Ciera car. GM spokeswoman Kathy Tanner said in Detroit the company was expected to announce that production of a new Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird, called F-cars, would be moved to the Canadian plant from GM's plant in Van Nuys, Calif. ``The Van Nuys facility will continue to produce the current F-car and the timetable for the introduction of the next generation hasn't been established,'' she said. It is expected that the shift will take place in time for the Ste. Therese plant to begin making Camaros and Firebirds in 1992 for the 1993 model year. Sales of Camaros and Firebirds this year through April 20 were down 35 percent and 39.6 percent, respectively. There are about 3,500 employees at the Ste. Therese plant and about 3,800 at the Van Nuys factory. It was not immediately unclear how the production shift would affect employment at the two plants. In place of the Camaro and Firebird, GM hopes to establish a ``flex plant'' at Van Nuys, Tanner said. ``It would be a facility capable of assembling a number of various models that would allow us to respond more quickly to the Western market,'' she said. She declined to elaborate. Small, sporty cars and sport-utility vehicles are popular in the West, especially Southern California.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Rally; Grains Are Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose sharply today on the Chicago Board of Trade following news of stronger soybean crushing activity, while grain futures were mixed. The Census Bureau's monthly report on the U.S. soybean crush showed a larger-than-expected 102.1 million bushels of beans crushed in March to produce soybean oil and meal. The report implies U.S. soybean stocks may be declining more rapidly than the market had previously believed, said William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. Further buying of soybean contracts was linked to rumors that the Soviet Union is in the market for soybean meal, analysts said. Expectations for new export sales of corn helped support the corn futures. Wheat futures were narrowly mixed. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.68 a bushel; corn was \ cent to } cent higher with May at $2.76\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent lower with May at $1.56{ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ to 3\ cents higher with May at $6.01} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .08 cent higher with June at 72.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .25 cent higher with April at 84.10 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent to .28 cent higher with June at 62.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent lower to .48 cent higher with May at 64.35 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled lower on Tuesday while pork futures were mixed.

The stock market struggled to a small gain today, bidding to reverse a week-long decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 111.27 points over the past five sessions, rose 3.83 to 2,658.33 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange issues, with 660 up, 519 down and 538 unchanged. Analysts said prices appeared to have fallen far enough in their recent slide to attract some buyers looking for ``bargains.'' But they questioned how far a rally could go without signs of a significant easing in upward pressure on interest rates. Yields on government bonds, which tend to influence the over-all level of long-term interest rates, have climbed lately to near 9 percent, the highest they have been in nearly a year. That development has dampened hopes that corporate profits might improve in the months ahead. Among actively traded blue chips, General Electric rose [ to 64{; American Telephone & Telegraph [ to 40; International Business Machines ] to 109\, and Philip Morris \ to 41~. The NYSE's composite index of more than 1,500 common stocks gained .42 to 181.93. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .19 at 343.70.

DOC.HEAD: Cray Research Reports Sharply Higher First-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Cray Research Inc. reported sharply higher first-quarter earnings and repeated earlier statements that it expects its profit for all of 1990 to increase. Net income for the first three months of 1990 totaled $9.5 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with earnings of $1.5 million, or 5 cents a share, in 1989's first quarter, the Minneapolis-based supercomputer maker said Tuesday. Revenue for the first quarter totaled $135.9 million, up 17 percent from $116.1 million in the same period of 1989. ``We continue to hold the view that revenue will be flat in 1990 but earnings will improve over last year,'' said Marcelo Gumucio, president and chief operating officer. Last year, Cray earned $89 million on revenue of $785 million. Cray results typically vary a great deal from quarter to quarter. ``One-quarter snapshots of Cray's numbers are not particularly meaningful,'' said Gary Smaby, an analyst with the Minneapolis-based Smaby Group. But Smaby said the 17 percent revenue increase in the first quarter does take pressure off the company's usually strong fourth quarter. Cray reported signing orders worth $80 million during the first quarter, down from $100 million during 1989's first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Co. Reports Lower Quarterly Profit
DOC.TEXT: Du Pont Co. reported Wednesday that its first-quarter profit declined 16 percent over a year ago, reflecting expenses from business restructurings and weakness in the automotive and housing industries. For the first three months of 1990, Du Pont earned $615 million, or 90 cents per share, compared with a profit of $736 million, or $1.03 a share, n 1989. Sales, though, rose 8 percent to $9.4 billion from $8.7 billion. The chemical giant said its latest results were depressed by several non-recurring charges, principally from business restructurings. Du Pont also said most of its businesses were effected by a softening in the automotive and housing industries. The company said its agricultural products were among businesses showing improved performance over the first quarter of 1989. First quarter earnings per share reflected a lower average number of common shares outstanding as a result of the company's stock re-purchase program. Since the program began in 1989, the company has repurchased 44 million shares out of an intended 60 million. ``In March, we began to see signs of strengthening in our businesses as a result of our cost improvement programs,'' said Chairman Edgar S. Wollard Jr. ``We know we'll have our work cut out for us, but we believe we will extend our four-year trend of steady earnings improvement and achieve our stated goal of maintaining or exceeding 16 percent return on equity through a business cycle.''

The stock market staged a modest upswing today, bidding to reverse a week-long decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 111.27 points over the past five sessions, rose 7.89 to 2,662.39 by noontime on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange issues, with 691 up, 555 down and 567 unchanged. Analysts said prices appeared to have fallen far enough in their recent slide to attract some buyers looking for ``bargains.'' But they questioned how far a rally could go without signs of a significant easing in upward pressure on interest rates. Yields on government bonds, which tend to influence the over-all level of long-term interest rates, have climbed lately to near 9 percent, the highest they have been in nearly a year. That development has dampened hopes that corporate profits might improve in the months ahead. Norton Co. led the active list, up 13} at 89. The company, which has been opposing a takeover bid from the British conglomerate BTR PLC, said it agreed to be acquired by Compagnie Saint-Gobain of France for $90 a share. Gainers among the blue chips included Bristol-Myers Squibb, up { at 53[; International Business Machines, up } at 109|; McDonald's, up [ at 31, and Philip Morris, up ] at 42. DOC.HEAD: ITT Posts Higher Earnings After Sale of French Stock
DOC.TEXT: ITT Corp. reported Wednesday that its first-quarter profit rose 27 percent over a year ago, due largely to a $47 million gain from the sale of stock in Paris-based Compagnie Generale d'Electricite. Net income for the first three months of 1990 totaled $253 million, or $1.88 per share, compared with earnings of $200 million, or $1.40 a share, last year. Sales were nearly flat, rising 2 percent to $4.93 billion from $4.83 billion. ITT said revenue results were impacted by the third-quarter sale of Communications Services Inc. ITT said its higher earnings reflected the sale of about 2 million shares of Compagnie Generale d'Electricite in which it gained about 33 cents per share. ITT reported mixed performances in its various divisions, with declines in electronic components, service businesses, financial operations and Sheraton hotels. Income at ITT's defense segment improved as a result of increased contract margins and product shipments. The pulp and timber division also showed improvement. Chairman Rand V. Araskog said he was optimistic about the rest of the year despite the lower results in some of ITT's businesses and ``a difficult business environment in the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Norton To Merge With `White Knight' French Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT ``companies'' to ``countries.''
DOC.TEXT: Norton Co., which has been fending off a hostile takeover bid from British conglomerate BTR PLC, said today it agreed to be acquired by the French firm Compagnie Saint-Gobain in a deal that values the abrasives manufacturer at around $1.8 billion. The $90-a-share cash offer exceeds BTR's bid of $1.6 billion, or $75 a share, which was rejected last month by Norton's board of directors. Wall Street applauded today's announcement. In active trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Norton jumped $13.50 to $88.75 a share by midday. The announced merger with Compagnie Saint-Gobain comes a day after a federal judge ordered Worcester-based Norton to reveal the amount of a ``white knight'' offer it said it had received last week. The court order came during a hearing on suits filed on behalf of some Norton shareholders seeking to require Norton to fully and fairly consider BTR's offer and ``take into consideration the interest of the shareholders.'' Norton told the Securities and Exchange Commission last Friday that a third party was interested in buying Norton for more money. BTR had planned to wage a proxy fight at Norton's annual shareholders' meeting set for Thursday. But one of Norton's biggest weapons was a new state law that would prevent BTR from taking immediate control over the Norton board. The law zoomed through the legislature last week and was signed by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, taking effect immediately. It permits a Massachusetts corporation to elect only one-third of its directors at a time, unless the company opts out of the requirement. BTR had said it wouldn't back down despite the state law. In a statement, Chairman John S. Nelson said, ``Norton has fought hard to remain independent because we believed this to be the ideal for all Norton constituencies.'' But Nelson said a negotiated merger was ``the best alternative'' to a BTR bid, which he termed as inadequate. Norton and Saint-Gobain said the merger was conditioned upon keeping Norton's headquaters and principal manufacturing operations in Worcester. The companies said Norton would continue operating under the same name and that employee policies and benefits would be continued at present levels. Norton also would remain an autonomous company with a separate board of directors, they said. ``These are the commitments on which we have formed our partnership, and the merger agreement provides specifically that these commitments will continue for at least five years,'' Nelson and Saint-Gobain Chairman Jean-Louis Beffa said in a joint statement. According to a statement, at least two-thirds of Norton's 20.37 million common shares outstanding must be tendered before the full financed cash offer beginning April 30, 1990. Norton is the world's largest manufacturer of abrasives and a leading producer of engineering materials, including advanced ceramics, performance plastics, and chemical process products. Norton, which had 1989 sales of approximately $1.5 billion, employs 16,000 people and operates 113 plans in the United States and 25 other countries. Saint-Gobain produces a variety of flat glass, fiber glass, piping, paper and wood products and has annual sales of more than $11 billion. The Paris-based company employees 88,000 people and operate 350 plants in the United States and 20 other countries.

DOC.HEAD: France's Air Inter Bans Smoking After Passenger Survey
DOC.TEXT: Air Inter announced Wednesday it will ban smoking on all its domestic flights after a two-month experiment found that 88 percent of passengers favored smoke-free flights. The French airline banned smoking on a temporary basis on March 1. The latest announcement said the restriction will be extended indefinitely, in accordance with the results of a survey conducted since then. Air Inter reported that a poll of 5,500 passengers found that 88 percent thought smoke-free flights are a positive thing, with 96 percent of non-smokers and 72 percent of smokers favoring such a ban. About 36 percent of Air Inter's passengers smoke, the airline said. Air Inter serves mainly domestic French routes but also operates some flights to Rome, Lisbon and London. A law banning smoking on virtually all domestic flights recently went into effect in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Announces 9.7 Percent Increase in Sugar Imports
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Adds Nicaragua and quota to list. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced today a 9.7 percent increase in the amount of foreign sugar that can be imported by U.S. processors from 40 countries. Yeutter said the increase boosts the sugar import quota to 2,834,865 metric tons for the period Jan. 1, 1989, through Sept. 30, 1990, an increase of 250,000 tons from 2,584,865 tons announced on Jan. 16. The latest quota boost was the fourth for 1989-90. Previous increases were made last Sept. 12 and Nov. 24. Yeutter said ``continued supply-demand imbalances'' forced a further adjustment in the sugar import quota. The latest figures included the reinstatement of Nicaragua's share of the U.S. sugar quota. An increase of at least 250,000 tons had been sought by the Sweetener Users Association, which represents industrial consumers of sugar and other sweeteners. Quotas are used to restrict the amount of foreign sugar that can enter the United States, thus protecting domestic producers from lower-priced foreign sugar being dumped on the U.S. market.
