DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Down; Gold Lower
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Updates with late European rates and midday rates in New York.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mostly lower in European trading Wednesday as support for the West German mark firmed. Gold was lower. Dealers said market activity was generally focused on cross-rate movements between the mark and other currencies, particularly the British pound and the Japanese yen. ``It's as much a switch back into marks as any other factor,'' said Michael James, head of inter-bank dealing for Britain's Midland Bank. The dollar held relatively firm against the yen largely on the Japanese unit's weakness rather than any substantive move in the dollar. But some dealers suggested firmer long-term U.S. interest rates helped the dollar by at least creating perceptions that Japanese investment capital would flow toward the dollar. Late in London, the dollar was quoted at 1.6820 marks, down from 1.6930 marks late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.10 yen to a closing 159.25 yen. In London, it was quoted late Wednesday at 158.59 yen. The pound sank following the British announcement of a merchandise trade deficit of 2.18 billion pounds in March, wider than 1.39 billion pounds a month earlier. The Bank of England stepped in to signal support at around $1.6260. Sterling finished the day slightly stronger against the dollar, trading at $1.6370 late Wednesday compared to $1.6345 Tuesday. Other late rates compared with late Tuesday's levels were: 1.4665 Swiss francs, down from 1.4865; 5.6455 French francs, down from 5.6795; 1.8970 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9100; 1,234.00 Italian lire, down from 1,241.00; and 1.1603 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1590. Selected dollar rates at midday in New York included: 1.6845 West German marks; 158.945 Japanese yen; 1.4650 Swiss francs; 1.16025 Canadian dollars and 1,233.25 Italian lire. Gold traded in London at late a bid of $371.25 a troy ounce, down from $378.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the late bid was $371, down from $377.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.02 to close at a bid of $375.95 per troy ounce. Silver fell in London to a bid of $4.97 dollars a troy ounce from Tuesday's $5.10.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Promises to Finish Valdez Cleanup by Summer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead to show the meeting was briefly interrupted, changes `aides' to `executives' in 5th graf
DOC.TEXT: An environmentalist group briefly disrupted the Exxon Corp. annual meeting today while executives told shareholders the Alaskan shore slimed with oil from the Exxon Valdez should be cleaned by summer's end. ``Very substantial progress has obviously been made,'' Exxon President Lee R. Raymond said in detailing the cleanup of the worst oil spill in U.S. history, now a rallying cry for the environmental movement. Raymond cited a ``massive summer-long effort'' last year, the scouring of winter storms and the application last fall of a fertilizer to speed the biological decay of the oil. In contrast with the roughly 250 demonstrators who attended last year's annual meeting in New Jersey, about 20 people outside today's gathering carried signs urging a boycott of Exxon products. But later inside while Exxon executives spoke, they were interrupted when Jay Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation, took issue with the upbeat review of Exxon's Alaska operations. ``We call that bull---,'' he said, suggesting the damage goes beyond the environment. ``Listen to the people of Alaska whose lives have been destroyed and you're putting the profits in your pockets,'' Hair said, to loud boos from the audience. Exxon has come under harsh criticism from environmentalists, politicians and many shareholders for what was perceived as its inadequate response to the Alaska disaster, the worst oil spill in U.S. history. The meeting agenda was dominated by the 11 million-gallon spill, which occurred March 24, 1989, when the tanker Exxon Valdez hit a reef. Shareholders were scheduled to vote on six environmentally related resolutions. Some environmental groups also have called informally for Chairman Lawrence G. Rawl to resign, although he is not expected to do so. Demonstrators handed out leaflets suggesting 10 questions shareholders should ask Exxon management about its response to the oil spill and other problems. Once inside the George R. Brown Convention Center, shareholders passed through metal detectors and then passed through an elaborate display called ``Progress in Alaska'' detailing Exxon's cleanup efforts in Prince William Sound. Some of the criticism against Exxon has been over its decision to reduce activity last September in preparation for Alaska's harsh winter. One display told shareholders that ``nature takes over the cleaning job with intense storm activity'' during the fall, winter and spring. Exxon executives said the company will resume full-scale cleanup within a few weeks after a survey is completed of remaining damage. Spokesman Henry W. Beathard estimated the job would be finished by the end of summer. Rawl and Raymond each touted Exxon's environmental efforts during remarks opening the meeting, attended by more than 1,000 shareholders. ``In addition to reaffirming our own commitment to safety and environmental protection, Exxon has been an active participant in the development of guiding principles for the petroleum and chemical industries,' Rawl said. The company had spent some $2 billion for spill-related expenses through the end of 1989 and faces possible further costs for civil and criminal damages linked to the disaster and other oil spills. The environment-related shareholder resolutions include pledges by Exxon to reduce its emissions of pollutants and toxic waste, create a special environmental affairs committee on its board of directors and follow the so-called Valdez Principles for corporate environmental conduct. Exxon says all the resolutions are duplicative and unnecessary, and should be rejected by shareholders. Also today, Exxon said it would join other oil companies in reformulating some of its gasolines to burn cleaner. Exxon said it would market its gasolines in 40 markets in the East and along the Gulf Coast. Exxon will sell the reformulated gasoline in the New York area year-round and in other areas during the summer.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed lower Wednesday on London's Stock Exchange after the government reported a larger trade deficit for March. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 16.8 points, or 0.8 percent, at 2,143.1. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 13.7 points at 1,683.5 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 8.24 points to close at 1,163.90. Volume was 392.8 million shares compared with the 372.9 million shares Tuesday. Shares prices began falling immediately after the government reported that the merchandise trade deficit soared to 2.18 billion pounds, or $3.6 billion, in March from 1.39 billion pounds in February. The latest deficit was Britain's second worst ever, and made traders bearish about the prospects for share prices.

DOC.HEAD: Realtors Say Home Sales Sluggish in March
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Existing home sales in March remained below 1989 levels for the second straight month as mortgage interest rates stayed in the double-digits, a real estate trade group reported Wednesday. The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted 3.40 million units, unchanged from the number of sales in February but down from the 3.52 million rate in January. The annual rate for a particular month represents what the total number of sales for the year would be if the pace were maintained for 12 consecutive months. During all of 1989, actual sales totaled 3.44 million units. Realtors chief economist John A. Tuccillo said the 3.40 million pace, the slowest since a 3.38 million rate last July, was sustainable for the rest of the year. The Commerce Department is scheduled to report new home sales for March next Monday. New home sales rose 3.1 percent to an annual rate of 607,000 units in February after plunging 6.8 percent the previous month. But the pace of sales remained below the 649,000 new homes sold in 1989 and analysts placed the blame on mortgage rates and declining consumer confidence. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. reported that 30-year conventional fixed-rate mortgages averaged between 10.22 percent and 10.34 percent during March, high when compared to the single-digit rates at the end of 1989. The Realtors said the high rates had a dual effect on the existing home market. Consumer uncertainty triggered purchases by prospective buyers fearing higher rates in the future while it curbed sales by others hoping for lower rates in the months ahead. ``The rate-watchers who are making their move now tend to be in less expensive markets,'' said Realtors president Norman D. Flynn. ``Those who are holding back in hopes of rate declines tend to be in the higher-priced markets.'' The Realtors said the national median price of existing homes was $96,100 in March, up $900 from February. The median price of a new home in February was $130,000, according to the Commerce Department. The median means that half of the homes cost more, half less. Existing home sales in the Northeast continued to be sluggish in March, falling 16.9 percent to an annual rate of 490,000 units. The median price there was $148,200, up 3.3 percent from the previous month. Sales also fell in the West, down 1.5 percent to an annual rate of 640,000. The median price was $143,300, the same as February's. Sales were unchanged at an annual rate of 890,000 units in the Midwest where the median price was $72,900, down 1.6 percent. The South posted the only sales gain, up 3.8 percent to 1.36 million units. The median price was up 0.9 percent to $86,000.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 1st-Qtr Earnings Gain
DOC.TEXT: Norfolk Southern Corp. reported Wednesday its first-quarter net income rose 4.8 percent on a 2.7 percent revenue increase. The company said its earned $140.2 million, or 84 cents a share, in the first three months of the year, up from $133.8 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier in its previous first-quarter record. First-quarter revenue rose to $1.14 billion from $1.11 billion a year earlier. ``Strong coal traffic has continued into 1990, with coal, coke and iron ore revenues up 11.1 percent over last year,'' Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Arnold B. McKinnon said. The higher ore traffic more than offset a 1.3 percent drop in merchandise revenues and a 2.4 percent decline in revenues from the company's North American Van Lines subsidiary, McKinnon said. He said revenue rose 7 percent in agricultural commodities, 5.4 percent for chemicals and 2.6 percent for paper.

DOC.HEAD: It's Butterflies Vs. Honeybees for National Insect
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS newspaper names in 2nd item, 4th graf, bgng, Contest winners... to make it Star Tribune and 5th graf, Lee Egerstrom ... to make it Saint Paul Pioneer Press. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Capitol Hill is aflutter and abuzz with lobbying campaigns by friends of the monarch butterfly and the honeybee. Advocates of each critter say the United States is long past due for a national insect. There is a national bird, the bald eagle, so let's have a national bug, they say. So far, the House and Senate have not been pushed into deciding. But the Entomological Society of America, which observed its 100th year in 1989, is working on behalf of the monarch butterfly. Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., has introduced a butterfly bill in the House and has added 16 co-sponsors. But Rep. Stephen L. Neal, D-N.C., has a honeybee measure waiting that has 38 co-sponsors. In the Senate, no champion of the butterfly has stepped forth, says Douglas W.S. Sutherland, chairman of the society's national insect subcommittee. ``We're looking, but so far we haven't had any luck,'' Sutherland said Tuesday. Sen. Larry Pressler, R-S.D., has a honeybee bill and a number of cosponsors. Pressler and others point to the honeybee's valuable contributions to agriculture as a crop pollinator as well as a provider of honey. That's the story in the House, too, where John Taylor, an aide to Neal, said their bill would recognize the importance of beekeepers and bees as ``an integral part'' of U.S. agriculture. ``I think the strength of our (bill) is that the bee is such a big part of agriculture,'' Taylor said. ``The bee pollinates the food that you and I eat.'' According to the Agriculture Department, U.S. honeybees produce about 250 million pounds of honey and unintentionally pollinate more than 90 cultivated crops with a combined annual value of billions of dollars. Sutherland, an entomologist for the Environmental Protection Agency, said Tuesday that he recognized the honeybee's important role in agriculture but thinks the monarch deserves the national title. The society's membership of about 2,000 voted on which insect to support, and the familiar orange-and-black monarch came out on top, followed by the tiger swallow-tail butterfly, a large yellow species. Sutherland said the convergent lady beetle was third among the society's members, and the honeybee was fourth. Overall, he said, the two butterflies received more than 70 percent of the vote. The monarch's appeal partly stems from its wide range over the United States, he said. The swallow-tail, on the other hand, is not found in all states. Sutherland said the monarch is a benign, native American creature that feeds on milkweed and harms no one. Eastern varieties migrate to an area in the mountains southwest of Mexico City, while the western monarchs flock to the California coast, he said. Lobbying help for the monarch is forming among garden clubs, many school children and others, Sutherland said. ``A healthy environment for the monarch is a healthy environment for everybody, basically,'' he said.

Steven H. Lee of the Dallas Morning News has been named winner of this year's Glenn Cunningham Memorial Award by the National Association of Agricultural Journalists. Lee and other annual award recipients were honored Monday night at the group's 37th annual dinner at the National Press Club. The association was formerly the Newspaper Farm Editors of America. The three-day conference concluded Tuesday. Contest winners in specific categories included: news, Steven H. Lee; column-analysis, T.J. Gilles, Great Falls (Mont.) Tribune; features, Sharon Schmickle, Star Tribune, Minneapolis, Minn.; series, Anne Fitzgerald, The Wichita (Kan.) Eagle; and special projects, Scott Kilman, Wall Street Journal. Lee Egerstrom of the Saint Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press was elected president of the association. Egerstrom had been vice president and took over the top job last fall upon the resignation of Kathleen Davis of the Lubbock (Texas) Avalanche-Journal. Davis is now with Texas A&M University. Other officers include: Michael Flaherty, Wisconsin State Journal, vice president; and Audrey Mackiewicz, Huron, Ohio, executive secretary-treasurer. Regional vice presidents named were: East _ Marcia Taylor, The Farm Journal, Washington, D.C. Southeast _ Judith Egerton, The Courier Journal, Louisville, Ky. Midwest _ Wayne Falda, South Bend (Ind.) Tribune. Southwest _ Steven H. Lee, The Dallas (Texas) Morning News. West _ T.J. Gilles, Great Falls (Mont.) Tribune.

The Senate Agriculture Committee has voted to extend current government programs for wool, mohair and honey for five years with virtually no changes. ``The wool and mohair title (of the 1990 farm bill) is essentially a five-year extension of the program for wool in the 1985 farm bill,'' Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said Tuesday. The measure: _Authorizes loans, purchases and payments by the Agriculture Department to help the wool and mohair industry. _Sets a payment rate that would be the difference between the national average of all domestic wool receipts and the price the government predetermined that producers should get. Each producer's payment from the government would be calculated by applying this rate to net proceeds for wool sold the preceding year. The honey section of the farm bill also would be little changed from current policies. The price support for honey has dropped an average 5 percent each year for five years. Under the new legislation, support prices would be frozen at 56.86 cents a pound through 1995. Loan repayment rates would be unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Tenneco's Profit Up 23 Percent in First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Tenneco Inc. reported a 23 percent increase in earnings for the first quarter as revenue rose. The diversified energy company said Tuesday it earned $134 million, or $1.03 a share, in the first three months of the year, up from $109 million, or 82 cents a share, a year earlier. First-quarter revenue increased 8.4 percent to $3.6 billion from $3.32 billion. ``The first-quarter results in total are in line with expectations,'' said James L. Ketelsen, Tenneco's chairman. ``Those divisions with lower operating income in this year's first quarter were all budgeted to be lower than 1989. ``Our goals for 1990 remain to increase earnings per share by at least 15 percent, achieve a 20 percent rate of return on shareholders' equity and generate cash flow from our industrial operations in excess of our capital expenditures and dividend requirements.'' Among the company's divisions, earnings from the natural gas pipeline segment were down 22 percent at $90 million. Tenneco attributed the decline to warm weather. The farm and construction equipment division jumped to $48 million from $1 million, mainly because of higher sales volumes and prices. Tenneco's automotive operating income was $42 million, down from $49 million in the first quarter of 1989. Its Newport News Shipbuilding operations had earnings of $45 million, up from $30 million. Operating income for the chemicals and minerals businesses was $40 million in the first quarter, up from $32 million a year earlier. Packaging Corp. of America had income of $42 million, down $10 million from last year.

DOC.HEAD: Net Income Up Nearly 15 Percent for Fiscal 3rd Qtr
DOC.TEXT: CHICAGO (AP ) _ Sara Lee Corp. reported a 14.6 percent increase in its fiscal third-quarter net income Wednesday despite a slight decline in overall sales and a poor performance from its namesake bakery division. A company spokeswoman and an industry analyst both said the weak sales of Sara Lee's packaged meats and bakery products partly reflected increased consumer preference for breakfast cereal. ``People are eating cereal more than bacon and eggs and danish and bagels,'' said analyst Roger Spencer of PaineWebber Inc. Chicago-based Sara Lee reported net income of $108.9 million, or 44 cents a share, for the three months ended March 31 compared with $95 million, or 40 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales for the quarter fell 1.3 percent to $2.8 billion from $2.84 billion, reflecting both the disposition of some of Sara Lee's food-service businesses at the beginning of fiscal 1990 and a 9 percent drop in bakery unit volume after a 10 percent increase in last year's comparable quarter, Sara Lee said in a statement. Unit volume refers to the amount of product shipped as opposed to revenue, which refers to the dollars received from the sale of goods. Sales for Sara Lee's packaged meats and bakery division fell 13.5 percent to $1.2 billion and operating income for the unit plunged 25 percent to $45.2 billion. The division's poor performance was offset by a 2 percent sales increase and a 48 percent gain in operating income from the company's coffee and grocery division, and by increases of 14 percent in both sales and operating income for Sara Lee's packaged consumer products division. Company spokeswoman Anne McCarthy said bakery sales should improve with the planned introduction of new products in the second quarter. She said Sara Lee's recently introduced ``light'' baked goods have been successful. For the first nine months of fiscal 1990, net income rose 14 percent to $352 million, or $1.40 per share, from $307.8 million, or $1.32 per share, in the first nine months of fiscal 1989. Sales for the three quarters totaled $8.65 billion compared with $8.66 billion for the same period a year earlier. In addition to its baked goods, Sara Lee markets a variety of brand name products including Hanes underwear, L'eggs hoisery, Hillshire Farm and Jimmy Dean meats, Douwe Egberts coffee and Kiwi shoe polish.

DOC.HEAD: Surging Soybeans Lead Rise In Crop Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, led by a surging soybean market amid bullish news surrounding developments in the Soviet Union. Traders heaved ``a collective sigh of relief'' that President Bush had chosen not to impose economic sanctions against the Soviet Union in retaliation for Moscow's crackdown on Lithuanian independence, said Joel Karlin, an analyst in Chicago with Research Department Inc., a brokers' advisory service. Some traders had feared the U.S. would limit grain sales to the Soviets. Rumors of Soviet interest in soybean meal added further support, as did perceptions that Tuesday's steep drop in precious metal prices reflected Soviet selling of gold to get hard currency for more grain and soybean purchases, Karlin said. The Census Bureau's monthly report Tuesday on the U.S. soybean crush was also supportive. It showed a larger-than-expected 102.1 million bushels of beans crushed in March to produce soybean oil and meal. The report implied U.S. soybean stocks may be declining more rapidly than the market had previously believed, said William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 3\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.71 a bushel; corn futures were 2} cents to 4 cents higher with May at $2.79 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2 cents higher with May at $1.58} a bushel; and soybeans were 8} cents to 13} cents higher with May at $6.09{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: March Construction Contracts Up 4 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hold for release at 6:30 p.m. EDT _ time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Contracts for new construction rose 3 percent nationwide in March, reversing a five-month slide of building activity that had been concentrated in the Northeast, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc. reported Wednesday. The Dodge Index, which uses 1982 as its base of 100, increased to 156 in March from 150 in February, although it remained well off its most recent peak of 181 reached last September. The yearly pace of total contracting was $244.97 billion last month, up from $235.96 billion in February. March's improved rate reflected a 15 percent surge in non-residential projects. Homebuilding construction eased 2 percent, while public works and utilities projects fell 1 percent. ``With the exception of offices, March contracts for non-residential construction revealed a general strengthening of commerical, industrial and institutional building,'' said George A. Christie, vice president and chief economist of F.W. Dodge. Institutional building, which includes construction of schools and health-care facilities, was up 29 percent in March, partly due to two large hospital renovation projects in the New York area. For the first three months of 1990, construction contracting trailed 1989's first quarter value by 6 percent. The Northeast, where contracting has fallen off in recent months, showed the biggest decline in building activity, off 25 percent from the previous year's quarter. The South lagged percent over the 1989 quarter. Posting modest gains were the North-Central region, where building activity rose 5 percent, and the West, with a 3 percent increase.

The stock market showed a moderate gain today, bidding to reverse a week-long decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 111.27 points over the past five sessions, rose 15.32 to 2,669.82 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange issues, with 765 up, 631 down and 536 unchanged. Analysts said prices appeared to have fallen far enough in their recent slide to attract some buyers looking for ``bargains.'' But they questioned how far a rally could go without signs of a significant easing in upward pressure on interest rates. Yields on government bonds, which tend to influence the over-all level of long-term interest rates, have climbed lately to near 9 percent, the highest they have been in nearly a year. That development has dampened hopes that corporate profits might improve in the months ahead. Norton Co. led the active list, up 13{ at 88}. The company, which has been opposing a takeover bid from the British conglomerate BTR PLC, said it agreed to be acquired by Compagnie Saint-Gobain of France for $90 a share. Gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up ~ at 109}; General Electric, up [ at 64{; Sears Roebuck, up | at 36, and Philip Morris, up { at 42[. The NYSE's composite index of more than 1,500 common stocks gained .86 to 182.37. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .03 at 343.92. Volume on the Big Board came to 110.33 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: America West Blames First-Quarter Loss on Higher Fuel Prices
DOC.TEXT: America West Airlines said Wednesday the higher price of jet fuel in the first three months of the year was the main factor behind its $2.6 million net loss for the quarter. America West, the nation's 10th-largest airline, said it was its first quarterly loss after seven consecutive quarters in the black. The airline said the loss of $2.6 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with net income of $10.1 million, or 58 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1989. The year-earlier results included a $7.4 million gain from the sale of foreign tax benefits related to aircraft acquisition. First-quarter revenue rose 30.8 percent to $304.8 million from $233.1 million. ``The sharp rise in fuel prices left America West, as well as the entire airline industry, with disappointing results for the first quarter 1990,'' said Al Frei, America West's chief financial officer. ``America West's fuel expenses for the 1990 quarter increased approximately $9 million over the corresponding 1989 quarter.'' ``Increased payroll expense, travel agency commissions and catering costs also added to higher operating expenses,'' Frei added. The airline said the price it paid for jet fuel rose 22 percent _ from 58 cents a gallon to 71 cents _ in the last year. Frei and America West Chairman Edward R. Beauvais predicted that the quarterly slump would be short-lived. They cited a 2.9 percent gain in load factor, or number of available seats occupied, despite a 30 percent increase in capacity from the year-earlier quarter. ``Continued strengthening of our traffic and subsiding fuel prices leave us very optimistic for positive results in the second quarter and the balance of the year,'' Beauvais said.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Record First-Quarter Sales, Profits
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. reported on Wednesday record profits and sales in the first quarter of 1990, but still received a healthy dose of criticism at its annual meeting. The world's largest brewer said it earned $182.5 million, or 64 cents a share, in the latest quarter, up 9 percent from $167.1 million, or 58 cents a share, for the same period in 1989. Sales were up 8 percent, including a nearly 3 percent rise in barrels of beer sold, in the quarter, to $2.59 billion compared with $2.39 billion in 1989's first quarter. Despite the favorable report, August Busch III, chairman and president of the company, spent much of his time at the annual meeting defending the company in both prepared remarks and answers to stockholders' questions. He defended the company's decision to cut its prices to match competitors' prices, a move that stock analysts said was Anheuser-Busch's attempt to speed up its effort to reach 50 percent market share by the mid-1990s. ``This does not mean we are trying to start a price war in the brewing industry,'' Busch said. Anheuser-Busch increased its market share in 1989 to 42 percent of the market from about 40 percent in 1988. One out of every four beers sold in the United States is a Budweiser, according to the company. The chairman also defended the Anheuser-Busch's efforts to prevent beer from being linked in any way to illegal drugs and praised the various programs the company sponsors to urge responsible beer drinking. ``We will continue to do everything we can to ensure that beer plays a positive role in our society,'' Busch told the about 3,200 stockholders at the meeting. The company was also criticized for flooding the market with too many brands _ 17 at last count _ and for spending too much money promoting already popular beers. With three new products being launched this year already _ Busch Light, Bud Dry and the non-alcoholic O'Doul's _ Busch agreed that ``our plates, to say the least, are full.'' But he said there's no way around it. ``Proliferation of brands is somewhat disturbing to all of us. If we had our druthers, and we don't, we would sell one product,'' Busch said. ``But that isn't how the marketplace today works.'' Unless the company keeps coming up with new beers, new packages, new shelf space, market share and profits will be lost, Busch said. Anheuser-Busch, which gets 80 percent of its revenues from beer and beer-related sales, also owns Campbell Taggart Inc., the second largest commercial baker in the country, and the baseball team, the St. Louis Cardinals. The company is also the country's second largest theme-park operator with Busch Gardens and Sea World.
Stock prices braked a week-long slide with a mild rally today. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 12.84 at 2,667.34.

DOC.HEAD: Specialty Department Store Chain Founded in 1924 Sold for $1.5 Billion
With AM-Saks Sale Bjt
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC on Wednesday announced the sale of the Saks Fifth Avenue specialty department store chain to an international investment group for $1.5 billion. Here is a brief history of the retailer: _ The idea for what has become the Saks chain originated with Horace Saks and Bernard Gimbel, who independently operated stores in New York City in the early part of this century. The two merchants decided to open a fashionable specialty department store catering to affluent customers. The store on Fifth Avenue opened Sept. 15, 1924. _ From 1924 to 1969, Saks expanded and built a national recognition as an upscale retailer, mainly of higher priced apparel. _ Bernard Gimbel's cousin, Adam, became president after the sudden death of Horace Saks in 1926. Under Adam Gimbel, branch stores were opened and the flagship Manhattan store was redecorated in the opulent Art Moderne style from the 1925 Paris Exposition. _ Adam Gimbel retired as Saks president in 1969. At the time, there were 21 Saks stores. _ Saks in 1973 was bought by BATUS Inc., the U.S. holding company of the London-based conglomerate BAT Industries PLC. _ Under BAT's ownership, Saks has grown to include 45 stores operating in 30 major markets in 20 states. States in which there are Saks stores include Arizona, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Louisana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nevada, New Jersey, New York, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Texas and Virginia. A 46th store in Houston that has performed poorly is being closed while three new Saks are to be opened by the end of 1990. _ The flagship Fifth Avenue store was proclaimed a New York City landmark in 1965. _ BAT announced in September 1989 plans to sell Saks, its sister retailing operations, plus certain other assets as part of a strategy to thwart an unsolicited takeover attempt by an investment group led by the Anglo-French financier Sir James Goldsmith. The group on April 23 dropped its $22 billion bid but BAT said it would continue its restructuring and asset sales. _ Saks management announced March 15, 1990 that it had submitted a bid for the chain. The buyout proposal was made jointly with Tobu Department Store Co. Ltd. of Japan. _ The sale of its Breuner's furniture retail and rental subsidiaries were announced by BAT on March 27 and April 2, respectively. Negotiations continue for the sale of Ivey's, a specialty department store chain with 23 stores in the Carolinas and Florida. _ BAT announced on April 19 that it had agreed to sell Saks' sister retailer, Chicago-based Marshall Field & Co., to Dayton Hudson Corp. for $1.04 billion. _ BAT on April 25 announced it has accepted a bid of $1.5 billion for Saks from Investcorp, an international investment bank with a wide range of retail and other holdings. The bid was one of a handful of final proposals for the chain. _ In commenting on its acquisition, Investcorp said it will keep all existing Saks stores open for business and will carry on current expansion and renovation plans. Benefits for Saks' employees will be continued at current levels. _ Paul Soldatos, a member of Investcorp's management committee that led the effort to buy Saks, said the group relies on professional managers to run businesses. He said in an interview that Investcorp will meet with Saks management as soon as possible to discuss the future. He said no meeting had taken place yet because Saks' management had been competing in the auction.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hard-Hats Cynical About USX Corporate Wrangling
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Far from the boardroom battles between Carl Icahn and USX Corp. over the bottom line on steel, the Steel Valley is bottoming out. This town's mammoth mill forged the locks for the Panama Canal, the girders for the Golden Gate Bridge, the beams for the Empire State Building, the wheels for Disneyland rides and the armor plate that crushed Hitler and Hirohito. But after more than a century of steelmaking, it was shuttered in 1986 as part of a corporate overhaul. It is an icon of the smokestack age and a way of life extinct. About 9,000 people were employed here a decade ago. Wreckers toil at the Homestead Works now, like scavengers picking innards of a carcass. The last of five generations of steelworkers who witnessed the demolition talk caustically about Wall Street raiders and corporate revamping. ``Ninety-nine out of 100 people who lost their jobs see it as the wrangling between two sharks who have already eaten them,'' said Mike Stout, 40, an ex-steelworker who runs a printing shop. ``They are extremely bitter. They feel betrayed. They want nothing to do with U.S. Steel ever again.'' Icahn, USX's largest shareholder with 13.3 percent of its stock, sees steel as a drain on the company's Marathon Oil Co. and Texas Oil and Gas Corp. Last year, energy accounted for 65 percent of business for USX, which changed its name from U.S. Steel four years ago and remains the nation's largest steelmaker. Ten years ago, steel was 70 percent of sales. Icahn envisions a separate entity called U.S. Steel Co., of which 80 percent would be peddled to USX shareholders. USX executives oppose the idea, though they agreed to hold a nonbinding shareholder vote May 7. But to the laborers who once felt the open hearth furnaces cook through their steel-toed shoes, splitting the company would be a meaningless formality. For them, the furnaces are no longer an eternal flame. ``People sort of accept it as fact that U.S. Steel is going to be chopped up,'' said Bob Anderson, a former steelworker who runs Homestead's Rainbow Kitchen, a food, job and clothing bank. ``They've already dismembered the plants. Now they're going to dismember the corporation,'' Anderson said. ``It could be the final nail in the coffin, the death of a way of life. It's not the Steel Valley anymore. We're an industrial graveyard.'' As proof of changing times, a fantasy-like oasis has sprouted amid the ashes. The Sandcastle amusement park beckons visitors with water slides, sandy beach and wooden boardwalk. It adjoins the bankrupt Mesta Machine Corp., once the world's largest maker of steelmaking equipment. The region was called Steel Valley because hulking mills sprouted along the Monongahela River south of Pittsburgh. The river network and direct access to coal fields made it an ideal place for steel, basic metal of the 20th century. The valley also was the backbone of U.S. Steel, the world's first billion- dollar corporation. Some of capitalism's wealthiest barons forged the company out of a 1901 debt-financed megadeal that was the biggest acquisition in history up to that point. In today's dollars, the $1.4 billion deal would be worth about $23 billion and would dwarf most of today's mergers. The centerpiece was Andrew Carnegie's mills in the Steel Valley, which merged with seven other steel companies and John Rockefeller's iron mines through J.P. Morgan's financing. The company prospered. So did legions of Slavs, Poles, Italians, Irish and German immigrant laborers, drawing steady paychecks to raise families. But the raw and brutal work had a price _ the whistles, hisses, rumbles, the stench of sulphur, eyesores of slag heaps, rivers that ran like industrial sewers and air so dirty it blotted out the sun while street lights burned in the afternoon. Today, Renaissance Pittsburgh is a corporate center with a gleaming skyline, service-based industry, clean air and rivers. Rand McNally rated it the nation's most liveable place in 1986, and it is now ranked third. But in steel's heyday, muckraking author Lincoln Steffens recoiled at the belching furnaces and called the area ``hell with the lid off.'' When asked how the city could spruce itself up in the 1940s, architect Frank Lloyd Wright said, ``Abandon it.'' Back then, U.S. Steel was more than just a job or a profit-loss statement. It was a paternal entity that dominated local politics, determined land use, paid most of the taxes and built libraries, gyms and music halls. The company and its predecessors also had their own security. Hired guns often battled union organizers. In 1892, 10 people were killed and scores injured when 300 armed Pinkerton guards fired on strikers at Carnegie's Homestead Works. U.S. Steel fused with all aspects of life, even the sporting and spiritual. Its logo adorns the helmets of Pittsburgh's pro football team, the Steelers. A stained glass window in a Homestead church pictures steel being poured. ``Everybody in one way or another depended on U.S. Steel. It was everybody's safety net,'' said Jo DeBolt, director of the Steel Industry Heritage Task Force, which hopes to salvage part of the cadaver of Homestead Works as a museum. ``Imagine spending your whole life doing something you're proud of and all at once it's gone. People lost their sense of place. If you live in the Steel Valley and you don't make steel anymore, what are you?'' Mrs. DeBolt said. The safety net disintegrated in the 1980s. Failure to modernize, sweetheart labor deals and imports contributed to the collapse. Steel Valley became the symbolic capital of the rust bowl. In 1979, 26,000 people worked for U.S. Steel in the valley. Today about 4,000 toil at three remaining plants. The only steelmaking plant is the Edgar Thomson Works, built in 1875 as Carnegie's first mill. He named it for the president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the biggest customer of Carnegie's rails. The overhaul made USX leaner and meaner. It takes less time and labor costs to make steel. But it came with a social cost: USX sold or closed 15 plants or mining operations in the past 10 years, including Homestead. Overall, the region around Steel Valley lost 100,000 manufacturing jobs and 30 percent of its population. Workers sought jobs elsewhere in the biggest industrial dislocation of the decade. For those who stayed, the main industry became survival. A survey sponsored last year by the United Steelworkers of America showed 40 percent of the workers remain jobless. Those who found work take home 40 percent to 68 percent less than their steel wages. To help, Allegheny County Mental Health created a program called Bridge to Recovery in 1986. It is run by Lois Brown, 40, an ex-steelworker whose father worked 40 years in a steel mill and whose grandfather worked in a tin mill. Her daughter works for USX. ``For many of the people affected, it's too painful to think about. This was a way of life almost from the beginning of time. Now there's nothing left. It's like it never existed,'' Mrs. Brown said. Still, for many remaining USX workers, the battle with Icahn is worrisome. Although they have no love for USX and still smart from a six-month lockout four years ago, the hard hats tend to align themselves with the company. ``We know USX. We'd rather deal with the devil than the unknown,'' said Gary Hubbard of the USW, whose ranks have declined to 700,000, half its all-time peak. ``We are very much opposed to mergers and acquisitions for no other purpose than to saddle healthy companies with a huge debt burden,'' he said. ``The workers always pay the price.'' The jitters are worst among those working at the remnants of Steel Valley. ``The bombs are going to go off,'' Barney Oursler of the Mon Valley Unemployed Committee said of the corporate haggling. ``All they can hope for is they can duck so they don't get killed in the explosion.''

DOC.HEAD: Two-Year Note Yields Rise
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes rose in Wednesday's auction to the highest level in a year. The average yield was 8.9 percent, up from 8.59 percent at the last auction on March 27. It was the highest rate since two-year notes averaged 9.34 percent on April 26, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8~ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,995.50. A total of $10.5 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $26.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Weaken Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices tumbled Wednesday amid heavy selling motivated by technical market forces and speculation that sluggish demand will not soak up much of the supply glut. Some of the heaviest selling occured in the gasoline futures pits on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline plunged 1.79 cents to 62.60 cents a gallon, reversing course after several days of advances. The contract had gained 0.85 cent on Tuesday. Unleaded gasoline contracts for delivery further in the future also ended lower. The contract for June delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, dropped 34 cents to $18.66 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after falling 7 cents on Tuesday. Contracts for later delivery also posted losses. The May contract of wholesale home heating oil fell 0.25 cent to 52.40 cents a gallon after settling 0.47 cent lower on Tuesday. The June, July and August contracts ended with steeper declines. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.552 per million British thermal units, down from $1.555 on Tuesday. Analysts said the slide in unleaded gasoline prices appeared to be a correction after a recent runup. They said there wasn't any fundamental supply or demand news on which to pin the selloff. Energy market analysts said prices generally remain under pressure from bearish supply estimates. A weekly report released late Tuesday after the market closed showed crude oil stocks rose 1.2 million barrels last week, adding to an already abundant inventory. Although the report from the American Petroleum Institute was unsurprising, analysts said it reinforced the notion that supplies will significantly exceed expected demand in the near future.

DOC.HEAD: Company Agrees to French Merger in Takeover Fight With British
DOC.TEXT: After weeks of fighting off hostile advances from a British conglomerate, Norton Co. said Wednesday it had agreed to a $1.8 billion merger with a French firm. News of Norton's proposed $90-a-share merger with Compagnie Saint-Gobain sent Norton's stock sharply higher on the New York Stock Exchange. Norton's stock rose $13.37{ a share to $88.62{ and was the most active issue on the exchange with more than 4.5 million shares traded. The offer tops the $1.6 billion, $75-a-share offer from BTR PLC, the British company that had been pursuing Norton. BTR responded to the proposed merger by announcing it is withdrawing its bid to put three people on Norton's board of directors, but is extending its offer to May 3. The extension is in case the Norton-Saint-Gobain merger goes sour, said a BTR spokesman in New York city who declined to give his name. ``Essentially, we're pleased by it (the higher bid),'' the spokesman said. ``We're 4.9 percent shareholders of Norton.'' Chairman John S. Nelson said Norton decided to take the Paris-based company's offer to avert a long and potentially bloody battle with BTR. ``Given the increasing risk of the worst alternative for all constituencies _ fighting a war of attrition only to be bought in the end by BTR for an inadequate price with no protection for employees and the Worcester community _ we have concluded that a negotiated merger ... is the best alternative,'' Nelson said in a statement. ``Saint-Gobain is a real strategic partner for Norton. Aside from the fact that it's offered a premium price for the company, it understands Norton's businesses, it believes in research and development,'' said Andrea Priest, a New York-based spokeswoman for Norton. Analyst Alvin Donius of New York-based Altman, Brenner Wasserman agreed the two companies were a good match. Norton is a leading manufacturer of abrasives and engineering materials, including advanced ceramics, performance plastics and chemical process products. It had 1989 sales of approximately $1.5 billion, employs 16,000 people and operates 113 plants in the U.S. and 25 other countries. Saint-Gobain produces a variety of flat glass, fiber glass, piping, paper and wood products with annual sales of more than $11 billion. It employs 88,000 people and operates 350 plants. ``I think that it's an ideal situation for Norton and Saint-Gobain,'' Donius said. ``There is great synergy _ technology, research and development, manufacturing _ the whole nine yards.'' Although Saint-Gobain's offer was considerably higher than BTR's, Donius said he believes the French firm can afford the expense. The merger, which requires tender of at least two-thirds of Norton's common shares before April 30, delighted Norton employees, who had banded together to fight the takeover after BTR's offer in March. Employees held frequent rallies, published a daily newsletter and lobbied for legislation to make the takeover more difficult. After Wednesday's announcement, Norton employees went out into the company parking lot for an impromptu rally to celebrate their apparent escape from BTR, who they were convinced would have decimated the Worcester company. ``The mood is great,'' said Tom Morrison, an organizer of a group formed by employees to fight BTR's hostile takeover bid. ``We're really proud of what we did. Things are really good. Hopefully, BTR's going away and this company we're setting up with seems to be a very good move,'' he said. The proposed merger announcement came a day after a federal judge ordered Norton to reveal the amount of an offer the company said it received last week. Norton told the Securities and Exchange Commission last Friday that a third party was interested in buying Norton for more money than BTR. The company's regular shareholders meeting is Thursday. Conditions of the merger included keeping the Norton name and leaving its headquarters and principal manufacturing operations in Worcester. The companies said employee policies and benefits would continue at present levels and Norton would retain a separate board of directors. Saint-Gobain chairman Jean-Louis Beffa said he made the agreement to expand his company's U.S. business interests and also because ``we did not want to see it (Norton) dismembered or subjected to debt that would interfere with its strategic plans.''

DOC.HEAD: Holiday Inns Reorganizing, Cutting 600 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Holiday Inns Inc. announced Wednesday it will eliminate 600 jobs as it reorganizes its hotel management efforts into separate divisions overseeing franchise operations and its company-owned hotels. The company, purchased by the British brewery and hotel conglomerate Bass PLC in February, plans to concentrate on its primary business: hotels. ``We have the most recognizable hotel brand in the world, and we are going to focus all our efforts on building it,'' Chairman Bryan D. Langton said. ``This will mean we will discontinue all secondary or satellite businesses.'' The changes include the resignation of Kenneth B. Hamlet as president and chief executive officer of the hotel division, Langton said. The company is eliminating 260 jobs its Hotel Services Division, which buys the furnishings for Holiday Inns motel rooms. About 210 jobs will be lost in the Holiday Clubs division, Langton said in a statement. Holiday Inns is cutting 50 jobs in its administrative headquarters in Memphis and getting rid of 80 positions in its international business section. Bass opened international headquarters for Holiday Inns in Atlanta last month, shortly after it completed the $2.2 billion acquisition of the hotel chain. Holiday Corp. shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale about three years after Bass became involved in the business by buying eight European Holiday Inns. Bass, which has more than 7,300 pubs and restaurants in the United Kingdom and brews a variety of beers _ including Bass and Carling Black Label _ sought the Holiday Inns in an effort to establish itself as an international force in the hotel industry. Holiday Inns have 1,589 hotels and 318,012 rooms in 52 countries around the world.
