DOC.HEAD: When This Credit Rater Says Jump, States Ask How High
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: He can strike fear deep into the hearts of the most financially acrobatic state and municipal treasurers because of his power to shape the bottom lines of their budgets. Hyman C. Grossman, who evaluates their fiscal health for Standard & Poor's Corp., demonstrated that clout last month when he told New York's budget makers he didn't like the state's numbers. The influential rating agency downgraded New York's credit standing. The move jolted New York's byzantine budget process, causing Republicans and Democrats alike to repent for years of effective deficit spending and work toward a true balanced budget. The sudden conversion to the cause of fiscal probity didn't come cheap. The rating move is expected to cost the state's taxpayers $180 million in higher debt interest payments over the next four years. ``Someone once called us ... a fourth branch of government,'' Grossman says. It's not a label he likes, though. He stresses that the agency tries to keep its distance from public officials to guarantee a dispassionate view of government finances. ``We're an important link in moving financing from the government to the ultimate investor really,'' Grossman says. ``We're kind of an umpire. We've got to call it as we see it.'' Grossman constantly speaks in the plural voice, emphasizing that he doesn't sit alone behind the plate. The company's municipal department has 120 analysts, and every major borrower is reviewed by a committee of at least five people. ``A major rating change has to be pretty close to unanimous,'' he says. But as managing director of criteria and rating policy, he sets the pace for the department. He also chairs the rating committees for several key borrowers, including New York state and city, New Jersey, Florida and Texas. Grossman, 55, has been making calls on state and local government finances for 27 years at S&P. He's seen everything from the near bankruptcy of New York City in the mid-1970s to the big state surpluses of the mid '80s to the shortfalls currently plaguing many state treasurers, particularly in the Northeast. He says the pressures facing the states today are serious. The federal government has cut back sharply on aid for social services, transportation and water treatment. At the same time, sluggish economies have curbed the growth of income and sales tax revenues, and corporate taxes aren't picking up the slack. The debt-financed takeover boom of the 1980s has hurt state coffers by substituting tax-deductible debt for equity. The record $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco, for example, probably will cost North Carolina $100 million in lost income this year, one quarter of its budget shortfall, Grossman says. As New York state seeks to cope with a projected $1.5 billion shortfall, Grossman has suggested the state consider an income tax surcharge. But he dismisses the idea that S&P tries to dictate policy. ``We're not necessarily advocates of higher taxes or lower taxes or more or less spending. But we are advocates of ... credible and balanced financial operations,'' he says. There's a fine line between dictating specific policies and pushing for change, though. Grossman was well aware of the political impact of a rating change when his team voted to downgrade New York after repeatedly expressing concern about the state's accumulated deficits and a yawning budget gap for the latest fiscal year. ``Frankly, if you express concern, concern, concern and you keep the rating, you don't change policy. And we felt that policy needed to be changed. Not that we're dictating policy. But the only way attention could be called to this credit deterioration was to change the rating.'' The decision dropped the state's rating by two notches to single-A, the third lowest among the states after lowly Louisiana and Massachusetts. Telephoning state officials with the news was ``not easy, but it's part of our job,'' Grossman says. Budget director Dall W. Forsythe said the state was surprised by the two-notch drop, and that S&P didn't wait until legislators and the executive had agreed on a budget package. ``We disagree ... on some of their judgments and decisions,'' he said. But he didn't challenge Grossman's expertise. ``He is a very knowledgeable professional,'' he says. Rating governments is a natural for Grossman, who has a lifelong interest in public policy. A New York City native, Grossman studied political science at New York University and became active in local Democratic politics. He spent one year in law school but left to marry in 1960 and earn a living on Wall Street. He served as council president in his hometown of Marlboro Township in the New Jersey suburbs from 1977 to 1981. (The council agreed at the outset not to seek a rating from S&P if it borrowed during the period, which it didn't.) As a member of the Governmental Accounting Standards Advisory Council, Grossman is helping to revise accounting guidelines for public bodies across the country. Assessing the creditworthiness of a state or municipality is more complex and subjective than rating a corporation, Grossman says. You can't just look at widget sales and debt payment schedules. The rater has to judge the political process that produces the budget. ``You develop a credibility assessment of the government you're dealing with,'' Grossman says. In New York's case, years of papering over the deficit with one-shot financing deals wore credibility too thin, he says. Grossman also emphasizes the strength or weakness of an area's underlying economy, something Forsythe says distinguishes S&P from its chief rival, Moody's Investors Service. Grossman doesn't like computer models, though. He relies on his nose for anecdotal evidence. On a trip to Austin, Texas, for example, he dropped into a real estate broker's office and was startled to find the office vacancy rate was 38 percent, hardly a robust indicator. Two weeks before last Christmas he took a lunchtime tour of a half dozen of Manhattan's most exclusive jewelry and department stores, talking to salespeople to assess the consumer mood. ``I said, `Tell me, how's business?' `Well, Mr. Grossman, we're not supposed to talk about this. But this is the worst Christmas we've had in seven years,''' he recalled them saying. For Grossman, that was a sure sign the recession in the area's financial services industry would give the city and state a double whammy, crimping income and sales tax revenues. To treasurers making decisions that affect millions of taxpayers, that may seem a flippant way to forecast. But Grossman trusts his methods, calling them ``informal but very reliable.'' That's just the kind of confidence you'd expect in an umpire.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday April 29

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Milken-Boesky, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are short profiles of some of the major figures in Wall Street's financial scandals: _IVAN BOESKY, the former speculator in takeover stocks, was accused of running a broad insider trading network. He settled charges by paying $100 million and pleading guilty to one count of lying to federal regulators. He was released from federal custody April 4 after completing two years of a three-year prison term. _MICHAEL R. MILKEN, former head of junk-bond trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., pleaded guilty Tuesday to six counts of violating federal securities and tax laws and agreed to pay $600 million. He faces up to 28 years in prison at sentencing Oct. 1. Four of the six charges involved dealings with Boesky, but none were for insider trading or racketeering. Milken had been charged with 98 counts of fraud and racketeering in March 1989. _DENNIS LEVINE, a former managing director at Drexel, was paroled last year after serving 17 months of a two-year prison term for securities fraud, tax evasion and perjury. Levine's confessions about a broad insider trading ring led prosecutors to Boesky. Levine pleaded guilty to four felonies and returned $11.6 million in alleged illegal profits. _MARTIN SIEGEL, pleaded guilty in 1987 to illegal stock trading and tax evasion while head of mergers and acquisitions at Kidder, Peabody & Co. He also agreed to return $9 million in cash and securities to settle civil charges for his role in illegal dealings with Boesky. Siegel, a former Drexel managing director, is awaiting sentencing. _BOYD L. JEFFERIES, a Los Angeles stockbroker snared in the Boesky web, was placed on probation and fined $250,000 after two years of helping the government. He pleaded guilty to two felony counts in 1987 and then testified in the trials of GAF Corp. and corporate raider Paul Bilzerian. _BRUCE NEWBERG, a former Drexel trader, was indicted with Milken and convicted with five others in the Princeton-Newport Partners racketeering and fraud trial. He was sentenced to three months in prison in the Princeton-Newport case. Newberg was Milken's assistant at Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., high-yield bond division. His status in the Milken indictment is unresolved. _PAUL A. BILZERIAN, the Florida takeover strategist, last year received four years in prison for his conviction on nine counts of securities fraud, conspiracy and making false statements, and was fined $1.5 million. The prison sentence for the former Singer Co. chairman was the stiffest in the Wall Street scandals so far. Bilzerian is is free pending appeal. _ROBERT FREEMAN, former head of arbitrage for Goldman, Sachs & Co., was arrested along with two other executives for insider trading. Implicated by Siegel, Freeman pleaded guilty to one felony count and this month was sentenced to four months in prison and fined $1 million.

DOC.HEAD: American To Spend Billions on Customer Amenities, Depite First Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: The corporate parent of American Airlines said Wednesday it will spend $11 billion to expand passenger services and amenities in a bid to become the nation's premiere international airline. AMR Corp. said it was embarking on the five-year plan that will include such luxuries as lobster, chateaubriand and chocolate mousse served on special china, and possibly even airborne fax machines, despite a $19.3 million first-quarter loss reported last week. ``We feel there is a place in the market for a premier United States international airline, and our ambition is to be that _ to become known as the U.S. flag carrier,'' said George Mueller, vice president of customer services for AMR, based in Fort Worth. The program will include the previously announced $7.7 billion investment in international aircraft, AMR said in simultaneous news conferences in Arlington and Chicago, American's second-largest hub after Dallas-Fort Worth. An estimated $655 million is earmarked for terminal expansions, AMR said. The new amenities will include almost fully reclining seats, private video screens in first class sections and more spacious seating in business class. None of the changes will be included on domestic flights, but Mueller said there will be no cuts in domestic service to finance the amenities on international flights. The improvements will also include more up-scale menus, designed by culinary experts such as Paul Prudhomme. AMR hopes the moves will let American become a recognized international carrier and not just a mammoth domestic airline with a handful of overseas flights. The airline has spent billions on planes ticketed for international routes and hundreds of millions to acquire routes to Latin America and London. It is aggressively seeking government approval for new routes to Japan. AMR's announcement follows last week's report that it lost $19.3 million during the first three months of the year, compared with a $156.7 million profit last year. The loss of 31 cents per share came on a total operating revenue of $2.69 billion. In the same period last year the company earned $1.60 per share on revenue of $2.45 billion. Asked about AMR's large planned outlay coming after the reported loss, Mueller said: ``If you are going to go after and capture a market share in the international market, you're not going to do that by cutting services.'' Analysts expect most airlines to report losses or a smaller profit than last year. AMR's loss was less than many industry analysts had expected.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metal Futures Plunge; Platinum Leads Sell-Off
DOC.TEXT: Precious metal futures prices plunged Wednesday as a supply-connected collapse of platinum prices triggered selling in the gold and silver markets, which had already been weakened by a lack of investor demand. Gold for spot delivery traded as low as $370 an ounce for the first time since April 2 and silver plummeted to its lowest level in nearly four years. On other commodity markets, copper futures surged to an eight-month high; oil futures were sharply lower; grains and soybeans retreated; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $5.20 to $5.70 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in April at $370.70 a troy ounce; silver was 7.5 cents to 9.1 cents lower with April at $4.919, the lowest settlement price for a near-month silver contract on the exchange since May 19, 1986. Platinum futures finished $15.60 lower across the board on the New York Mercantile Exchange with July at $472.20 a troy ounce, the lowest near-month platinum settlement since April 2. The tumble extended Tuesday's steep losses in gold and silver, which analysts had attributed mainly to weak investor demand in the face of rising interest rates. Waves of selling swept easily through the thinly-traded platinum market early in the session amid signs of physical platinum sales by the Japanese and an announcement by the world's largest platinum producer of plans to increase production beginning in 1991. Analysts agreed the expansion plans by South Africa's Rustenburg Platinum Co. may have no effect on supplies of refined platinum for several years. But because the company is such a large supplier, its announcement ``really set us off,'' said James Steel, a metals analyst with the futures brokerage Refco Inc. Some analysts also cited sluggish spring car sales, inferring a corresponding drop in platinum demand for use in automobile catalytic converters. Analyst Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. discounted that notion, noting that car makers buy platinum on an annual contract basis. ``I really think it was a technical sell-off and all these things were excuses,'' she said. Some analysts pointed out, though, that supplies of silver certified as deliverable on the Commodity Exchange _ reported Wednesday at 254.5 million troy ounces _ are near record highs. The exchange reported supplies of deliverable copper at about 6,000 tons on Wednesday, one day before the April contract is due to expire. Another exchange report indicated that more than 10,000 tons of copper would have been needed to satisfy all outstanding April contracts as of Tuesday, the last day for which statistics were available. The apparent shortfall in deliverable supplies was the main factor behind Wednesday dramatic surge in copper futures prices, analysts said. Copper settled 1.1 cents to 10 cents higher with the April contract up 10 cents at $1.34 a pound, the highest settlement of a near-month copper contract since Aug. 25. Crude oil and gasoline futures tumbled on the New York Merc amid heavy selling motivated by technical market forces and speculation that sluggish demand will not soak up much of the supply glut. A weekly report released Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute showed U.S. crude oil stocks rose 1.2 million barrels last week, adding to an already abundant inventory. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 19 cents to 34 cents lower with June at $18.66 a barrel; heating oil was .25 cent to .60 cent lower with May at 52.40 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.2 cents to 1.79 cents lower with May at 62.60 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade, led by a surging soybean market amid perceptions that the Soviet Union may be preparing to buy more U.S. grain and soybean meal. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 3\ cents higher with May at $3.71 a bushel; corn futures were 2} cents to 4 cents higher with May at $2.78} a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2{ cents higher with May at $1.58} a bushel; soybeans were 10} cents to 13 cents higher with May at $6.09\ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures settled .02 cent to .22 cent lower with June at 72.85 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent to .42 cent higher with April at 84.27 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .70 cent higher with June at 62.52 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .08 cent to .60 cent lower with May at 63.95 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major currencies Wednesday in light trading as the Swiss franc and the West German mark rose sharply, traders said. Gold prices slipped. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for April delivery settled at $370.70 a troy ounce, $5.20 below Tuesday's close. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a troy ounce of gold at $371.25 as of 4 p.m. EDT, down $4.50 from Tuesday's late bid. Traders said the Swiss franc was boosted by the Swiss central bank's decision Tuesday to raise interest rates. That caused the dollar to lose strength against the currency, said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange at PaineWebber International Inc. The mark strengthened against the dollar on the belief that the West German central bank will raise its official interest rate shortly to help stem inflation, Troni said. Higher West German interest rates make returns on the mark relatively more attractive as an investment. Linda McLaughlin, a currency trader with Chemical Bank, said the dollar lost value due to technical factors, with little economic news to affect the currency. She described the trading as light. In late London trading, the dollar fetched 1.4665 Swiss francs, down from 1.4865 late Tuesday. Later, in New York, the dollar traded at 1.4575 Swiss francs, down from 1.4875 late Tuesday. In late London trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6820 marks, down from 1.6930 marks late Tuesday. It stood at 1.6780 marks late in New York, lower than Tuesday's late 1.6980 marks. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.10 yen to a closing 159.25 yen. In London, it was quoted late Wednesday at 158.59 yen. In New York, the dollar finished at 158.73 yen, down from 158.95 yen late Tuesday. The pound sank in London following the British announcement that the merchandise trade deficit widened in March to 2.18 billion pounds from February's 1.39 billion pounds. However, the currency later finished stronger on buying by the Bank of England. Sterling finished the day in London at $1.6370 compared with $1.6345 Tuesday. Later in New York, the pound rose to $1.6405 from $1.6347 on Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late quotes, included: 5.6345 French francs, down from 5.6980; 1,231.00 Italian lire, down from 1,244.75; and 1.1608 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15955. Selected dollar rates late in Europe compared with late Tuesday's levels included: 5.6455 French francs, down from 5.6795; 1.8970 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9100; 1,234.00 Italian lire, down from 1,241.00; and 1.1603 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1590. Gold traded in London at a late bid of $371.25 a troy ounce, down from $378.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the late bid was $371 an ounce, down from $377.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.02 to close at a bid of $375.95 per troy ounce. Silver bullion for current delivery fell on New York's Comex to $4.919, down from $4.994 Tuesday. Silver fell in London to a bid of $4.97 a troy ounce from Tuesday's $5.10.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Slump Blamed for Poor Job Growth in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: The Northeast's continued manufacturing slump and a tight labor market are largely to blame for the region's anemic job growth in the past two years, a labor report says. The region's poor showing in a state-by-state ranking of the number of new jobs created _ seven Northeast states were in the bottom 10 _ follows an economic boom in the early 1980s for the Northeast, said a report by the New York regional Bureau of Labor Statistics office. ``The 1980s were a glorious period for the Northeast, but then they just ran out of steam,'' regional commissioner Samuel Ehrenhalt said Wednesday. His report was released Tuesday in Albany, N.Y. Before the last ranking, which covered a two-year period ending in December 1987, only one of the seven states _ Pennsylvania _ had previously been in the bottom 10 of new jobs created. The two Northeast states to fare better than the bottom 10 were Maine, which was No. 9, and Vermont, which was listed as No. 31. Maine had previously been listed as No. 10 for a ranking covering 1979-87 while Vermont was No. 8. Overall, the nine Northeastern states accounted for 9 percent of the nation's new jobs from 1987-89, compared to the 21 percent share from the early 1980s. The report said that over the past two years, the Northeast continued on a 20-year path of having the poorest factory record among the four regions. But it also said that expansion has slowed since December 1987, especially in such major growth sectors as services, trade and finance. Construction has also weakened considerably, the report said. Ehrenhalt said a slowdown in the population growth in the Northeast, and accompanying tight labor markets, also were to blame for the region's slow job growth. ``If you're not growing that many more customers, you don't need that many more retail stores,'' he said. In contrast to the Northeast's problems, seven of the top 10 states in job growth were in the West. Nevada, which experienced a 17.1 percent job growth, came in at No. 1, followed by Idaho and then Washington. Nationally, job growth increased by 2.3 percent in 1989, compared to the 3.2 percent in each of the previous two years. Here are the seven Northeast states in the bottom 10, followed by job growth and then the previous ranking. _No. 41: New Jersey, 3.2 percent, No. 16. _No. 42, Pennsylvania, 2.9 percent, No. 41. _No. 45, New York, 1.9 percent, No. 27. _No. 47, Connecticut, 0.7 percent, No. 19. _No. 48, Rhode Island, 0.3 percent, No. 25. _No. 49, Massachusetts, 0.2 percent, No. 17. _No. 50, New Hampshire, -0.9 percent, No. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 30 Percent Profit Increase in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co. said Wednesday its fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 30 percent from a year ago because of higher unit sales volume and a lower effective tax rate. The company said it earned $404 million, or $1.14 a share, in the three months ended March 31, up from $310 million, or 92 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 12.8 percent to $6.12 billion from $5.43 billion a year earlier. For the first nine months of its fiscal year, Procter & Gamble said it earned $1.32 billion, or $3.71 a share, up 27.3 percent from $1.04 billion, or $3.06 a share, a year earlier. Nine-month revenue rose 11.9 percent to $17.87 billion from $15.97 billion a year earlier. The company makes and markets laundry, cleaning and personal care products, and food and beverage products.

DOC.HEAD: Says He'll Increase USX Holdings If Proposal Approved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 new grafs after 11th graf pvs, USX stock ... to UPDATE with Corry comments. Picks up 12th graf pvs, Icahn said ...
DOC.TEXT: Carl Icahn said Wednesday that if USX Corp. shareholders approve his proposal to spin off its steel business, he would increase his USX stock holdings by $800 million and pledge not to seek control of the company. Icahn, USX's largest stockholder with a 13.3 percent stake, was apparently trying to counter suggestions that he has proposed the spinoff solely as a way to drive up the price of USX stock and then profit by selling his holdings. ``We have no intention of selling if the vote goes in favor of a restructuring,'' Icahn said during a meeting with investors and analysts here. ``If we win this vote, the company will do something'' that should ultimately increase the value of USX's shares, said Icahn, who is the chairman of Trans World Airlines and is a prominent takeover strategist. Shareholders are to vote on Icahn's non-binding proposal at the company's annual meeting May 7 in Findlay, Ohio, home of USX's Marathon Oil Co. subsidiary. Under the plan, which USX management opposes, 80 percent of the company's U.S. Steel division would be spun off as a separate company with the proceeds of the sale distributed to USX shareholders. Icahn, believing the company would be worth more to shareholders broken up, said Wednesday he would buy USX stock at a price up to $48 _ the amount he believes shareholders would receive if his plan were carried out. He said he would sign a ``standstill'' agreement under which he would not try to take over USX. ``We're not looking for control,'' he said. Asked what he would do if he loses the vote, Icahn said he did not yet know. ``We'll cross that bridge when we come to it,'' he said. However, he said he was concerned about the future of USX if shareholders spurn his proposal, saying the steel division needs an equity infusion that it is unlikely to receive while linked to the stronger Marathon unit. USX stock rose $1.25 to $34 a share in New York Stock Exchange composite trading Wednesday. ``It seems to me that Icahn is simply trying to buy votes and distract stockholders from the serious questions that we and a number of prominent analysts have raised about his proposal to break up USX,'' USX Chairman Charles Corry said in a prepared statement. Icahn's offer to buy some additional shares could seriously threaten the value of all outstanding USX shares, the chairman said. ``Icahn's announcement is totally conditional and subject to his sole discretion,'' Corry said. ``It does not commit him to pay any particular price and is subject to a standstill agreement with USX that would have to be satisfactory to him.'' ``Icahn could obviously refuse to buy any shares saying the company was not willing to give him satisfactory terms for such a standstill agreement.'' Icahn said he believes a restructuring of USX would give stockholders $9 a share for their U.S. Steel holdings, and $39 for their Marathon holdings. However, he said Wednesday there were many other steps besides his proposal that USX could take to restructure and raise its stock price. He likened the situation at USX with that of Texaco Inc., which restructured in 1989 after a series of battles with Icahn, including a takeover bid and his unsuccessful attempt to unseat the oil company's board. If his USX proposal garnered 51 percent of the vote, ``I think the company will do something relatively dramatic,'' Icahn said. ``A number of people on the board are waiting for that kind of message.'' Skepticism over Icahn's motives follow a number of unsuccessful bids in the past, including a 1987 run at USX. Many observers believed he sought the Texaco restructuring _ which included the sale of billions of dollars in assets _ for his own financial gain.

DOC.HEAD: Net Up 20 Percent in 2nd Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. said Wednesday its second-quarter profit rose 20 percent on a 26 percent sales increase, and cited better results from its theme parks, filmed entertainment and consumer products divisions. In the quarter ended March 31, Disney earned $178.5 million, or $1.29 per share, on revenue of $1.3 billion, the company reported Wednesday. That compared with $149 million, or $1.08 per share, on revenue of $1.03 billion during the same quarter a year earlier. Both profits and sales figures were at record levels, the latest in a string of record earnings for the entertainment conglomerate. Best-ever attendance at the theme parks, combined with higher per capita guest spending and expanded resort operations, were factors in increased revenues and operating income in the theme parks segment, Disney said. The Disney-MGM Studios attraction in Florida, which opened in May 1989, was a major draw, the company said. Quarterly revenues in the division rose 22 percent to $710 million; operating income was up 14 percent to $194 million. Home video sales of ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' ``Dead Poets Society'' and ``Turner and Hooch'' and the theatrical release of ``The Little Mermaid'' and ``Pretty Woman'' led the filmed entertainment results higher, with growth in international television and home video key factors, Disney said. Revenues in the division increased by 30 percent to $469 million, while operating income rose by 40 percent to $58 million. Increased merchandise licensing, the success of ``The Little Mermaid'' sound track and European publishing activities contributed to a 29 percent rise in revenues in the consumer products division, to $125 million. Operating income rose 24 percent to $59 million. Disney said it also set records for earnings during a six-month period. For the first six months of fiscal 1990, Disney said profits rose 19 percent to $353 million, or $2.55 a share, from $297.3 million, or $2.16 a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 25 percent to $2.59 billion in the latest six months from $2.08 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Camaro, Firebird Production Heading to Quebec from California.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf and ADDS two grafs to UPDATE with announcement in Canada.
DOC.TEXT: Production of the Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird will be moved to Canada from Southern California, clearing the way for a new style of manufacturing at a General Motors Corp. plant. GM of Canada Ltd. announced late Wednesday that the next generation of the sports cars, called F-cars, would be produced at its plant in Ste. Therese, Quebec, probably in late 1992. That will open up GM's plant in Van Nuys, Calif., where the cars are made currently, for a new carmaking strategy. There are about 3,500 employees at the Ste. Therese plant and about 3,800 at Van Nuys. Sales of Camaros and Firebirds have been suffering this year, like those of other GM cars. Through April 20, Camaro sales were down 35 percent compared with last year, and Firebird sales were off 39.6 percent. GM spokeswoman Kathy Tanner said Wednesday in Detroit that there was a proposal to make the Van Nuys plant GM's first ``flex plant'' once production of the current F-car is ended. ``It would be a facility capable of assembling a number of various models that would allow us to respond more quickly to the Western market,'' she said, declining to elaborate. partment to combat grasshoppers in the state of committee member Sen. Quentin Burdick, D-N.D., and in South Dakota and Minnesota. In both its House and Senate versions, the bill was being largely financed through cuts or transfers from the Pentagon's 1990 budget. The Senate bill claimed $2.8 billion in defense savings, $1 billion more than the House. The bill also includes a provision aimed at solving the drawn-out fight between the Bush administration and Congress over the Pentagon's ability to transfer funds to military personnel accounts to avoid massive layoffs. Bush had failed last year to exempt military personnel from the cuts imposed by a budget-cutting law. The provision says $780 million of unspent funds from defense programs, including the Strategic Defense Initiative, land-based missiles and bomber programs, could be used to cover the shortfall in the personnel accounts. When the Pentagon earlier this year asked Congress to let it transfer money to cover personnel costs, House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin objected and criticized the administration for having put weapons before people.

DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide Shareholders Vote Against Increased Gas Payment
With AM-Bhopal
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp. shareholders voted not to increase a $470 million settlement to victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas leak despite hearing stories of the victims' misery at Wednesday's annual meeting. ``One man in the hospital is totally paralyzed on one side and has great difficulty breathing,'' said the Rev. Andy Smith, a director of the American Baptist Churches USA, who recently visited Bhopal. ``I also saw great anger against the corporation there, and many women and children raised their fists in anger.'' Stockholders agreed with the company's directors and overwhelmingly defeated Smith's proposal, as well as a resolution to shut down a Union Carbide plant in South Africa. They were less sympathetic when it came to their pocketbooks, grilling Chairman Robert D. Kennedy about Carbide's stock price, dividends and plans to keep the company profitable during a downturn in the chemical industry. ``We are as concerned as you are with the fact that our share price has gone down in recent months,'' Kennedy told shareholders. He acknowledged the stock has traded below $20 a share this week, down from $24 a year ago and $33 in February 1989, after the Bhopal settlement was reached. But he said he was optimistic the chemical and plastics maker will do well through the downturn, saying its operations are the most efficient in the industry. Union Carbide just reported a 53 percent drop in net earnings in the first three months of the year. It attributed the decline to weaker prices and overcapacity, as well as shutdowns at three chemical plants during a winter cold spell. Union Carbide last year agreed to pay $470 million to compensate for the deadly leak of methyl isocyanate gas from its plant in Bhopal, India. About 3,600 people died in what was the world's largest industrial accident. ``I walked through the streets and spoke to many victims. I was in their homes,'' Smith said. ``What I found was appalling because the people are still suffering.'' He said one doctor told him at least 50,000 people had lung damage. Many cannot work because of breathing problems. ``We believe that the $470 million is totally inadequate,'' he told the meeting, urging stockholders to pay for long-term medical care. Kennedy defended the settlement, saying fewer victims have come forward than the government originally estimated. He also said those who want more humanitarian aid should gripe to the Indian government. ``Every single time that Union Carbide has attempted to act unilaterally with any kind of humane response, ... we have been rebuffed,'' he said. ``They don't want our help. They don't want us meddling in caring for their people.'' The new Indian government, which took power earlier this year, has asked that the settlement agreed to by its predecessor be set aside. It says much more compensation should be paid. At a press briefing later, Kennedy acknowledged it will take time for the Bhopal disaster to fade. ``I think we will never put Bhopal behind us fully, but I also believe you regain your image one day at a time, one year at a time, by what you do and the record you achieve,'' he said. Kennedy encouraged one speaker to provide the company with independent test results indicating soil and drinking water near the Bhopal plant still contain toxic materials. Marco Kaltofen, scientific director of the National Toxics Campaign in Boston, had asked the company for a schedule for cleaning up the toxics. Kennedy also told stockholders Union Carbide was reducing emissions and improving standards for handling toxic wastes and materials at its facilities. He said the company has signed on to a set of industry standards that aim to cut emissions, spills, leaks and hazardous materials.

DOC.HEAD: Setting of Sun Just the Latest Problem for Ingersoll
DOC.BYLINE: With AM-St. Louis Sun ^By RANDOLPH PICHT
DOC.TEXT: Ralph Ingersoll II hasn't been having a very good spring. On Wednesday, the bold and gracious 43-year-old newspaper publisher announced that his new, headline-grabbing project, the St. Louis Sun, was folding after only seven months of publication. Five days earlier an effort to clear away much of his junk-bond debt was unsuccessful when not a single bondholder signed up to sell their bonds for cut-rate prices. Ingersoll, editor-in-chief of the Sun and chairman and chief executive officer of Princeton, N.J.-based Ingersoll Publications Co., stressed on Wednesday that the troubles are not related. ``I emphasize the sole reason the St. Louis Sun did not succeed was the inability to generate adequate single-copy sales,'' Ingersoll said at Wednesday's unexpected news conference to announce the end of the Sun. But even though his problems have intensified lately, Ingersoll, the son of a respected newspaper editor, has remained cool and upbeat. In an April 12 interview, while the Sun apparently was hitting a low point, Ingersoll said the paper had plenty of good news as well as some problems. ``The changes are all evolutionary, not revolutionary,'' he said then. When he launched the Sun last September, he said he wanted to prove that new newspapers, if properly designed and promoted, could be introduced in the United States just as they had been in other countries. He said he was planning to move to St. Louis and would personally direct the rise of the Sun. He spent many late nights in the newspaper's high-tech newsroom learning about sophisticated equipment and refining ``the look'' of the Sun. ``I'm disappointed. I feel that we gave it our very best shot,'' Ingersoll said Wednesday. With the setting of the Sun, Ingersoll can turn his attention to trying to negotiate a deal to buy back up to $158.6 million of the $240 million of junk-bond debt at Community Newspapers Inc., an Ingersoll Publications subsidiary. The company went on an expansion spree with proceeds from junk bond issues. But the junk market has collapsed in recent months and the bonds have been selling at about 40 cents on the dollar. That has put the company in a bind because it is required in June to reset the terms on its $125 million of 13 percent bonds so that the securities trade at 101 cents on the dollar. Judging by current market conditions, that would require a staggering new interest rate of more than 26 percent. Ingersoll offered to buy back up to 80 percent of the issue for 55 cents on the dollar. He also offered to pay 25 cents on the dollar for 51 percent of the company's $114.9 million in 14 percent bonds, which aren't due to be reset until next year. Ingersoll has extended his offer to buy the bonds until May 4 and on Wednesday he said he was considering upping his offer to bondholders, but he wouldn't say how much. ``I don't do my negotiating in public,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Genentech Reports First-Quarter Results
DOC.TEXT: Genentech Inc. reported first quarter profits rose to $13.3 million, or 15 cents a share, from $7.4 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier. The biotechnology company said Wednesday the increase reflected a pre-tax gain of about $11.9 million from the March sale of its 25 percent interest in Genencor, the industrial enzyme joint venture Genentech helped found in 1982. Revenues for the first three months of the year rose 32 percent to $120.2 million from $91.1 million. The company also reported expenses of $11.7 million in the quarter related to its proposed merger with Roche Holdings Inc., the Swiss drug company. Merger expenses are expected to total about $150 million when the transaction is completed, leaving the company with a loss for the year, Genentech said in a statement. ``It was a real strong revenue quarter,'' said John Girton, an analyst with Von Kasper & Company. ``There was good product showing.'' Sales of the company's human growth hormone, Protopin, increased to $35 million from $24.9 million a year earlier. Activase, Genentech's heart attack drug, maintained about a two-thirds market share during the quarter. Sales of the drug were $54.9 million, up from $48.1 million for the first quarter of 1989 but down from the $56.7 million for the fourth quarter of 1989. ``Genentech now has five potential new products in human clinical trials and we believe one of the most promising pipelines in the industry,'' said G. Kirk Raab, president and chief executive officer. ``The pending investment by Roche should give us the additional resources and financial stability to maximize the potential of this pipeline.''

DOC.HEAD: Low Gas Prices Force Mesa To Cut Further Cuts Distribution
DOC.TEXT: Mesa Limited Partnership, the energy company headed by T. Boone Pickens, said it lost $18.24 million in the first quarter and would suspend cash distributions to preferred unitholders until natural gas prices increase. The decision, which takes affect after the first quarter payment, comes four months after Mesa stopped paying common unitholders because of low natural gas prices. Distributions to unitholders in a partnership are akin to dividends paid to stockholders of a corporation. ``The warmest winter in 30 years provided no opportunity for significant improvement in prices this past winter,'' Pickens said in explaining the decision. ``We expect prices this summer to be about equal with those received in 1989,'' he said. ``The partnership will continue to report losses until gas prices increase.'' Pickens said the average natural gas price during the first quarter was $1.90 per million British thermal units. On Wednesday, trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange ended with gas for June delivery at $1.552 per million BTUs, down from Tuesday's $1.555. Mesa said it lost $18.24 million, or 30 cents per common unit, in the quarter ended March 31, compared with a profit of $14.61 million, or 15 cents per unit, a year earlier. Revenues slumped to $96.5 million from $105 million. Mesa last year reduced its quarterly payout to both common and preferred unitholders to 37.5 cents a unit from 50 cents. Mesa met the payments with proceeds from stock investments and not its energy operations, but even those earnings have slumped. Earnings from marketable securities plummetted to $3.75 million in the latest quarter from $41.9 million in the first quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Receives $240 Million Thai Engine Order
DOC.TEXT: Thai Airways International has placed a $300 million order for General Electric Co. engines to power five Boeing 747-400 jetliners and four Airbus Industrie A330 jetliners, GE said. The order consists of 28 installed and six spare CF6-80C2 and -80E1 engines made by GE's Aircraft Engine Division, based in the Cincinnati suburb of Evendale. Thai is scheduled to take delivery of the Boeing aircraft in late 1991, while the A330s are scheduled for delivery in 1993, GE said Wednesday. In East Hartford, Conn., meanwhile, Pratt & Whitney said Thai Airways and the Royal Thai Air Force had placed an engine order worth up to $240 million. Thai Airways has placed a firm order for four A330s, each to be powered by two PW4000 engines. It also placed options on engines for four additional aircraft. The firm order is worth about $78 million and the option could be worth an additional $80 million if exercised, Pratt & Whitney said. The airline also placed firm orders for 10 PW4000 engines plus spares worth about $70 million to power five A300 jets. The Royal Thai Air Force placed a $12 million order for two PW4000s to power its new Airbus A310 to be delivered in 1991, Pratt & Whitney said. Pratt & Whitney is a division of Hartford-based United Technologies Corp.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Japan Reach Agreement on Wood Product Sales
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to include summary of agreement. Also on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Japan reached agreement Wednesday to expand sales of American wood products as the Bush administration hinted that Japan's actions will keep it off a ``hit list'' of countries with the most offensive trade barriers. The agreement wrapped up the final outstanding case cited by the Bush administration a year ago when it targeted Tokyo for priority market-opening negotiations. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, announcing the successful conclusion of the talks, said the agreement, which lowers tariffs and revises Japanese building code standards, should result in a $1 billion increase in American export sales while providing ``lower-cost and higher-quality wood housing to Japanese consumers.'' The administration a year ago targeted Japan for its barriers to sales of American wood products, satellites and supercomputers. All three issues have been settled in the last five weeks after months of talks with little progress. The government of Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has pushed to lower trade tensions between the two economic superpowers since President Bush and Kaifu held a recent trade summit in California. The Bush administration faces a Monday deadline for deciding whether to target Japan in a second round of market-opening negotiations under a tough section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301. Various American industry groups and members of Congress argue that the administration must cite Japan again to keep pressure on a country that accounts for nearly half of America's overall trade deficit. But Hills, while saying the administration has not made its final decision, strongly indicated that she opposed targeting Japan again. She said that in a review of 33 Japanese trade barriers, she could find none that could best be resolved through use of the Super 301 process. That provision provides for retaliatory sanctions if the barriers aren't removed within a specified period of time. She told the committee that the flurry of concessions made by Japan in the past month indicated that Kaifu's government seriously intended to resolve trade frictions. However, various senators said Tokyo's record in honoring past agreements was weak and that there was no evidence the latest round of commitments would make a dent in America's $49 billion deficit with Japan. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said the administration would be making a serious mistake if it failed to target Japan under Super 301, which he called the cornerstone of the 1988 trade law. He and Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., both held out the threat that Congress would block approval of pending trade agreements with Eastern European countries, the Soviet Union and China if the administration failed to target Japan. ``If the administration ignores a trade law that Congress has constitutionally enacted, I am concerned it may poison the well for the consideration of those agreements,'' Bentsen told Hills. However, Hills asked the committee to give her more leeway in choosing the best way to gain market access with Japan. `I need a little of your confidence and just a little longer tether,'' she said. Bush and the economic policy group of his Cabinet were scheduled to hear Thursday from Hills on the Super 301 designation, with indications that an announcement on the issue could come late Thursday or Friday. Last year, the administration cited Japan, Brazil and India for the priority negotiations. Hills said that the discussions with Japan and Brazil had been successful, but that no progress had been made in talks with India concerning foreign investment and insurance. Some in the administration have argued that no country should be cited this year, but Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., said such a decision would send a ``dangerous and inaccurate'' message that America is not concerned about unfair barriers. Sen. Don Riegle, D-Mich., warned Hills that he would push for legislation to extend the requirement for the administration to target countries, which was due to expire this year. ``If a foreign country thinks they can slide by this year with talk and talk, we are going to come back and tighten up'' the law, Riegle said. However, Sens. Bob Packwood, R-Oregon, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., both said that they feared that targeting Japan after it had met U.S. demands would be wrong.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices declined slightly on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday morning while the dollar moved higher against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 42.15 points, or 0.14 percent, ending the morning session at 29,459.23. The index, which shed 177.69 points Tuesday, regained more than 200 points in the first hour of morning trading before falling back. The dollar was changing hands at 158.98 yen at late morning, up from Tuesday's close of 158.15 yen. It opened at 158.96 yen and ranged between 158.80 yen and 159.15 yen during morning trading. Traders attributed the Nikkei's setback to declines in stock index futures prices that discouraged market players. Haruhito Ichimura, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co., said many investors were reluctant to buy issues ahead of the ``Golden Week'' holidays that start Saturday and go through May 6 for many Japanese companies. ``They are trying to stay on the safer side especially due to uncertainties over foreign exchange fluctuations,'' he said. In currency dealings, the dollar's strength followed its overnight upswing in New York, dealers said. The dollar gained ground as market players bought the West German mark against the yen, which indirectly helped weaken the yen against the dollar, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. Buying and selling was evenly matched when the dollar crossed the 159-yen level, he added. ``Trading was thin ahead of the Golden Week holidays,'' Kanai said. Masaaki Tanahashi, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said holidays that shut markets in Australia and New Zealand Wednesday kept trading very light.
